<p>506</p>

<li>
<p>507</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Each of a pair of homologous chromosomes contains genes for the same traits. For example, the ability to roll one's tongue is coded for on a single gene. Because one chromosome of each pair is inherited from the father and one from the mother, an individual has two genes controlling the ability to roll the tongue. Such paired genes are called alleles. Corresponding alleles contain genes concerned with the same trait, but they need not be identical. An individual may have:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>⋅</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\cdot</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">⋅</span></span></span></span></span> two identical forms of the gene (homozygous)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>⋅</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\cdot</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">⋅</span></span></span></span></span> two different forms of the gene (heterozygous).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>One copy of the tongue-rolling gene may code for the ability to roll the tongue, but the corresponding gene on the other chromosome of the pair may be a different form and code for inability to tongue roll. This simple example involves only two forms of the same gene but other characteristics are more complex. Eye colour is a diverse trait with a wide range of pigment colours and patterns possible, and is controlled by more than one gene.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>508</p>

The book pages were scanned and converted to EPUB format automatically. This process relies on optical character recognition, and is somewhat susceptible to errors. The book may not offer the correct reading sequence, and there may be weird characters, non-words, and incorrect guesses at structure. Some page numbers and headers or footers may remain from the scanned page. The process which identifies images might have found stray marks on the page which are not actually images from the book. The hidden page numbering which may be available to your ereader corresponds to the numbered pages in the print edition, but is not an exact match; page numbers will increment at the same rate as the corresponding print edition, but we may have started numbering before the print book's visible page numbers. The Internet Archive is working to improve the scanning process and resulting books, but in the meantime, we hope that this book will be useful to you.</p>
<p>The Internet Archive was founded in 1996 to build an Internet library and to promote universal access to all knowledge. The Archive's purposes include offering permanent access for researchers, historians, scholars, people with disabilities, and the general public to historical collections that exist in digital format. <div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="preface">Preface<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preface" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Ross &amp; Wilson has been a core text for students of anatomy and physiology for almost 60 years. This latest edition has been written to meet the needs of healthcare professionals, including nurses and students of nursing, the allied health professions and complementary therapies, many of whom have found previous editions invaluable. It retains the successful and straightforward approach to the description of body systems and how they work. The anatomy and physiology of health are supplemented by sections describing common age-related changes to structure and function, before the pathology and pathophysiology of some important disorders and diseases are considered.</p>
<p>The human body is presented system by system. The reader must, however, remember that physiology is an integrated subject and that, although the systems are considered in separate chapters, all function cooperatively to maintain health. The first three chapters provide an overview of the body and describe its main structures and fundamental processes.</p>
<p>The later chapters are organised into three further sections, reflecting those areas essential for normal body function: communication; intake of raw materials and elimination of waste; and protection and survival. The revised and updated text is supported and illustrated with a rich array of newly redrawn figures, photographs and micrographs.</p>
<p>This edition is accompanied by a companion website (<a href="https://evolve.elsevier.com/Waugh/anatomy/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://evolve.elsevier.com/Waugh/anatomy/</a>) with over 100 animations and an extensive range of online self-test activities reflecting the content of each chapter. The material in this textbook is also supported by the new 5th edition of the accompanying study guide, which gives students who prefer paper-based activities the opportunity to test their learning and deepen their knowledge.</p>
<p>Additional supporting features include learning outcomes, a comprehensive glossary, a list of common prefixes, suffixes and roots, and extensive in-text chapter cross-references. New features include end-of-chapter 'review and revise' questions, as well as short 'spot check' questions at the end of each section, allowing students to test their understanding of the content.</p>
<p>We are always pleased to receive feedback from readers, which informs future editions of Ross &amp; Wilson, ensuring it continues to meet the learning needs of students in an evolving educational environment.</p>
<p>Anne Waugh Allison Grant April 2018</p>
<p>This page intentionally left blank</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="acknowledgements">Acknowledgements<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acknowledgements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Preparation of a new textbook relies on the contribution of a range of professionals and the 13th edition of this textbook would not have been possible without the efforts of many people. We are very grateful to Richard Tibbitts for his new, imaginative and high-quality illustrations, which contribute significantly to the long-standing appeal and educational value of this textbook. We also gratefully acknowledge the work of Janet Ross and Kathleen Wilson, the original authors and founders of this project.</p>
<p>The publishing team at Elsevier provided excellent support at all stages of the project and we are particularly indebted to Alison Taylor, Sheila Black and Kirsty Guest.</p>
<p>A significant contribution to the preparation of the new 13th edition has been the feedback and constructive comments from users of previous editions, including students, educators and other professionals. The publishers solicited feedback from faculty members and students; respondents represented the global reach of this book including the UK and Ireland, Belgium, The Netherlands, Poland, India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Afghanistan, Nepal, Malaysia, Mauritius, Ghana, Kenya, Namibia, Nigeria, South Africa, Sudan, Tanzania, Uganda, Zambia, Zimbabwe,</p>
<p>Trinidad and Tobago, Australia and the USA. This feedback was exceptionally positive, but the constructive suggestions made have informed the current revision.</p>
<p>To everyone who took the time and trouble to offer feedback we offer our sincerest thanks. Particular acknowledgment is reserved for the following readers: Victor Assenga, 1st year Student Nurse, Tanzania; Nicola Crick, 3rd year Student Nurse, UK; Tomas Jalowiecki, Emergency Medical Technician, UK; D. Damilola Olaiya, 4th year Student Nurse, Nigeria; and Rawya Ahmed Salim, Pharmacist, Kenya, each of whom contributed to the idea that self-assessment in each chapter would help bring the book right up-to-date and further assist our readers with the (occasionally arduous!) task of getting to grips with the fundamentals of human biology.</p>
<p>We are always grateful for comments, information and suggestions concerning the content and organisation of the material in this textbook.</p>
<p>Thanks are also due to our families, Andy, Seona and Struan, for their continued patience, support and acceptance of lost evenings and weekends.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-56fea422.jpeg" alt="img-4.jpeg"></p>
<p>The <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>13</mn><mrow><mo>∧</mo><mo>∧</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">13^{\wedge \wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">3</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> edition of Ross &amp; Wilson Anatomy and Physiology in Health and Illness comes with a range of helpful online learning tools that aim to reinforce your knowledge and make learning accessible and enjoyable.</p>
<p>You are invited to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\log</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mop">lo<span style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span></span></span></span></span> in to EVOLVE using the URL <a href="https://evolve.elsevier.com/Laugh/anatomy/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://evolve.elsevier.com/Laugh/anatomy/</a>. Here you will find a wide range of educational features that have been specially prepared by the authors to help reinforce your understanding of anatomy and physiology and help you apply the information you have recently acquired to ensure that you get the 'bigger picture'.</p>
<p>The website offers a large selection of self-assessment material in a variety of innovative formats, including 'dragand drop', fill in 'the blanks', and answer true/false to over 450 questions covering the topics found within the main textbook.</p>
<p>Central to the application of your knowledge is access to a variety of 'real-life' Case Studies that will introduce you to a series of characters who have experienced recent illness or trauma. Some individuals are suffering from disorders such as asthma or diabetes, hypertension or leukaemia while others have nutritional deficits, hearing loss, or colour blindness. Whether the characters are undergoing cancer treatment or have suffered a road traffic accident, or otherwise injured themselves whilst walking or working in the garden, each scenario is designed to help you think about normal physiology and then consider what happens when things go wrong. There are almost 26 Case Studies, with 170 related questions, which can be approached on a chapter-by-chapter basis or in a single learning session at the end of your A&amp;P studies.</p>
<p>If you are a visual learner, Elsevier is pleased to pro <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">\</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\backslash</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">\</span></span></span></span></span> you with access to over 100 videos - many of them comple new - covering a range of topics relating to anatomy i
physiology. You are able to watch a broad range of animated film sequences relating to cellular activities such as passive and active transport, as well as specific anatomical structures and how they work such as the structure and functions of a nephron, airflow through the lungs or the events of a nerve impulse.</p>
<p>Providing a wide range of supplementary anatomical schematics, the unique Body Spectrum(C) software allows you to identify specific biological structures and colourise them, using a range of different online 'paints'. This provides an engaging means of memorising different components of the human body and seeing how they fit together. Readers can use the software in Study Mode, for self-directed learning, or Quiz Mode, for monitoring self-progress. Each of the schematics can be printed out, in colour or black and white, to be included in personal revision notes and/or wall posters.</p>
<p>If you are new to biology and the language of medicine, you may find the pronunciation of some of its terms challenging. To help you with this, Elsevier is pleased to offer you an online audio-glossary with over 1700 entries. Learn to pronounce Wernicke's, facioscapulohumeral dystrophy and ascites before you go on placement.</p>
<p>Finally, carefully chosen 'weblinks' direct readers to quality-assured additional resources such as further teaching aids, research and professional advisory bodies, patient advice websites, and help with studying in English.</p>
<p>However, and whenever, you choose to use the website you will find its helpful 'critical thinking' approach supports you as you work towards a full understanding of the fundamental principles of human biology.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-ba46dedd.jpeg" alt="img-5.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-53ca3e8f.jpeg" alt="img-6.jpeg"></p>
<p>We are aware of the importance of faculty support for teaching staff wherever they practice in the world.</p>
<p>To help you with the core task of imparting knowledge to the next generation of health professionals, and other students of life sciences, Elsevier is pleased to offer lecturers access to the artwork collection found within Ross &amp; Wilson Anatomy and Physiology in Health and Illness 13*^ edition.</p>
<p>Newly created by the team that brought the world Gray's Anatomy for Students, each artwork piece is fully copyright cleared and available for use in a variety of formats, including, for example, classroom handouts for use in tests and overhead presentations. The online art comes with and without labels, or even Teader lines', for lecturers who require plain images, to facilitate its use in as many teaching contexts as possible.</p>
<p>These artworks are made freely available for educators' use in the course of their teaching. If you wish to use them for commercially driven purposes, or are at all unsure about legitimate use, please approach our Permissions Helpdesk via <a href="mailto:permissionshelpdesk@elsevier.com" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">permissionshelpdesk@elsevier.com</a> for further discussion (see also the copyright page). Anything you need to use for regular teaching purposes - classroom, homework, face-to-face or distance learning, on full time or part-time programmes, in whatever country you work in - is ready to go!</p>
<p>The lecturer resource facility also contains a collection of Test Questions, arranged by chapter subject, which will allow you to create tests and quizzes for students. The collection is customisable, in that you can add new questions of your own, or delete ones that cover topics that are not important to your own student group. The content is offered in twoformats: PowerPoint, which facilitates classroom participation via popular software such as iClicker, or in MSWord, which allows students to undertake paper-based tests for anyone working in a more traditional setting.</p>
<p>Finally, the Online Student Resource facility provides access to well over 100 animations - many of which are brand new - which you will find helpful in your teaching programme. Topics covered range from principles of basic science, such as molecule formation and chemical bonding, to anatomical features and physiological processes, the latter of which cover a broad range of subjects ranging from airflow through the lungs through to blood clotting and the hepatoportal circulation.</p>
<p>You can find the animation files and the other teaching material by registering at <a href="https://evolve.elsevier.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">https://evolve.elsevier.com/</a> Waugh/ anatomy/.

A/P: anterior/posterior. This indicates that the figure has been drawn from above or below using a transverse section, and shows the relationship of the structures to the front/back of the body.</p>

e.g. Figure 16.21</p>

margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ngle entity, but is made up of a number of systems tha <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">r</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">r</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{\wedge} \mathrm{rrk}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">rrk</span></span></span></span></span></span> interdependently. Each system is associated with a specific function that is normally essential for the well-being of the individual. Should one system fail, the consequences can extend to others, and may greatly reduce the ability of the body to function normally. Integrated working of the body systems ensures survival. The human body is therefore complex in both structure and function, and this book uses a systems approach to explain the fundamental structures and processes involved.</p>
<p>Anatomy is the study of the structure of the body and the physical relationships between its constituent parts. Physiology is the study of how the body systems work, and the ways in which their integrated activities maintain the life and health of the individual. Pathology is the study of abnormalities and pathophysiology considers how they affect body functions, often causing illness.</p>
<p>This chapter introduces the body systems and how they are organised. The following section provides an overview</p>
<p>of the levels of structural complexity found within body systems; the smallest units of living matter are cells that form the building blocks for the diverse body organs. The human body contains around 30 trillion cells.</p>
<p>For survival, many essential processes must be carried out within the body. Some involve communication and transport, others relate to taking in raw materials and getting rid of wastes and yet others ensure the body remains able to protect itself and that the human species survives. These processes are used as headings in the next section to introduce the body systems, which are then explored in depth in later chapters.</p>
<p>Use of standardised anatomical terminology enables the physical relationships between structures within the body to be described accurately and communicated consistently. This chapter also explains some of this fundamental terminology, which is then applied to provide an overview of the organisation of the body, focusing on the skeleton and body cavities.</p>
<p>Most body systems become less efficient with age. Physiological decline is a normal part of ageing and</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter">CHAPTER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>should not be confused with illness or disease, although some conditions do become more common in older life. Maintaining a healthy lifestyle can not only slow the effects of ageing but also protect against illness. The general impact of ageing is outlined in this chapter and its effects on body function are explored in more detail in later chapters.</p>
<p>The final section of this chapter provides a framework for studying diseases, an outline of mechanisms that cause disease and some common disease processes. Building on the normal anatomy and physiology, a systems approach is adopted to consider common illnesses at the end of the later chapters.</p>
<p>Levels of structural complexity</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcome">Learning outcome<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the levels of structural complexity within the body.</li>
</ul>
<p>Within the body there are different levels of structural organisation and complexity. The most fundamental of these is chemical. Atoms combine to form molecules, of which there is a vast range in the body. The structures, properties and functions of important biological molecules are considered in Chapter 2.</p>
<p>Cells are the smallest independent units of living matter. They are too small to be seen with the naked eye, but when magnified using a microscope, different types</p>
<p>can be distinguished by their size, shape and the dyes they absorb when stained in the laboratory. Most body cells have become specialised (differentiated), to carry out a particular function that contributes to body needs. Fig. 1.1 shows some highly magnified nerve cells. The specialised function of nerve cells is to transmit electrical signals (nerve impulses); these are integrated and coordinated, allowing the millions of nerve cells in the body to provide a rapid and sophisticated communication system. In complex organisms such as the human body, cells with similar structures and functions are found together, forming tissues. The structure and functions of cells and tissues are explored in Chapter 3.</p>
<p>Organs are made up of a number of different types of tissue and have evolved to carry out a specific function. There are around 80 organs, each of which is associated with one or more body systems. Fig. 1.2 shows that the stomach is lined by a layer of epithelial tissue and that its wall contains layers of smooth muscle tissue. Both tissues contribute to the functions of the stomach, but in different ways.</p>
<p>Systems consist of a number of organs and tissues that together contribute to one or more survival needs of the body. For example, the pancreas, stomach and liver are all organs considered to be part of the digestive system. They</p>
<p>Figure 1.1 Nerve cells (neurones). Coloured scanning electron micrograph. (Steve G Schmeissner/Science Photo Library, reproduced with permission.)
all contribute to the ingestion, digestion and absorption of nutrients, but individually have very different functions. The body's systems work interdependently and must communicate and coordinate their functions for the body to remain healthy. The structure and functions of the body systems are considered in later chapters.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="spot-check">- SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Define the term 'cell differentiation'.</li>
</ol>
<p>Survival needs of the body</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="system-level">SYSTEM LEVEL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#system-level" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Digestive system
Figure 1.2 The levels of structural complexity.
By convention, body systems are described separately in the study of anatomy and physiology, but in reality they work interdependently. This section provides an introduction to body activities, linking them to survival needs: communication, intake of raw materials and elimination of waste, and survival of the body itself and of the species (Table 1.1).</p>
<p>Communication
Communication requires transport systems to ensure that all body cells are supplied with the very many substances needed to support them, as well as allowing for waste excretion; this involves the blood and the cardiovascular and lymphatic systems.</p>
<p>Communication systems receive, collate and respond to information that may originate either within the body (internally) or from its environment (externally). Internal communication involves mainly the nervous and endocrine systems; these are important in the maintenance of</p>
<p>Table 1.1 Survival needs and related body activities</p>
<p>Survival need Body activities</p>
<p>Communication</p>
<p>International communication: nervous system, endocrine system</p>
<p>External communication: special senses, verbal and non-verbal communication</p>
<p>Transport systems: blood, cardiovascular system, lymphatic system</p>
<p>Intake of raw materials and elimination of waste</p>
<p>Ingestion of nutrients (eating)</p>
<p>Elimination of wastes: carbon dioxide, urine, faeces</p>
<p>Protection of the body itself and species Protection against the external environment: skin</p>
<p>Defence against microbial infection: resistance and immunity</p>
<p>Body movement</p>
<p>Survival of the species: reproduction and transmission of inherited characteristics
homeostasis (Ch. 2) and regulation of vital body functions. Communication with the external environment involves the special senses, and verbal and non-verbal activities, and all of these also depend on the nervous system.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="transport-systems">Transport systems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transport-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood">Blood<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The blood (Ch. 4) transports substances around the body through a large network of blood vessels. In adults the body contains 5-6 litres of blood. It consists of two parts: a fluid called plasma, and blood cells suspended in the plasma.</p>
<p>Plasma. This is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">90%</span></span></span></span></span> water with a wide range of substances dissolved or suspended in it. These include:</p>
<ul>
<li>nutrients absorbed from the alimentary canal</li>
<li>oxygen absorbed from the lungs</li>
<li>chemicals synthesised by body cells, e.g. hormones</li>
<li>waste materials produced by all cells to be eliminated from the body by excretion.</li>
</ul>
<p>Blood colls. There are three distinct groups, classified according to their functions (Fig. 1.3).</p>
<p>Erythrocytes (red blood cells) transport oxygen and, to a lesser extent, carbon dioxide between the lungs and all body cells.</p>
<p>Leukocytes (white blood cells) are mainly concerned with protection of the body against infection and foreign
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-672f19f0.jpeg" alt="img-17.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 1.3 Blood showing red blood cells, white blood cells (yellow) and platelets (pink). Coloured soanning eleotron micrograph. (National Cancer Institute/Science Photo Library, reproduced with permission.)</p>
<p>substances. There are several types of leukocytes, which carry out their protective functions in different ways. These cells are larger and less numerous than erythrocytes.</p>
<p>Platelets (thrombocytes) are tiny cell fragments that play an essential part in blood clotting.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cardiovascular-system">Cardiovascular system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cardiovascular-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The cardiovascular system (Ch. 5) consists of a network of blood vessels and the heart (Fig. 1.4). 1.1</p>
<p>Blood veSSOIS. There are three types:</p>
<ul>
<li>arteries, which carry blood away from the heart</li>
<li>veins, which return blood to the heart</li>
<li>capillaries, which link the arteries and veins.</li>
</ul>
<p>Capillaries are tiny blood vessels with very thin walls consisting of only one layer of cells, which enables exchange of substances, such as nutrients, oxygen and cellular waste products, between the blood and body tissues. Blood vessels form a massive network that transports blood to:
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-52f5f294.jpeg" alt="img-18.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 1.4 The circulatory system.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-d2e90f5b.jpeg" alt="img-19.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>the lungs (pulmonary circulation), where oxygen is absorbed from the air in the lungs and, at the same time, carbon dioxide is excreted from the blood into the air</li>
<li>cells in all other parts of the body (general or systemic circulation) (Fig. 1.5).</li>
</ul>
<p>Heart. The heart is a muscular sac with four chambers, which pumps blood round the body and maintains the blood pressure.</p>
<p>The heart muscle is not under conscious (voluntary) control. At rest the heart contracts, or beats, between 65 and 75 times per minute. The rate is greatly increased when body oxygen requirements are increased, e.g. during exercise.</p>
<p>The rate at which the heart beats can be counted by taking the pulse. The pulse can be felt most easily where a superficial artery can be pressed gently against a bone, usually at the wrist.</p>
<p>Lymphatic system
The lymphatic system (Ch. 6; Fig. 1.6) consists of a series of lymph vessels, which begin as blind-ended tubes in the tissue spaces between the blood capillaries and tissue cells.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-8fad1f20.jpeg" alt="img-20.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 1.5 Circulation of the blood through the heart and the pulmonary and systemic circulations.</p>
<p>Structurally, they are similar to veins and blood capillaries but the pores in the walls of the lymph capillaries are larger than those of the blood capillaries. Lymph is tissue fluid that also contains material drained from tissue spaces, including plasma proteins and, sometimes, bacteria or cell debris. It is transported along lymph vessels and returned to the bloodstream near the heart.</p>
<p>There are collections of lymph nodes situated at various points along the length of the lymph vessels. Lymph is filtered as it passes through these nodes, removing microbes and other materials. Other lymphatic organs include the spleen and the thymus.</p>
<p>The lymphatic system also provides the sites for formation and maturation of lymphocytes, the white blood cells involved in immunity (Ch. 15).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="internal-communication">Internal communication<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#internal-communication" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is carried out through the activities of the nervous and endocrine systems.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-d75d8bb4.jpeg" alt="img-21.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 1.6 The lymphatic system. Lymph nodes and vessels.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-4449afe1.jpeg" alt="img-22.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 1.7 The nervous system.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="nervous-system">Nervous system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nervous-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The nervous system (Ch. 7) is a rapid communication system. The main components are shown in Fig. 1.7.</p>
<p>The central nervous system consists of:</p>
<ul>
<li>the brain, situated inside the skull</li>
<li>the spinal cord, which extends from the base of the skull to the lumbar region (lower back).</li>
</ul>
<p>The spinal cord is protected from injury as it lies within the bones of the spinal column.</p>
<p>The peripheral nervous system is a network of nerve fibres, which are either:</p>
<ul>
<li>sensory or afferent nerves, which transmit signals from the body to the brain, or</li>
<li>motor or efferent nerves, which transmit signals from the brain to the effector organs, such as muscles and glands.</li>
</ul>
<p>The somatic (common) senses are pain, touch, heat and cold. These sensations arise following stimulation
of specialised sensory receptors at nerve endings found throughout the skin.
Nerve endings within muscles and joints respond to changes in the position and orientation of the body, maintaining posture and balance. Yet other sensory receptors are activated by stimuli in internal organs and control vital body functions, e.g. heart rate, respiratory rate and blood pressure. Stimulation of any of these receptors sets up impulses that are conducted to the brain in sensory (afferent) nerves.</p>
<p>Communication along nerve fibres (cells) is by electrical impulses that are generated when nerve endings are stimulated. Nerve impulses (action potentials) can travel at speeds of over 100 metres per second, so responses are almost immediate, making rapid and fine adjustments to body functions possible.</p>
<p>Communication between nerve cells is also required, since more than one nerve is involved in the chain of events occurring between the initial stimulus and the reaction to it. Nerves communicate with each other by releasing a chemical (the neurotransmitter) into tiny gaps between them. In only a few thousandths of a second, the neurotransmitter quickly travels across the gap and either stimulates or inhibits the next nerve cell, thus ensuring the message is transmitted.</p>
<p>Sensory nerves transmit impulses from the body to appropriate parts of the brain, where the incoming information is analysed and collated. The brain responds by sending impulses along motor (efferent) nerves to the appropriate effector organ(s). In this way, many aspects of body function are continuously monitored and adjusted, usually by negative feedback control (Ch. 2), and usually subconsciously, e.g. regulation of blood pressure.</p>
<p>Reflex actions are fast, involuntary, and usually protective motor responses to specific stimuli. They include:</p>
<ul>
<li>withdrawal of a finger from a very hot surface</li>
<li>constriction of the pupil in response to bright light</li>
<li>control of blood pressure.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="endocrine-system">Endocrine system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#endocrine-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The endocrine system (Ch. 9) consists of a number of discrete glands situated in different parts of the body. They synthesise and secrete chemical messengers called hormones that circulate round the body in the blood. Hormones stimulate target glands or tissues, influencing metabolic and other cellular activities and regulating body growth and maturation. Endocrine glands detect and respond to levels of particular substances in the blood, including specific hormones. Changes in blood hormone levels are usually controlled by negative feedback mechanisms (see Figs <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2.12</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>2.13</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2.12,2.13</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">2.12</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">2.13</span></span></span></span></span> and 9.4). The endocrine system provides slower and more precise control of body functions than the nervous system.</p>
<p>In addition to the glands that have a primary endocrine function, it is now known that many other tissues also secrete hormones as a secondary function; some of these are explored further in Chapter 9.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-dc186765.jpeg" alt="img-23.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 1.8 Combined use of the special senses: vision, hearing, smell, taste and balance.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="communication-with-the-external-environment">Communication with the external environment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#communication-with-the-external-environment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="special-senses">Special senses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#special-senses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Stimulation of specialised receptors in sensory organs or tissues gives rise to the sensations of sight, hearing, balance, smell and taste (Ch. 8). Although these senses are usually considered to be separate and different from each other, one sense is rarely used alone (Fig. 1.8). For example, when the smell of smoke is perceived, other senses such as sight and sound are used to try to locate the source of a fire. Similarly, taste and smell are closely associated in the enjoyment, or otherwise, of food. The brain collates incoming information with information from the memory and initiates a response by setting up electrical impulses in motor (efferent) nerves to effector organs, muscles and glands. Such responses enable the individual to escape from a fire, or to prepare the digestive system subconsciously for eating.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="verbal-communication">Verbal communication<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#verbal-communication" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Sound is produced in the larynx when expired air coming from the lungs passes through and vibrates the vocal cords (see Fig. 10.8) during expiration. In humans, recognisable sounds produced by coordinated contraction of the muscles of the throat and cheeks, and movements of the tongue and lower jaw, are known as speech.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="non-verbal-communication">Non-verbal communication<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#non-verbal-communication" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Posture and movements are often associated with non-verbal communication, e.g. nodding the head and shrugging the shoulders. The skeleton provides the bony framework of the
body (Ch. 16), and movement takes place at joints between bones. Skeletal muscles move the skeleton and attach bones to one another, spanning one or more joints in between. They are stimulated by the part of the nervous system under voluntary (conscious) control. Some non-verbal communication, e.g. changes in facial expression, may not involve the movement of bones.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="intake-of-raw-materials-and-elimination-of-waste">Intake of raw materials and elimination of waste<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intake-of-raw-materials-and-elimination-of-waste" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This section considers substances taken into and excreted from the body, which involves the respiratory, digestive and urinary systems. Oxygen, water and food are taken in, and carbon dioxide, urine and faeces are excreted.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="intake-of-oxygen">Intake of oxygen<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intake-of-oxygen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Oxygen gas makes up about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>21</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">21 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">21%</span></span></span></span></span> of atmospheric air. A continuous supply is essential for human life because it is needed for most chemical activities that take place in the body cells. Oxygen is necessary for the series of chemical reactions that result in the release of energy from nutrients. This chemical energy is essential fuel for all cellular activity.</p>
<p>The upper respiratory system carries air between the nose and the lungs during breathing (Ch. 10). Air passes through a system of passages, including the nasal cavity, the pharynx (throat, also part of the digestive tract), the larynx (voice box), the trachea, two bronchi (one bronchus to each lung) and a large number of bronchial passages (Fig. 1.9). These end in alveoli, millions of tiny air sacs in each lung. They are surrounded by a network of tiny capillaries and are the sites where vital gas exchange between the lungs and the blood takes place. 1.2</p>
<p>Nitrogen, which makes up about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>80</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">80 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">80%</span></span></span></span></span> of atmospheric air, is breathed in and out, but cannot be used by the body in this gaseous form. The nitrogen needed by the body is obtained by eating protein-containing foods, mainly meat and fish.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ingestion-of-nutrients-eating">Ingestion of nutrients (eating)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ingestion-of-nutrients-eating" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Nutrition is considered in Chapter 11. A balanced diet is important for health and provides nutrients, substances that are absorbed, usually following digestion, and promote body function, including cell building, growth and repair. Nutrients include water, carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins and mineral salts. They serve vital functions including:</p>
<ul>
<li>maintenance of water balance within the body</li>
<li>provision of fuel for energy production, mainly carbohydrates and fats</li>
<li>provision of the building blocks for synthesis of large and complex molecules needed by the body.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-c7af18b2.jpeg" alt="img-24.jpeg"></p>
<p>Pharynx Larynx
Left bronchus

Figure 1.9 The respiratory system.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="digestion">Digestion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#digestion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The digestive system evolved because food is chemically complex and seldom in a form that body cells can use. Its function is to break down, or digest, food so that it can be absorbed into the circulation and then used by body cells. The digestive system consists of the alimentary canal and accessory organs (Fig. 1.10).</p>
<p>Alimentary canal
This is essentially a tube, about 9 m long in the average adult, that begins at the mouth and continues through the pharynx, oesophagus, stomach, small and large intestines, rectum and anus.</p>
<p>Mouth</p>
<p>Liver
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-6b2089f9.jpeg" alt="img-25.jpeg"></p>
<p>Salivary gland Pharynx</p>
<p>11
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>.11</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">.11^{\wedge} \mathrm{II}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord">.1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">II</span></span></span></span></span></span>
. 1</p>

Figure 1.10 The digestive system.</p>
<ul>
<li>anabolism, building or synthesising large and complex substances</li>
<li>catabolism, breaking down substances to provide energy and raw materials for anabolism, and substances for excretion as waste.</li>
</ul>
<p>The sources of energy are mainly dietary carbohydrates and fats. However, if these are in short supply, proteins are used.</p>
<p>Accessory organs
These are the salivary glands, pancreas and liver (see Fig. 1.10), which lie outside the alimentary canal. The salivary glands and pancreas synthesise and release digestive enzymes, which are involved in the chemical breakdown of food, while the liver secretes bile; these substances enter the alimentary canal through connecting ducts.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="metabolism">Metabolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Chemical reactions occur continuously in all body cells and the overall activity is called metabolism. Metabolic reactions are classified into two main groups:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="elimination-of-wastes">Elimination of wastes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#elimination-of-wastes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="carbon-dioxide">Carbon dioxide<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carbon-dioxide" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This gas is a waste product of cellular metabolism. Because it dissolves in body fluids to make an acid solution, it must be excreted in appropriate amounts to maintain pH (acidity or alkalinity) within the normal range. Most carbon dioxide is excreted through the lungs during expiration.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="urine">Urine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#urine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Urine is formed by the kidneys, which are part of the urinary system (Ch. 13). The organs of the urinary system
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-1e5ae5b3.jpeg" alt="img-26.jpeg"></p>
<p>Kidney
Ureter</p>
<p>Bladder
Urethra
Figure 1.11 The urinary system.
Figure 1.12 The skin. Coloured scanning electron micrograph. (Steve G
Schmeissner/Science Photo Library, reproduced with permission.)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-43232dd3.jpeg" alt="img-27.jpeg">
are shown in Fig. 1.11. Urine consists of water and waste products, mainly those of protein breakdown, e.g. urea. Under the influence of hormones from the endocrine system, the kidneys regulate water balance. They also play a role in maintaining blood pH within the normal range. The bladder stores urine until it is excreted during micturition. Q 1.3,1.4</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="faeces">Faeces<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#faeces" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The waste materials from the digestive system are excreted as faeces during defaecation. They contain indigestible food residue that remains in the alimentary canal because it cannot be absorbed, as well as large numbers of microbes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="protection-of-the-body-itself-and-of-the-species">Protection of the body itself and of the species<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#protection-of-the-body-itself-and-of-the-species" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The body needs and related activities explored in this section are: protection against the external environment, defence against infection, movement and survival of the species.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="protection-against-the-external-environment">Protection against the external environment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#protection-against-the-external-environment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The skin (Fig. 1.12) forms a physical barrier against invasion by microbes, chemicals and dehydration (Ch. 14). It consists of two layers: the epidermis and the dermis.</p>
<p>The epidermis lies superficially and is composed of several layers of cells that grow towards the surface from its deepest layer. The skin surface consists of dead flattened cells that are constantly being rubbed off and replaced from below. The epidermis provides the barrier between the moist internal environment and the dry atmosphere of the external environment.</p>
<p>The dermis contains tiny sweat glands that have little canals or ducts, leading to the surface. Hairs grow from follicles in the dermis. The dermis is rich in sensory nerve endings sensitive to pain, temperature and touch. It is a vast organ that constantly provides the central nervous system with sensory input from the body surfaces. The skin also plays an important role in the regulation of body temperature.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="defence-against-infection">Defence against infection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#defence-against-infection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The body has many means of self-protection from invaders, which confer resistance and/or immunity (Ch. 15). They are divided into two categories: specific and non-specific defence mechanisms.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="non-specific-defence-mechanisms">Non-specific defence mechanisms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#non-specific-defence-mechanisms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are effective against any invaders. The skin protects most of the body surface, although there are also other protective features at body surfaces; for example, sticky mucus secreted by mucous membranes traps microbes and other foreign materials. Some body fluids contain antimicrobial substances; for example, gastric juice contains hydrochloric acid, which kills most ingested microbes. If microbes succeed in entering the body to infect the tissues, other important nonspecific (general) defence mechanisms are activated, including complement and the inflammatory response (Ch. 15).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="specific-defence-mechanisms">Specific defence mechanisms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#specific-defence-mechanisms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The body generates a specific (immune) response against any substance it identifies as foreign. Such substances are called antigens and include:</p>
<ul>
<li>pollen from flowers and plants</li>
<li>bacteria and other microbes</li>
<li>cancer cells or transplanted tissue cells.</li>
</ul>
<p>Following exposure to an antigen, lifelong immunity against further invasion by the same antigen often develops. Over a lifetime, an individual gradually builds up immunity to millions of antigens. Allergic reactions are abnormal immune responses to an antigen that usually poses no threat to the body, e.g. the effects of pollen in people with hay fever.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="movement">Movement<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#movement" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Movement of the whole body, or parts of it, is essential for many body activities, e.g. obtaining food, running from danger, avoiding injury and reproduction.</p>
<p>Most body movement is under conscious (voluntary) control. Exceptions include protective movements (reflexes) that are carried out before the individual is aware of them, e.g. the rapid withdrawal of the hand from a hot cooker.</p>
<p>The musculoskeletal system includes the bones of the skeleton, skeletal muscles and joints. The skeleton provides the rigid body framework and movement takes place at joints between two or more bones. Skeletal muscles (Fig. 1.13), under the control of the voluntary nervous system, maintain posture and balance, and move the skeleton. A brief description of the skeleton is given later in this chapter on page 13 , and a more detailed account of bones, muscles and joints is presented in Chapter 16 .</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="survival-of-the-species">Survival of the species<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#survival-of-the-species" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Survival of a species depends on successful reproduction, with the parents transmitting their genetic material to their children. As in many other species, this involves fusion of a male and a female sex cell, a process called sexual reproduction.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-36b95736.jpeg" alt="img-28.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 1.13 The musculoskeletal system.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="transmission-of-inherited-characteristics">Transmission of inherited characteristics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transmission-of-inherited-characteristics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Individuals with the most advantageous genetic make-up are most likely to survive, reproduce and pass their genes on to the next generation. This is the basis of natural selection, i.e. 'survival of the fittest'. Chapter 17 explores the transmission of inherited characteristics.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reproduction">Reproduction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reproduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Successful reproduction (Ch. 18) is essential to ensure the continuation of a species and its genetic characteristics from one generation to the next. Ova (eggs) are produced by two ovaries situated in the female pelvis (Fig. 1.14). During a female's reproductive years, usually only one ovum is released at about monthly intervals and it travels towards the uterus in the uterine tube. In males, spermatozoa are produced in large numbers by the two testes, situated in the scrotum. From each testis, spermatozoa pass through the deferent duct (vas deferens) to the urethra.</p>
<p>During sexual intercourse (coitus) the spermatozoa are deposited in the vagina. They then swim upwards through the uterus and fertilise the ovum in the uterine tube. Fertilisation (Fig. 1.15) occurs when a female egg cell or ovum fuses with a male sperm cell or spermatozoon. The fertilised ovum (zygote) then passes into the uterus, embeds itself in the uterine wall and grows to maturity during pregnancy or gestation, in about 40 weeks.</p>
<p>When the ovum is not fertilised, it is expelled from the uterus along with the uterine lining as bleeding, known as menstruation. In females, the reproductive cycle consists of phases associated with changes in hormone levels involving the</p>
<p>endocrine system. One cycle takes around 28 days and the cycles are continuous between puberty and the menopause, except during pregnancy. At ovulation (see Fig. 18.8) an ovum is released from one of the ovaries mid-cycle. There is no such cycle in the male but hormones, similar to those of the female, are involved in the production and maturation of spermatozoa.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-b3cb35b8.jpeg" alt="img-29.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 1.14 The reproductive systems. (A) Female. (B) Male.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="introduction-to-anatomy">Introduction to anatomy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction-to-anatomy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to: ■ define common anatomical terms.</p>
<p>This part of the chapter explains the anatomical terminology used to ensure that relationships between body structures are described consistently. An overview of the bones forming the skeleton is provided and the contents of the body cavities are explored.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="anatomical-terms">Anatomical terms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anatomical-terms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The anatomical position
The position is used in all anatomical descriptions to ensure accuracy and consistency. The body is in the upright position with the head facing forward, the arms at the sides with the palms of the hands facing forward, and the feet together.</p>
<p>Directionai terms
These paired terms are used to describe the location of body parts in relation to others, and are explained in Table 1.2.</p>
<p>Regional terms
These are used to describe parts of the body (Fig. 1.16).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-52f56350.jpeg" alt="img-30.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 1.15 Fertilisation showing spermatozoon (orange) and ovum (blue). Coloured soanning eleotron micrograph. (Thierry Berrod, Mona Lisa Production/Science Photo, reproduced with permission.)</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="body-planes">Body planes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#body-planes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There are three body planes (Fig. 1.17), which lie at right angles to each other. These divide the body into sections and are used to visualise or describe its internal arrangement from different perspectives. The anatomical position (already described) is used as the reference position in descriptions using body planes.</p>
<p>Median plane
When the body is divided longitudinally through the midline into right and left halves, it has been divided in the median plane, e.g. Fig. 1.17. A sagittal section is any section made parallel to the median plane.</p>
<p>Frontal (coronal) plane
A coronal or frontal section divides the body longitudinally into its anterior (front) and posterior (back) sections, e.g. Fig. 7.19.</p>
<p>Transverse plane
A transverse or horizontal section provides a cross-section dividing the body or body part into upper and lower parts.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-ac9f3611.jpeg" alt="img-33.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 1.17 Body planes.
This may be at any level, e.g. through the cranial cavity, thorax, abdomen, a limb or an organ, e.g. Fig. 7.28.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="anatomical-reference-icons-used-in-this-book">Anatomical reference icons used in this book<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anatomical-reference-icons-used-in-this-book" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These icons have been used in some of the figures to clarify relationships between body parts. The figures have a compass-like icon labelled with anatomical directions corresponding to the paired directional terms shown in Table 1.2. A full description of all the icons used in the book is provided on page xix.</p>
