<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="organisation-of-the-body">Organisation of the body<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#organisation-of-the-body" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>identify the principal bones of the axial skeleton and the appendicular skeleton</li>
<li>state the boundaries of the four body cavities</li>
<li>list the contents of the body cavities.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-skeleton">The skeleton<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-skeleton" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The skeleton (Fig. 1.18) is the bony framework of the body. It forms the cavities and fossae (depressions or hollows) that protect some structures, forms the joints and gives attachment to muscles. A detailed description of the bones is given in Chapter 16. Table 16.1 (p. 427) lists the terminology related to the skeleton.</p>
<p>The skeleton is described in two parts: axial and appendicular (the appendages attached to the axial skeleton).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="axial-skeleton">Axial skeleton<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#axial-skeleton" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The axial skeleton (axis of the body) consists of the skull, vertebral column, sternum (breast bone) and ribs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="skull">Skull<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#skull" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The skull is described in two parts: the cranium, which contains the brain, and the face. It consists of several bones, which develop separately but fuse together as they mature. The only movable bone is the mandible or lower jaw. The names and positions of the individual bones of the skull can be seen in Fig. 1.19.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-6592e0f9.jpeg" alt="img-34.jpeg"></p>
<p>Cranium
Clavicle</p>
<p>Scapula</p>
<p>Sternum Humerus Ribs</p>
<p>Femur</p>
<p>Radius Ulna Pelvis Carpal</p>
<p>Metacarpal</p>
<p>bones</p>
<p>Phalanges</p>
<p>Patella</p>
<p>Tibia Fibula</p>
<p>Tarsal bones Metatarsal bones -—. Phalanges^</p>
<p>Figure 1.18 The skeleton. Anterior view of the axial skeleton (gold) and
appendicular skeleton (brown).</p>
<p>Functions</p>
<p>The various parts of the skull have specific and different
functions (see p. 434). In summary these are:</p>
<ul>
<li>protection of delicate structures, including the brain, eyes and inner ears</li>
<li>maintenance of patency of the nasal passages, enabling breathing</li>
<li>eating, enabled by the teeth, embedded in the mandible and maxilla, and by movement of the mandible, allowing chewing.</li>
</ul>
<p>Vertebral column</p>
<p>This consists of 24 movable bones (vertebrae) plus the sacrum
and coccyx. The bodies of the bones are separated from each</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-1cd52c03.jpeg" alt="img-35.jpeg"></p>
<p>Parietal bone</p>
<p>Temporal bone</p>
<p>Squamous suture</p>
<p>Lambdoidal suture</p>
<p>Occipital bone</p>
<p>Coronal suture ■</p>
<p>Frontal bone - Sphenoid bone</p>
<p>Nasal bone</p>
<p>Lacrimal bone Ethmoid bone Zygomatic bone Maxilla</p>
<p>Mandible</p>
<p>Figure 1.19 The skull. Bones of the cranium and face viewed from the left side.
other by intervertebral discs consisting of fibrocartilage. The vertebral column is described in five parts and the bones of each part are numbered from above downwards (Fig. 1.20):</p>
<ul>
<li>7 cervical</li>
<li>12 thoracic</li>
<li>5 lumbar</li>
<li>1 sacrum (5 fused bones)</li>
<li>1 coccyx (4 fused bones).</li>
</ul>
<p>The first cervical vertebra, called the atlas, forms a joint (articulates) with the skull. Thereafter, each vertebra forms a joint with the vertebrae immediately above and below. More movement is possible in the cervical and lumbar regions than in the thoracic region.</p>
<p>The sacrum consists of five vertebrae fused into one bone that articulates with the fifth lumbar vertebra above, the coccyx below and an innominate (pelvic or hip) bone at each side.</p>
<p>The coccyx consists of the four terminal vertebrae fused into a small triangular bone that articulates with the sacrum above.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The vertebral column has several important functions:</p>
<ul>
<li>It protects the spinal cord. In each vertebra there is a hole, the vertebral foramen; collectively, the foramina form a canal in which the spinal cord lies.</li>
<li>Adjacent vertebrae form openings (intervertebral foramina), which protect the spinal nerves as they pass from the spinal cord (see Fig. 16.27).</li>
<li>In the thoracic region the ribs articulate with the vertebrae, forming joints that allow movement of the ribcage during respiration.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="thoracic-cage">Thoracic cage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thoracic-cage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The thoracic cage (see Fig. 1.23A) is formed by:</p>
<ul>
<li>12 thoracic vertebrae</li>
<li>12 pairs of ribs</li>
<li>1 sternum or breast bone.</li>
</ul>
<p>Functions</p>
<p>The thoracic cage:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Protects the contents of the thorax, including the heart, lungs and large blood vessels.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Forms joints between the upper limbs and the axial skeleton. The upper part of the sternum, the manubrium, articulates with the clavicles, forming the only joints between the upper limbs and the axial skeleton.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Gives attachment to the muscles of respiration:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Intercostal muscles occupy the spaces between the ribs. When they contract, the ribs move upwards and outwards, increasing the capacity of the thoracic cage, and inspiration occurs.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The diaphragm is a dome-shaped muscle that separates the thoracic and abdominal cavities. When it contracts, it assists with inspiration.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Enables breathing to take place.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-9c943ed5.jpeg" alt="img-36.jpeg"></p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>C1 (atlas)
Intervertebral
Intervertebral
Cervical vertebrae (7)
Thoracic vertebrae (12)
Lumbar vertebrae (5)
Sacrum
Coccyx</p>
<p>Figure 1.20 The vertebral column. Lateral view.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="appendicular-skeleton">Appendicular skeleton<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#appendicular-skeleton" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The appendicular skeleton consists of the shoulder girdles and upper limbs, and the pelvic girdle and lower limbs (see Fig. 1.18).</p>
<p>The shoulder girdles and upper limbs. Each shoulder girdle consists of a clavicle and a scapula. Each upper limb comprises:</p>
<ul>
<li>1 humerus</li>
<li>1 radius</li>
<li>1 ulna</li>
<li>8 carpal bones
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-414dacfe.jpeg" alt="img-37.jpeg"></li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 1.21 The body cavities.</p>
<ul>
<li>5 metacarpal bones</li>
<li>14 phalanges.</li>
</ul>
<p>The pelvic girdle and lower limbs. The bones of the pelvic girdle are the two innominate bones and the sacrum. Each lower limb consists of:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>1 femur</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>1 tibia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>1 fibula</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>1 patella</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>7 tarsal bones</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>5 metatarsal bones</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>14 phalanges.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Functions
The appendicular skeleton has two main functions:</p>
<ul>
<li>Voluntary movement. The bones, muscles and joints of the limbs are involved in movement of the skeleton. This ranges from the very fine finger movements needed for writing to the coordinated movement of all the limbs associated with running and jumping.</li>
<li>Protection of blood vessels and nerves. These delicate structures run along the length of bones of the limbs and are protected from injury by the associated muscles and skin. They are most vulnerable where they cross joints and where bones can be felt immediately below the skin.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cavities-of-the-body">Cavities of the body<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cavities-of-the-body" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The body organs are contained and protected within four cavities: cranial, thoracic, abdominal and pelvic (Fig. 1.21).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cranial-cavity">Cranial cavity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cranial-cavity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The cranial cavity contains the brain. Its boundaries are formed by the bones of the skull (Fig. 1.22):</p>
<p>Anteriorly - 1 frontal bone Laterally - 2 temporal bones Posteriorly - 1 occipital bone Superiorly - 2 parietal bones</p>
<p>Inferiorly - 1 sphenoid and 1 ethmoid bone and parts of the frontal, temporal and occipital bones.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="thoracic-cavity">Thoracic cavity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thoracic-cavity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This cavity is situated in the upper part of the trunk. Its boundaries are formed by the thoracic cage and supporting muscles (Fig. 1.23A):</p>
<p>Anteriorly - the sternum and costal cartilages of the ribs Laterally - 12 pairs of ribs and the intercostal muscles Posteriorly - the thoracic vertebrae Superiorly - the structures forming the root of the neck Inferiorly - the diaphragm, a dome-shaped muscle.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-9c265980.jpeg" alt="img-38.jpeg"></p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="contents">Contents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#contents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The main organs and structures contained in the thoracic cavity are shown in Fig. 1.23B. These include:</p>
<ul>
<li>the trachea, 2 bronchi, 2 lungs</li>
<li>the heart, aorta, superior and inferior venae cavae, numerous other blood vessels</li>
<li>the oesophagus</li>
<li>lymph vessels and lymph nodes</li>
<li>some important nerves.</li>
</ul>
<p>The mediastinum is the space between the lungs, including the structures found there, such as the heart, oesophagus and blood vessels.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="abdominal-cavity">Abdominal cavity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abdominal-cavity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the largest body cavity and is oval in shape (Figs 1.24 and 1.25). It occupies most of the trunk and its boundaries are:</p>
<p>Superiorly - the diaphragm, which separates it from the thoracic cavity
Anteriorly - the muscles forming the anterior abdominal wall
Posteriorly - the lumbar vertebrae and muscles forming the posterior abdominal wall</p>
<p>Laterally - the lower ribs and parts of the muscles of the abdominal wall
Inferiorly - it is continuous with the pelvic cavity.
By convention, the abdominal cavity is divided into the nine regions shown in Fig. 1.26. This facilitates the description of the positions of the organs and structures it contains.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="contents">Contents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#contents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Most of the abdominal cavity is occupied by the organs and glands of the digestive system (see Figs 1.24 and 1.25). These are:</p>
<ul>
<li>the stomach, small intestine and most of the large intestine</li>
<li>the liver, gall bladder, bile ducts and pancreas.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-4018c676.jpeg" alt="img-41.jpeg"></li>
</ul>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pelvic-cavity">Pelvic cavity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pelvic-cavity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The pelvic cavity is roughly funnelshaped and extends from the lower end of the abdominal cavity (Figs 1.27 and 1.28). Its boundaries are:</p>
<p>Superiorly - it is continuous with the abdominal cavity
Anteriorly - the pubic bones Posteriorly - the sacrum and coccyx Laterally - the innominate bones Inferiorly - the muscles of the pelvic floor.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="contents">Contents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#contents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The pelvic cavity contains the following structures:</p>
<ul>
<li>sigmoid colon, rectum and anus</li>
<li>some loops of the small intestine</li>
<li>urinary bladder, lower parts of the ureters and the urethra</li>
<li>in the female, the organs of the reproductive system: the uterus, uterine tubes, ovaries and vagina (see Fig. 1.27)</li>
<li>in the male, some of the organs of the reproductive system: the prostate gland, seminal vesicles, spermatic cords, deferent ducts (vasa deferentia), ejaculatory ducts and the urethra (common to the reproductive and urinary systems) (see Fig. 1.28).
■・SPOT CHECK</li>
</ul>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="introduction-to-ageing">Introduction to ageing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction-to-ageing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>list the main features of ageing</li>
<li>outline the implications of ageing human populations.</li>
</ul>
<p>After birth, many changes occur as the body grows and develops to maturity. The peak of mature physiological function is often relatively shortlived, as age-related changes begin to impair performance; for example, kidney function begins to decline from about 30 years of age. At both extremes of the lifespan, many aspects of body function are less efficient; for example, temperature regulation is less effective in infants and older adults.</p>
<p>Maturity of most body organs occurs during puberty and maximal efficiency during early adulthood. Most organs are able to repair and replace their tissues, with the notable exceptions of the brain and myocardium (heart muscle). At maturity, many organs have considerable functional reserve.
or 'spare capacity', which usually declines gradually thereafter. The functional reserve means that considerable loss of function must occur before physiological changes are evident. Alterations in body function during older life need careful assessment, as ageing is generally associated with decreasing efficiency of body organs and/or increasing frailty. Although a predisposing factor for some conditions, the ageing process is not accompanied by any specific illnesses or diseases.</p>
<p>The process of ageing is poorly understood, although it affects people in different ways. There is no single known cause, although many theories have been proposed, and there is enormous individual variation in the rate of ageing. The lifespan of an individual is influenced by many factors, some of which are hereditary (Ch. 17) and beyond individual control. Others not readily susceptible to individual influence include poverty, which is associated with poor health. However, peoples' lifestyle choices may also strongly influence longevity; for example, lack of exercise, cigarette smoking and alcohol misuse contribute to a shorter lifespan.</p>
<p>Several common age-associated changes that occur in particular organs and systems are well recognised and these include greying hair and wrinkling of the skin. Further examples are shown in Fig. 1.29, and these and other changes are highlighted, together with their physiological and sometimes clinical consequences, at the end of the physiology section in relevant chapters. Increasing age is a risk factor for some diseases, e.g. most cancers, coronary heart disease and dementia.</p>
<p>The World Health Organization (WHO, 2012) predicts that the number of people aged 60 years and over globally will increase from 605 million to 2 billion between 2000 and 2050 (Fig. 1.30). The 20th century saw the proportion of older people increasing in high-income countries. Over the first half of the 21 st century, this trend is predicted to spread to most areas of the world, including low- and middleincome countries. Increasing life expectancy will impact on healthcare, and the role of prevention of and early interventions in ill-health will become increasingly important.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction-to-the-study-of-illness">Introduction to the study of illness<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction-to-the-study-of-illness" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>list mechanisms that commonly cause disease</li>
<li>define the terms aetiology, pathogenesis and prognosis</li>
<li>name some common disease processes.</li>
</ul>
<p>To understand the specific diseases described in later chapters, knowledge of the relevant anatomy and physiology is necessary, as well as familiarity with the pathological processes outlined here.</p>
<p>Human beings can suffer from a wide range of illnesses, disorders and diseases, which vary from minor but often very troublesome conditions to the very serious. The study of abnormalities can be made much easier when a systematic approach is adopted. In order to achieve this in later chapters where specific diseases are explained, the headings shown in Box 1.1 will be used as a guide. Causes (aetiology) are outlined first when there are clear links between them and the effects of the abnormality (pathogenesis).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="aetiology">Aetiology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#aetiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Diseases are usually caused by one or more of a limited number of mechanisms, which may include:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>genetic abnormalities, either inherited or acquired</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>infection by microorganisms, such as bacteria, viruses, microbes or parasites, e.g. worms</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>chemicals</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>ionising radiation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>physical trauma</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>degeneration, e.g. excessive use or ageing.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>In some diseases, more than one of these aetiological factors is involved; in others, however, no specific cause</p>
<p>Box 1.1 Suggested framework for understanding diseases
Aetiology: the cause of the disease
Complications: other consequences that might arise if the disease progresses
Pathogenesis: the nature of the disease process and its effect on normal body functioning</p>
<p>Prognosis: the likely outcome
has been identified and these may be described as essential, idiopathic or spontaneous. Although the precise cause of a disease may not be known, predisposing (risk) factors are usually identifiable.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pathogenesis">Pathogenesis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The main processes causing illness or disease are outlined here. Box 1.2 contains a glossary of disease-associated terminology.</p>
<p>Inflammation
Inflammation (p. 409) is a tissue response to any kind of tissue damage, such as trauma or infection. Inflammatory conditions are easily recognised by the suffix '-itis', e.g. appendicitis.</p>
<p>Tumours
Tumours (p. 57) arise when abnormal cells escape normal growth controls and proliferate. The rate of their production exceeds that of normal cell death, causing a mass to develop. Tumours are recognised by the suffix '-oma', e.g. carcinoma.</p>
<p>Abnormal immune mechanisms
Abnormal immune mechanisms (p. 417) are undesirable responses of the normally protective immune system. Allergic conditions (p. 417) are the result of an abnormal immune response to a foreign trigger known as an antigen, e.g. hay fever</p>
<p>(p. 285). In autoimmune diseases, such as rheumatoid arthritis (p. 470), the body develops self-antigens that attack and damage its own tissues.</p>
<p>Box 1.2 Glossary of terminology associated with disease
Acquired: a disorder that develops any time after birth (compare with congenital)
Acute: a disease with sudden onset often requiring urgent treatment (compare with chronic)</p>
<p>Chronic: a long-standing disorder that cannot usually be cured (compare with acute)</p>
<p>Communicable: a disease that can be transmitted (spread) from one individual to another</p>
<p>Congenital: a disorder that one is born with (compare with acquired)
Iatrogenic: a condition that results from healthcare intervention
Sign: an abnormality seen or measured by people other than the patient
Symptom: an abnormality described by the patient
Syndrome: a collection of signs and symptoms that tend to occur together</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="section-1-the-body-and-its-constituents">SECTION 1 The body and its constituents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-1-the-body-and-its-constituents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Thrombosis, embolism and infarction
Thrombosis, embolism and infarction (p. 124) are the effects and consequences of abnormal changes in the blood and/ or blood vessel walls.</p>
<p>Degeneration
This is often associated with normal ageing but may also arise prematurely when structures deteriorate, causing impaired function, e.g. in muscular dystrophy (p. 472).</p>
<p>Metabolic abnormalities
These cause undesirable metabolic effects, e.g. diabetes mellitus (p. 255).
Genetic abnormalities
These may be either inherited (e.g. phenylketonuria, p. 484) or caused by environmental factors such as exposure to ionising radiation (p. 57).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5205029c">■ SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5205029c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="8">
<li>Compare and contrast the terms 'congenital' and 'acquired'.</li>
</ol>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="review-and-revise">Review and revise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-and-revise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Complete the following statements:</p>
<ol>
<li>The three types of blood vessels are <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>

<p>Choose one answer to complete each of the following statements:
3. The blood cells that transport oxygen in the blood are
the: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>

d. Leukocytes.
4. The female egg cell is also known as the: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>

<p>Because living tissues are composed of chemical bui blocks, the study of anatomy and physiology depencfe on some understanding of biochemistry - the chemistry of life. This chapter introduces core concepts in chemistry that will underpin the remaining chapters in this book. Some of the key physiological processes on which body function depends, including homeostasis and the movement of fluids between body compartments, will also be explored.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="atoms-molecules-and-compounds">Atoms, molecules and compounds<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atoms-molecules-and-compounds" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>define the following terms: atomic number, atomic weight, isotope, molecular weight, ion, electrolyte, pH , acid and alkali</li>
<li>describe the structure of an atom</li>
<li>discuss the types of bond that hold molecules together</li>
<li>outline the concept of molar concentration</li>
<li>explain the importance of buffers in the regulation of pH .</li>
</ul>
<p>All matter in our universe is built of particles called atoms. An element contains only one type of atom, e.g. carbon, sulphur or hydrogen. Substances containing two or more types of atom combined are called compounds. For example, water is a compound containing both hydrogen and oxygen atoms.</p>
<p>There are 92 naturally occurring elements, but the wide variety of compounds making up living tissues are composed almost entirely of only four elements: carbon, hydrogen, oxygen and nitrogen. Small amounts (about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>4</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">4 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">4%</span></span></span></span></span> of body weight) of others are present, including sodium, potassium, calcium and phosphorus.</p>
<p>Atoms are mainly empty space, with a tiny central nucleus containing protons and neutrons surrounded by clouds of tiny orbiting electrons (Fig. 2.1). Neutrons carry no electrical charge, but protons are positively charged, and electrons are negatively charged. Because atoms contain equal numbers of protons and electrons, they carry no net charge.</p>
<p>These subatomic particles differ also in terms of their mass. Electrons are so small that their mass is negligible, but the bigger neutrons and protons carry one atomic mass unit each. The physical characteristics of electrons, protons and neutrons are summarised in Table 2.1.</p>
<p>CHAPTER
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-44dc5d08.jpeg" alt="img-48.jpeg"></p>
<p>Electron shells
Nucleus

Neutron

<p>Particle

Atomic number and atomic weight
What makes one element different from another is the number of protons in the nuclei of its atoms (Fig. 2.2). This is called the atomic number and each element has its own atomic number, unique to its atoms. For instance, hydrogen has only 1 proton per nucleus, oxygen has 8 and sodium has 11 . The atomic numbers of hydrogen, oxygen and sodium are therefore 1,8 and 11 , respectively. The atomic weight of an element is the sum of the protons and neutrons in the atomic nucleus.</p>
<p>The electrons are shown in Fig. 2.1 as though they orbit in concentric rings round the nucleus. These shells represent the different energy levels of the atom's</p>
<p>electrons, not their physical positions. The first energy level can hold only two electrons and is filled first. The second energy level can hold only eight electrons and is filled next. The third and subsequent energy levels hold increasing numbers of electrons, each containing more than the preceding level.</p>
<p>When the atom's outer electron shell does not contain a stable number of electrons, the atom is reactive and can donate, receive or share electrons with one or more other atoms to achieve stability. The great number of possible combinations of different types of atom yields the wide range of substances of which the world is built and on which biology is based. This is described more fully in the section discussing molecules and compounds.</p>
<p>Figure 2.3 The isotopes of hydrogen.
Isotopes
Isotopes are atoms of an element in which there is a different number of neutrons in the nucleus. This does not affect the electrical activity of these atoms because neutrons carry no electrical charge, but it does affect their atomic weight. For example, there are three forms of the hydrogen atom. The most common form has one proton in the nucleus and one orbiting electron. Another form (deuterium) has one proton and one neutron in the nucleus. A third form (tritium) has one proton and two neutrons in the nucleus and one orbiting electron. Each is an isotope of hydrogen (Fig. 2.3).</p>
<p>Because the atomic weight of an element is actually an average atomic weight calculated using all its atoms, the true atomic weight of hydrogen is 1.008 , although for most practical purposes it can be taken as 1 .</p>
<p>Chlorine has an atomic weight of 35.5 because it contains two isotopes, one with an atomic weight of 35 (with 18 neutrons in the nucleus) and the other 37 (with 20 neutrons in the nucleus). Because the proportion of these two forms is not equal, the average atomic weight is 35.5 .</p>
<p>Some isotopes are unstable because of these extra neutrons in the nucleus, and achieve a more stable state by emitting radiation, which can be detected with a Geiger counter. Such isotopes are called radioisotopes, and are useful in many branches of science, including medicine. For example, the
radiation they emit can be used to kill cancer cells, and other radioisotopes may be used as tracer materials and injected into the bloodstream to show up blockages in blood vessels.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="molecules-and-compounds">Molecules and compounds<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#molecules-and-compounds" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>As mentioned earlier, the atoms of each element have a specific number of electrons around the nucleus. When the number of electrons in the outer shell of an element is either the maximum number (see Fig. 2.1) or a stable proportion of this fraction, the element is described as inert or chemically unreactive, and it will not easily combine with other atoms. These elements are the inert gases - helium, neon, argon, krypton, xenon and radon.</p>
<p>Molecules consist of two or more atoms that are chemically combined. The atoms may be of the same element; for example, a molecule of atmospheric oxygen (O 2 ) contains two oxygen atoms. Most substances, however, are compounds and contain two or more different elements; for example, a water molecule (H 2 O ) contains two hydrogen atoms and an oxygen atom. Q 2.1</p>
<p>Compounds containing carbon and hydrogen are classified as organic, and all others as inorganic. Living tissues are based on organic compounds, but the body requires inorganic compounds too.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="covalent-and-ionic-bonds">Covalent and ionic bonds<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#covalent-and-ionic-bonds" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The vast array of chemical processes on which life is based is completely dependent on the way atoms come together, bind and break apart. For example, the humble water molecule is a crucial foundation of all life on Earth. If water was a less stable compound and the atoms came apart easily, human biology could never have evolved. On the other hand, the body is dependent on the breaking down of various molecules (e.g. sugars, fats) to release energy for cellular activities. When atoms are joined together, they form a chemical bond that is generally one of two types: covalent or ionic. IJ2.2</p>
<p>Covalent bonds are formed when atoms share their electrons with each other. Most molecules are held together with this type of bond; it forms a strong and stable link between its constituent atoms. A water molecule is built using covalent bonds. Hydrogen has one electron in its outer shell, but the optimum number for this shell is two. Oxygen has six electrons in its outer shell, but the optimum number for this shell is eight. Therefore, if one oxygen atom and two hydrogen atoms combine, each hydrogen atom will share its electron with the oxygen atom, giving the oxygen atom a total of eight outer electrons, making it stable. The oxygen atom shares one of its electrons with each of the two hydrogen atoms, so that each hydrogen atom has two electrons in its outer shell, and they too are stable (Fig. 2.4).</p>
<p>Ionic bonds are weaker than covalent bonds and are formed when electrons are transferred from one atom to another. For example, when sodium ( Na ) combines</p>
<p>with chlorine <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{Cl})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Cl</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> to form sodium chloride <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{NaCl})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">NaCl</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>, the only electron in the outer shell of the sodium atom is transferred</p>
<p>Oxygen
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-00115bba.jpeg" alt="img-51.jpeg">
to the outer shell of the chlorine atom (Fig. 2.5). This leaves the sodium atom with eight electrons in its outer (second) shell, and it is therefore stable. The chlorine atom also has eight electrons in its outer shell, which, although not filling the shell, is a stable number. The sodium atom is now positively charged because it has given away a negatively charged electron, and the chloride ion is now negatively charged because it has accepted sodium's extra electron. The two atoms therefore stick together because they are carrying opposite, mutually attractive, charges.</p>
<p>When sodium chloride is dissolved in water, the ionic bond breaks and the two atoms separate. The atoms are charged because they have traded electrons, so are no longer called atoms, but ions. Sodium, with the positive charge, is a cation, written <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Na}^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8251em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Na</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8251em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> and chloride, being negatively</p>
<p>Figure 2.4 A water molecule, showing the covalent bonds between hydrogen and oxygen.</p>
<p>Figure 2.5 Formation of the ionic compound, sodium chloride.
charged, is an anion, written <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo mathvariant="normal" lspace="0em" rspace="0em">′</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Cl}^{\prime}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8362em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Cl</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8362em;"><span style="top: -3.1473em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">′</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>. By convention the number of electrical charges carried by an ion is indicated by the superscript plus or minus signs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="electrolytes">Electrolytes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#electrolytes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>An ionic compound, e.g. sodium chloride, dissolved in water is called an electrolyte because it conducts electricity. Electrolytes are important body constituents because they:</p>
<ul>
<li>conduct electricity, essential for muscle and nerve function</li>
<li>exert osmotic pressure, keeping body fluids in their own compartments</li>
<li>act as buffers (p.33) to resist pH changes in body fluids.</li>
</ul>
<p>Many biological compounds, e.g. carbohydrates, are not ionic, and therefore have no electrical properties when dissolved in water. Important electrolytes other than sodium and chloride include potassium <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\left(\mathrm{K}^{\wedge}\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0019em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span>, calcium <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>∧</mo><mo>∧</mo></mrow></msup><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\left(\mathrm{Ca}^{\wedge \wedge}\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.2em; vertical-align: -0.35em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">(</span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Ca</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8251em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">)</span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, bicarbonate <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{HCO}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">HCO</span></span></span></span></span></span> 3 ) and phosphate (P 04 ").</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="measurement-of-substances-in-body-fluids">Measurement of substances in body fluids<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#measurement-of-substances-in-body-fluids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There is no single way of measuring and expressing the concentration of different substances in body fluids. Sometimes the unit used is based on weight in grams or fractions of a gram (see also p. 533), e.g. milligrams, micrograms or nanograms. If the molecular weight of the substance is known, the concentration can be expressed as moles, millimoles or nanomoles per litre. A related measure is the milliequivalent (mEq) per litre.</p>
<p>Sometimes it is most convenient to measure the quantity of a substance in terms of its activity; insulin, for instance, is measured in international units (IU).</p>
<p>Table 2.2 gives examples of the normal plasma levels of some important substances, given in molar concentrations and alternative units.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="acids-bases-and-ph-mathbf-p-h-ph">Acids, bases and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="bold">p</mi><mi mathvariant="bold">H</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{p H}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8805em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbf">pH</span></span></span></span></span></span><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acids-bases-and-ph-mathbf-p-h-ph" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The measuring system used to express the concentration of hydrogen ions {[irt]) in a fluid is pH , which is an indicator of its acidity or alkalinity. Living cells are very sensitive to changes in [ff], and since the biochemical processes of life continually produce or consume hydrogen ions.
sophisticated homeostatic mechanisms (p.36) in the body constantly monitor and regulate pH .</p>
<p>An acid substance releases hydrogen ions when in solution. On the other hand, a basic (alkaline) substance accepts hydrogen ions, often with the release of hydroxyl <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mo mathvariant="normal">′</mo><mo mathvariant="normal">′</mo></mrow></msup><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\left(\mathrm{OH}^{\prime \prime}\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.2em; vertical-align: -0.35em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">(</span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">OH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8251em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">′′</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">)</span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ions. A salt releases other anions and cations when dissolved; sodium chloride is therefore a salt because in solution it releases sodium and chloride ions.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-ph-mathbf-p-h-ph-scale">The <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="bold">p</mi><mi mathvariant="bold">H</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{p H}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8805em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbf">pH</span></span></span></span></span></span> scale<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-ph-mathbf-p-h-ph-scale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The standard scale for measurement of hydrogen ion concentration in solution is the pH scale (Fig. 2.6). The scale measures from 0 to 14 , with 7 , the midpoint, as neutral; this is the pH of pure water. Water is a neutral molecule, neither acid nor basic (alkaline), because when the molecule breaks up into its constituent ions, it releases one and one <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mo mathvariant="normal">′</mo><mo mathvariant="normal">′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{OH}^{\prime \prime}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8251em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">OH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8251em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">′′</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, which balance one another. With the notable exception of gastric juice, most body fluids are close to neutral because they contain buffers, themselves weak acids and bases, to keep their pH within narrow ranges.</p>
<p>A pH reading of below 7 indicates an acid solution, while readings of above 7 indicate basic (alkaline) solutions. Fig. 2.6 shows the pH of some common fluids (see also p. 533). A change of one whole number on the pH scale indicates a 10fold change in [ff]. Therefore, a solution of pH 5 contains 10 times as many hydrogen ions as a solution of pH 6 .</p>
<p>Not all acids ionise completely when dissolved in water. The hydrogen ion concentration is, therefore, a measure of the amount of dissociated acid (ionised acid) rather than of the total amount of acid present. Strong acids dissociate more extensively than weak acids; for example, hydrochloric</p>

<p>Likewise, not all bases dissociate completely. Strong bases dissociate more fully, i.e. they release more <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mtext>w&nbsp;</mtext></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{OH}^{\text {w }}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7376em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">OH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7376em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">w&nbsp;</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> than weaker ones.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ph-values-of-body-fluids">pH values of body fluids<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ph-values-of-body-fluids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The pH of body fluids is generally maintained within relatively narrow limits.
The highly acid pH of the gastric juice is maintained by hydrochloric acid secreted by the parietal cells in the walls of the gastric glands. The low pH of the stomach fluids destroys microbes and toxins swallowed in food or drink. Saliva has a pH of between 5.4 and 7.5 , which is the optimum value for the action of salivary amylase, the enzyme present in saliva that initiates the digestion of carbohydrates. Amylase is destroyed by gastric acid when it reaches the stomach.</p>
<p>Blood pH is kept between 7.35 and 7.45 , and outside this narrow range there is severe disruption of normal physiological and biochemical processes. Normal</p>
<p>metabolic activity of body cells constantly produces acids and bases, which would tend to alter the pH of the tissue fluid and blood. Chemical buffers, which can reversibly bind hydrogen ions, are responsible for keeping body pH stable.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="buffers">Buffers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#buffers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Despite the constant cellular production of acids and bases, body pH is kept stable by systems of buffering chemicals in body fluids and tissues. These buffering mechanisms are important homeostatic (p.36) mechanisms and temporarily neutralise fluctuations in pH , but can function effectively only if there is some means by which excess acid or bases can be excreted from the body. The organs most active in this way are the lungs and the kidneys. The lungs are important regulators of blood pH because they excrete carbon dioxide (CO 2 ). CO 2 increases [ff] in body fluids because it combines with water to form carbonic acid, which then dissociates into a bicarbonate ion and a hydrogen ion.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>20</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><msup><mn>03</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CO} 2+\mathrm{H} 20 \mathrm{oH} 2 \mathrm{C} 03^{\wedge}+\mathrm{HCO} 3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8352em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">oH</span></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span><span class="mord">0</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">3</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">HCO</span></span><span class="mord">3</span></span></span></span></span>
carbon carbonic hydrogen bicarbonate
dioxide acid 'on ion
The lungs, therefore, help to control blood pH by regulating levels of excreted CO 2. The brain detects rising [ <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{H}_{\mathrm{i}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3175em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">i</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ] in the blood and stimulates breathing, causing increased CO 2 loss and a fall in [ff]. Conversely, if blood pH becomes too basic, the brain can reduce the respiration rate to increase CO 2 levels and increase [ff], decreasing pH towards normal (see Ch. 10).</p>
<p>The kidneys regulate blood pH by adjusting the excretion of hydrogen and bicarbonate ions as required. If pH falls, hydrogen ion excretion is increased and bicarbonate conserved; the reverse happens if pH rises. In addition, the kidneys generate bicarbonate ions as a by-product of
amino acid breakdown in the renal tubules; this process also generates ammonium ions, which are rapidly excreted.</p>
<p>Other buffer systems include body proteins, including haemoglobin in red blood cells, which absorb excess ff, and phosphate, which is particularly important in controlling intracellular pH . The buffer and excretory systems of the body together maintain the acid-base balance so that the pH range of body fluids remains within normal, but narrow, limits.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acidosis-and-alkalosis">Acidosis and alkalosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acidosis-and-alkalosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The buffer systems just described compensate for most pH fluctuations, but these reserves are limited and, in extreme cases, can become exhausted. When the pH falls below 7.35 and all the reserves of alkaline buffers are used up, the condition of</p>
<p>acidosis exists. In the reverse situation, when the pH rises above 7.45 , the increased alkali uses up all the acid reserve and the state of alkalosis exists.</p>
<p>Acidosis and alkalosis are both dangerous, particularly to the central nervous system and the cardiovascular system. In practice, acidotic conditions are more common than alkalotic ones because the body tends to produce more acid than alkali. Acidosis may follow respiratory problems if the lungs are not excreting CO 2 as efficiently as normal, or if the body is producing excess acids (e.g. diabetic ketoacidosis, p. 256), or in kidney disease if renal <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{H}^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> excretion is reduced. Alkalosis may be caused by loss of acidic substances through vomiting, diarrhoea, endocrine disorders or diuretic therapy, which stimulates increased renal excretion. Rarely, it may follow increased respiratory effort, such as in an acute anxiety attack where excessive amounts of CO 2 are lost through overbreathing (hyperventilation).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="spot-check">SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>How many isotopes of hydrogen exist? Explain the differences in atomic structure between them.</li>
<li>Release of cellular acidic waste products does not usually lead to a significant drop in pH . Explain why.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="important-biological-molecules">Important biological molecules<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#important-biological-molecules" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe in simple terms the chemical nature of sugars, proteins, lipids, nucleotides and enzymes</li>
<li>discuss the biological importance of each of these important groups of molecules.</li>
</ul>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="carbohydrates">Carbohydrates<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carbohydrates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Carbohydrates (sugars and starches) contain carbon, oxygen and hydrogen, usually in the ratio 1:1:2. The carbon atoms are normally arranged in a ring, with the oxygen and hydrogen atoms linked to them. The structures of glucose, fructose and sucrose are shown in Fig. 2.7. When two sugar molecules combine to form a bigger sugar molecule, a water molecule is expelled and the bond formed is called a glycosidic linkage.</p>
<p>Glucose, the cells' preferred fuel molecule, is a monosaccharide (mono = one; saccharide <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span></span></span></span></span> sugar). Monosaccharides can be linked together to form bigger sugars, ranging in size from two sugar units (disaccharides), e.g. sucrose (table sugar) (see Fig. 2.7), to long chains containing many thousands of monosaccharides, such as starch. Such complex carbohydrates are called polysaccharides.</p>
<p>Glucose can be broken down in either the presence (aerobically) or the absence (anaerobically) of oxygen, but the process is much more efficient when O 2 is used. During this process, energy, water and carbon dioxide are released (p. 343). To ensure a constant supply of glucose for cellular metabolism, blood glucose levels are tightly controlled. Functions of sugars include:</p>
<ul>
<li>providing a ready source of energy to fuel cell metabolism (p.341)</li>
<li>providing a form of energy storage, e.g. glycogen (p.343)</li>
<li>forming an integral part of the structure of DNA and RNA (p. 477 and p. 478)</li>
<li>acting as receptors on the cell surface, allowing the cell to recognise other molecules and cells.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="amino-acids-and-proteins">Amino acids and proteins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#amino-acids-and-proteins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Amino acids always contain carbon, hydrogen, oxygen and nitrogen, and many carry sulphur, magnesium, phosphate, iron or other trace metals in addition. In human biochemistry, 20 amino acids are used as the principal building blocks of protein, although there are others; for instance, there are some amino acids used only in certain proteins, and some are seen only in microbial products. The amino acids used</p>
<p>NH 2 NH 2
