<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ribosomes">Ribosomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ribosomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are tiny granules composed of RNA and protein. They synthesise proteins from amino acids, using RNA as the template (see Fig. 17.5). When present in free units or in small clusters in the cytoplasm, the ribosomes make proteins for use within the cell. These include the enzymes required for metabolism. Metabolic pathways consist of a series of steps, each driven by a specific enzyme. Ribosomes are also found on the outer surface of the nuclear envelope and rough endoplasmic reticulum (see Fig. 3.6 and next section), where they manufacture proteins for export from the cell.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="endoplasmic-reticulum">Endoplasmic reticulum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#endoplasmic-reticulum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is an extensive series of interconnecting membranous canals in the cytoplasm (Eig. 3.6). There are two types: smooth and rough. Smooth ER synthesises lipids and steroid hormones, and is also associated with the detoxification of some drugs. Some of the lipids are used to replace and repair the</p>
<p>plasma membrane and membranes of organelles. Rough ER is studded with ribosomes. These are the site of synthesis of proteins, some of which are "exported' from cells, i.e. enzymes and hormones that leave the parent cell by exocytosis (Eig. 3.5 F ) to be used by cells elsewhere.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="golgi-apparatus">Golgi apparatus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#golgi-apparatus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The Golgi apparatus consists of stacks of closely folded flattened membranous sacs (Fig. 3.7). It is present in all cells
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-3710c829.jpeg" alt="img-72.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 3.7 Coloured transmission electron micrograph showing the Golgi apparatus (green). (Science Photo Library, reproduced with permission.)
but is larger in those that synthesise and export proteins. The proteins move from the ER to the Golgi apparatus, where they are 'packaged' into membrane-bound vesicles. The vesicles are stored and, when needed, they move to the plasma membrane and fuse with it, expelling the contents from the cell. This process is called exocytosis (Fig. 3.5F).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lysosomes">Lysosomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lysosomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Lysosomes are small membranous vesicles pinched off from the Golgi apparatus. They contain a variety of enzymes involved in breaking down fragments of organelles and large molecules (e.g. RNA, DNA, carbohydrates, proteins) inside the cell into smaller particles that are either recycled, or exported from the cell as waste material.</p>
<p>Lysosomes in white blood cells contain enzymes that digest foreign material such as microbes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cytoskeleton">Cytoskeleton<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cytoskeleton" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This consists of an extensive network of tiny protein fibres (Fig. 3.8). The cytoskeleton provides an internal support system for the cell, as well as guiding the movement of materials around the cell interior.</p>
<p>Microfilaments</p>
<p>These tiny fibres, made of actin, are anchored to the inside of the cell membrane and give the cell support and shape. Actin is also involved in the contractile process in muscle cells (p. 456).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="microtubules">Microtubules<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microtubules" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are large, rigid proteins that give the cell mechanical support and also provide the guidance tracking for internal movement of, for example:</p>
<ul>
<li>organelles</li>
<li>chromosomes during cell division.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-1be03e22.jpeg" alt="img-73.jpeg"></li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 3.8 Fibroblasts. Fluorescent light micrograph showing nuclei (purple) and cytoskeletons (yellow and blue). (R. Torsten Wittman/ Science Photo Library, reproduced with permission.)</p>
<p>Centrosome
This directs organisation of microtubules within the cell. It consists of a pair of centrioles (small clusters of microtubules) and plays an important role in cell division.</p>
<p>Cell extensions
These project from the plasma membrane in some types of cell. Their main components are microtubules, which allow movement. They include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Microvilli - tiny projections that contain microfilaments. They cover the exposed surface of certain types of cell, e.g. absorptive cells that line the small intestine (Fig. 3.9).</li>
</ul>
<p>By greatly increasing the surface area, microvilli make the structure of these cells ideal for their function, maximising absorption of nutrients from the small intestine.</p>
<ul>
<li>Cilia - microscopic hair-like projections containing microtubules that lie along the free borders of some cells (see Fig. 10.12). They beat in unison, moving substances along the surface, e.g. mucus moves upwards in the respiratory tract.</li>
<li>Flagella - single, long, whip-like projections containing microtubules, which form the Tails' of spermatozoa (see Fig. 1.15) that propel them through the female reproductive tract.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-cell-cycle">The cell cycle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-cell-cycle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Damaged, dead and worn-out cells, depending on their type, can often by replaced by cell division, maintaining tissue integrity and function. The frequency with which cell division occurs varies with different types of tissue (p. 55). Normally, this is carefully regulated to allow effective maintenance and repair of body tissues. At the end of their natural lifespan.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-fd2389c9.jpeg" alt="img-74.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 3.9 Microvilli in small intestine. Coloured scanning electron micrograph. (Eye of Science/Science Photo Library, reproduoed with permission.)
ageing cells are programmed to 'self-destruct' and their components are removed by phagocytosis in a process known as apoptosis (p. 56).</p>
<p>Cells with nuclei have 46 chromosomes and divide by mitosis, a process that results in two new, genetically identical daughter cells. The only exception to this is the formation of gametes (sex cells), i.e. ova and spermatozoa, which takes place by meiosis (p. 480).</p>
<p>The period between two cell divisions is known as the cell cycle. This has two phases that can be seen on light microscopy: mitosis (M phase) and interphase (Fig. 3.10).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="interphase">Interphase<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#interphase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the longer phase and three separate stages are recognised:</p>
<ul>
<li>First gap phase (GJ - the cell grows in size and volume. This is usually the longest phase and most variable in length. Sometimes cells do not continue round the cell cycle but enter a resting phase (Go); despite being called the resting phase, cells at this stage are usually highly active, carrying out their specific functions. The cell may stay in Go for the rest of its life, but may also re-enter the cell cycle and start dividing again if need be.</li>
<li>Synthesis of DNA (S phase) - the chromosomes replicate, forming two identical copies of DNA (p. 476). Therefore, following the S phase, the cell now has 92 chromosomes, i.e. enough DNA for two cells, and is nearly ready to divide by mitosis.</li>
<li>Second gap phase (G 2 ) - there is further growth and preparation for cell division.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-3250f68c.jpeg" alt="img-75.jpeg"></li>
</ul>
<p>S phase
(DNA replication)
Go
Figure 3.10 The cell cycle.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mitosis">Mitosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mitosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Mitosis (Figs 3.11 and 3.12) is a continuous process involving four distinct stages visible by light microscopy.</p>
<p>Prophase</p>
<p>During this stage the replicated chromatin becomes tightly coiled and easier to see under the microscope. Each of the original 46 chromosomes (called a chromatid at this stage) is paired with its copy in a double chromosome unit. The two chromatids are joined to each other at the centromere (see Fig. 3.11). The mitotic apparatus appears; this consists of two centrioles separated by the mitotic spindle, which is formed from microtubules. The centrioles migrate, one to each end of the cell, and the nuclear envelope disappears.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="metaphase">Metaphase<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#metaphase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The chromatids align on the centre of the spindle, attached by their centromeres.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="anaphase">Anaphase<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anaphase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The centromeres separate, and one of each pair of sister chromatids (now called chromosomes again) migrates to each end of the spindle as the microtubules that form the mitotic spindle shorten.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-f73fe466.jpeg" alt="img-76.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>Centriole Mitotic spindle
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-7a3c365d.jpeg" alt="img-77.jpeg"></li>
</ul>
<p>Sister chromatids (now separated)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-34fc8581.jpeg" alt="img-78.jpeg"></p>
<p>Anaphase
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-a51a081a.jpeg" alt="img-79.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-e68ffa29.jpeg" alt="img-80.jpeg"></p>
<p>Two identical daughter cells
Cytokinesis
Figure 3.11 The stages of mitosis.
Telophase
The mitotic spindle disappears, the chromosomes uncoil and the nuclear envelope reforms.</p>
<p>Following telophase, cytokinesis occurs: the cytosol, intracellular organelles and plasma membrane split, forming two identical daughter cells.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="10-spot-check">10 SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#10-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

</ol>

<p>Figure 3.12 Mitosis. Light micrograph showing cells at different stages of reproduction with chromatin/chromatids shown in pink. (Dr Gopal Murti/Science Photo Library, reproduced with permission.)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="epithelial-tissue">Epithelial tissue<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#epithelial-tissue" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This tissue type covers the body and lines cavities, hollow organs and tubes. It is also found in glands. The structure of epithelium (Fig. 3.13) is closely related to its functions, which include:</p>
<ul>
<li>protection of underlying structures from, for example, dehydration or chemical and mechanical damage</li>
<li>secretion</li>
<li>absorption.</li>
</ul>
<p>The cells are very closely packed and the intercellular substance, the matrix, is minimal. The cells usually lie on a basement membrane, which is an inert connective tissue made by the epithelial cells themselves. Epithelial tissue may be:</p>
<ul>
<li>simple: a single layer of cells</li>
<li>stratified: several layers of cells.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="tissues">Tissues<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tissues" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the structure and functions of epithelial, connective and muscle tissue</li>
<li>outline the structure and functions of epithelial and synovial membranes</li>
<li>compare and contrast the structure and functions of exocrine and endocrine glands.</li>
</ul>
<p>Tissues consist of large numbers of the same type of cells and are classified according to the size, shape and functions of their constituent cells. There are four main types of tissue, each with subtypes. They are:</p>
<ul>
<li>epithelial tissue or epithelium</li>
<li>connective tissue</li>
<li>muscle tissue</li>
<li>nervous tissue.</li>
</ul>
<p>Simple epithelium
Simple epithelium consists of a single layer of identical cells and is divided into three main types. It is usually found on absorptive or secretory surfaces, where the</p>
<p>single layer enhances these processes, and seldom on surfaces subject to stress. The types are named according to the shape of the cells, which differs according to their functions. The more active the tissue, the taller the cells.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="squamous-pavement-epithelium">Squamous (pavement) epithelium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#squamous-pavement-epithelium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is composed of a single layer of flattened cells (Fig. 3.13A). The cells fit closely together like paving stones, forming a thin and very smooth membrane across which diffusion occurs easily. It forms the lining of the following structures:</p>
<ul>
<li>heart - where it is known as endocardium</li>
<li>blood vessels where it is also known</li>
<li>lymph vessels as endothelium</li>
<li>alveoli of the lungs</li>
<li>collecting ducts of nephrons in the kidneys (see Fig. 13.8).</li>
</ul>
<p>I</p>
<p>Basement membrane
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-90193d2c.jpeg" alt="img-82.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 3.13 Simple epithelium. (A) Squamous. (B) Cuboidal. (C) Columnar.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-e709252a.jpeg" alt="img-83.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cuboidal-epithelium">Cuboidal epithelium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cuboidal-epithelium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This consists of cube-shaped cells fitting closely together and lying on a basement membrane (Fig. 3.13B). It forms the walls of kidney tubules and is found in some glands such as the thyroid (see Fig. 9.8). Cuboidal epithelium is actively involved in secretion, absorption and/ or excretion.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="columnar-epithelium">Columnar epithelium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#columnar-epithelium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is formed by a single layer of tall, thin cells on a basement membrane (Fig. 3.13C). It lines many organs and often has adaptations that make it well suited to a specific function. The lining of the stomach is formed from simple columnar epithelium without surface structures. The free surface of the columnar epithelium lining the small intestine is covered with microvilli (see Fig. 3.9). Microvilli provide a very large surface area for absorption of nutrients from the small intestine. In the trachea, columnar epithelium is ciliated (see Fig. 10.12) and also contains goblet cells that secrete mucus. This means that inhaled particles that stick to the mucus layer are moved towards the throat by cilia in the respiratory tract. In the uterine tubes, ova are propelled along towards the uterus by ciliary action.
stratified epithelium
Stratified epithelium consists of several layers of cells of various shapes. Continual cell division in the lower (basal) layers pushes cells above nearer and nearer to the surface, where they are shed. Basement membranes are usually absent. The main function of stratified epithelium is to protect underlying structures from mechanical wear and tear. There are two main types: stratified squamous and transitional.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="stratified-squamous-epithelium">Stratified squamous epithelium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stratified-squamous-epithelium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Stratified squamous epithelium (Fig. 3.14) is composed of several layers of cells. In the deepest layers the cells are mainly columnar and, as they grow towards the surface, they become flattened and are then shed.</p>
<p>Keratinised stratified epithelium
This is found on dry surfaces subjected to wear and tear, i.e. skin, hair and nails. The surface layer consists of dead epithelial cells that have lost their nuclei and contain the protein keratin. This forms a tough, relatively waterproof protective layer that prevents drying of the live cells underneath. The surface layer of skin is rubbed off and is replaced from below (see Figs 1.12 and 14.5).</p>
<p>Non-keratinised stratified epithelium
This protects moist surfaces subjected to wear and tear, and prevents them from drying out, e.g. the conjunctiva of the eyes, the lining of the mouth, the pharynx, the oesophagus and the vagina (Fig. 3.15).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-deaaa242.jpeg" alt="img-84.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 3.14 Stratified epithelium.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-fd2a2f80.jpeg" alt="img-85.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 3.15 Section of non-keratinised stratified squamous epithelial lining of the vagina. (Magnified x 100.) (Teiser AG, Young JK, Baidwin KM 2007 Eisevier's integrated histoiogy. Mosby: Edinburgh.)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="transitional-epithelium">Transitional epithelium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transitional-epithelium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Transitional epithelium (Fig. 3.16) is composed of several layers of pear-shaped cells. It lines several parts of the urinary tract, including the bladder, and allows for stretching as the bladder fills.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="connective-tissue">Connective tissue<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#connective-tissue" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Connective tissue is the most abundant tissue in the body. The cells in this tissue are more widely separated from each other than in epithelial tissues, and intercellular substance (matrix) is present in considerably larger amounts. There are usually fibres present in the matrix, which may be of a semisolid jelly-like consistency or dense and rigid, depending on the position and function of the tissue. The fibres form a supporting network to which the cells attach.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-44add15a.jpeg" alt="img-86.jpeg">
c</p>
<p>Figure 3.16 Transitional epithelium. (A) Relaxed. (B) Stretched. (C) Light micrograph of the bladder wall showing transitional epithelium (pink) above the smooth muscle and connective tissue layer (red).
(C, Steve G Schmeissner/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)
Most types of connective tissue have a good blood supply. Major functions of connective tissue are:</p>
<ul>
<li>binding and structural support</li>
<li>protection</li>
<li>transport</li>
<li>insulation.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cells-in-connective-tissue">Cells in connective tissue<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cells-in-connective-tissue" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Connective tissue, excluding blood (Ch. 4), is found in all organs, where it supports the specialised tissue. The range of cell types involved includes fibroblasts, fat cells, macrophages, leukocytes and mast cells.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fibroblasts">Fibroblasts<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fibroblasts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Fibroblasts are large cells with irregular processes (see Fig. 3.8). They manufacture collagen and elastic fibres, and a matrix of extracellular material. Collagen fibres are shown in Fig. 3.17. Very fine collagen fibres, sometimes called reticulin fibres, are found in highly active tissue, such as the liver and reticular tissue. Fibroblasts are particularly active in tissue repair (wound healing), when they may bind together the cut surfaces of wounds or form granulation tissue following tissue destruction (p. 399). The collagen fibres formed during wound healing shrink as</p>
<p>they age, sometimes interfering with the functions of the organ involved and with adjacent structures.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-00f3b67d.jpeg" alt="img-87.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 3.17 Collagen fibres. Coloured scanning electron micrograph. (Steve G Schmeissner/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<p>Fat cells
Also known as adipocytes, these cells occur singly or in groups in many types of connective tissue and are especially abundant in adipose tissue (see Fig. 3.20B). They vary in size and shape according to the amount of fat they contain.</p>
<p>Macrophages
These are large irregular-shaped cells with granules in the cytoplasm. Some are fixed, i.e. attached to connective tissue fibres, and others are motile. They are an important part of the body's defence mechanisms because they are actively phagocytic, engulfing and digesting cell debris, bacteria and other foreign bodies. Their activities are typical of those of the monocyte-macrophage defence system, e.g. monocytes in blood, hepatic macrophages (Kupffer cells) in liver sinusoids, sinus-lining cells in lymph nodes and spleen, and microglial cells in the brain (see Fig. 4.13).</p>
<p>Leukocytes
White blood cells (p. 68) are normally found in small numbers in healthy connective tissue but neutrophils migrate in significant numbers during infection, when they play an important part in tissue defence. Plasma cells develop from Blymphocytes, a type of white blood cell (p. 70). They synthesise and secrete specific defensive antibodies into the blood and tissues (Ch. 15).</p>
<p>Mast cells
These are similar to basophil leukocytes (p. 69). They are found in loose connective tissue, under the fibrous capsule of some organs, e.g. liver and spleen, and in considerable numbers round blood vessels. Their cytoplasm is packed with granules containing heparin, histamine and other substances, which are released following tissue damage (Fig. 3.18). Release of the granular contents is called</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-752d303c.jpeg" alt="img-88.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 3.18 Mast cell. Coloured transmission eleotron micrograph showing nucleus (pink and brown) and cytoplasm (green) packed with granules (brown). (Medimage/Science Photo Library.</p>
<p>Reproduced with permission.)
degranulation. Histamine is involved in local and general inflammatory reactions; it stimulates secretion of gastric juice and is associated with the development of allergies and hypersensitivity states (p. 417). Heparin prevents coagulation of blood, which helps to maintain blood flow through inflamed tissues, supplying cells with oxygen and glucose and bringing additional protective leukocytes to the area.</p>
<p>Loose (areolar) connective tissue
This is the most generalised type of connective tissue. The matrix is semisolid with many fibroblasts and some fat cells (adipocytes), mast cells and macrophages, widely separated by elastic and collagen fibres (Fig. 3.19). It is found in almost every part of the body, providing elasticity and tensile strength. It connects and supports other tissues, for example:</p>
<ul>
<li>under the skin</li>
<li>between muscles</li>
<li>supporting blood vessels and nerves</li>
<li>in the alimentary canal</li>
<li>in glands supporting secretory cells.</li>
</ul>
<p>Adipose tissue
Adipose tissue consists of fat cells (adipocytes), containing large fat globules, in a matrix of areolar tissue (Fig. 3.20). There are two types: white and brown.</p>
<p>White adipose tissue</p>
<p>This makes up 20-25% of body weight in adults with a normal body mass index (Ch. 11); more is present in obese people and less in those who are underweight. Adipose tissue secretes the hormone leptin (Table 9.4). The kidneys and eyeballs are supported by adipose tissue, which is also found between muscle fibres and under the skin, where it acts as a thermal insulator and energy store.</p>
<p>Brown adipose tissue
This has more mitochondria and a more extensive capillary network than white adipose tissue, and is more metabolically active. When it is broken down, it generates more heat than adipose tissue does and is important in keeping the newborn infant warm. In adults, brown fat is found in small amounts in the upper chest and neck areas.</p>
<p>Reticular tissue
Reticular tissue (Fig. 3.21) has a semisolid matrix with fine, branching reticulin fibres. It contains reticular cells and white blood cells (monocytes and lymphocytes). Reticular tissue is found in lymph nodes and lymphatic organs (see Fig. 6.1).</p>
<p>Dense connective tissue
This contains more fibres and fewer cells than loose connective tissue.
A
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-932b2281.jpeg" alt="img-89.jpeg"></p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fibrous-tissue">Fibrous tissue<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fibrous-tissue" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Fibrous tissue (Fig. 3.22A) is made up mainly of closely packed bundles of collagen fibres (see Fig. 3.17) with very little matrix. Fibrocytes (old and inactive fibroblasts) are few in number and lie in rows between the bundles of fibres. Fibrous tissue is found:</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-55d993e3.jpeg" alt="img-93.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 3.22 Dense connective tissue. (A) Fibrous tissue. (B) Elastic tissue.</p>
<ul>
<li>forming ligaments, which bind bones together</li>
<li>functioning as an outer protective covering for bone, called periosteum</li>
<li>functioning as an outer protective covering of some organs, e.g. the kidneys, lymph nodes and the brain</li>
<li>forming muscle sheaths, called muscle fascia (see Fig. 16.16), which extend beyond the muscle to become the tendon that attaches the muscle to bone.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="elastic-tissue">Elastic tissue<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#elastic-tissue" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Elastic tissue (Fig. 3.22B) is capable of considerable extension and recoil. There are few cells and the matrix consists mainly of masses of elastic fibres secreted by fibroblasts. It is found in organs where stretching or alteration of shape is required, e.g. in large blood vessel walls, the trachea and bronchi, and the lungs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood">Blood<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This fluid connective tissue is described in detail in Chapter 4.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cartilage">Cartilage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cartilage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cartilage is firmer than other connective tissues. The cells (chondrocytes) are sparse and lie embedded in matrix, reinforced by collagen and elastic fibres. There are three types: hyaline cartilage, fibrocartilage and elastic fibrocartilage.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hyaline-cartilage">Hyaline cartilage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hyaline-cartilage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The chondrocytes in this tissue are arranged in small groups within cell nests and the bluish-white matrix is solid and smooth (Fig. 3.23A). Hyaline cartilage provides flexibility.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-f0f999fd.jpeg" alt="img-94.jpeg"></p>
<p>Chondrocytes Cell nest Solid matrix
A
B
C
Figure 3.23 Cartilage. (A) Hyaline cartilage. (B) Fibrocartilage. (C) Elastic fibrocartilage.
support and smooth surfaces for movement at joints. It is found:</p>
<ul>
<li>on the ends of long bones that form joints</li>
<li>forming the costal cartilages, which attach the ribs to the sternum</li>
<li>forming part of the larynx, trachea and bronchi.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fibrocartilage">Fibrocartilage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fibrocartilage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This consists of dense masses of white collagen fibres in a matrix similar to that of hyaline cartilage with the cells widely dispersed (Fig. 3.23B). It is a tough, slightly flexible, supporting tissue found:</p>
<ul>
<li>as pads between the bodies of the vertebrae, called the intervertebral discs</li>
<li>between the articulating surfaces of the bones of the knee joint, called semilunar cartilages</li>
<li>on the rim of the bony sockets of the hip and shoulder joints, deepening the cavities without restricting movement.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="elastic-fibrocartilage">Elastic fibrocartilage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#elastic-fibrocartilage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This flexible tissue consists of yellow elastic fibres lying in a solid matrix with chondrocytes lying between the fibres (Fig. 3.23C). It provides support and maintains the shape of, for example, the pinna or lobe of the ear, the epiglottis and part of the tunica media of blood vessel walls.</p>
<p>Bone cells (osteocytes) are surrounded by a matrix of collagen fibres strengthened by inorganic salts, especially calcium and phosphate. This provides bones with their characteristic strength and rigidity. Bone also has considerable capacity for growth in the first two decades of life, and for regeneration throughout life. Two types of bone can be identified by the naked eye:</p>
<ul>
<li>compact bone, having a solid or dense appearance</li>
<li>spongy or cancellous bone, having a 'spongy' or fine honeycomb appearance.</li>
</ul>
<p>These are described in detail in Chapter 16.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="muscle-tissue">Muscle tissue<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscle-tissue" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This tissue is able to contract and relax, providing movement within the body and of the body itself. Muscle contraction requires a rich blood supply providing sufficient oxygen, calcium and nutrients and removing waste products. There are three types of specialised contractile cells, also known as fibres: skeletal muscle, smooth muscle and cardiac muscle.</p>
<p>Skeletal muscle
This type is described as skeletal because it forms those muscles that move the bones (of the skeleton), striated because striations (stripes) can be seen on microscopic examination (Fig. 3.24) and voluntary as it is under conscious control. Although most skeletal muscle moves bones, the diaphragm is made from this type of muscle to accommodate a degree of voluntary control in breathing. In reality, many movements can be finely coordinated, e.g. writing, but may also be controlled subconsciously. For example, maintaining an upright posture does not normally require thought unless a new locomotor skill is being learned, e.g. skating or cycling, and the diaphragm maintains breathing during sleep.</p>
<p>These fibres (cells) are cylindrical, contain multiple nuclei and can be up to 35 cm long. Skeletal muscle contraction is stimulated by motor nerve impulses originating in the brain or spinal cord and ending at the neuromuscular junction (p. 456). The properties and functions of skeletal muscle are explained in detail in Chapter 16.</p>
<p>Smooth muscle
Smooth muscle (Fig. 3.25) is described as non-striated, visceral or involuntary, as it does not have striations and is</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-43c7cb35.jpeg" alt="img-95.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 3.24 Skeletal muscle fibres. (A) Diagram. (B) Coloured scanning electron micrograph of skeletal muscle fibres and connective tissue fibres (bottom right). (B, Professors PM Motta, PM Andrews, KR Porter and J Vial/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)
not under conscious control. Some smooth muscle has the intrinsic ability to initiate its own contractions (automaticity), e.g. peristalsis (p. 315). It is innervated by the autonomic nervous system (p. 186). Additionally, autonomic nerve impulses, some hormones and local metabolites regulate its contraction. Smooth muscle is rich in mitochondria that fuel slow and sustained activity. It fatigues much more slowly than skeletal muscle. Smooth muscle cells are usually organised in sheets in the walls of hollow organs, so that contraction and relaxation determine pressure within the organ, for example:</p>
<ul>
<li>regulating the diameter of blood vessels and parts of the respiratory tract</li>
<li>propelling contents along, e.g. in the ureters, ducts of glands and the alimentary tract</li>
<li>expelling contents of the urinary bladder and uterus.</li>
</ul>
<p>When examined under a microscope, the cells are seen to be spindle-shaped with only one central nucleus.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cardiac-muscle">Cardiac muscle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cardiac-muscle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is found only in the heart wall. It is not under conscious control but, when viewed under a microscope, cross-stripes (striations) characteristic of skeletal muscle can be seen. Each fibre (cell) has one nucleus and one or more branches (Fig. 3.26). The ends of the cells and their branches are in very close contact with the ends and branches of adjacent
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-b48201ec.jpeg" alt="img-96.jpeg"></p>
<p>B</p>
<p>Figure 3.25 Smooth muscle. (A) Diagram. (B) Fluorescent light micrograph showing actin, a contractile muscle protein (green), nuclei (blue) and capillaries (red). (B, R Bick, B Poindexter, UT Medioal School/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-e87389eb.jpeg" alt="img-97.jpeg"></p>
<p>Nucleus Intercalated disc
Figure 3.26 Cardiac muscle fibres.
cells. Microscopically, these 'joints', or intercalated discs, appear as lines that are thicker and darker than the ordinary cross-stripes. This arrangement gives cardiac muscle the appearance of a sheet of muscle rather than a very large number of individual fibres. This is significant when the heart contracts, as a wave of contraction spreads from cell to cell across the intercalated discs, which means that the cardiac muscle fibres do not need to be stimulated individually.</p>
<p>The heart has an intrinsic pacemaker system, which means that it beats in a coordinated manner without external nerve stimulation, although the rate at which</p>
<p>it beats is influenced by autonomic nerve impulses, some hormones, local metabolites and other substances (Ch. 5).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-f7c6f480.jpeg" alt="img-98.jpeg"></p>
<p>Nuclei
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-1a787ee0.jpeg" alt="img-99.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="nervous-tissue">Nervous tissue<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nervous-tissue" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Two types of tissue are found in the nervous system:</p>
<ul>
<li>Excitable cells - these are called neurones and they initiate, receive, conduct and transmit information.</li>
<li>Non-excitable cells - these are also known as glial cells and they support the neurones.</li>
</ul>
<p>Both types are described in detail in Chapter 7.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="tissue-regeneration">Tissue regeneration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tissue-regeneration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The extent to which regeneration is possible, following tissue damage, depends on the normal rate of turnover of particular types of cell. Those with a rapid turnover regenerate most effectively. There are three general categories:</p>
<ul>
<li>Tissues in which cell replication is a continuous process regenerate quickly; these include epithelial cells of, for example, the skin, mucous membrane, secretory glands, uterine lining and reticular tissue.</li>
<li>Other tissues retain the ability to replicate but do so infrequently; these include the liver, kidney, fibroblasts and smooth muscle cells. These tissues take longer to regenerate.</li>
<li>Some cells are normally unable to replicate; these include nerve cells (neurones) and skeletal and cardiac muscle cells, meaning that damaged tissue cannot be replaced.</li>
</ul>
<p>Extensively damaged tissue is usually replaced by fibrous tissue, meaning that the functions of the original tissue are lost and the function of the organ as a whole is often impaired.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="membranes">Membranes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#membranes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="epithelial-membranes">Epithelial membranes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#epithelial-membranes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These membranes are sheets of epithelial tissue and supporting connective tissue that cover or line many internal structures or cavities. The main ones are mucous membrane, serous membrane and the skin (cutaneous membrane; Ch. 14).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mucous-membrane-q-3-4">Mucous membrane Q 3.4<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mucous-membrane-q-3-4" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the moist lining of the alimentary, respiratory and genitourinary tracts and is sometimes referred to as the mucosa. The membrane surface consists of epithelial cells, some of which produce a secretion called mucus, a slimy, tenacious fluid that is discharged on to the epithelial surface. As the cells fill up with mucus they have the appearance of a goblet or flask and are known as goblet cells (see Fig. 12.5). Organs lined by mucous membrane have a moist slippery surface. Mucus protects the lining membrane from drying, and from mechanical and chemical injury. In the respiratory tract it traps inhaled particles, preventing them from entering the alveoli of the lungs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="serous-membrane-q-3-5">Serous membrane Q 3.5<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#serous-membrane-q-3-5" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Serous membranes, or serosa, secrete serous watery fluid. They consist of a double layer of loose areolar connective tissue lined by simple squamous epithelium. The parietal layer lines a cavity and the visceral layer surrounds organs (the viscera) within the cavity. The two layers are separated by serous fluid secreted by the epithelium. There are three sites where serous membranes are found:</p>
<ul>
<li>the pleura lining the thoracic cavity and surrounding the lungs (p. 272)</li>
<li>the pericardium lining the pericardial cavity and surrounding the heart (p. 86)</li>
<li>the peritoneum lining the abdominal cavity and surrounding abdominal organs (p. 314).</li>
</ul>
<p>The serous fluid between the visceral and parietal layers enables an organ to glide freely within the cavity without being damaged by friction between it and adjacent organs. For example, the heart changes its shape and size during each beat, and friction damage is prevented by the arrangement of pericardium and its serous fluid.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="synovial-membrane-ij3-6">Synovial membrane IJ3.6<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#synovial-membrane-ij3-6" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This membrane lines the cavities of moveable joints and surrounds tendons that could be injured by rubbing against bones, e.g. over the wrist joint. It is not an</p>
<p>epithelial membrane but instead consists of areolar connective tissue and elastic fibres.</p>
<p>Synovial membrane secretes clear, sticky, oily synovial fluid, which lubricates and nourishes the joints (Ch. 16).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="glands">Glands<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#glands" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Glands are groups of epithelial cells that produce specialised secretions. Those that discharge their secretion on to the epithelial surface of hollow organs, either directly or through a duct, are called exocrine glands and these vary considerably in size, shape and complexity, as shown in Fig. 3.27. Their secretions include mucus, saliva, digestive juices and earwax. Fig. 3.28 shows simple tubular glands of the large intestine.</p>
<p>Other glands discharge their secretions into blood and lymph. These are called endocrine glands (ductless glands) and they secrete hormones (Ch. 9).</p>
<ul>
<li>SPOT CHECK</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="changes-in-cell-size-and-number">Changes in cell size and number<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#changes-in-cell-size-and-number" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The earlier part of this chapter explored characteristics typical of normal cells and tissues, but these may be affected by physiological and/or pathological changes.</p>
<p>Cells may enlarge, in a process known as hypertrophy (Fig. 3.29), in response to additional demands; for example, skeletal muscle cells hypertrophy in response to fitness training, increasing the bulk and tone of the exercised muscle. A decrease in the size or the number of cells is
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-2f1bec2e.jpeg" alt="img-103.jpeg"></p>
<p>Hyperplasia
Hypertrophy
Combined hypertrophy and hyperplasia
Figure 3.29 Hyperplasia and hypertrophy.
referred to as atrophy. Without use, muscle fibres atrophy (and muscle mass also decreases), e.g. those of a limb in a plaster cast applied to immobilise a fracture. Impaired nutrient or oxygen supply can also lead to atrophy.</p>
<p>Hyperplasia (Fig. 3.29) occurs when cells divide more quickly than previously, increasing cell numbers (and size of the tissue/organ), e.g. the glandular milkproducing tissue of the breasts during pregnancy and breast feeding. Abnormal hyperplasia can lead to the development of tumours when mitosis is no longer controlled and the daughter cells may show abnormal internal characteristics (see cell differentiation, p. 58).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cell-death">Cell death<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cell-death" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Two different mechanisms are recognised: apoptosis and necrosis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="apoptosis">Apoptosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#apoptosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is normal, genetically programmed cell death, in which an ageing cell at the end of its life cycle shrinks and its remaining fragments are phagocytosed without any inflammatory reaction. In later life, fewer cells lost by apoptosis are replaced, contributing to the general reduction in tissue mass and organ size in older adults.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="necrosis">Necrosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#necrosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is cell death resulting from lack of oxygen (ischaemia), injury or a pathological process. The plasma membrane ruptures, releasing the intracellular contents and triggering the inflammatory response. Inflammation is the first stage of tissue repair and is needed to clear the area of cell debris before healing and tissue repair can progress (Ch. 14).</p>
<ul>
