<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="control-of-coagulation">Control of coagulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-coagulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The process of blood clotting relies heavily on several self-perpetuating processes that is, once they have started, a positive feedback mechanism promotes their continuation. For example, thrombin is a powerful stimulator of its own production. Control and braking mechanisms are therefore essential to limit clotting to the affected area
and terminate the process at the appropriate time. These include:</p>
<ul>
<li>The perfect smoothness of normal blood vessel lining prevents platelet adhesion in healthy, undamaged blood vessels.</li>
<li>Activated clotting factors are rapidly deactivated by anticoagulants, such as heparin and antithrombin III.</li>
<li>Activated clotting factors are quickly cleared from the blood by the liver.</li>
<li>SPOT CHECK</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>Relate the main structural features of the red blood cell to its function.</li>
<li>Define diapedesis.</li>
<li>What is the difference between a platelet plug and a blood clot?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="erythrocyte-disorders">Erythrocyte disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#erythrocyte-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes</p>
<p>After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>define the term anaemia</li>
<li>compare and contrast the causes and effects of iron deficiency, megaloblastic, aplastic, hypoplastic and haemolytic anaemias</li>
<li>explain why polycythaemia occurs.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="anaemias">Anaemias<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anaemias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Anaemia is the inability of the blood to carry enough oxygen to meet body needs. Usually, this is because there are low haemoglobin levels, but sometimes it is due to production of faulty haemoglobin.</p>
<p>Anaemia is classified depending on the cause:</p>
<ul>
<li>Production of insufficient or defective erythrocytes - if the number of red blood cells being released is too low or the red blood cells are defective in some way, anaemia may result. Important causes include iron deficiency, vitamin B 12 / folic acid deficiency and bone marrow failure.</li>
<li>Blood loss or excessive erythrocyte breakdown (haemolysis) - if erythrocytes are lost from the circulation, either through blood loss in haemorrhage or by accelerated haemolysis, anaemia can result.</li>
</ul>
<p>Anaemia can cause abnormal changes in red cell size or colour, detectable microscopically. Characteristic changes are listed in Table 4.3. Anaemia may be associated with a normal red cell count and no abnormalities of erythrocyte structure (normochromic normocytic anaemia). For example, following sudden haemorrhage, the red cells in the bloodstream are normal in size, shape and colour, but their numbers are fewer.</p>
<p>Table 4.3 Terms used to describe red blood cell characteristics</p>
<p>Term
Definition</p>
<p>Normochromic
Cell colour normal</p>
<p>Normocytic
Cells normal-sized</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Microcytic</th><th>Cells smaller than normal</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Macrocytic</td><td>Cells bigger than normal</td></tr><tr><td>Hypochromic</td><td>Cells paler than normal</td></tr><tr><td>Haemolytic</td><td>Rate of cell destruction raised</td></tr><tr><td>Megaloblastic</td><td>Cells large and immature</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Anaemia may be asymptomatic. Signs and symptoms relate to the inability of the blood to supply body cells with enough oxygen, and may include pallor, fatigue and breathlessness on exertion. Additionally, the body's attempt to compensate for this can lead to: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>⋅</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\cdot</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">⋅</span></span></span></span></span> tachycardia - the heart rate increases to improve blood supply and speed up circulation <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>⋅</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\cdot</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">⋅</span></span></span></span></span> palpitations or angina pectoris (p. 133) - caused by the increased effort of the overworked heart muscle.</p>
<p>Iron deficiency anaemia This is the most common form of anaemia in many parts of the world. Dietary iron comes mainly from red meat, fortified cereals and highly coloured vegetables. Daily iron requirement in men is about 1-2 mg. Women need 3 mg daily to counter blood loss during menstruation and to meet the needs of the growing fetus during pregnancy. Children require more than adults to meet their growth requirements. Normally, only about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span> of dietary iron is absorbed, although this increases in iron deficiency, such as following haemorrhage or in pregnancy.</p>
<p>In iron deficiency anaemia, the red blood cell count is often normal, but the cells are small, pale and of variable size and they contain less haemoglobin than normal.</p>
<p>The amount of haemoglobin in each cell is regarded as below normal when the mean cell haemoglobin (MCH) is less than <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>27</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">27 \mathrm{pg} / \mathrm{cell}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">27</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">pg</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">cell</span></span></span></span></span></span> (see Table 4.1). The anaemia is regarded as severe when the haemoglobin level is below <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>9</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>100</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">9 \mathrm{~g} / 100 \mathrm{~mL}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">9</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span><span class="mord">/100</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mL</span></span></span></span></span></span> blood.</p>
<p>Iron deficiency anaemia can result from deficient intake, unusually high iron requirements, or poor absorption from the alimentary tract.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="deficient-intake">Deficient intake<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#deficient-intake" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Because of the relative inefficiency of iron absorption, deficiency occurs frequently, even in individuals whose requirements are normal. It generally develops slowly over a prolonged period of time, and symptoms appear only once the anaemia is well established. The risk of deficiency increases if the daily diet is restricted in some way, as in poorly planned vegetarian diets, or in weight-reducing diets where the range of foods eaten is small. Babies dependent on milk may also suffer mild iron deficiency anaemia if weaning on to a mixed diet is delayed much past the first year, since the liver carries only a few months' store and milk is a poor source of iron. Other at-risk groups include older adults and the alcohol-dependent, whose diet can be poor.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="high-requirements">High requirements<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#high-requirements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In pregnancy, iron requirements are increased to support both fetal growth and the additional load on the mother's cardiovascular system. Iron requirements also rise when there is chronic blood loss, the causes of which include peptic ulcers (p.352), heavy menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Table 4.3. Tastes used to monitor red blood and bloods</p>
<p>haemorrhoids, regular aspirin intake or carcinoma of the gastrointestinal tract (pp. 353 and 357 ).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="malabsorption">Malabsorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#malabsorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Because iron absorption is dependent on an acid environment in the stomach, an increase in gastric pH may reduce it; this may follow excessive use of antacids or removal of part of the stomach, or may occur in pernicious anaemia (see later), when the acid-releasing (parietal) cells of the stomach are destroyed. Loss of surface area for absorption in the intestine, e.g. after surgical removal, can also cause deficiency.</p>
<p>Vitamin Bi2/folic acid deficiency anaemias
Deficiency of vitamin B 12 and/or folic acid impairs erythrocyte maturation (see Fig. 4.5) and abnormally large erythrocytes (megaloblasts) appear in the blood. During normal erythropoiesis (see Fig. 4.3), several cell divisions occur and the daughter cells at each stage are smaller than the parent cell because there is not much time for cell enlargement between divisions. In vitamin B 12 and/or folic acid deficiency, the rate of DNA and RNA synthesis is reduced, delaying cell division. The cells therefore grow larger than normal between divisions. Circulating cells are immature and larger than normal, and some are nucleated (mean cell volume (MCV) <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>94</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">f</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;94 \mathrm{fL}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">94</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">fL</span></span></span></span></span></span> ). The haemoglobin content of each cell is</p>
<p>normal or raised. The cells are fragile and their lifespan is reduced to between 40 and 50 days. Depressed production and early lysis cause anaemia.</p>
<p>Vitamin B12 deficiency anaemia Pernicious anaemia
This is the most common form of vitamin B 12 deficiency anaemia. It is an autoimmune disease in which autoantibodies destroy intrinsic factor (IF) and gastric parietal cells ( p. 326). Females are affected more often than males, and there is frequently an association with other autoimmune disorders, particularly thyroid disease. It is common in the elderly.</p>
<p>Dietary deficiency of vitamin B12
Vitamin B 12 is widely available in animal-derived foodstuffs, including dairy products, meat and eggs, so deficiency is rare except in strict vegans, who eat no animal products at all. The liver has extensive stores of the vitamin, so deficiency can take several years to appear.</p>
<p>Other causes of vitamin B12 deficiency
These include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Gastrectomy (removal of all or part or the stomach) - this leaves fewer cells available to produce IF.</li>
<li>Chronic gastritis, malignant disease and ionising radiation these damage the gastric mucosa, including the parietal cells that produce IF.</li>
<li>Malabsorption - if the terminal ileum is removed or inflamed, e.g. in Crohn's disease, the vitamin cannot be absorbed.</li>
</ul>
<p>Compiications of vitamin B12 deficiency anaemia
These may appear before the signs of anaemia. Because vitamin B 12 is used in myelin production, deficiency leads to irreversible neurological damage, commonly in the spinal cord (p. 200). Mucosal abnormalities, such as glossitis (inflammation of the tongue), are also common, although they are reversible.</p>
<p>Folic acid deficiency anaemia
Folic acid deficiency causes a form of megaloblastic anaemia identical to that seen in vitamin B 12 deficiency, but not associated with neurological damage. It may be due to:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>dietary deficiency, e.g. in infants if there is a delay in establishing a mixed diet, in alcoholism, in anorexia and in pregnancy</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>malabsorption from the jejunum caused by coeliac disease, tropical sprue or anticonvulsant drugs, for example</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>interference with folate metabolism by cytotoxic and anticonvulsant drugs, for example.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Aplastic anaemia
Aplastic (hypoplastic) anaemia results from bone marrow failure. Erythrocyte numbers are reduced. Since the bone marrow also produces leukocytes and platelets, leukopenia (low white cell count) and thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) are also likely. When all three cell types are low, the condition is called pancytopenia, and is accompanied by anaemia, diminished immunity and a tendency to bleed. The condition is occasionally inherited. Usually no cause is identified, but known causes include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Drugs, e.g. cytotoxic therapy; rarely, aplastic anaemia may occur as an adverse reaction to anti-inflammatory and anticonvulsant drugs and some antibiotics.</li>
<li>Ionising radiation.</li>
<li>Some chemicals, e.g. benzene and its derivatives.</li>
<li>Viral disease, including hepatitis.</li>
</ul>
<p>The presenting symptoms are usually infection, anaemia, bleeding and bruising.
Haemolytic anaemias
These occur when erythrocyte breakdown is increased beyond normal. Most haemolysis takes place in the liver or spleen and the normal erythrocyte lifespan of about 120 days can be considerably shortened. If the condition is relatively mild, red cell numbers may remain stable because the red bone marrow production of erythrocytes increases to
compensate, so there may be ongoing haemolysis without anaemia. However, if the bone marrow cannot compensate, red blood cell numbers will fall and anaemia results.</p>
<p>Even in the absence of symptoms of anaemia (pallor, tiredness, dyspnoea, etc.), haemolytic anaemias can cause additional symptoms such as jaundice or splenomegaly.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="congenital-haemolytic-anaemias">Congenital haemolytic anaemias<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#congenital-haemolytic-anaemias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In these diseases, genetic abnormality leads to the synthesis of abnormal haemoglobin and increased red cell membrane fragility, reducing their oxygen-</p>
<p>carrying capacity and lifespan. The most common forms are sickle cell anaemia and thalassaemia.</p>
<p>Sickle cell anaemia
The abnormal haemoglobin molecules become misshapen when deoxygenated, making the erythrocytes sickle-shaped (Fig. 4.17). If the cells contain a high proportion of abnormal haemoglobin, sickling is permanent. Sickled cells are rapidly removed and haemolysed, leading to anaemia. Sickle cells do not move smoothly through the circulation. They obstruct blood flow, leading to intravascular clotting, tissue ischaemia and infarction. Acute episodes (sickle crises), caused by blockage of small vessels, cause acute pain in the affected area, often the hands and feet. Longer-term problems arising from poor perfusion and anaemia include cardiac disease, kidney failure, retinopathy, poor tissue healing and slow growth in children. Obstruction of blood flow to the brain greatly increases the risk of stroke and seizures, and both mother and child are at significant risk of complications in pregnancy. Respiratory complications, including pulmonary hypertension, are common and can be fatal. Children's growth and development can be impaired, and there may be a delay in sexual maturity.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-4cfb7d33.jpeg" alt="img-121.jpeg"></p>
<p>Sickled erythrocyte Normal erythrocyte
Figure 4.17 Scanning electron micrograph showing three normal erythrocytes and one sickled erythrocyte. (Eye of Science/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<p>Black people are more affected than others. Some individuals with sickle cell anaemia have a degree of immunity to malaria because the lifespan of the sickled cells is shorter than the time needed for the malaria parasite to mature inside the erythrocytes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="thalassaemlas">Thalassaemlas<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thalassaemlas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These inherited conditions cause abnormal haemoglobin production, which in turn reduces erythropoiesis and stimulates haemolysis. The resultant anaemia may present in a range of forms, from mild and asymptomatic to profound and lifethreatening. Symptoms in moderate to severe thalassaemia include bone marrow expansion and splenomegaly (enlarged spleen), as production of red blood cells</p>
<p>increases to correct the anaemia. In the most severe form of the disease, regular blood transfusions are required, which can lead to iron overload.</p>
<p>Haemolytic disease of the newborn
In this disorder, the mother's immune system makes antibodies to the baby's red blood cells, destroying fetal erythrocytes. The antigen system involved is usually (but not always) the Rhesus ( Rh ) antigen.</p>
<p>An <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi></mrow><mtext>"&nbsp;</mtext></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Rh}^{\text {" }}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9334em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Rh</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.9334em;"><span style="top: -3.1473em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">"&nbsp;</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> mother carries no Rh antigen on her red blood cells, but she can produce anti-Rh antibodies. If she conceives a child fathered by an <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Rh}^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8362em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Rh</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8362em;"><span style="top: -3.1473em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> man, and the baby inherits the Rh antigen from him, the baby may also be <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Rh}^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8362em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Rh</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8362em;"><span style="top: -3.1473em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> i.e. different from the mother. During pregnancy, the placenta protects the baby from the mother's immune system, but at delivery a few fetal red blood cells may enter the maternal circulation. Because they carry an antigen (the Rh antigen) that is foreign to the mother, her immune system will be stimulated to produce neutralising antibodies to it. The red cells of second and subsequent <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Rh}^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8362em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Rh</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8362em;"><span style="top: -3.1473em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> babies are attacked by these maternal antibodies, which can cross the placenta and enter the fetal circulation (Fig. 4.18). In the most severe cases the baby dies in the womb from profound anaemia. In less serious circumstances the baby suffers some degree of anaemia, which is corrected with blood transfusions.</p>
<p>The disease is much less common than it used to be because it was discovered that if an <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi></mrow><mtext>"&nbsp;</mtext></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Rh}^{\text {" }}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9334em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Rh</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.9334em;"><span style="top: -3.1473em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">"&nbsp;</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> mother is given an injection of anti-Rh antibodies within 72 hours of the delivery of an <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Rh}^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8362em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Rh</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8362em;"><span style="top: -3.1473em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> baby, her immune system does not make its own anti-Rh antibodies to the fetal red cells. Subsequent pregnancies are therefore not affected. The anti-Rh antibodies given to the mother bind to, and neutralise, any fetal red cells present in her circulation before her immune system becomes sensitised to them.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="acquired-haemolytic-anaemias">Acquired haemolytic anaemias<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acquired-haemolytic-anaemias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In this context, 'acquired' means haemolytic anaemia in which no familial or racial factors have been identified. There are several causes.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-1e7c382a.jpeg" alt="img-122.jpeg"></p>
<p>Father: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Rh}+</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7778em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Rh</span></span><span class="mord">+</span></span></span></span></span> (antigen present)</p>
<p>Mother: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi></mrow><mrow><mo mathvariant="normal">′</mo><mo mathvariant="normal">′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Rh}^{\prime \prime}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8362em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Rh</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8362em;"><span style="top: -3.1473em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">′′</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> (no antigen)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-39def415.jpeg" alt="img-123.jpeg"></p>
<p>Baby: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Rh}^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8362em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Rh</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8362em;"><span style="top: -3.1473em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> (inherited from father)
Fetal red cells cross placenta at delivery, stimulating maternal lymphocytes to make anti-Rh antibodies
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-25df0ffb.jpeg" alt="img-124.jpeg"></p>
<p>Red cells of subsequent <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>∧</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Rh}^{2 \wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8984em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Rh</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8984em;"><span style="top: -3.1473em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> babies attacked by anti-Rh antibodies
Figure 4.18 The immunity of haemolytic disease of the newborn.
or chronic, and primary or secondary to other diseases, e.g. carcinoma, viral infection or other autoimmune diseases.</p>
<p>Blood transfusion reactions
Individuals do not normally produce antibodies to their own red blood cell antigens; if they did, the antigens and antibodies would react, causing clumping and lysis of the erythrocytes (see Fig. 4.8). However, if individuals receive a transfusion of blood carrying antigens different from their own, their immune system will recognise them as foreign, make antibodies to them and destroy them (transfusion reaction). This adverse reaction between the blood of incompatible recipients and donors leads to haemolysis within the cardiovascular system. The breakdown products of haemolysis lodge in and block the filtering mechanism of the nephron, impairing kidney function. Other principal signs of a transfusion reaction include fever, chills, lumbar pain and shock.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="polycythaemia">Polycythaemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#polycythaemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is an abnormally high red blood cell count, which increases blood viscosity, slows blood flow and raises the risk of intravascular clotting, ischaemia and infarction. Erythrocyte count may be abnormally high simply because the plasma volume is reduced, as in burns, and this is called relative polycythaemia. True polycythaemia occurs when plasma volume is normal, but erythrocyte numbers are genuinely high.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="primary-polycythaemia">Primary polycythaemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#primary-polycythaemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Most cases of primary polycythaemia are associated with a specific genetic mutation that interferes with erythropoietin control of erythrocyte numbers, leading to a condition called polycythaemia vera. Patients present with itching, tiredness, headache, and sometimes complications from thrombosis. There is often liver and splenic enlargement. It is most common in the over-60s.</p>
<p>Chemical agents
These substances cause early or excessive haemolysis, for
example:</p>
<ul>
<li>some drugs, especially when taken long term in large doses, e.g. sulphonamides</li>
<li>chemicals encountered in the general or work environment, e.g. lead, arsenic compounds</li>
<li>microbial toxins, e.g. Streptococcus pyogenes, Clostridium perfringens.</li>
</ul>
<p>Autoimmunity
In autoimmunity, individuals make antibodies to their
own red cell antigens, causing haemolysis. It may be acute</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="secondary-polycythaemia">Secondary polycythaemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#secondary-polycythaemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This may be an expected compensatory response in hypoxic situations, such as living at altitude, heart failure or heavy smoking. It may also result from inappropriately high erythropoietin levels, seen in some kidney tumours, for example.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="6">
<li>What is pernicious anaemia?</li>
<li>Describe the pathology of sickle cell anaemia.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="leukocyte-disorders">Leukocyte disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#leukocyte-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>define the terms leukopenia and leukocytosis</li>
<li>review the physiological importance of abnormally increased and decreased leukocyte numbers in the blood</li>
<li>discuss the main forms of leukaemia, including the causes, signs and symptoms of the disease.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="leukopenia">Leukopenia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#leukopenia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In this condition, the total blood leukocyte count is less than <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>107</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>4000</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">4 \times 107 \mathrm{~L}(4000 / \mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">107</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">4000/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span> ").
Granulocytopenia (neutropenia)
This is a general term meaning abnormally low numbers of circulating granulocytes (polymorphonuclear leukocytes), commonly called neutropenia because 40-75% of granulocytes are neutrophils. Reduced numbers of circulating granulocytes occur when production does not keep pace with the normal removal of cells or when the lifespan of the cells is shortened. Extreme shortage or the absence of granulocytes is called agranulocytosis. A temporary reduction occurs in response to inflammation but the numbers are usually quickly restored. Inadequate granulopoiesis may be caused by:</p>
<ul>
<li>drugs, e.g. cytotoxic drugs, phenothiazines, some sulphonamides and antibiotics</li>
<li>irradiation of the bone marrow, e.g. radiotherapy</li>
<li>red bone marrow disorders, e.g. leukaemias, some anaemias</li>
<li>severe infections.</li>
</ul>
<p>In conditions where the spleen is enlarged, excessive numbers of granulocytes are trapped, reducing the number in circulation. Neutropenia predisposes to severe infections that can lead to septicaemia and death. Septicaemia is the presence of significant numbers of active pathogens in the blood (see also septic shock, p. 122).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="leukocytosis">Leukocytosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#leukocytosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>An increase in the number of circulating leukocytes occurs as a normal protective reaction in a variety of pathological conditions, especially infections. When the infection subsides, the leukocyte count returns to normal.</p>
<p>Pathological leukocytosis exists when a blood leukocyte count of more than 11 x <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>5</mn></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><mn>11</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>000</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>5</mn></msup><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10^{5} / \mathrm{L}\left(11,000 / \mathrm{mm}^{5}\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.2em; vertical-align: -0.35em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">5</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">(</span></span><span class="mord">11</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">000/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">5</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">)</span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is unnecessarily
sustained and can involve more than one type of leukocyte.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="leukaemia">Leukaemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#leukaemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Leukaemia is a malignant proliferation of white blood cell precursors by the bone marrow. It results in the uncontrolled increase in the production of leukocytes and/ or their precursors. As the tumour cells enter the blood the total leukocyte count is usually raised but in some cases it may be normal or even low. The proliferating immature leukaemic blast cells crowd out other blood cells formed in bone marrow, causing anaemia, thrombocytopenia and leukopenia (pancytopenia). Because the leukocytes are immature when released, immunity is reduced and the risk of infection high.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes-of-leukaemia">Causes of leukaemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-of-leukaemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Some causes of leukaemia are known but many cases cannot be accounted for. Some people may have a genetic predisposition triggered by environmental factors, including viral infection. Other known causes include ionising radiation, chemicals and genetic factors.</p>
<p>Ionising radiation
Radiation from, for example. X-rays and radioactive isotopes causes malignant changes in the precursors of white blood cells. The DNA of the cells may be damaged and some cells die while others reproduce at an abnormally rapid rate. Leukaemia may develop at any time after irradiation, even 20 or more years later.</p>
<p>Chemicals
Some chemicals, e.g. benzene, cytotoxic drugs and asbestos, generate mutations in the DNA of the white blood cell precursors in the bone marrow.</p>
<p>Genetic factors
Identical twins of leukaemia sufferers have a much higher risk than normal of developing the disease, suggesting involvement of genetic factors.</p>
<p>Types of leukaemia
Leukaemias are usually classified according to the type of cell involved, the maturity of the cells and the rate at which the disease develops (see Fig. 4.3).</p>
<p>Acute leukaemias</p>
<p>These types usually have a sudden onset and affect the poorly differentiated and immature 'blast' cells (see Fig. 4.3). They can be aggressive diseases, especially in older people. The rapid progress of bone marrow invasion quickly</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>causes bone marrow failure and culminates in anaemia, haemorrhage and susceptibility to infection. The mucous membranes of the mouth and upper gastrointestinal tract are most commonly affected.</p>
<p>Leukocytosis is usually present in acute leukaemia. The bone marrow is packed with large numbers of immature and abnormal cells.</p>
<p>Acute myeloblastic leukaemia
Acute myeloblastic leukaemia (AML) involves proliferation of myeloblasts (see Fig. 4.3), and is most common in adults between the ages of 25 and 60, the risk gradually increasing with age. The disease can often be cured or long-term remission achieved.</p>
<p>Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia
Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) is seen mainly in children, who have a better prognosis than adults, with up to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>70</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">70 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">70%</span></span></span></span></span> achieving cure. The cell responsible is a primitive B-lymphocyte.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chronic-leukaemias">Chronic leukaemias<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chronic-leukaemias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These conditions are less aggressive than the acute forms and the leukocytes are more differentiated, i.e. at the '-cyte' stage (see Fig. 4.3).</p>
<p>Leukocytosis is a feature of chronic leukaemia; there is crowding of the bone marrow with immature and abnormal leukocytes, although this varies depending on the form of the disease.</p>
<p>Chronic myeloid leukaemia
Chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML) occurs at all ages. Although its onset is gradual, in most patients it eventually reaches a rapidly progressive stage similar to AML and proves fatal; it may sometimes progress to ALL, however, which has a better prognosis. It is caused by an abnormality of chromosomes 22 and 9 (Philadelphia chromosome). Death usually occurs within 5 years.</p>
<p>Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia</p>
<p>Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL) involves proliferation of B-lymphocytes; it is usually less aggressive than CML. It is most often seen in the elderly; disease progression is usually slow, and survival times can be as long as 25 years.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="8">
<li>Why is leukaemia often associated with anaemia?</li>
<li>Which disorder is associated with the Philadelphia chromosome?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="haemorrhagic-diseases">Haemorrhagic diseases<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#haemorrhagic-diseases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>indicate the main causes and effects of thrombocytopenia</li>
<li>outline how vitamin K deficiency relates to clotting disorders</li>
<li>explain the term 'disseminated intravascular coagulation', including its principal causes</li>
<li>describe the physiological deficiencies present in the haemophilias.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="thrombocytopenia">Thrombocytopenia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thrombocytopenia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is defined as a blood platelet count below <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>150</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi></mrow></msup><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><mn>150</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>000</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">150 \times 10^{&lt;/} \mathrm{~L}\left(150,000 / \mathrm{mm}^{2}\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">150</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.238em; vertical-align: -0.35em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.888em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mrel mtight">&lt;</span><span class="mord mtight">/</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">(</span></span><span class="mord">150</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">000/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">)</span></span></span></span></span></span></span> but spontaneous bleeding does not usually occur unless the count falls below 30 x lOVL ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>30</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>000</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">30,000 / \mathrm{mm}^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0019em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">30</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">000/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ). It may be due to a reduced rate of platelet production or increased rate of destruction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reduced-platelet-production">Reduced platelet production<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reduced-platelet-production" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is usually due to bone marrow deficiencies, and therefore production of erythrocytes and leukocytes is also reduced, giving rise to pancytopenia. It is often due to:</p>
<ul>
<li>crowding out of platelets from the bone marrow in bone marrow diseases, e.g. leukaemias, pernicious anaemia, malignant tumours</li>
<li>ionising radiation, e.g. X-rays or radioactive isotopes, which damage the rapidly dividing precursor cells in the bone marrow</li>
<li>drugs that can damage bone marrow, e.g. cytotoxic drugs, chloramphenicol, chlorpromazine, sulphonamides.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="increased-platelet-destruction">Increased platelet destruction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#increased-platelet-destruction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A reduced platelet count occurs when platelet production does not keep pace with destruction of damaged and worn-out ones. This occurs in disseminated intravascular coagulation (see later) and autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura.</p>
<p>Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
This condition, which usually affects children and young adults, may be triggered by a viral infection such as measles. Antiplatelet antibodies are formed that coat platelets, leading to platelet destruction and their removal from the circulation. A significant feature of this disease is the presence of purpura: haemorrhages into the skin ranging</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>in size from pinpoints to large blotches. The severity of the disease varies from mild bleeding into the skin to severe haemorrhage. When the platelet count is very low there may be severe bruising, haematuria and gastrointestinal or intracranial haemorrhages.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vitamin-k-deficiency">Vitamin K deficiency<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vitamin-k-deficiency" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Vitamin K is required by the liver for the synthesis of many clotting factors and therefore deficiency predisposes to abnormal clotting.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="haemorrhagic-disease-of-the-newborn">Haemorrhagic disease of the newborn<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#haemorrhagic-disease-of-the-newborn" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Newborn babies, especially if premature, have limited stores of vitamin K and this can cause bleeding in the first few months of life. Bleeding may be minor, but significant prolonged bleeding, e.g. into the brain, can occur.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="deficiency-in-adults">Deficiency in adults<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#deficiency-in-adults" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Vitamin K is fat soluble and bile salts are required in the colon for its absorption. Deficiency may occur in liver disease, prolonged obstruction of the biliary tract or any other disease where fat absorption is impaired, e.g. coeliac disease (p.360). Dietary deficiency is rare because a sufficient supply of vitamin K is usually synthesised by bacteria in the colon. However, it may occur during treatment with drugs that sterilise the bowel.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="disseminated-intravascular-coagulation">Disseminated intravascular coagulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disseminated-intravascular-coagulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), the coagulation system is inappropriately activated within blood vessels, leading to formation of intravascular clots and fibrin deposition in the tissues. Because of this consumption of clotting factors and platelets, there is a consequent tendency to haemorrhage. DIC is a common complication of a number of other disorders, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>severe infection, such as septicaemia, when endotoxins are released by Gramnegative bacteria</li>
<li>severe trauma</li>
<li>premature separation of the placenta, when amniotic fluid enters the maternal blood</li>
<li>acute pancreatitis, when digestive enzymes are released into the blood</li>
<li>advanced cancer</li>
<li>transfusion of very large volumes of blood.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="congenital-disorders">Congenital disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#congenital-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-haemophilias">The haemophilias<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-haemophilias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The haemophilias are a group of inherited clotting disorders, carried by genes present on the X chromosome (i.e.
inheritance is sex-linked, p. 482). The faulty genes code for abnormal clotting factors (factor VIII and Christmas factor), and if inherited by a male child, always cause haemophilia. Women inheriting one copy are carriers, but, provided their second X chromosome bears a copy of the normal gene, their blood clotting is normal. It is possible, but unusual, for a woman to inherit two copies of the abnormal gene and have haemophilia.</p>
<p>Haemophiliacs experience repeated episodes of severe and prolonged bleeding at any site, even in the absence of trauma. Recurrent bleeding into joints is common, causing severe pain and, in the long term, permanent joint damage. The disease ranges in severity from mild forms, where the defective factor has partial activity, to extreme forms, where bleeding can take days or weeks to control.</p>
<p>The two main forms of haemophilia differ only in the clotting factor involved; the clinical picture in both is identical.</p>
<ul>
<li>Haemophilia A - factor VIII is abnormal and is less biologically active than normal</li>
<li>Haemophilia B (Christmas disease) - this is less common and factor IX is deficient, resulting in deficiency of thromboplastin (clotting factor III).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="von-willebrand-disease">von Willebrand disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#von-willebrand-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In this disease, a deficiency in von Willebrand factor causes low levels of factor VIII; it is the most common inherited bleeding disease. As its inheritance is not sex-linked, haemorrhages due to impaired clotting occur equally in males and females.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="10">
<li>Why does coeliac disease sometimes lead to prolonged clotting times?</li>
</ol>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="list-b">List B<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#list-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-cardiovascular-system">The cardiovascular system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-cardiovascular-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
