<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter-cji">CHAPTER CJI<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-cji" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The first part of this chapter describes the structure and function of the cardiovascular system, comprising the heart, a fist-sized muscular organ lying between the lungs, and an extensive system of blood vessels, carrying blood pumped by the heart to all body tissues. Impressively, the average adult contains nearly <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>100</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>000</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">100,000 \mathrm{~km}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">000</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">km</span></span></span></span></span></span> of blood vessels, more than enough to stretch around the Equator twice, and the heart beats over two and a half billion times in an average 70-year lifespan. Cardiovascular function normally declines with age, as discussed on page 120. Disease of the cardiovascular system is common in most parts of the world, and some common cardiovascular conditions are discussed in the illnesses section.</p>
<p>The lymphatic system is closely connected, both structurally and functionally, with the cardiovascular system and is discussed in Chapter 6.</p>
<p>The heart pumps blood into two anatomically separate systems of blood vessels (Fig. 5.1):</p>
<ul>
<li>the pulmonary circulation</li>
<li>the systemic circulation.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-b65bb012.jpeg" alt="img-125.jpeg"></li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 5.1 The relationship between the pulmonary and the systemic circulations.
The right side of the heart pumps blood to the lungs (the pulmonary circulation), where gas exchange occurs, i.e. the blood collects oxygen from the air sacs and excess carbon dioxide diffuses into the air sacs for exhalation. The left side of the heart pumps blood into the systemic circulation, which supplies the rest of the</p>
<p>body. Here, tissue wastes are passed into the blood for excretion, and body cells extract nutrients and oxygen.</p>
<p>The cardiovascular system ensures a continuous flow of blood to all body cells, and is subject to continual physiological adjustments to maintain an adequate blood supply. Should the supply of oxygen and nutrients to body cells become inadequate, tissue damage occurs and cell death may follow.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="blood-vessels">Blood vessels<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-vessels" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the structures and functions of arteries, veins and capillaries</li>
<li>explain the relationship between the different types of blood vessel</li>
<li>explain the mechanisms by which exchange of nutrients, gases and wastes occurs between the blood and the tissues.</li>
</ul>
<p>Blood vessels vary in structure, size and function. Arteries and their smaller branches, arterioles, carry blood away from the heart. Arterioles branch into enormous networks of thin-walled capillaries, which are tiny exchange vessels, allowing nutrients, water and oxygen to diffuse into the tissues, and cellular wastes such as carbon dioxide to diffuse into the bloodstream and be transported away. Capillaries merge to form small venules, which in turn merge to form large veins, carrying blood back to the heart (Fig. 5.2). IJ5.1</p>
<p>Although the structure of the walls of arteries and veins displays important differences to reflect their different functions, both contain three layers of tissue:</p>
<ul>
<li>Tunica adventitia, an outer layer of fibrous tissue, which protects and supports the vessel.</li>
<li>Tunica media, a middle layer containing variable amounts of smooth muscle and elastic tissue.</li>
<li>Tunica intima, or endothelium, a smooth lining layer only one cell thick. This endothelium is the only layer present in capillary walls, which are therefore much thinner than in arteries and veins.</li>
</ul>
<p>Arteries and arterioles
Arterial walls are thicker than venous walls to withstand the higher pressure of blood in the arterial system. The</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="endothelium">Endothelium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#endothelium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="venule">Venule<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#venule" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="arteries">Arteries<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#arteries" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Carry blood from the heart</p>
<p>Tunica intima (endothelium)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="arteriole">Arteriole<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#arteriole" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

Tunica intima (endothelium)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="capillary">Capillary<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#capillary" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Figure 5.2 The relationship between the heart and the different types of blood vessel.
structure of arterial walls varies, depending on how close the artery lies to the heart. In the largest arteries (sometimes called elastic arteries) the tunica media contains more elastic tissue and little smooth muscle. This allows the vessel wall to stretch, absorbing the pressure wave generated by the heart as it beats. These proportions gradually change as the arteries branch many times and become smaller, until in the arterioles (the smallest arteries) the tunica media consists almost entirely of smooth muscle. This enables their diameter to be precisely controlled, which regulates the pressure within them. Systemic blood pressure is mainly determined by the resistance these tiny arteries offer to blood flow, and for this reason they are called resistance vessels.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="anastomoses-and-end-arteries">Anastomoses and end-arteries<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anastomoses-and-end-arteries" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Anastomoses are arteries that form a link between the main arteries supplying an area, e.g. the arterial supply to the palms of the hand (p. 108) and soles of the feet, the brain, the joints and, to a limited extent, the heart muscle. If one artery supplying the area is blocked, anastomotic arteries provide a collateral circulation. This is most likely to provide an
adequate blood supply when the blockage occurs gradually, giving the anastomotic arteries time to dilate.</p>
<p>An end-artery is an artery that is the sole source of blood to a tissue, e.g. the branches from the circulus arteriosus (circle of Willis) in the brain or the central artery to the retina of the eye. When an end-artery is blocked the tissues it supplies die because there is no alternative blood supply.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="capillaries-and-sinusoids">Capillaries and sinusoids<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#capillaries-and-sinusoids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The smallest arterioles branch into huge numbers of minute capillaries. Capillary walls consist of a single layer of endothelial cells sitting on a very thin basement membrane, permeable to water and other small molecules. Blood cells and large molecules such as plasma proteins are normally too large to diffuse through. The capillaries form a vast network of tiny vessels that link the smallest arterioles to the smallest venules. Capillary diameter varies from 3-4 jam (about half the diameter</p>
<p>of a red blood cell) to about 170 jam in the liver, where rapid and extensive exchange of materials is very important to allow the liver to modify the composition of the blood flowing through it. The capillary
bed is the site of exchange of substances between the blood and the tissue fluid, which bathes the body cells, and, with the exception of cells on the skin surface and in the cornea of the eye, every body cell lies close to a capillary.</p>
<p>In certain places, including the liver and bone marrow, the capillaries are significantly wider and leakier than normal. These capillaries are called sinusoids and because their walls are incomplete and their lumen is much larger than usual, blood flows through them more slowly under less pressure and can come directly into contact with the cells outside the sinusoid wall. This allows much faster exchange of substances between the blood and the tissues, useful, for example, in the liver, which regulates the composition of blood arriving from the gastrointestinal tract.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="capillary-refill-time">Capillary refill time<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#capillary-refill-time" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When an area of skin is pressed firmly with a finger, it turns white (blanches) because the blood in the capillaries under the finger has been squeezed out. Normally it should take less than 2 seconds for the capillaries to refill once the finger is removed and for the skin to turn pink again. Although the test may produce unreliable results, particularly in adults, its use in children can be helpful and a prolonged capillary refill time suggests poor perfusion or dehydration.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="veins-and-venules">Veins and venules<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#veins-and-venules" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Capillaries converge to form tiny venules. Blood pressure drops significantly in the capillary beds, so blood passing into the venous system does so under very low pressure. Venous walls are therefore thinner than arterial walls, although they have the same three layers of tissue.</p>
<p>When cut, the veins collapse, whereas the thicker-walled arteries remain open. When an artery is cut, blood spurts at high pressure while a slower, steady flow of blood escapes from a vein.</p>
<p>Some veins possess valves, which prevent backflow of blood (Fig. 5.3). They are formed by a fold of tunica intima and strengthened by connective tissue. The cusps are semilunar (half-moon) in shape with the concavity towards the heart. Valves are abundant in the veins of the limbs, especially the lower limbs where blood must travel a considerable distance against gravity when the individual is standing. They are absent in very small and very large veins in the thorax and abdomen. Valves and the skeletal muscle pump (p. 95) ensure one-way flow back to the heart.</p>
<p>Veins are called capacitance vessels because they stretch, and therefore have the capacity to hold a large proportion of the body's blood. At any one time, about twothirds of the body's blood is in the venous system. This allows the vascular system</p>
<p>to absorb (to an extent) sudden changes in blood volume, such as in haemorrhage; the veins can constrict, helping to prevent a sudden fall in blood pressure.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-aa445a5f.jpeg" alt="img-127.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 5.3 Interior of a vein. (A) The valves and cusps. (B) The direction of blood flow through a valve.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-5e8fbac5.jpeg" alt="img-128.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 5.4 The exchange of gases in internal respiration.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="blood-supply">Blood supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The outer layers of tissue of thick-walled blood vessels receive their blood supply via a network of blood vessels called the vasa vasorum. Thin-walled vessels and the endothelium of the others receive oxygen and nutrients by diffusion from the blood passing through them.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="capillary-exchange">Capillary exchange<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#capillary-exchange" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="exchange-of-gases">Exchange of gases<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#exchange-of-gases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Internal respiration (Fig. 5.4; see also p. 280) is the process by which gases are exchanged between capillary blood and local body cells. Exchange of gases in the lungs, across the capillary walls there, is called external respiration.</p>
<p>Oxygen is carried from the lungs to the tissues in combination with haemoglobin (p. 65) as oxyhaemoglobin. When the blood arrives in the capillaries, with their permeable walls, it diffuses down its concentration gradient, from the oxygen-rich arterial blood, into the tissues, where oxygen levels are lower because of constant tissue consumption.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-56454bd5.jpeg" alt="img-129.jpeg"></p>
<p>Arterial end of capillary
Venous end of capillary
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-d4539caa.jpeg" alt="img-130.jpeg"></p>
<p>Arterial end of capillary Venous end of capillary
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span></span></span></span></span> Hydrostatic pressure * <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup><mo>∧</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{\wedge} \wedge</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">∧</span></span></span></span></span> Net movement of water <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>−</mo><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">-{ }^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8352em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">−</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> Osmotic pressure
Figure 5.5 Effect of capillary pressures on water movement
between capillaries and cells. Figure 5.6 Diffusion of fluid, nutrients and waste products
between capillaries and cells.
Oxyhaemoglobin is an unstable compound and breaks up (dissociates) easily to liberate oxygen. Factors tbat increase dissociation are discussed on page 66.</p>
<p>Carbon dioxide is one of the waste products of cell metabolism and it diffuses into tbe blood across tbe tbin capillary wall down its concentration gradient. Blood transports carbon dioxide by three different mechanisms to the lungs for excretion:</p>
<ul>
<li>dissolved in the water of the blood plasma - 7%</li>
<li>in chemical combination with sodium in the form of sodium bicarbonate - 70%</li>
<li>in combination with haemoglobin - <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>23</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">23 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">23%</span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
</ul>
<p>Nutrients, including glucose, amino acids, fatty acids, vitamins and mineral salts required by all body cells, are transported round the body in the plasma. They diffuse through the semipermeable capillary walls into the tissues (Fig. 5.5). Water exchanges freely between the plasma and tissue fluid by osmosis. Diffusion and osmosis are described on page 36 .</p>
<p>Capillary fluid dynamics
The two main forces determining overall fluid movement across the capillary wall are the hydrostatic pressure (blood pressure), which tends to push fluid out of the bloodstream, and the osmotic pressure of the blood, which tends to pull it back in, and is due mainly to the presence of plasma proteins, especially albumin (Fig. 5.6).</p>
<p>At the arterial end the hydrostatic pressure is about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>35</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5 \mathrm{kPa}(35 \mathrm{mmHg}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">kPa</span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">35</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mmHg</span></span></span></span></span></span> ), and the opposing osmotic pressure of the blood is only <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>3</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>25</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">3 \mathrm{kPa}(25 \mathrm{mmHg})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">kPa</span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">25</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mmHg</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>. The net force at the arterial end of the capillary is therefore an outward pressure of 2 kPa
( 15 mmHg ) and this drives fluid out of the capillary and into the tissue spaces. This net loss of fluid from the bloodstream must be reclaimed because over 20 litres of fluid are filtered out of the body's capillaries every day.</p>
<p>At the venous end of the capillary the situation is reversed. Blood flow is slower than at the arterial end because the hydrostatic pressure drops along the capillary to only <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>15</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2 \mathrm{kPa}(15 \mathrm{mmHg})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">kPa</span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">15</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mmHg</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>. The osmotic pressure remains unchanged at 3 kPa ( 25 mmHg ) and, because this now exceeds hydrostatic pressure, fluid moves back into the capillary.</p>
<p>This transfer of substances, including water, to the tissue spaces is a dynamic process. As blood flows slowly through the large network of capillaries from the arterial to the venous end, there is constant change. Not all the water and cell waste products return to the blood capillaries. Of the 24 litres or so of fluid that move out of the blood across capillary walls every day, only about 21 litres return to the bloodstream at the venous end of the capillary bed. The remaining 3 litres drain away from the tissue spaces in the minute lymph capillaries, which originate as blind-ended tubes with walls similar to, but more permeable than, those of the blood capillaries (Fig. 5.5). This extra tissue fluid and some cell waste materials enter the lymph capillaries, forming lymph that is eventually returned to the bloodstream (Ch. 6).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="spot-check">- SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span>
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="2em"></mspace></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\qquad</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 2em;"></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="heart">Heart<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#heart" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the structure of the heart and its position within the thorax</li>
<li>trace the circulation of the blood through the heart and the blood vessels of the body</li>
<li>outline the conducting system of the heart</li>
<li>relate the electrical activity of the cardiac conduction system to the cardiac cycle</li>
<li>describe the main factors determining heart rate and cardiac output.</li>
</ul>
<p>The heart is a roughly cone-shaped hollow muscular organ. It is about 10 cm long and weighs about 225 g in women and 310 g in men.</p>
<p>The flattened base of the heart, perhaps confusingly, is the superior surface, with the pointed apex below pointing downwards and left.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="f11a2637">Position <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">□</mi><mn>5.2</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square 5.2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">□</span><span class="mord">5.2</span></span></span></span></span><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#f11a2637" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The heart lies obliquely in the thoracic cavity (Fig. 5.7) in the mediastinum (the space between the lungs), slightly more to the left of the chest. The apex is about 9 cm to the left of the midline at the level of the 5th intercostal space, i.e. a little</p>
<p>Midline</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-af10214e.jpeg" alt="img-131.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 5.7 Position of the heart in the thorax.
below the nipple and slightly nearer the midline. The base extends to the level of the 2nd rib.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="organs-associated-with-the-heart">Organs associated with the heart<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#organs-associated-with-the-heart" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Inferiorly - the apex, which rests on the central tendon of the diaphragm (Fig. 5.8).
Superiorly - the great blood vessels, i.e. the aorta, superior vena cava, pulmonary artery and pulmonary veins, which enter the heart at its base. Posteriorly - the oesophagus, trachea, left and right
bronchus, descending aorta, inferior vena cava and thoracic vertebrae.
Laterally - the lungs; the left lung overlaps the left side of the heart.
Anteriorly - the sternum, ribs and intercostal muscles.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="structure-the-heart-wall">Structure The heart wall<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure-the-heart-wall" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The heart wall is composed of three layers of tissue (Fig. 5.9A): pericardium, myocardium and endocardium.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pericardium">Pericardium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pericardium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The pericardium is the outermost layer and is made up of two sacs. The outer sac (the fibrous pericardium) consists of fibrous tissue and the inner (the serous pericardium) of a continuous double layer of serous membrane.</p>
<p>The fibrous pericardium is continuous with the tunica adventitia of the great blood vessels above and is attached to the diaphragm below. Its inelastic, fibrous nature protects and prevents over-distension of the heart.</p>
<p>The serous pericardium is a membrane formed by a single layer of endothelial cells, folded over itself so that it forms a double membrane around the heart, with</p>
<p>an enclosed space in between the layers (Fig. 5.10). A similar arrangement is seen round the lungs with the pleura (see Fig. 10.15).</p>
<p>The inner layer is firmly attached to the myocardium below and is called the visceral pericardium. The outer layer is the parietal pericardium, and it lines the fibrous pericardium. About 20 mL of lubricating fluid, the pericardial fluid, lie between the two layers, so that the heart can beat without rubbing against the fibrous pericardium.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="myocardium">Myocardium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#myocardium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The myocardium is composed of specialised cardiac muscle found only in the heart (see Fig. 5.9B). It is striated, like skeletal muscle, but is not under voluntary control. Each fibre (cell) has a nucleus and one or more branches. The ends of the cells and their branches are in very close contact with the ends and branches of adjacent cells. Microscopically, these 'joints', or intercalated discs, are thicker, darker lines than the striations. This arrangement gives cardiac muscle the appearance of being a sheet of muscle rather than a very
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-ca596124.jpeg" alt="img-132.jpeg"></p>
<p>Trachea,
Right brachiocephalic trunk <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> Superior vena cava^

large number of individual cells. Because of the end-to-end continuity of the fibres, each one does not need to have a separate nerve supply. When an impulse is initiated, it spreads from cell to cell via the branches and intercalated discs over the whole 'sheet' of muscle, causing contraction. The 'sheet' arrangement of the myocardium enables the whole heart to contract in a coordinated and efficient manner.</p>
<p>Running through the myocardium is also the network of specialised conducting fibres responsible for transmitting the heart's electrical signals. The myocardium is thickest at the apex and thins out towards the base (Fig. 5.11). The wall of the left ventricle is thicker than the right because it has to pump blood around the body, whereas the right ventricle pumps blood, under low pressure, only to the lungs.</p>
<p>Specialised muscle cells in the walls of the atria secrete atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP, p. 247).</p>
<p>Fibrous tissue in the heart
The myocardium is supported by a network of fine fibres that run through all the heart muscle. This is called the fibrous skeleton of the heart. In addition, the atria and the ventricles are separated by a ring of fibrous tissue, which does not conduct electrical impulses. Consequently, when a wave of electrical activity passes over</p>
<p>the atrial muscle, it can spread only to the ventricles through the conducting system that bridges the fibrous ring from atria to ventricles (Fig. 5.16).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="endocardium">Endocardium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#endocardium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This lines the chambers and valves of the heart. It is a thin, smooth membrane to ensure smooth flow of blood through the heart. It consists of flattened epithelial cells, and it is continuous with the endothelium lining the blood vessels.</p>
<p>The heart is divided into a right and left side by the septum (Fig. 5.11), a partition consisting of myocardium covered by endocardium. After birth, blood cannot cross the septum from one side to the other. Each side is divided by an atrioventricular valve into the upper atrium and the ventricle below; Fig. 5.12A). The atrioventricular valves are formed by double folds of endocardium strengthened by a little fibrous tissue. The right atrioventricular valve (tricuspid valve) has three flaps or cusps, and the left atrioventricular valve (mitral valve) has two cusps. Flow of blood in the heart is one-way: blood enters the heart via the atria and passes into the ventricles below.</p>
<p>The valves between the atria and ventricles open and close passively, according to changes in pressure in the chambers (Fig. 5.12B and C). They open when the pressure in the atria is greater than that in the ventricles. During ventricular systole (contraction) the pressure in the ventricles rises above that in the atria and the valves snap shut, preventing backward flow of blood. The valves are prevented from</p>
<p>Interior of the heart <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">□</mi><mrow><mn mathvariant="bold">5.3</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn mathvariant="bold">5.4</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn mathvariant="bold">5.5</mn></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square \mathbf{5 . 3 , 5 . 4 , 5 . 5}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8694em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">□</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbf">5.3</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord mathbf">5.4</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord mathbf">5.5</span></span></span></span></span></span>

opening upwards into the atria by inelastic tendinous cords, called chordae tendineae (Fig. 5.12D), which fasten the inferior surface of the cusps to the papillary muscles. The papillary muscles, tiny extensions of the myocardium, anchor the chordae tendineae firmly to the ventricular wall.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="flow-of-blood-through-the-heart">Flow of blood through the heart<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#flow-of-blood-through-the-heart" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The two largest veins of the body, the superior vena cava and inferior vena cava (Fig. 5.13), empty their contents into the right atrium. This blood passes through the right atrioventricular valve into the right ventricle, and from there is pumped into the pulmonary artery or trunk. The opening of the pulmonary artery is guarded by the pulmonary valve, formed by three semilunar cusps (Fig. 5.14). This valve prevents the backflow of blood into the right ventricle when the ventricular muscle relaxes. The pulmonary trunk divides into left and right pulmonary arteries, which carry the venous blood to the lungs, where exchange of gases takes place: carbon dioxide is excreted and oxygen is absorbed.</p>
<p>Two pulmonary veins from each lung carry oxygenated blood back to the left atrium. Blood then passes through the left atrioventricular valve into the left ventricle, and from there it is pumped into the aorta, the first artery of the general circulation. The opening of the aorta is guarded by the aortic valve, formed by three semilunar cusps (Fig. 5.14), which prevents blood flowing back into the left ventricle at the end of each contraction.</p>
<p>The blood thus passes from the right to the left side of the heart via the lungs, or pulmonary circulation (see Fig. 5.1). Note that both atria contract at the same time and this is followed by the simultaneous contraction of both ventricles.</p>
<p>The muscle layer of the walls of the atria is thinner than that of the ventricles (see Fig. 5.11). This is consistent with the amount of work they do. The atria, significantly helped by gravity, pump the blood only through the atrioventricular valves into the ventricles, whereas the more powerful ventricles pump the blood to the lungs and round the whole body.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="blood-supply-to-the-heart-the-coronary-circulation">Blood supply to the heart (the coronary circulation)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-supply-to-the-heart-the-coronary-circulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="arterial-supply">Arterial supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#arterial-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The heart is supplied with arterial blood by the right and left coronary arteries, which branch from the aorta immediately distal to the aortic valve (Fig. 5.15; see also Fig. 5.14). The coronary arteries receive about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">5%</span></span></span></span></span> of the blood pumped from the heart, although the heart is only about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.5 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">0.5%</span></span></span></span></span> of body weight. This disproportionately large blood supply, of which most goes to the left ventricle, highlights the importance of the heart to body function. The coronary arteries branch throughout the heart, eventually forming a vast network of capillaries.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="venous-drainage">Venous drainage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#venous-drainage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Most of the venous blood is collected into a number of cardiac veins that join to form the coronary sinus, which
opens into the right atrium. The remainder passes directly into the heart chambers through little venous channels.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b00b5c83">Conducting system of the heart <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">□</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">□</span></span></span></span></span> se, 5.7<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b00b5c83" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The heart possesses the property of autorhythmicity, which means it generates its own electrical impulses and beats independently of nervous or hormonal control, i.e. it is not reliant on external mechanisms to initiate each heartbeat. However, it is supplied with both sympathetic and parasympathetic nerve fibres, which increase and decrease, respectively, the intrinsic heart rate. In addition, the heart responds to a number of circulating hormones, including adrenaline (epinephrine) and thyroxine.</p>
<p>Small groups of specialised neuromuscular cells in the myocardium initiate and conduct impulses, causing coordinated and synchronised contraction of the heart muscle (Fig. 5.16).</p>

<p>Sinoatrial node
The sinoatrial node (SA node) is a small mass of specialised cells that lies in the wall of the right atrium near the opening of the superior vena cava (Fig. 5.16).</p>
<p>The sinoatrial cells generate these regular impulses because they are electrically unstable. This instability leads them to discharge (depolarise) regularly, usually between 60 and 90 times a minute. This depolarisation is followed by recovery (repolarisation), but almost immediately their instability leads them to discharge again. Because the SA node discharges faster than any other part of the heart, it normally sets the heart rate and is called the pacemaker of the heart. Firing of the SA node triggers atrial contraction.</p>
<p>The impulse from the SA node arrives at the atrioventricular node about 0.1 second later. This is the only
conducting pathway linking the atria and the ventricles because of the ring of fibrous non-conducting tissue separating the upper and lower parts of the heart.</p>
<p>Atrioventricular node
The atrioventricular node (AV node) is a small mass of neuromuscular tissue that is situated in the wall of the atrial septum near the atrioventricular valves (Fig. 5.16). Normally, the AV node merely transmits the electrical signals from the atria into the ventricles. There is a delay here; the electrical signal takes 0.1 second to pass through into the ventricles. This allows the atria to finish contracting before the ventricles start.</p>
<p>The AV node also has a secondary pacemaker function and takes over this role if there is a problem with the SA

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="atrioventricular-bundle">Atrioventricular bundle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atrioventricular-bundle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The atrioventricular bundle (AV bundle or bundle of His) is a mass of specialised fibres that originates from the AV node. The AV bundle passes through the fibrous ring that separates atria and ventricles then, at the upper end of the ventricular septum, it divides into right and left bundle branches. Within the ventricular myocardium the branches break up into fine fibres, called the Purkinje fibres. The AV bundle, bundle branches and Purkinje fibres transmit electrical impulses from the AV node to the apex of the myocardium, where the wave of ventricular</p>
<p>contraction begins; it then sweeps upwards and outwards, pumping blood into the pulmonary artery and the aorta.</p>
<p>Nerve supply to the heart
As mentioned earlier, the heart is influenced by autonomic (sympathetic and parasympathetic) nerves originating in the cardiovascular centre in the medulla oblongata.</p>
<p>The vagus nerve (parasympathetic) supplies mainly the SA and AV nodes and atrial muscle. Vagal stimulation reduces the rate of SA node firing, decreasing the rate and force of the heartbeat.</p>
<p>Sympathetic nerves supply the SA and AV nodes and the myocardium, and stimulation increases the rate and force of the heartbeat.</p>
<p>Factors affecting heart rate
The most important ones are listed in Box 5.1 and explained in more detail on page 95 .</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cardiac-cycle">Cardiac cycle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cardiac-cycle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>At rest, the healthy adult heart is likely to beat at a rate of 60-90 b.p.m. During each heartbeat, or cardiac cycle (Fig. 5.17), the heart contracts (systole) and then relaxes (diastole).</p>
<p>Box 5.1 The main factors affecting heart rate
Autonomic activity Circulating hormones Activity and exercise Gender Age
Temperature Baroreceptor reflex Emotional states
Stages of the cardiac cycle
To take 74 b.p.m. as an example, each cycle lasts about 0.8 second and consists of:</p>
<ul>
<li>atrial systole - contraction of the atria</li>
<li>ventricular systole - contraction of the ventricles</li>
<li>complete cardiac diastole - relaxation of the atria and
ventricles.
It does not matter at which stage of the cardiac cycle a description starts. For convenience the period when the atria are filling has been chosen.</li>
</ul>
<p>The atria are continually filling with blood from the superior and inferior venae cavae (into the right atrium) and the pulmonary veins (into the left atrium). As pressure rises in the atria the atrioventricular valves are pushed open and blood flows passively into the ventricles, helped by gravity if the thorax is upright. Up to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>70</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">70 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">70%</span></span></span></span></span> of ventricular filling can be accomplished without any atrial contraction at all.</p>
<p>The SA node triggers a wave of contraction that spreads over the myocardium of both atria, emptying the atria and completing ventricular filling (atrial systole 0.1 second; Fig. 5.17A). When the electrical impulse reaches the AV node it is slowed down, delaying atrioventricular transmission. This delay means that the mechanical result of atrial stimulation, atrial contraction, lags behind the electrical activity by a fraction of a second. This allows the atria to finish emptying into the ventricles before the ventricles begin to contract. After this brief delay, the AV node triggers its own electrical impulse, which quickly spreads to the ventricular muscle via the AV bundle, the bundle branches and Purkinje fibres. This results in a wave of contraction that sweeps upwards from the apex of the heart and across the walls of both ventricles, pumping the blood into the pulmonary artery and the aorta (ventricular systole 0.3 second; Fig. 5.17B). The high pressure generated during ventricular contraction forces the atrioventricular valves to close, preventing backflow of blood into the atria.</p>
<p>Contraction of the ventricles is followed by complete cardiac diastole, a period of 0.4 second, when atria and ventricles are relaxed. During this time the myocardium recovers, ready for the next heartbeat, and the atria refill, ready for the next cycle (Fig. 5.17C).</p>
<p>The valves of the heart and those of the great vessels open and close, according to the pressure within the chambers of the heart. The atrioventricular valves open during atrial filling and systole because pressure in the atria is higher than in the ventricles. When the ventricles contract, there is a rapid increase in the ventricular pressure, and when it rises above atrial pressure the atrioventricular valves close. When the ventricular pressure rises above that in the pulmonary artery and in the aorta, the pulmonary and aortic valves open and blood flows into these vessels. When the ventricles relax and the pressure within them falls, the reverse process occurs. First the pulmonary and aortic valves close, then the atrioventricular valves open and the cycle begins again.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="box-5-1-the-main-factors-affecting-heart-rate">Box 5.1 The main factors affecting heart rate<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#box-5-1-the-main-factors-affecting-heart-rate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="heart-sounds">Heart sounds<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#heart-sounds" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>If the ear or the diaphragm of a stethoscope is placed on the chest wall a little below the left nipple and slightly nearer the midline, the heartbeat can be heard over the apex of the heart.</p>
<p>There are four heart sounds, each corresponding to a particular event in the cardiac cycle. The first two are most
easily distinguished, and through the stethoscope sound like Tub dup'. The first sound. Tub', is fairly loud and is due to the closure of the atrioventricular valves. This corresponds with the start of ventricular systole. The second sound, 'dup', is softer and is due to the closure of the aortic and pulmonary valves. This corresponds with ventricular diastole.</p>
<p>Electrical activity in the heart <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">□</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">□</span></span></span></span></span> s.s
The body tissues and fluids conduct electricity well, so the electrical activity in the heart can be recorded on the skin
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-188df072.jpeg" alt="img-149.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 5.18 Electrocardiogram of one cardiac cycle. (A), (B) and (C) correspond to the phases of the cardiac cycle shown in Fig. 5.17.
surface using electrodes positioned on the limbs and/ or the chest. This recording, called an electrocardiogram (ECG), shows the spread of the electrical signal generated by the SA node as it travels through the atria, the AV node and the ventricles. The normal ECG tracing shows five waves, which, by convention, have been named P, Q, R, S and T (Fig. 5.18).</p>
<p>The P wave represents the impulse from the SA node sweeping over the atria (atrial depolarisation).</p>
<p>The QRS complex represents the very rapid spread of the impulse from the AV node through the AV bundle and the Purkinje fibres, and the electrical activity of the ventricular muscle (ventricular depolarisation). Note the delay between the completion of the P wave and the onset of the QRS complex. This represents the conduction of the impulse through the AV node, which is much slower than conduction elsewhere in the heart, and allows atrial contraction to finish completely before ventricular contraction starts.</p>
<p>The T wave represents the relaxation of the ventricular muscle (ventricular repolarisation). Atrial repolarisation occurs during ventricular contraction, and so is not seen because of the larger QRS complex.</p>
<p>The ECG described above and shown in Fig. 5.18 represents normal heart rhythm originating from the SA node, and so is called sinus rhythm. Normally, the heart rate falls somewhere between 60 and 90 b.p.m. A heart rate over 100 b.p.m. is called tachycardia, and below 60 b.p.m. is bradycardia.</p>
<p>The ECG is a fundamental clinical tool that, when read accurately, can precisely identify conduction abnormalities, the location of areas of ischaemic myocardium and nodal malfunction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cardiac-output">Cardiac output<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cardiac-output" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The cardiac output is the amount of blood ejected from each ventricle every minute. The amount expelled by each contraction of each ventricle is the stroke volume. Cardiac output is expressed in litres per minute ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{L} / \mathrm{min}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">min</span></span></span></span></span></span> ) and is calculated by multiplying the stroke volume by the heart rate (measured in beats per minute):</p>
<p>Cardiac output <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span></span></span></span></span> Stroke volume <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">x</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span></span></span></span></span> Heart rate
In a healthy adult at rest the stroke volume is approximately 70 mL and if the heart rate is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>72</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">72 / \mathrm{min}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">72/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">min</span></span></span></span></span></span>, the cardiac output is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5 \mathrm{~L} / \mathrm{min}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">min</span></span></span></span></span></span>. This can increase to around <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>25</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">25 \mathrm{~L} / \mathrm{min}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">25</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">min</span></span></span></span></span></span> in exercise, and up to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>35</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">35 \mathrm{~L} / \mathrm{min}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">35</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">min</span></span></span></span></span></span> in athletes. This increase during exercise is called the cardiac reserve.</p>
<p>Factors affecting cardiac output are listed in Box 5.2.
stroke volume
The stroke volume is determined by the volume of blood in the ventricles immediately before they contract, i.e. the ventricular end-diastolic volume (VEDV), sometimes called preload. In turn, preload depends on the amount of blood returning to the heart through the superior and inferior venae cavae (the venous return). Increased preload leads to stronger myocardial contraction and more blood is expelled, increasing stroke volume and cardiac output. In this way, the heart, within physiological limits, always pumps out all the blood that it receives, allowing it to adjust cardiac output to match body needs. This capacity to increase the stroke volume with increasing preload is finite, and when the limit is reached, i.e. venous return to the heart exceeds cardiac output (i.e. more blood is arriving in the atria than the ventricles can pump out), cardiac output decreases and the heart begins to fail. Other factors that increase the force and rate of myocardial contraction include increased sympathetic nerve activity and circulating hormones, e.g. adrenaline (epinephrine), noradrenaline (norepinephrine) and thyroxine.</p>
<p>Box 5.2 Summary of factors affecting cardiac output</p>
