<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="arterial-blood-pressure">Arterial blood pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#arterial-blood-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This affects the stroke volume, as it creates resistance to blood being pumped from the ventricles into the great arteries. This resistance (sometimes called afterload) is determined by the distensibility, or elasticity, of the large arteries and the peripheral resistance of arterioles (p. 96). Increasing afterload increases the workload of the ventricles because it increases the pressure against which they have to pump. This may actually reduce stroke volume if systemic blood pressure becomes significantly higher than normal.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-volume">Blood volume<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-volume" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is normally kept constant by the kidneys. Should blood volume fall, e.g. through sudden haemorrhage, this can cause stroke volume, cardiac output and venous return to fall. However, the body's compensatory mechanisms will tend to return these values towards normal, unless the blood loss is too sudden or severe for compensation (see Shock,
p.122).</p>
<p>Venous return
Venous return is the major determinant of cardiac output and the heart normally pumps out all blood returned to it. Systemic venous pressure is much lower than arterial pressure, as the pressure wave from the heart is lost as blood flows through capillaries at low pressure. The blood returns to the heart, assisted by venous valves, despite opposition from gravity but helped by the contraction of skeletal muscles and the respiratory pump.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effect-of-gravity">Effect of gravity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effect-of-gravity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Gravity resists venous return from all structures below the level of the heart when the body is upright, and can lead to pooling of blood in the lower limbs. Lying down and/or elevating the feet improve blood flow back to the heart.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="muscular-contraction">Muscular contraction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscular-contraction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The contraction of skeletal muscles surrounding the deep veins compresses them, pushing blood towards the heart. In the lower limbs, this is called the skeletal muscle pump (Fig. 5.19). Wearing compressive stockings and doing exercises on long flights or during periods of immobility promotes the action of the skeletal muscle pump, helping venous return and reducing the risk that blood pooling in the legs might clot.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="respiratory-pump">Respiratory pump<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#respiratory-pump" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>During inspiration, chest expansion creates a negative pressure within the thorax, assisting flow of blood towards the heart from the head and arms.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="heart-rate">Heart rate<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#heart-rate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The heart rate is a major determinant of cardiac output. If heart rate rises, cardiac output increases, and if it falls.</p>
<p>Figure 5.19 The skeletal muscle pump.
cardiac output falls too. The main factors determining heart rate are outlined here.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="autonomic-nervous-system">Autonomic nervous system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#autonomic-nervous-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The intrinsic rate at which the heart beats is a balance between sympathetic and parasympathetic activity and this is the most important factor in determining heart rate. Sympathetic nervous system activity increases heart rate, whereas parasympathetic activity decreases it.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="circulating-chemicals">Circulating chemicals<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#circulating-chemicals" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The hormones adrenaline (epinephrine) and noradrenaline (norepinephrine), secreted by the adrenal medulla, have the same effect as sympathetic stimulation, i.e. they increase the heart rate. Other hormones, including thyroxine, increase heart rate. Hypoxia and elevated carbon dioxide levels, e.g. in exercise, stimulate heart rate. Electrolyte imbalances may also affect it; for example, hyperkalaemia depresses cardiac function and leads to bradycardia. Some drugs, such as the preceptor antagonists (e.g. atenolol) used in hypertension, can also cause bradycardia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="position">Position<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#position" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When a person is upright, the heart rate is usually faster than when lying down.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gender">Gender<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gender" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The heart rate is faster in women than men.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="age">Age<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#age" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In babies and small children the heart rate is more rapid than in older children and adults.

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="temperature">Temperature<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#temperature" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The heart rate rises and falls with body temperature.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="baroreceptor-reflex">Baroreceptor reflex<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#baroreceptor-reflex" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>See page 98 .
) <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>⋅</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\cdot</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">⋅</span></span></span></span></span> SPOT CHECK
3. Describe the location of the heart and its relationship to surrounding structures.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>What is the function of the sinoatrial node and what is the consequence if it fails?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="blood-pressure">Blood pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Learning outcomes</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">After studying this section, you should be able to:</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">- define the term blood pressure</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">describe the main factors controlling blood vessel</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">diameter</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">- list the factors that influence blood pressure</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">explain the two main mechanisms that control</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">blood pressure.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Blood pressure (BP) is the force or pressure that the blood exerts on the walls of blood vessels. Systemic arterial blood pressure maintains the essential flow of blood into and out of the organs of the body. Keeping blood pressure within normal limits is very important. High blood pressure can damage blood vessels, causing bleeding from sites of blood vessel rupture. Blood flow through tissue beds may be inadequate if blood pressure is too low. This is particularly dangerous for essential organs such as the heart, brain or kidneys.</p>
<p>Blood pressure falls at rest and during sleep. It increases with age and is usually higher in women than in men.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="systolic-and-diastolic-pressures">Systolic and diastolic pressures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#systolic-and-diastolic-pressures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When the left ventricle contracts and pushes blood into the aorta, arterial blood pressure rises sharply and produces the systolic blood pressure. In adults it is about 120 mmHg . In complete cardiac diastole, when the heart is resting between beats, the pressure within the arteries is much lower and is called diastolic blood pressure. In an adult this is about 80 mmHg . Whereas systolic pressure reflects the peak pressure generated by left ventricular contraction, diastolic blood pressure reflects the degree of constriction within the vascular system and tends to fluctuate less than the systolic pressure. The difference between systolic and diastolic blood pressures is the pulse pressure. Factors that increase systolic pressure, e.g. increased cardiac output, or that reduce the compliance of blood vessels, increase
pulse pressure. Increased pulse pressure is seen in older people with atherosclerosis (p. 125) because their blood vessels are stiff and less compliant, so that each time the heart beats, the pressure in the vascular system rises very sharply.</p>
<p>Arterial blood pressure is measured with a sphygmomanometer and is usually expressed with the systolic pressure written above the diastolic pressure:</p>
<p>120
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>m</mi><mi>H</mi><mi>g</mi><msup><mn>80</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{BP}=-m m H g 80^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">BP</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9463em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">−</span><span class="mord mathnormal">mm</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">g</span><span class="mord">8</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>
Relationship between pressure, flow and blood vessel diameter</p>
<p>Blood pressure, blood flow and blood vessel diameter are all very closely interrelated.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="tunica-media-and-vessel-diameter">Tunica media and vessel diameter<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tunica-media-and-vessel-diameter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The tunica media of large arteries contains much elastic tissue, to allow them to expand easily with each heartbeat and to minimise the workload of the heart. When the left ventricle ejects blood into the elastic aorta, the vessel expands to accommodate it and then recoils elastically. This pushes the blood forwards into the arterial system, and a wave of distension and recoil occurs throughout the large arteries, keeping pressure high and the blood moving forwards. In contrast, the tunica media of the smallest arteries and their branches, the arterioles, are rich in smooth muscle and contain much less elastic tissue. Autonomic nerve fibres supply this smooth muscle and control the vessel diameter, regulating flow and pressure. These are the most important vessels that determine systemic blood pressure, and are referred to as resistance vessels because they determine the resistance against which the heart has to pump.</p>
<p>Veins contain only a little muscle in their walls, which contracts in response to a fall in blood pressure. Because the venous system contains the majority of the body's blood, even a small degree of venoconstriction can make a significant difference to blood pressure, e.g. following haemorrhage.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-vessel-diameter-and-blood-flow">Blood vessel diameter and blood flow<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-vessel-diameter-and-blood-flow" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Resistance to flow of fluids along a tube is determined by three factors: the diameter of the tube, the length of the tube and the viscosity of the fluid. The most important factor determining how easily blood flows through blood vessels is the first of these variables, i.e. the diameter of the resistance vessels (the peripheral resistance). Peripheral resistance is a major factor in blood pressure regulation, which is discussed further on page 96 .</p>
<p>Blood vessel diameter is regulated by the smooth muscle of the tunica media, which is supplied by sympathetic nerves of the autonomic nervous system (p. 186). There is no parasympathetic nerve supply to most blood vessels</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i-thinner">I Thinner<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-thinner" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

Figure 5.20 The relationship between sympathetic stimulation and blood vessel diameter.
and therefore vascular smooth muscle tone (degree of contraction) is determined by the degree of sympathetic activity. Sympathetic activity generally constricts blood vessel smooth muscle and narrows the vessel (vasoconstriction), increasing the pressure inside. A degree of resting sympathetic activity maintains a constant baseline tone in the vessel wall and prevents pressure falling too low (Fig. 5.20) Decreased sympathetic nerve stimulation relaxes the smooth muscle, thinning the vessel wall and enlarging the lumen (vasodilation). This results in increased blood flow under less pressure.</p>
<p>Constant adjustment of blood vessel diameter helps to regulate peripheral resistance and systemic blood pressure.</p>
<p>Although most arterioles respond to sympathetic stimulation with vasoconstriction, the response is much less marked in some arteriolar beds, e.g. in skeletal muscle and the brain. This is important so that in a stress response, such as the flight or fight response (p. 243), when sympathetic activity is very high, these essential tissues receive the extra oxygen and nutrients they need.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="autoregulation">Autoregulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#autoregulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The oxygen and nutrient requirements of tissues vary, depending on activity, so it is important that blood flow is
regulated locally to ensure that blood flow matches tissue needs. The ability of an organ to control its own blood flow through local vasodilation or vasoconstriction according to need is called autoregulation. Some organs, including the central nervous system, liver and kidneys, receive proportionately higher blood flow as a matter of course. Other tissues, such as resting skeletal muscle, receive much less, but their blood supply can increase as much as 20 -fold during heavy exercise. Other examples include increase of blood flow through the gastrointestinal tract after a meal to allow for greater activity there, and adjustments to blood flow through the skin in the control of body temperature (p. 397). Autoregulation in the kidney protects the delicate glomerular capillaries from damage if systemic blood pressure is high, and also ensures the brain receives adequate blood supply when blood pressure falls. The main mechanisms associated with this local control of blood flow include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Release of metabolic waste products, e.g. CO 2 and lactic acid - active tissues release more wastes than resting tissues, and increased levels of waste increase blood flow into the area.</li>
<li>Tissue temperature - a rise in metabolic activity increases tissue temperature, which in turn causes vasodilation and increased blood flow.</li>
<li>Hypoxia, or lack of oxygen - stimulates vasodilation and a rise in blood flow through the affected tissue.</li>
<li>Release of vasodilator chemicals - inflamed and metabolically active tissues produce a number of vasodilators, which increase blood supply to the area. One important vasodilator is nitric oxide, which is very short-lived but important in dilating the larger arteries supplying an organ. Other agents include substances released in the inflammatory response, such as histamine and bradykinin (p. 410).</li>
<li>Action of vasoconstrictors - the sympathetic hormone adrenaline (epinephrine), released from the adrenal medulla, is a powerful vasoconstrictor. Others include angiotensin 2 (p.377).</li>
</ul>
<p>Factors determining blood pressure
Blood pressure is determined by cardiac output and peripheral resistance. Change in either of these parameters tends to alter systemic blood pressure, although the body's compensatory mechanisms usually adjust for any significant change.</p>
<p>Blood pressure <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span></span></span></span></span> Cardiac output x Peripheral resistance</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cardiac-output">Cardiac output<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cardiac-output" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Cardiac output is determined by the stroke volume and the heart rate (p. 95). Factors that affect the heart rate and stroke volume were described earlier; they may increase or decrease cardiac output and, in turn, blood pressure. An
increase in cardiac output raises both systolic and diastolic pressures. An increase in stroke volume increases systolic pressure more than diastolic pressure.
the heart rate and by dilating or constricting blood vessels. Activity in these fibres is essential for control of blood pressure (Fig. 5.21).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="peripheral-resistance">Peripheral resistance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#peripheral-resistance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The heart pumps blood into a closed circulatory system against the pressure of blood already there. This resistance is called the peripheral resistance, and it is determined mainly by the diameter of the systemic blood vessels. If there is a high degree of systemic vasoconstriction, the resistance to blood flow and the blood pressure increase. Vasodilation, on the other hand, reduces peripheral resistance and blood pressure. The small muscular arterioles are most important in controlling peripheral resistance. Age-related stiffening of the arterial walls increases peripheral resistance and blood pressure (p. 126).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="control-of-blood-pressure">Control of blood pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-blood-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Blood pressure is controlled in two ways:</p>
<ul>
<li>short-term control, on a moment-to-moment basis, which involves mainly the baroreceptor reflex, discussed below, and also chemoreceptors and circulating hormones</li>
<li>long-term control, which involves regulation of blood volume by the kidneys and the renin-angiotensinaldosterone system (RAAS, p. 377).</li>
</ul>
<p>Short-term blood pressure regulation
The cardiovascular centre (CVC) is a collection of interconnected neurones in the medulla and pons of the brain stem. The CVC receives, integrates and coordinates inputs from:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>baroreceptors (pressure receptors)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>chemoreceptors</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>higher centres in the brain.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>The CVC sends autonomic nerves (both sympathetic and parasympathetic) to the heart and blood vessels (Table 5.1). It controls blood pressure by slowing down or speeding up</p>
<p>Table 5.1 The effects of the autonomic nervous system on the heart and blood vessels</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Sympathetic</th><th style="text-align: left;">Parasympathetic</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">stimulation</td><td style="text-align: left;">stimulation</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Heart</td><td style="text-align: left;">TRate iRate</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">Tstrength of contraction <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>∧</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\wedge</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5556em;"></span><span class="mord">∧</span></span></span></span></span> Strength of &lt;br&gt; contraction</td></tr></tbody></table>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="baroreceptors">Baroreceptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#baroreceptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Within the wall of the aortic and carotid sinuses there are baroreceptors, nerve endings sensitive to stretch (pressure) (Fig. 5.22), which are the body's principal moment-tomoment regulatory mechanism for controlling blood pressure. A rise in blood pressure in these arteries stimulates the baroreceptors, increasing their input to the CVC. The CVC responds by increasing parasympathetic nerve activity to the heart; this slows the heart down. At the same time, sympathetic stimulation to the blood vessels is inhibited, causing vasodilation. The net result is a fall in systemic blood pressure to reverse the initial rise.</p>
<p>Conversely, if pressure within the aortic arch and carotid sinuses falls, the rate of baroreceptor discharge also falls. The CVC responds by increasing sympathetic drive to the heart to speed it up. Sympathetic activity in blood vessels is also increased, leading to vasoconstriction. Both these measures counteract the falling blood pressure. Baroreceptor control of blood pressure is also called the baroreceptor reflex (Fig. 5.22).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-2d29bb1e.jpeg" alt="img-153.jpeg"></p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="when-blood-pressure-rises">WHEN BLOOD PRESSURE RISES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#when-blood-pressure-rises" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="when-blood-pressure-falls">WHEN BLOOD PRESSURE FALLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#when-blood-pressure-falls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chemoreceptors">Chemoreceptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chemoreceptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are nerve endings situated in the carotid and aortic bodies; they are primarily involved in control of respiration (see Fig. 10.26). They are sensitive to changes in the levels of carbon dioxide, oxygen and the acidity of the blood <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{pH})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">pH</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>
(Fig. 5.23). Rising blood CO 2 , falling blood O 2 levels and/or falling arterial blood pH all indicate failing tissue perfusion. When these changes are detected by the chemoreceptors, they send signals to the CVC, which then increases sympathetic drive to the heart and blood vessels, pushing

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cardiovascular">Cardiovascular<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cardiovascular" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>centre
(CVC)
Figure 5.23 The role of chemoreceptors in the control of arterial blood pressure.
blood pressure up to improve tissue blood supply. Because respiratory effort is also stimulated, blood oxygen levels rise as well.</p>
<p>Chemoreceptor input to the CVC influences its output only when severe disruption of respiratory function occurs or when arterial blood pressure falls to less than 80 mmHg . Similar chemoreceptors are found on the brain surface in the medulla oblongata, and they respond to changes in carbon dioxide/oxygen levels and pH of the surrounding cerebrospinal fluid. Changes from normal activate responses similar to those described earlier for the aortic/carotid receptors.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="higher-centres-in-the-brain">Higher centres in the brain<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#higher-centres-in-the-brain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Input to the CVC from the higher centres is influenced by emotional states such as fear, anxiety, pain and anger that may stimulate changes in blood pressure.</p>
<p>The hypothalamus in the brain controls body temperature and influences the CVC, which responds by adjusting the diameter of blood vessels in the skin. This important mechanism regulates conservation and loss of heat so that core body temperature remains in the normal range (p.397).</p>
<p>Long-term blood pressure regulation
Slower, longer-lasting changes in blood pressure are effected by the RAAS (p. 377) and the action of antidiuretic hormone (ADH, p. 374). Both of these systems regulate blood volume, thus influencing blood pressure. In addition, ANP (p. 247), a hormone released by the heart itself, causes sodium and water loss from the kidney and reduces blood pressure, opposing the activities of both ADH and the RAAS.</p>
<p>Pressure in the pulmonary circulation
Pulmonary blood pressure is much lower than pressure in the systemic circulation. This is because the pulmonary circulation contains only about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span> of the total circulating blood volume, and there are so many capillaries in the lungs that pressure is kept low. If pulmonary capillary pressure exceeds 25 mmHg , fluid is forced out of the bloodstream and into the air sacs (pulmonary oedema, p. 138), with very serious consequences. Autoregulation in the pulmonary circulation makes sure that blood flow through the vast network of capillaries is directed through well-oxygenated air sacs (p. 281).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pulse">Pulse<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pulse" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>define the term 'pulse'</li>
<li>list the main sites on the body surface where the pulse is detected</li>
<li>describe the main factors affecting the pulse.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-cddd29dd.jpeg" alt="img-157.jpeg"></li>
</ul>
<p>The pulse can be felt with gentle finger pressure in a superficial artery when its wall is distended by blood pumped from the left ventricle during contraction (systole). The wave passes quickly as the arterial wall recoils. Each contraction of the left ventricle forces about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>60</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>80</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">60-80 \mathrm{~mL}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">60</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">80</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mL</span></span></span></span></span></span> of blood through the already full aorta and into the arterial system. The aortic pressure wave is transmitted through the arterial system and can be felt at any point where a superficial artery can be pressed firmly but gently against a bone (Fig. 5.24). The number of pulse beats per minute normally represents the heart rate and varies considerably in different people and in the same person at different times. An average of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>60</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>80</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">60-80</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">60</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">80</span></span></span></span></span> b.p.m. is common at rest. The term bradycardia refers to a pulse rate below 60 b.p.m. and tachycardia is a pulse rate above 100 b.p.m. Information that may be obtained from the pulse includes:</p>
<ul>
<li>The heart rate.</li>
<li>The regularity of the heartbeat - the intervals between beats should be equal.</li>
<li>The volume or strength of the beat - it should be possible to compress the artery with moderate pressure, stopping the flow of blood; the compressibility of the blood vessel gives some indication of the blood pressure and the state of the blood vessel wall.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-28fd9692.jpeg" alt="img-158.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>The tension - the artery wall should feel soft and pliant under the fingers.</li>
</ul>
<p>Factors affecting the pulse
In health, the pulse rate and the heart rate are identical.
Factors influencing heart rate are summarised on page 95 .
In certain circumstances, the counted pulse may be less than
the heart rate. This may occur, for example, in the following
circumstances:</p>
<ul>
<li>The arteries supplying the peripheral tissues are narrowed or blocked and the blood therefore is not pumped through them with each heartbeat. This can happen, for example, in peripheral vascular disease of the leg, reducing blood flow to the foot. Provided enough blood is reaching an extremity to nourish it, it will remain pink in colour and warm to touch, even if the pulse cannot be felt.</li>
<li>There is some disorder of cardiac contraction, e.g. atrial fibrillation (p. 134), and the heart is unable to generate enough force with each contraction to circulate blood to the peripheral arteries.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="7">
<li>What is the definition of bradycardia?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="circulation-of-the-blood">Circulation of the blood<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#circulation-of-the-blood" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes</p>
<p>Although circulation of blood round the body is continuous (see Fig. 5.1), it is convenient to describe it in two parts:</p>
<ul>
<li>pulmonary circulation</li>
<li>systemic or general circulation (Figs 5.25 and 5.26).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="6c7bddd3">Pulmonary circulation <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">□</mi><mi mathvariant="bold">s</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi><mi mathvariant="bold">g</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square \mathbf{s} . \mathbf{g}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8694em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">□</span><span class="mord mathbf">s</span><span class="mord">.</span><span class="mord mathbf" style="margin-right: 0.01597em;">g</span></span></span></span></span><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6c7bddd3" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is the circulation of blood from the right ventricle to the lungs and back to the left atrium. In the lungs, carbon dioxide is excreted and oxygen is absorbed.</p>
<p>After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the circulation of the blood through the lungs, naming the main vessels involved</li>
<li>list the arteries supplying blood to all major body structures</li>
<li>outline the venous drainage involved in returning blood to the heart from the body</li>
<li>explain the arrangement of blood vessels relating to the portal circulation.</li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 5.24 The main pulse points.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-b218ec96.jpeg" alt="img-159.jpeg"></p>
<p>Right common carotid artery Right vertebral artery Right subclavian artery

<li>

Right common iliac artery <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7519em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> Right external iliac artery -Right femoral artery

Figure 5.27 The aorta and its main branches.
The pulmonary artery or trunk, carrying deoxygenated blood, leaves the upper part of the right ventricle. It passes upwards and divides into left and right pulmonary arteries at the level of the 5th thoracic vertebra. The pulmonary arteries enter their respective lungs at the hilum, and divide into smaller branches that in turn eventually give rise to the dense network of capillaries surrounding the alveoli, the tiny air sacs of the lungs.</p>
<p>Exchange of gases takes place between capillary blood and air in the alveoli (p. 280). In each lung the capillaries containing oxygenated blood merge into progressively larger venules, and eventually form two pulmonary veins. These two pulmonary veins leave each lung, returning oxygenated blood to the left atrium of the heart. During atrial systole, this blood is pumped into the left ventricle, and during ventricular systole, it is forced into the aorta, the first artery of the general circulation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="systemic-or-general-circulation">Systemic or general circulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#systemic-or-general-circulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The blood pumped out from the left ventricle is carried by the branches of the aorta around the body and returns to the right atrium of the heart by the superior and inferior venae cavae. Fig. 5.25 shows the general positions of the aorta and
the main arteries of the limbs. Fig. 5.26 provides an overview of the venae cavae and the veins of the limbs.</p>
<p>The circulation of blood to the different parts of the body will be described in the order in which their arteries branch off the aorta.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="major-blood-vessels">Major blood vessels<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#major-blood-vessels" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The aorta is the largest artery of the body. The two largest veins, the superior and inferior venae cavae, return blood from all body parts to the heart.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="aorta">Aorta<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#aorta" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The aorta (Fig. 5.27) begins at the upper part of the left ventricle and, after passing upwards for a short way, it arches backwards and to the left. It then descends behind the heart through the thoracic cavity a little to the left of the thoracic vertebrae. At the level of the 12th thoracic vertebra it passes behind the diaphragm, then downwards in the abdominal cavity to the level of the 4th lumbar vertebra, where it divides into the right and left common iliac arteries.</p>
<p>Throughout its length the aorta gives off numerous branches. Some of the branches are paired, i.e. there is a right and left branch with the same name (e.g. the right and left
renal arteries supplying the kidneys), and some are single or unpaired (e.g. the coeliac artery).</p>
<p>The aorta will be described here according to its location:</p>
<ul>
<li>thoracic aorta</li>
<li>abdominal aorta.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="thoracic-aorta">Thoracic aorta<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thoracic-aorta" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The thoracic part of the aorta (Fig. 5.27) lies above the diaphragm and is described in three parts:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>ascending aorta</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>arch of the aorta</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>descending aorta in the thorax.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Ascending aorta. This is the short section of the aorta that rises from the heart. It is about 5 cm long and lies well protected behind the sternum.</p>
<p>The right and left coronary arteries are its only branches. They open just above the level of the aortic valve (see Fig. 5.14) and supply the myocardium.</p>
<p>Arch of the aorta. The aorta curves sharply downwards behind the left side of the heart, in front of the trachea, forming the aortic arch. The arch is clearly visible on frontal chest X-rays, and three arteries arise from its upper curve: the brachiocephalic artery, the left common carotid artery and the left subclavian artery.</p>
<p>The brachiocephalic artery is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">4-5 \mathrm{~cm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">cm</span></span></span></span></span></span> long and passes obliquely upwards, backwards and to the right. At the level of the sternoclavicular joint it divides into the right common carotid artery and the right subclavian artery.</p>
<p>Descending aorta in the thorax. This is the long segment of the aorta that descends to the diaphragm and begins at the level of the 4th thoracic vertebra. It extends downwards immediately in front of the bodies of the thoracic vertebrae to the level of the 12th thoracic vertebra, where it passes behind the diaphragm to become the abdominal aorta.</p>
<p>The descending aorta in the thorax gives off many paired branches that supply the walls and organs of the thoracic cavity (p. 110).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="abdominal-aorta">Abdominal aorta<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abdominal-aorta" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The abdominal aorta (Fig. 5.27) is a continuation of the thoracic aorta. The name changes when the aorta enters the abdominal cavity by passing behind the diaphragm at the level of the 12th thoracic vertebra. It descends in front of the vertebral column to the level of the 4th lumbar vertebra, where it divides into the right and left common iliac arteries.</p>
<p>Many branches arise from the abdominal aorta, some paired and some unpaired, supplying the abdominal structures and organs (p. 111).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="venae-cavae">Venae cavae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#venae-cavae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The superior and inferior venae cavae (Fig. 5.28) are the largest veins in the body and empty blood directly into the right atrium of the heart (see Fig. 5.13). The superior vena</p>
<p>cava drains all body structures lying above the diaphragm and the inferior vena cava drains blood from all structures below the diaphragm.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="superior-vena-cava">Superior vena cava<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#superior-vena-cava" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is about 7 cm long and is formed by the union of the left and right brachiocephalic veins.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inferior-vena-cava">Inferior vena cava<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inferior-vena-cava" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is formed at the level of the 5th lumbar vertebra by the union of the right and left common iliac veins, and ascends through the abdomen, lying close against the vertebral column and parallel to and just to the right of the descending abdominal aorta. It passes through the central tendon of the diaphragm into the thorax at the level of the 8th thoracic vertebra. As the inferior vena cava ascends through the abdomen, veins draining pelvic and abdominal organs empty into it (p. 112).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="arterial-supply">Arterial supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#arterial-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The paired arteries supplying the head and neck are the common carotid arteries and the vertebral arteries (Figs 5.29 and 5.30).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="carotid-arteries">Carotid arteries<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carotid-arteries" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The right common carotid artery is a branch of the brachiocephalic artery. The left common carotid artery arises directly from the arch of the aorta. These pass upwards on either side of the neck and have the same distribution on each side. The common carotid arteries are embedded in a fascia, called the carotid sheath. At the level of the upper border of the thyroid cartilage each divides into an internal carotid artery and an external carotid artery.</p>
<p>The carotid sinuses are slight dilations at the point of division (bifurcation) of the common carotid arteries into their internal and external branches. The walls of the sinuses are thin and contain numerous nerve endings of the glossopharyngeal nerves. These nerve endings, or baroreceptors, are stimulated by changes in blood pressure in the carotid sinuses. The resultant nerve impulses initiate reflex adjustments of blood pressure through the vasomotor centre in the medulla oblongata (p. 98).</p>
<p>The carotid bodies are two small groups of chemoreceptors, one lying in close association with each common carotid artery at its bifurcation. They are supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerves and are stimulated by changes in the carbon dioxide and oxygen content of blood. When activated, they initiate reflex adjustments of respiration through the respiratory centre in the medulla oblongata (p. 275).</p>
<p>External carotid artery (Fig. 5.29). This artery supplies the superficial tissues of the head and neck, via a number of branches:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="circulation-in-the-head-and-neck">Circulation in the head and neck<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#circulation-in-the-head-and-neck" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Right internal jugular veinRight brachiocephalic vein
Right subclavian vein
Superior vena cava
Azygos vein
Intercostal veins
Hepatic veins
Right renal vein — Right gonadal vein
Right common iliac vein Right internal iliac vein Right external iliac vein
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-1c0e46d2.jpeg" alt="img-162.jpeg"></p>
<p>Left internal jugular vein Left external jugular vein

<p>Diaphragm Left suprarenal vein — Left kidney
Left gonadal vein - Lumbar veins
Figure 5.28 The venae cavae and the main veins that form them.</p>
<ul>
<li>The superior thyroid artery supplies the thyroid gland and adjacent muscles.</li>
<li>The lingual artery supplies the tongue, the membrane that lines the mouth, the structures in the floor of the mouth, the tonsil and the epiglottis.</li>
<li>The facial artery passes outwards over the mandible just in front of the angle of the jaw and supplies the muscles of facial expression (p. 458) and structures in the mouth. A pulse can be felt where the artery crosses the jawbone.</li>
<li>The occipital artery supplies the posterior part of the scalp.</li>
<li>The temporal artery passes upwards over the zygomatic process in front of the ear and supplies the frontal, temporal and parietal parts of the scalp. The temporal pulse can be felt in front of the upper part of the ear.</li>
<li>The maxillary artery supplies the muscles of mastication; a branch of this artery, the middle meningeal artery, runs deeply to supply structures in the interior of the skull.</li>
</ul>
<p>Internal carotid artery. The internal carotid artery is a major
contributor to the circulus arteriosus (circle of Willis) (Figs
5.30 and 5.31 ), which supplies most of the brain. It also has
branches that supply the eyes, forehead and nose. It ascends
to the base of the skull and passes through the carotid foramen in the temporal bone.</p>
<p>Circulus arteriosus (circle of Willis). Most of the brain is supplied with arterial blood by an arrangement of arteries called the circulus arteriosus or the circle of Willis, Fig. 5.31. Four large arteries, the two internal carotid arteries and the two vertebral arteries (see Fig. 5.30), unite to form this complete circular channel lying in the subarachnoid space on the underside of the brain. The vertebral arteries arise from the subclavian arteries, pass upwards through the foramina in the transverse processes of the cervical vertebrae, enter the skull through the foramen magnum, and then join to form the basilar artery. The arrangement in the circulus arteriosus is such that the brain receives an adequate blood supply even if a contributing artery is damaged and during extreme movements of the head and neck.</p>
<p>Anteriorly, the two anterior cerebral arteries arise from the internal carotid arteries and are joined by the anterior communicating artery.</p>
<p>Posteriorly, the two vertebral arteries join to form the basilar artery. After travelling for a short distance the basilar artery divides to form two posterior cerebral arteries, each of
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-4ed30ec9.jpeg" alt="img-163.jpeg"></p>
<p>Maxillary artery
Facial artery

Internal carotid artery

<ul>
<li>Common carotid artery</li>
</ul>
<p>Vertebral artery</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-df92705d.jpeg" alt="img-164.jpeg"></p>

which is joined to the corresponding internal carotid artery by a posterior communicating artery, completing the circle. The circulus arteriosus is therefore formed by:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>two anterior cerebral arteries</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>two internal carotid arteries</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>one anterior communicating artery</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>two posterior communicating arteries</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>two posterior cerebral arteries</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>one basilar artery.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>From this circle, the anterior cerebral arteries pass forwards to supply the anterior part of the brain, the middle cerebral arteries pass laterally to supply the sides of the brain, and the posterior cerebral arteries supply the posterior part of the brain.</p>
<p>Branches of the basilar artery supply parts of the brain stem.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="venous-return">Venous return<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#venous-return" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Venous blood from the head and neck is returned by deep and superficial veins.
Superficial veins with the same names as the branches of the external carotid artery return venous blood from the superficial structures of the face and scalp, and unite to form the external jugular vein (Fig. 5.32).</p>
<p>Figure 5.30 Arteries forming the circulus arteriosus (circle of Willis).
The external jugular vein begins in the neck at the level of the angle of the jaw. It passes downwards in front of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, then behind the clavicle before entering the subclavian vein.</p>
<p>Venous blood from the deep areas of the brain is collected into channels called the dural venous sinuses (Fig. 5.33), which are formed by layers of dura mater lined with endothelium. The dura mater is the outer protective covering of the brain (p. 162). The main venous sinuses are:</p>
<ul>
<li>The superior sagittal sinus - carries the venous blood from the superior part of the brain. It begins in the frontal region and passes directly backwards in the midline of the skull to the occipital region, where it turns to the right side and continues as the right transverse sinus.</li>
<li>The inferior sagittal sinus - lies deep within the brain and passes backwards to form the straight sinus.</li>
<li>The straight sinus - runs backwards and downwards to become the left transverse sinus.</li>
<li>The transverse sinuses - begin in the occipital region. They run forwards and medially in a curved groove of the skull, to become continuous with the sigmoid sinuses.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-bd11fa38.jpeg" alt="img-165.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 5.31 The circulus arteriosus (circle of Willis) viewed from below.</p>
<ul>
<li>The sigmoid sinuses - a continuation of the transverse sinuses. Each curves downwards and medially, and lies in a groove in the mastoid process of the temporal bone. Anteriorly, only a thin plate of bone separates the sinus from the air cells in the mastoid process of the temporal bone. Interiorly, it continues as the internal jugular vein.</li>
</ul>
<p>The internal jugular veins begin at the jugular foramina in the middle cranial fossa (see Fig. 16.12) and each is the continuation of a sigmoid sinus. They run downwards in the neck behind the sternocleidomastoid muscles. Behind the clavicle they unite with the subclavian veins, carrying blood from the upper limbs, to form the brachiocephalic veins.</p>
<p>The brachiocephalic veins are situated one on each side in the root of the neck. Each is formed by the union of the internal jugular and the subclavian veins. The left brachiocephalic vein is longer than the right and passes obliquely behind the manubrium of the sternum, where it joins the right brachiocephalic vein to form the superior vena cava (see Fig. 5.28).</p>
<p>The superior vena cava, which drains all the venous blood from the head, neck and upper limbs, is about 7 cm long. It passes downwards along the right border of the sternum and ends in the right atrium of the heart.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="circulation-in-the-upper-limb-arterial-supply-the-subclavian-arteries">Circulation in the upper limb Arterial supply The subclavian arteries<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#circulation-in-the-upper-limb-arterial-supply-the-subclavian-arteries" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The right subclavian artery arises from the brachiocephalic artery, the left branches from the arch of the aorta. They are slightly arched and pass behind the clavicles and over the first ribs before entering the axillae, where they continue as the axillary arteries (Fig. 5.34).</p>
<p>Before entering the axilla, each subclavian artery gives off two branches: the vertebral artery, which passes upwards to supply the brain (see Fig. 5.30), and the</p>
<p>internal thoracic artery, which supplies the breast and a number of structures in the thoracic cavity.</p>
<p>The axillary artery is a continuation of the subclavian artery and lies in the axilla. The first part lies deeply, then it runs more superficially to become the brachial artery.</p>
<p>The brachial artery is a continuation of the axillary artery. It runs down the medial aspect of the upper arm, passes to the front of the elbow and extends to about 1 cm below the joint, where it divides into the radial and ulnar arteries.</p>
<p>The radial artery passes down the radial or lateral side of the forearm to the wrist. Just above the wrist it lies superficially and can be felt in front of the radius, as the radial pulse. The artery then passes between the first and second metacarpal bones and enters the palm of the hand.</p>
<p>The ulnar artery runs downwards on the ulnar or medial aspect of the forearm to cross the wrist and pass into the hand.</p>
<p>There are anastomoses between the radial and ulnar arteries, called the deep and superficial palmar arches, from which palmar metacarpal and palmar digital arteries arise to supply the structures in the hand and fingers.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="venous-return">Venous return<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#venous-return" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The Upper limb is drained by both deep and superficial veins (Fig. 5.35). The deep veins follow the course of the arteries and have the same names:</p>
<ul>
<li>palmar metacarpal veins</li>
<li>deep palmar venous arch</li>
<li>ulnar and radial veins</li>
<li>brachial vein</li>
<li>axillary vein</li>
<li>subclavian vein.</li>
</ul>
<p>The superficial veins begin in the hand and consist of the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>cephalic vein</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>basilic vein</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>median vein</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>median cubital vein.</p>
</li>
</ul>
