<p>in the axillary vein. Throughout its length it receives blood from the superficial tissues on the lateral aspects of the hand, forearm and arm.</p>
<p>The basilic vein begins at the back of the hand on the ulnar aspect. It ascends on the medial side of the forearm and upper arm, then joins the axillary vein. It receives blood from the medial aspect of the hand, forearm and arm. There are many small veins that link the cephalic and basilic veins.</p>
<p>The median vein is a small vein that is not always present. It begins at the palmar surface of the hand, ascends on the front of the forearm and ends in the basilic vein or the median cubital vein.</p>
<p>The brachiocephalic vein is formed when the subclavian and internal jugular veins unite. There is one on each side.</p>
<p>The superior vena cava is formed when the two brachiocephalic veins unite. It drains all the venous blood from the head, neck and upper limbs and opens into the right atrium. It is about 7 cm long and passes downwards along the right border of the sternum.</p>
<p>Circulation in the thorax
Arterial supply
Branches of the thoracic aorta (see Fig. 5.27) supply structures in the chest, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>bronchial arteries, which supply lung tissues not directly involved in gas exchange</li>
<li>oesophageal arteries, which supply the oesophagus</li>
<li>intercostal arteries, which run along the inferior border of each rib and supply the intercostal muscles, some
muscles of the thorax, the ribs, skin and its underlying connective tissues.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="venous-return">Venous return<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#venous-return" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Most of the venous blood from the organs in the thoracic cavity is drained into the azygos vein and the hemiazygos vein (see Fig. 5.28). Some of the main veins that join them are the bronchial, oesophageal and intercostal veins. The azygos vein joins the superior vena cava and the hemiazygos vein joins the left brachiocephalic vein. At the distal end of the oesophagus, some oesophageal veins join the azygos vein, and others the left gastric vein. A venous plexus is formed by anastomoses between the veins joining the azygos vein and those joining the left gastric veins, linking the general and portal circulations (see Fig. 12.47). There are many anastomotic connections between veins draining the thoracic and abdominal</p>
<p>cavities, so that if one channel becomes blocked, the blood has an alternative route back to the heart.</p>
<p>Circulation in the abdomen</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="arterial-supply">Arterial supply<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#arterial-supply" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Branches of the abdominal aorta (see Fig. 5.27) supply structures in the abdomen.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="paired-branches">Paired branches<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#paired-branches" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These include the:</p>
<ul>
<li>Phrenic arteries, supplying the diaphragm.</li>
<li>Renal arteries, supplying the kidneys.</li>
<li>Suprarenal arteries, supplying the adrenal glands.</li>
<li>Gonadal arteries, supplying the ovaries (female) and testes (male). These arteries are much longer than the other paired branches because the gonads begin their development high in the abdominal cavity. As fetal development proceeds, they descend into the pelvis and their supplying arteries become correspondingly longer to maintain supply.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="unpaired-branches">Unpaired branches<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#unpaired-branches" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These include the:</p>
<ul>
<li>Coeliac artery (sometimes called the coeliac trunk. Fig. 5.36), a short thick artery about 1.25 cm long. It arises immediately below the diaphragm and divides into three branches:</li>
<li>the left gastric artery supplying the stomach</li>
<li>the splenic artery supplying the spleen and pancreas</li>
<li>the hepatic artery supplying the liver, gall bladder and parts of the stomach, duodenum and pancreas.</li>
</ul>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="venous-return">Venous return<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#venous-return" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Blood drains from some abdominal organs directly into the inferior vena cava via veins named as the corresponding arteries (see Fig. 5.28). Hepatic veins drain the liver, renal veins drain the kidneys, suprarenal veins drain the adrenal glands, lumbar veins drain lower abdominal structures and gonadal veins drain the ovaries (female) and testes (male). However, most blood from the digestive organs in the abdomen is drained into the hepatic portal vein and passes through the liver before being emptied into the inferior vena cava (the portal circulation).</p>
<p>Portal circulation <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">□</mi><mn>5.10</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square 5.10</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">□</span><span class="mord">5.10</span></span></span></span></span>
As a general rule, venous blood passes from the tissues to the heart by the most direct route through only one
capillary bed. In the portal circulation, venous blood from the capillary beds of the abdominal part of the digestive system, the spleen and pancreas travels first to the liver (Fig. 5.38). In the liver, it passes through a second capillary bed, the hepatic sinusoids, before entering the general circulation via the inferior vena cava. In this way, blood with a high concentration of nutrients, absorbed from the stomach and intestines, goes to the liver first. This supplies the liver with a rich source of nutrients for its extensive metabolic activities and ensures that the composition of blood leaving the alimentary tract can be appropriately regulated. It also ensures that unwanted and/or potentially toxic materials such as drugs are eliminated before the blood is returned into general circulation. This is called first-pass metabolism.</p>
<p>Note that rectal veins draining blood from the lower two-thirds of the rectum empty into systemic veins, not the portal vein, and so this blood travels to the heart</p>
<p>without first passing through the liver. Drugs absorbed from rectal formulations are therefore absorbed directly into the general circulation. This delays their elimination by the liver, which can be very useful clinically.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="portal-vein">Portal vein<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#portal-vein" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is formed by the union of several veins (Fig. 5.39; see also Fig. 5.38), each of which drains blood from the area supplied by the corresponding artery:</p>
<p>R

Circulation in the pelvis and lower limb</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="arterial-supply-common-iliac-arteries">Arterial supply Common iliac arteries<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#arterial-supply-common-iliac-arteries" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The abdominal aorta divides at the level of the 4th lumbar vertebra into the right and left common iliac arteries (see Fig. 5.27). In front of the sacroiliac joint each divides into the internal and the external iliac arteries.</p>
<p>The internal iliac artery runs medially to supply the organs within the pelvic cavity. In the female, one of the largest branches is the uterine artery, which provides the main arterial blood supply to the reproductive organs.</p>
<p>The external iliac artery runs obliquely downwards and passes behind the inguinal ligament into the thigh, where it becomes the femoral artery.</p>
<p>The femoral artery (Fig. 5.40) begins at the midpoint of the inguinal ligament and extends downwards in front of the thigh. The femoral pulse can be felt at the origin of the femoral artery. It then turns medially and eventually passes round the medial aspect of the femur to enter the popliteal space, where it becomes the popliteal artery. It supplies blood to the structures of the thigh and some superficial pelvic and inguinal structures.</p>
<p>Common iliac artery</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="external-iliac-artery">External iliac artery<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#external-iliac-artery" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inguinal-ligament">Inguinal ligament<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inguinal-ligament" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Deep artery of thigh -
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-cf160170.jpeg" alt="img-174.jpeg"></p>
<p>Internal iliac artery</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="femoral-artery">Femoral artery<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#femoral-artery" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="popliteal-artery">Popliteal artery<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#popliteal-artery" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Figure 5.40 The femoral artery and its main branches.
The popliteal artery (Fig. 5.41) passes through the popliteal fossa behind the knee, where the popliteal pulse can be felt. It supplies the structures in this area, including the knee joint. At the lower border of the popliteal fossa it divides into the anterior and posterior tibial arteries.</p>
<p>The anterior tibial artery (Fig. 5.41) passes forwards between the tibia and fibula, and supplies the structures in the front of the leg. It lies on the tibia, runs in front of the ankle joint and continues over the dorsum (top) of the foot as the dorsalis pedis artery.</p>
<p>The dorsalis pedis artery is a continuation of the anterior tibial artery and passes over the dorsum of the foot, where the pulse can be felt, supplying arterial blood to the structures in this area. It ends by passing between the first and second</p>
<p>metatarsal bones into the sole of the foot, where it contributes to the formation of the plantar arch.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-57229d95.jpeg" alt="img-175.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 5.42 Veins of the leg.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-39ad4b51.jpeg" alt="img-176.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 5.41 The right popliteal artery and its main branches.
The posterior tibial artery (Fig. 5.41) runs downwards and medially on the back of the leg. Near its origin it gives off a large branch called the peroneal artery, which supplies the lateral aspect of the leg. In the lower part it becomes superficial and passes medial to the ankle joint to reach the sole of the foot, where it continues as the plantar artery.</p>
<p>The plantar artery supplies the structures in the sole of the foot. This artery, its branches and the dorsalis pedis artery form the plantar arch, from which the digital branches arise to supply the toes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="venous-return">Venous return<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#venous-return" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There are both deep and superficial veins in the lower limb (Fig. 5.42). Blood entering the superficial veins passes to the deep veins through communicating veins. Movement of blood towards the heart is partly dependent on contraction of skeletal muscles. Backward flow is prevented by a large number of valves. Superficial veins receive less support from surrounding tissues than deep veins.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="deep-veins">Deep veins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#deep-veins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The deep veins (Fig. 5.42) accompany the arteries and their
branches, and have the same names. They are:</p>
<ul>
<li>The femoral vein, which ascends in the thigh to the level of the inguinal ligament, where it becomes the external iliac vein.</li>
<li>The external iliac vein, the continuation of the femoral vein where it enters the pelvis lying close to the femoral
artery. It passes along the brim of the pelvis, and at the level of the sacroiliac joint it is joined by the internal iliac vein to form the common iliac vein.</li>
<li>The internal iliac vein, which receives tributaries from several veins draining the organs of the pelvic cavity.</li>
<li>Two common iliac veins, which begin at the level of the sacroiliac joints. They ascend obliquely and end a little to the right of the body of the 5th lumbar vertebra by uniting to form the inferior vena cava.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="superficial-veins">Superficial veins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#superficial-veins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The two main superficial veins (Fig. 5.42) draining blood from the lower limbs are the small and the great saphenous veins.</p>
<p>The small saphenous vein begins behind the ankle joint, where many small veins that drain the dorsum of the foot join together. It ascends superficially along the back of the leg and in the popliteal space it joins the popliteal vein, a deep vein.</p>
<p>The great saphenous vein is the longest vein in the body. It begins at the medial half of the dorsum of the foot and runs upwards, crossing the medial aspect of the tibia and continuing up the inner side of the thigh. Just below the inguinal ligament it joins the femoral vein.</p>
<p>Many communicating veins link the superficial veins, and also link the superficial and deep veins of the lower limb.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="spot-check">- SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="8">
<li>Name the three sections of the aorta.</li>
<li>What is the key feature of the hepatic portal circulation?</li>
</ol>
<p>Summary of the main blood vessels
The main blood vessels are summarised in Fig. 5.43.
Fetal circulation
Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>outline the functions of the placenta</li>
<li>describe the fetal circulation</li>
<li>compare blood flow through the heart, lungs and liver before and shortly after birth.</li>
</ul>
<p>Features of the fetal circulation <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">□</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square \mathrm{s} . \mathrm{n}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">□</span><span class="mord mathrm">s</span><span class="mord">.</span><span class="mord mathrm">n</span></span></span></span></span>
The developing fetus obtains its oxygen and nutrients, and excretes its waste, via the mother's circulation. To this
end, both maternal and fetal circulations develop specific adaptations unique to pregnancy. Because the lungs, gastrointestinal system and kidneys do not begin to function till after birth, certain modifications in the fetal circulation divert blood flow to meet prenatal requirements.</p>
<p>Placenta</p>
<p>This is a temporary structure that provides an interface between the mother and fetus, and allows the exchange of substances between their circulatory systems. It develops from the surface of the fertilised ovum embedded into the maternal uterine endometrium (Fig. 5.44). It is expelled from the uterus during the final stage of labour soon after birth, when it is no longer needed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="structure">Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The mature placenta (Fig. 5.44A) is pancake-shaped, weighs around 500 g , has a diameter of 20 cm and is about 2.5 cm thick, although wide individual variations occur. The placenta is firmly attached to the uterine wall and consists of an extensive network of fetal capillaries bathed in maternal blood. While the fetal capillaries are in very close proximity to the maternal blood supply, the two circulations are completely separate. Branches of the uterine artery bring maternal blood (about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>500</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">500 \mathrm{~mL} / \mathrm{min}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">500</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mL</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">min</span></span></span></span></span></span> ) into chambers in the placenta called intervillous spaces. Projecting into the intervillous spaces are bundles of capillaries bringing blood from the fetus. Oxygen and nutrients diffuse or are actively transported into the fetal blood from the maternal blood, and fetal wastes diffuse into the mother's blood. The placenta is attached to the fetus by a cord (the umbilical cord), which is usually about 50 cm long and contains two umbilical arteries and one umbilical vein wrapped in a soft connective tissue coat (Fig. 5.44B). The cord enters the fetus at a spot on the abdomen called the umbilicus.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Placental functions include exchange of substances, protection of the fetus and maintenance of pregnancy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="exchange-of-nutrients-and-wastes">Exchange of nutrients and wastes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#exchange-of-nutrients-and-wastes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Deoxygenated fetal blood flowing through the network of placental capillaries absorbs oxygen and nutrients from maternal blood and excretes its wastes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="protection-of-the-fetus">Protection of the fetus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#protection-of-the-fetus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Temporary passive immunity (p. 416) lasting for a few months is provided by maternal antibodies that cross the placenta before birth.</p>
<p>Indirect exchange between the fetal and maternal circulations provides a 'barrier' to potentially harmful substances, including bacteria and drugs, although some may cross into the fetus, causing abnormal development. Any substance causing abnormal fetal development is called a teratogen. Important teratogens include alcohol, certain drugs including some antibiotics and anticancer agents.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="kidneys">Kidneys<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#kidneys" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="maintenance-of-pregnancy">Maintenance of pregnancy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#maintenance-of-pregnancy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The placenta has an essential endocrine function and secretes the hormones that maintain pregnancy.</p>
<p>Human chorionic gonadotrophin (hCG). Human chorionic gonadotrophin (hCG) is secreted in early pregnancy, peaking at around 8 or 9 weeks and thereafter in smaller amounts. It stimulates the corpus luteum (p. 494) to continue secreting progesterone and oestrogen, which prevent menstruation and maintain the uterine endometrium, sustaining pregnancy in the early weeks (see Fig. 18.10).
Progostorone and oostrogon. As pregnancy progresses, the placenta takes over secretion of these hormones from the corpus luteum, which degenerates after about 12 weeks. From 12 weeks until delivery, the placenta secretes increasing levels of</p>
<p>oestrogen and progesterone. These hormones are essential for maintenance of pregnancy.</p>
<p>Fetal adaptations
These are shown in Fig. 5.45A.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ductus-venosus">Ductus venosus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ductus-venosus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is a continuation of the umbilical vein that returns blood directly into the fetal inferior vena cava, and most blood, therefore, bypasses the non-functional fetal liver.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ductus-arteriosus">Ductus arteriosus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ductus-arteriosus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This small vessel connects the pulmonary artery to the descending thoracic aorta and diverts blood into the systemic circulation, meaning that very little blood passes through the fetal lungs (see Fig. 5.58).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="foramen-ovale">Foramen ovale<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#foramen-ovale" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is an opening in the septum separating the two atria. It is covered with a flap of tissue that acts as a one-way valve (the atrioseptal valve, see Figs 5.45 and 5.59), allowing blood to flow between the right and left atria, so that most blood bypasses the non-functional fetal lungs.</p>
<p>These are summarised in Fig. 5.45B.
When the baby takes its first breath the lungs inflate for the first time, increasing pulmonary blood flow. Blood returning from the lungs increases the pressure in the left atrium, closing the flap over the foramen ovale and preventing blood flow between the atria. Blood entering the right atrium is therefore diverted into the right ventricle and into the pulmonary circulation through the pulmonary arteries. As the pulmonary circulation is established (see Fig. 5.1), blood oxygen levels increase, causing constriction and closure of the ductus arteriosus. If these adaptations to extrauterine life do not take place after birth, they become evident as congenital abnormalities (see Figs 5.58 and 5.59). When the placental circulation ceases, soon after birth, the umbilical vein, ductus venosus and umbilical arteries collapse, as they are no longer required.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="10-spot-check">10 SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#10-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

Effects of ageing on the cardiovascular system
Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the effects of ageing on the cardiovascular system.</li>
</ul>
<p>Ageing and the heart
As the heart gets older, its function generally declines; cardiac output falls and the conduction pathways become less efficient. Cardiac muscle cell numbers steadily reduce with age, but hypertrophy (cell enlargement) generally balances this and the ventricles of the heart in older adults are actually slightly larger than in younger people. The compliance (stretchability) of the heart falls with age, mainly because the fibrous skeleton of the heart stiffens, increasing the heart's workload. The ability of the heart muscle to
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-a3cbebc6.jpeg" alt="img-184.jpeg">
respond to adrenaline (epinephrine) and noradrenaline (norepinephrine) lessens, and the contractile strength of the heart and cardiac reserve are reduced. The older heart is therefore more prone to heart failure (p. 131).</p>
<p>These changes occur in the healthy ageing heart and are not consequences of disease. It is notable that age-related decline in cardiovascular function is greatly slowed in individuals who take regular exercise, even in old age.</p>
<p>Ageing and blood vessels
Vasoconstriction and vasodilation responses are less efficient in ageing blood vessels, so regulation of blood flow to the tissues is less well controlled. Arterial and arteriolar walls become stiffer and less compliant, which raises blood pressure and increases the work of the left ventricle. Blood pressure tends to rise with age, even in the absence of any
overt cardiovascular disease. The amount of smooth muscle in the walls of most arteries, including those of the heart, kidneys and brain, rises with age, which contributes to their stiffening. This means that the blood supply to most body</p>
<p>organs tends to fall, but in healthy old age it does not cause problems because it is matched by a general reduction in metabolic rate.</p>
<p>The baroreceptor reflex (p. 98) becomes less brisk with age, not only because the heart and blood vessels are slower to respond but also because of neuronal ageing. This may lead to postural hypotension (p. 138).
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;=</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;=</span></span></span></span></span> SPOT CHECK
12. Outline how age-related decline in heart function can be minimised.</p>
<p>Shock
These interfere with normal nervous control of blood vessel diameter, leading to vasodilation and hypotension.</p>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>define the term 'shock'</li>
<li>describe the main physiological changes that occur during shock</li>
<li>explain the underlying pathophysiology of the main causes of shock.</li>
</ul>
<p>Shock (circulatory failure) occurs when the metabolic needs of cells are not met because of inadequate blood flow. In effect, there is a reduction in circulating blood volume, in blood pressure and in cardiac output. This causes tissue hypoxia, an inadequate supply of nutrients and the accumulation of waste products. There are different ways of classifying shock, including by cause, which is described here.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hypovolaemic-shock">Hypovolaemic shock<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypovolaemic-shock" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This occurs when the blood volume is reduced by <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>15</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>25</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">15-25 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">15</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">25%</span></span></span></span></span>. Cardiac output may fall because of low blood volume and hence low venous return, as a result of different situations:</p>
<ul>
<li>Severe haemorrhage - whole blood is lost.</li>
<li>Extensive burns - serum is lost.</li>
<li>Severe vomiting and diarrhoea - water and electrolytes are lost.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cardiogenic-shock">Cardiogenic shock<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cardiogenic-shock" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This occurs in acute heart disease when damaged heart muscle cannot maintain an adequate cardiac output, e.g. in myocardial infarction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="septic-shock-bacteraemic-endotoxic">Septic shock (bacteraemic, endotoxic)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#septic-shock-bacteraemic-endotoxic" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Sepsis, or septicaemia, means active infection in the bloodstream, and it can lead to septic shock when it triggers a massive, systemic inflammatory and immune response. White blood cells are activated and a wide range of powerful inflammatory mediators are released into the blood, with widespread effects on organ function. Septic shock has a high mortality rate, even when treated. Symptoms include hypotension due to extensive vasodilation, depression of cardiac contractility, poor tissue perfusion and deteriorating mental state.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="neurogenic-shock">Neurogenic shock<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#neurogenic-shock" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The causes include sudden acute pain, severe emotional experience, spinal anaesthesia and spinal cord damage.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="anaphylactic-shock">Anaphylactic shock<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anaphylactic-shock" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Anaphylaxis (p. 417) is a severe allergic response that may be triggered in sensitive individuals by substances like penicillin, peanuts or latex rubber. Vasodilation, provoked by systemic release of inflammatory mediators, e.g. histamine and bradykinin, causes venous pooling and hypotension. Severe bronchoconstriction leads to acute respiratory difficulty and hypoxia. Onset is usually sudden, and in severe cases can cause death in a matter of minutes if untreated.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="physiological-changes-during-shock">Physiological changes during shock<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physiological-changes-during-shock" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In the short term, changes are associated with physiological attempts to restore an adequate blood circulation compensated shock (Fig. 5.46). If not corrected, the longer-term changes may be irreversible.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="compensated-shock">Compensated shock<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#compensated-shock" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>As the blood pressure falls, a number of compensatory reflexes are stimulated and hormone secretions increased in an attempt to restore it. These raise blood pressure by increasing peripheral resistance, blood volume and cardiac output (Fig. 5.46).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-8bae45bf.jpeg" alt="img-185.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 5.46 Compensatory mechanisms in shock. ADH, Antidiuretic hormone.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-d4b109a4.jpeg" alt="img-186.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 5.47 Unconnpensated shock.
Increased sympathetic stimulation increases heart rate and cardiac output, and also causes vasoconstriction, all of which increase blood pressure. Low blood volume and increased osmolarity of the blood cause secretion of ADH (p. 239) and activate the RAAS (p. 377). Consequent release of aldosterone reduces water and sodium excretion, and promotes vasoconstriction. The veins also constrict, helping to reduce venous pooling and support venous return.</p>
<p>If these compensatory mechanisms, plus any medical interventions available, are sufficient, then perfusion of the heart and brain can be maintained and the patient's condition may be stabilised.</p>
<p>Uncompensated shock
If the insult is more severe, shock becomes a self-perpetuating sequence of deteriorating cardiovascular function uncompensated shock (Fig. 5.47). Hypoxia causes cellular metabolism to switch to anaerobic pathways (p. 344), resulting in accumulation of lactic acid and progressive acidosis, which damages capillaries. The capillaries then become more permeable, leaking fluid from the vascular system into the tissues, further lowering blood pressure and tissue perfusion. Also, the accumulation of waste products causes vasodilation, making it harder for control mechanisms to support blood pressure. Organs, including the heart, are deprived of oxygen and may start to fail.</p>
<p>Eventually, the cardiovascular system reaches the stage when, although its compensatory mechanisms are running
at maximum, it is unable to supply the brain's requirements. As the brain, including the cardiovascular and respiratory centres in the brain stem, becomes starved of oxygen and nutrients, it begins to fail and there is loss of central control of the body's compensatory mechanisms. Circulatory collapse follows. Finally, degenerating cardiovascular function leads to irreversible and progressive brain stem damage, and death follows.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-1-1-spot-check"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">1%</span></span></span></span></span> SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-1-1-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="13">
<li>What is compensated shock?</li>
<li>How does severe allergy cause shock?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="thrombosis-and-embolism">Thrombosis and embolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thrombosis-and-embolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>define the terms 'thrombosis', 'embolism', 'ischaemia' and 'infarction'</li>
<li>explain, in general terms, the effects of the above on the body</li>
<li>describe three risk factors for thrombosis formation.</li>
</ul>
<p>Learning outcomes
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">□</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">□</span></span></span></span></span> Cardiac output
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">□</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">□</span></span></span></span></span> Blood pressure</p>
<p>Thrombosis
Thrombosis is the formation of a blood clot (thrombus) inside a blood vessel, interrupting blood supply to the tissues. The risk of a thrombus developing within a blood vessel is increased by several factors.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="slow-blood-flow">Slow blood flow<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#slow-blood-flow" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This may happen in immobility, e.g. with prolonged sitting or bedrest, or on longhaul flights; if a blood vessel is compressed by an adjacent structure such as a tumour or tight clothing; or if there is a sustained fall in blood pressure, as in shock.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="damage-to-the-blood-vessel-intima">Damage to the blood vessel intima<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#damage-to-the-blood-vessel-intima" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is usually associated with atherosclerosis (p. 125).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="increased-blood-coagulability">Increased blood coagulability<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#increased-blood-coagulability" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Dehydration, pregnancy and childbirth, blood clotting disorders, some malignant disease, the presence of an intravenous cannula and oestrogen (including when used as a contraceptive) all increase the risk of blood clots forming.</p>
<p>Embolism
Embolism is the blocking of a blood vessel by any mass of material (an embolus) travelling in the blood. This is usually a thrombus or a fragment of a thrombus, but other embolic materials are shown in Box 5.3.</p>
<p>Emboli originating in an artery travel away from the heart until they reach an artery too narrow to let them pass; they lodge there, partly or completely blocking blood supply to distal tissues. This is a common cause of stroke (p. 194), myocardial infarction (p. 133) and gangrenous limbs (Fig. 5.48). Emboli originating in veins</p>
<p>(deep vein thrombosis, or DVT; p. 127) travel towards the heart, and from there to the lungs in the pulmonary artery. They then lodge in the first branch that is narrower than they are (pulmonary embolism).</p>
<p>Box 5.3 Possible embolic materials
Fragments of atheromatous plaques (p. 125)
Fragments of vegetations from heart valves, e.g. in infective endocarditis (p. 133)
Tumour fragments, which may cause metastases
Amniotic fluid, during childbirth
Fat, from bone fractures
Air, from a punctured blood vessel, e.g. by a broken rib or during a clinical procedure</p>
<p>Nitrogen bubbles in decompression sickness (the 'bends')
Pus from an abscess</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pulmonary-embolism">Pulmonary embolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pulmonary-embolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Blockage of a pulmonary artery or one of its larger branches causes an immediate reduction in blood flow through the lung, and this is one of the most serious consequences of venous embolism. Massive pulmonary embolism blocks a main pulmonary artery and usually causes sudden collapse and death.</p>
<p>Infarction and ischaemia
Infarction is the term given to tissue death because of interrupted blood supply. The consequences of interrupting tissue blood supply depend of the size of the blocked artery and the functions of the affected tissue. Ischaemia is impaired tissue function due to hypoxia and accumulation of cellular wastes (Fig. 5.48).</p>
<p>Partial arterial blockage Complete arterial blockage causing ischaemia causing infarction

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="spot-check">- SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="blood-vessel-pathology">Blood vessel pathology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-vessel-pathology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>discuss the main causes, effects and complications of arterial disease, including atheroma, arteriosclerosis, venous thrombosis and aneurysm</li>
<li>discuss the underlying abnormality in varicose veins</li>
<li>list the predisposing factors and the common sites of occurrence of varicose veins</li>
<li>describe the main tumours that affect blood vessels.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="atheroma">Atheroma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atheroma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathological-changes">Pathological changes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathological-changes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Atheromatous plaques are patchy changes that develop in the tunica intima of large and medium-sized arteries. Initial changes show a fatty streak in the artery wall. Mature plaques consist of accumulations of cholesterol and other lipids, excess smooth muscle and fat-filled monocytes (foam cells). The plaque is covered with a rough fibrous cap. As plaques grow and thicken, they spread along the artery wall and protrude into the lumen. Eventually, the whole thickness of the wall and long sections of the vessel may be affected (Fig. 5.49). Plaques may rupture, exposing subintimal materials to the blood. This may cause thrombosis and vasospasm, and will compromise blood flow.</p>
<p>Arteries most commonly involved are those in the heart, brain, kidneys, small intestine and lower limbs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes-of-atheroma">Causes of atheroma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-of-atheroma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The origin of atheromatous plaques is uncertain. Fatty streaks present in artery walls of infants are usually absorbed but their incomplete absorption may be the origin of atheromatous plaques in later life.</p>
<p>Atherosclerosis (the presence of plaques) is considered to be a disease of older people because it is usually in this age group that clinical signs appear. Plaques start to form in childhood in developed countries, however. The incidence</p>
<p>Box 5.4 Predisposing factors in atherosclerosis

<p>Hyperlipidaemia, especially high levels of lowdensity lipoprotein (p. 302)
Excessive alcohol consumption
of atheroma is widespread in developed countries. Why atheromatous plaques develop is not clearly understood but the predisposing factors appear to exert their effects over a long period. This may mean that the development of atheroma can be delayed or even arrested by a change in lifestyle (Box 5.4).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ba8b797d">Effects of atheroma <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">□</mi><mn>5.12</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square 5.12</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">□</span><span class="mord">5.12</span></span></span></span></span><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ba8b797d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Atheromatous plaques may cause partial or complete obstruction of an artery (Fig. 5.49). The blockage may be complicated by clot formation. The consequences of this depend on the site and size of the artery involved and the extent of collateral circulation.</p>
<p>Narrowing of an artery
The tissues distal to the narrow point become ischaemic. The cells may receive enough blood to meet their minimum needs but not enough to cope with an increase in metabolic rate, e.g. when muscle activity is increased. This causes acute cramp-like ischaemic pain, which disappears when exertion stops. Cardiac muscle and skeletal muscles of the lower limb are most commonly affected. Ischaemic pain in the heart is called angina pectoris (p. 133), and in the lower limbs, intermittent claudication.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="occlusion-of-an-artery">Occlusion of an artery<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#occlusion-of-an-artery" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When an artery is completely blocked, the tissues it supplies rapidly degenerate (ischaemia), which leads to infarction (p. 124). If a major artery supplying a large amount of tissue is affected, the consequences are likely to be more severe than if the obstruction occurs in a minor vessel. If the tissue is well provided with a collateral circulation (such as the circulus arteriosus provides in the brain), tissue damage is less than</p>
