<p>Learning outcomes
Table 6.1 (common terms used in lymphatic system pathology</p>
<p>Learning outcomes</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lymphadenitis">Lymphadenitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lymphadenitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Acute lymphadenitis (acute infection of lymph nodes) is usually caused by microbes transported in lymph from other areas of infection. The nodes become inflamed, enlarged and congested with blood, and chemotaxis (directed movement of defensive cells into infected or damaged tissues) attracts large numbers of phagocytes. If lymph node defences (phagocytes and antibody production) are overwhelmed, the infection can cause abscess formation within the node. Adjacent tissues may become involved, and infected materials may be transported through other nodes and into the blood.</p>
<p>Acute lymphadenitis is secondary to a number of conditions. Minor lymphadenitis accompanies many infections and indicates the normal proliferation of defence cells. More serious infection occurs in, for example, measles, typhoid and catscratch fever, and wound or skin infections. Chronic lymphadenitis occurs following unresolved acute infections, and in tuberculosis, syphilis and some lowgrade infections.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="infectious-mononucleosis-glandular-fever">Infectious mononucleosis (glandular fever)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#infectious-mononucleosis-glandular-fever" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a highly contagious viral infection, usually of young adults, spread by direct contact. During the incubation period of 7-10 days, viruses multiply in the epithelial cells of the pharynx. They subsequently spread to cervical lymph nodes, then to lymphoid tissue throughout the body. Clinical features include tonsillitis, lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly. A common complication is myalgic encephalitis (chronic fatigue syndrome, p. 198).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lymphomas">Lymphomas<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lymphomas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are malignant tumours of lymphoid tissue and are classified as either Hodgkin or non-Hodgkin lymphomas.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hodgkin-lymphoma">Hodgkin lymphoma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hodgkin-lymphoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) is a group of diseases that almost always presents with painless enlargement of lymph nodes throughout the body, as lymphoid tissue within them proliferates. The superficial lymph nodes in the neck are often the first to be noticed. The disease is malignant and the cause is unknown. Males are more commonly affected than females and the two age groups displaying the highest incidence are 20-35 years and 50-70 years. The prognosis varies considerably but the pattern of spread is predictable because the disease spreads from one node to the next and to adjacent tissues, following local lymphatic channels. The effectiveness of treatment depends largely on the stage of the disease at which it begins, but is often curable, especially if caught early. The disease leads to reduced immunity because lymphocyte function is depressed, and recurrent
infection is therefore common. As lymph nodes enlarge, they may compress adjacent tissues and organs. Anaemia and changes in leukocyte numbers occur if the bone marrow is involved. It is rare for the disease to spread to non-lymphoid tissues or organs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="non-hodgkin-lymphomas">Non-Hodgkin lymphomas<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#non-hodgkin-lymphomas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Non-Hodgkin lymphomas (NHLs) constitute a group of lymphomas that are more common than HL; they may be associated with immunodeficiency states and certain viral infections, including HIV (p. 418). NHLs include multiple myeloma and Burkitt lymphoma, and may occur in any lymphoid tissue or in bone marrow. They are classified according to the type of cell involved and the degree of malignancy, i.e. low, intermediate or high grade. Low-grade tumours consist of well-differentiated cells and disease progress is slow, death occurring after a period of years. High-grade lymphomas consist of poorly differentiated cells and disease progress is rapid, death occurring in weeks or months. Some low- or intermediategrade tumours change their status to high grade with increased rate of progress.</p>
<p>The expanding lymph nodes may compress adjacent tissues and organs. Immunological deficiency leads to increased incidence of infections, and if the bone marrow or spleen (or both) is involved there may be varying degrees of anaemia and leukopenia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="6">
<li>Why does lymphadenitis often accompany infection?</li>
<li>In relation to lymphomas, describe the degree of differentiation and rate of progress of high-grade tumours.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="disorders-of-the-spleen">Disorders of the spleen<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-spleen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to: ■ identify the main causes of splenomegaly.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="splenomegaly">Splenomegaly<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#splenomegaly" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is enlargement of the spleen, and is usually secondary to other conditions, including infections, circulatory disorders, blood diseases and malignant neoplasms.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="infections">Infections<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The spleen may be infected by blood-borne microbes or by local spread of infection. The red pulp becomes congested</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcome">Learning outcome<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>with blood, and phagocytes and plasma cells accumulate within. Acute infections are rare.</p>
<p>Chronic infections
Some chronic infections cause splenomegaly but this is usually less severe than with acute infections. The most commonly occurring primary infections include tuberculosis (p. 291), typhoid fever (p. 355), malaria and infectious mononucleosis (see earlier).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="circulatory-disorders">Circulatory disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#circulatory-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>If blood flow through the liver is impeded - by fibrosis in liver cirrhosis, for example, or portal venous congestion in right-sided heart failure - blood backing up through the portal circulation can cause congestion and enlargement of the spleen.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-disease">Blood disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Splenomegaly may be caused by blood disorders. The spleen enlarges to deal with the extra workload associated with removing damaged, worn-out and abnormal blood cells in, for example, haemolytic and macrocytic anaemia, polycythaemia and chronic myeloid leukaemia (Ch. 4).</p>
<p>Splenomegaly may itself cause blood disorders. When the spleen is enlarged for any reason, especially in portal hypertension, excessive and premature haemolysis</p>
<p>of red cells or phagocytosis of normal white cells and platelets leads to marked anaemia, leukopenia and thrombocytopenia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="tumours">Tumours<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Benign and primary malignant tumours of the spleen are rare but blood-spread tumour fragments from elsewhere in the body may cause metastases. Splenomegaly caused by infiltration of malignant cells is characteristic of some conditions, especially chronic leukaemia, HL and NHL.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diseases-of-the-thymus-gland">Diseases of the thymus gland<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diseases-of-the-thymus-gland" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the principal disorders of the thymus gland.
functions of adjacent structures, e.g. the trachea, oesophagus or veins in the neck.
In myasthenia gravis (p. 472), most patients have either thymic hyperplasia (the majority) or thymoma (a minority), although the role of thymic function in this disorder is not understood.</li>
</ul>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sympathetic-division">Sympathetic division<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sympathetic-division" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="parasympathetic-division">Parasympathetic division<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#parasympathetic-division" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

CNS
Brain and spinal</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="central-nervous-system">CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#central-nervous-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Figure 7.1 Functional components of the nervous system.
The nervous system detects and responds to changes inside and outside the body. Together with the endocrine system, it coordinates and controls vital aspects of body function and maintains homeostasis. To this end the nervous system provides an immediate response while endocrine activity (Ch. 9) is, usually, slower and more prolonged.</p>
<p>The nervous system consists of the brain, the spinal cord and peripheral nerves (see Fig. 1.7). The structure and organisation of the tissues that form these components enable rapid communication between all parts of the body.</p>
<p>For descriptive purposes the parts of the nervous system are grouped as follows:</p>
<ul>
<li>the central nervous system (CNS), consisting of the brain and the spinal cord</li>
<li>the peripheral nervous system (PNS), consisting of all the nerves outside the brain and spinal
cord. 137.1</li>
</ul>
<p>The PNS comprises paired cranial and spinal nerves. Some of these are sensory (afferent), transmitting impulses to the CNS; some are motor (efferent), transmitting impulses from the CNS; and others are mixed, with both sensory and motor fibres. It is useful to consider two functional parts within the PNS:</p>
<ul>
<li>the sensory division</li>
<li>the motor division (Fig. 7.1).</li>
</ul>
<p>The motor division has two parts:</p>
<ul>
<li>the somatic nervous system, which controls voluntary movement of skeletal muscles</li>
<li>the autonomic nervous system, controlling involuntary processes such as heartbeat, peristalsis (p. 315) and glandular activity. The autonomic nervous system has two divisions: sympathetic and parasympathetic.</li>
</ul>
<p>In summary, the CNS receives sensory information about its internal and external environments from afferent nerves. The CNS integrates and processes this input and responds, when appropriate, by sending nerve impulses through motor nerves to the effector organs: muscles and glands. For example, responses to changes in the internal environment regulate essential involuntary body functions such as respiration and blood pressure; responses to changes in the external environment maintain posture and other voluntary activities.</p>
<p>The first sections of this chapter explore the structure and functions of the components of the nervous system, including the impact of ageing, while the final ones consider the effects on body function when one or more of the components do not function normally.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-e27604bf.jpeg" alt="img-217.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cells-and-tissues-of-the-nervous-system">Cells and tissues of the nervous system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cells-and-tissues-of-the-nervous-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>compare and contrast the structure and functions of myelinated and unmyelinated neurones</li>
<li>state the functions of sensory and motor nerves</li>
<li>explain the events that occur following release of a neurotransmitter at a synapse</li>
<li>briefly describe the functions of four types of neuroglial cell</li>
<li>outline the response of nervous tissue to injury.</li>
</ul>
<p>There are two types of nervous tissue: neurones and neuroglia. Neurones (nerve cells) are the working units of the nervous system that generate and transmit nerve impulses. Neurones are supported by connective tissue, collectively known as neuroglia, which is formed from different types of glial cell. There are vast numbers of both cell types: 1 trillion <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>∧</mo><mo>∧</mo></mrow></msup><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\left(10^{\wedge \wedge}\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0019em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span> glial cells and 10 times fewer <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>∧</mo><mo>∧</mo></mrow></msup><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\left(10^{\wedge \wedge}\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0019em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span> neurones.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="64f49690">Neurones <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">□</mi><mn>7.2</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square 7.2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">□</span><span class="mord">7.2</span></span></span></span></span><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#64f49690" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Each neurone (Fig. 7.2) consists of a cell body and its processes: one axon and, usually, many dendrites. Neurones are commonly referred to as nerve cells. Bundles of axons bound together are called nerves. Neurones cannot divide, and for survival they need a continuous supply of oxygen and glucose. Unlike many other cells, neurones can normally synthesise chemical energy (adenosine triphosphate, or ATP) only from glucose.</p>
<p>Neurones generate and transmit electrical impulses called action potentials. The initial strength of the action potential is maintained throughout the length of the neurone. Some neurones initiate action potentials while others act as 'relay stations' where they are passed on and sometimes redirected.</p>
<p>Action potentials can be initiated in response to stimuli from:</p>
<ul>
<li>outside the body, e.g. touch, light waves</li>
<li>inside the body, e.g. a change in the concentration of carbon dioxide in the blood alters respiration; a thought may result in voluntary movement.</li>
</ul>
<p>Transmission of nerve signals is both electrical and chemical. The action potential travelling down the nerve axon is an electrical signal, but because nerves do not come into direct contact with each other, the signal between a nerve cell and the next cell in the chain is nearly always chemical (p. 157).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-1bf8a4d4.jpeg" alt="img-218.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 7.2 The structure of neurones. Red arrow indicates direction of impulse conduction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cell-bodies">Cell bodies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cell-bodies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Nerve cells vary considerably in size and shape but they are all too small to be seen by the naked eye. Cell bodies form the grey matter of the nervous system and are found at the periphery of the brain and in the centre of the spinal cord. Groups of cell bodies are called nuclei in the CNS and ganglia in the PNS. An important exception is the basal ganglia (nuclei) situated within the cerebrum (p. 167).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="axons-and-dendrites">Axons and dendrites<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#axons-and-dendrites" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Axons and dendrites are extensions of cell bodies and form the white matter of the nervous system. Axons are found deep in the brain and in groups, called tracts, at the periphery of the spinal cord. They are referred to as nerves or nerve fibres outside the brain and spinal cord.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="axons">Axons<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#axons" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Each nerve cell has only one axon, which begins at a tapered area of the cell body, the axon hillock. Axons carry impulses away from the cell body and are usually much longer than the dendrites, sometimes as long as 100 cm .
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-b98cef93.jpeg" alt="img-219.jpeg"></p>
<p>Schwann cell cytoplasm</p>
<p>Schwann cell nucleus
Myelin sheath
Node of Ranvier
Neurilemma
(sheath of Schwann cell)
Nucleus of Schwann cell
Axon
Myelin sheath
Axolemma
Figure 7.3 Arrangement of myelin. (A) Myelinated neurone. (B) Unmyelinated neurone. (C) Length of myelinated axon.</p>
<p>Structure of an axon
The membrane of the axon is called the axolemma and it encloses the cytoplasmic extension of the cell body. Myelinated neurones. Large axons and those of peripheral nerves are surrounded by a myelin sheath (Figs 7.3A and C). This consists of a series of Schwann cells arranged along the length of the axon. Each one is wrapped around the axon so that it is covered by a number of concentric layers of Schwann cell plasma membrane. Between the layers of plasma membrane is a small amount of fatty substance called myelin. The outermost layer of the Schwann cell plasma membrane is the neurilemma. There are tiny areas of exposed axolemma between adjacent Schwann cells, called nodes of Ranvier (see Fig. 7.2), which assist the rapid transmission of action potentials in myelinated neurones. Fig. 7.4 shows a section through a nerve fibre at a node of Ranvier, where the area without myelin can be clearly seen. Unmyelinated neurones. Postganglionic fibres and some small fibres in the CNS are unmyelinated. In this type, several axons are embedded in one Schwann cell (see Fig. 7.3B). The adjacent Schwann cells are in close association and there is no exposed axolemma. Conduction of action potentials is significantly slower in unmyelinated fibres.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="dendrites">Dendrites<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dendrites" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are the many short processes that receive and carry incoming action potentials towards cell bodies. They have the same structure as axons but are usually shorter and branching. In motor neurones dendrites form part of synapses (see Fig. 7.7), and in sensory neurones they form the sensory receptors that respond to specific stimuli.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-9fbbf336.jpeg" alt="img-220.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 7.4 Node of Ranvier. Colour transmission electron micrograph of a longitudinal section of a myelinated nerve fibre. Nerve tissue is shown in blue and myelin in red. (CMEABG - UCBL1, ISM/ Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-action-potential-nerve-impulse-qy-s">The action potential (nerve impulse) Qy.s<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-action-potential-nerve-impulse-qy-s" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>An impulse is initiated by stimulation of sensory nerve endings or by the passage of an impulse from another nerve. Transmission of the action potential is carried out by movement of ions across the nerve cell membrane. In the resting state the nerve cell membrane is polarised due to differences in the concentrations of ions across the plasma membrane. This means that there is a different electrical charge on each side of the membrane, which is called the resting membrane potential. At rest the charge on the outside is positive and inside it is negative. The principal ions involved are:</p>
<ul>
<li>sodium <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\left(\mathrm{Na}^{\wedge}\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.2em; vertical-align: -0.35em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">(</span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Na</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8251em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">)</span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, the main extracellular cation</li>
<li>potassium <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\left(\mathrm{K}^{\wedge}\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0019em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span>, the main intracellular cation.</li>
</ul>
<p>In the resting state there is a continual tendency for these ions to diffuse down their concentration gradients, i.e. outwards and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Na}^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8251em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Na</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8251em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> into cells. When stimulated, the permeability of the nerve cell membrane to these ions changes. In response to the arrival of an action potential, sodium channels in the membrane open and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Na}^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8251em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Na</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8251em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> floods into the neurone from the extracellular fluid. This causes depolarisation and triggers an action potential. Depolarisation is very rapid, enabling the conduction of a nerve impulse along the entire length of a neurone in a few milliseconds. It passes from the point of stimulation in one direction only, i.e. away from the point of stimulation towards the area of resting potential. Action potential transmission along a nerve is one-way because the membrane behind the travelling action potential is temporarily unexcitable (refractory) until repolarisation occurs.</p>
<p>Almost immediately following the entry of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Na}^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8251em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Na</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8251em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> channels open and floods out of the neurone. The movement of these ions returns the membrane potential to its resting state. This is called the refractory period, during which restimulation is not possible. The action of the sodium-potassium pump, which is in continual operation, expels <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Na}^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8251em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Na</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8251em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> from the cell in exchange for (p. 158), returning levels of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Na}^{\wedge}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8251em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Na</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8251em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> and to the original resting state and repolarising the neurone.</p>
<p>In myelinated neurones, the insulating properties of the myelin sheath prevent the movement of ions. Therefore electrical changes across the membrane can occur</p>
<p>only at the gaps in the myelin sheath, i.e. at the nodes of Ranvier (see Fig. 7.2). When an impulse occurs at one node, depolarisation passes along the myelin sheath to the next node, so that the flow of current appears to Teap' from one node to the next. This is called 'saltatory conduction' (Fig. 7.5).</p>
<p>The speed of conduction depends on the diameter of the neurone: the larger the diameter, the faster the conduction.</p>
<p>In addition, myelinated fibres conduct action potentials faster than unmyelinated fibres because saltatory conduction is faster than continuous conduction, or simple propagation (Fig. 7.6). The fastest fibres can conduct action potentials to, for example, skeletal muscles at a rate of 130 metres per second, while the slowest impulses travel at 0.5 metres per second.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-synapse-and-neurotransmitters">The synapse and neurotransmitters<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-synapse-and-neurotransmitters" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>7.4</p>
<p>There is always more than one neurone involved in the transmission of a nerve impulse from its origin to its destination, whether it is sensory or motor. There is no physical contact between two neurones. The point at which the action potential passes from the presynaptic neurone to the postsynaptic neurone is the synapse (Fig. 7.7). At its free end, the axon of the presynaptic neurone breaks up into minute branches that terminate in small swellings called synaptic knobs, or terminal boutons. These are in close proximity to the dendrites and the cell body of the postsynaptic neurone. The space between them is the synaptic cleft. Synaptic knobs contain spherical membrane-bound synaptic vesicles, which store a chemical, the neurotransmitter that is released into the synaptic cleft.
Neurotransmitters are synthesised by nerve cell bodies, actively transported along the axons and stored in the synaptic vesicles. They are released by exocytosis in response to the action potential and diffuse across the synaptic cleft, where they act on specific receptor sites on the postsynaptic membrane. Their action is short-lived because immediately after they have acted on the postsynaptic membrane, they are either inactivated by enzymes or</p>
<p>Axon

<p>Figure 7.7 Synapse. Red arrows indicate direction of action potential.
taken back into the synaptic knob. Some important drugs mimic, neutralise (antagonise) or prolong neurotransmitter activity. Neurotransmitters usually have an excitatory effect on postsynaptic receptors but they are sometimes inhibitory.</p>
<p>There are more than 50 neurotransmitters in the brain and spinal cord, including noradrenaline (norepinephrine), adrenaline (epinephrine), dopamine, histamine, serotonin, gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) and acetylcholine. Other substances, such as enkephalins, endorphins and substance <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">P</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">P</span></span></span></span></span>, have specialised roles in, for example, transmission of pain signals. Fig. 7.8 summarises the main neurotransmitters of the peripheral nervous system.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="nerves">Nerves<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nerves" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A nerve consists of numerous neurones collected into bundles (bundles of nerve fibres in the CNS are known as tracts). For example, large nerves such as the sciatic nerves (p. 181) contain tens of thousands of axons. Each
bundle has several coverings of protective connective tissue (Fig. 7.9):</p>
<ul>
<li>Endoneurium is a delicate tissue surrounding each individual fibre, which is continuous with the septa that pass inwards from the perineurium.</li>
<li>Perineurium is a smooth connective tissue surrounding each bundle of fibres.</li>
<li>Epineurium is the fibrous tissue surrounding and enclosing a number of bundles of nerve fibres. Most large nerves are covered by epineurium.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sensory-or-afferent-nerves">Sensory or afferent nerves<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sensory-or-afferent-nerves" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Sensory nerves carry information from the body to the spinal cord (see Fig. 7.1). The impulses may then pass to the brain or to connector neurones of reflex arcs in the spinal cord (p. 175).</p>
<p>Sensory receptors
Specialised endings of sensory neurones respond to different stimuli (changes) inside and outside the body.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="somatic-cutaneous-or-common-senses">Somatic, cutaneous or common senses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#somatic-cutaneous-or-common-senses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These originate from the skin. They are pain, touch, heat and cold. Sensory nerve endings in the skin are fine branching filaments without myelin sheaths (see Fig. 14.4). When they are stimulated, an action potential is generated and transmitted by the sensory nerves to the brain, where the sensation is perceived.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="proprioceptor-senses">Proprioceptor senses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#proprioceptor-senses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These originate in muscles and joints (Ch. 16). They send information to the brain about the position of the body and its parts in space, enabling maintenance of posture and balance.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="speciai-senses">Speciai senses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#speciai-senses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are sight, hearing, balance, smell and taste, discussed in detail in Chapter 8.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="autonomic-afferent-nerves">Autonomic afferent nerves<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#autonomic-afferent-nerves" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These originate in internal organs, glands and tissues - e.g. the baroreceptors involved in the control of blood pressure (Ch. 5), and the chemoreceptors involved in the control of respiration (Ch. 10) - and are associated with reflex regulation of involuntary activity and visceral pain.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="motor-or-efferent-nerves">Motor or efferent nerves<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#motor-or-efferent-nerves" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Motor nerves originate in the brain, spinal cord and autonomic ganglia. They transmit impulses to the effector organs: muscles and glands (see Fig. 7.1). There are two types:</p>
<ul>
<li>somatic nerves - involved in voluntary and reflex skeletal muscle contraction</li>
</ul>
<p>Type of nerve <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi><mrow><mo fence="true">[</mo><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∧</mo></msup></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{J}\left[{ }^{\wedge}\right.</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0019em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">J</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">[</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∧</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span> Spinal cord

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id=""><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span></span></span></span></span>.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1">1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-c0c512a1.jpeg" alt="img-223.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 7.9 Transverse section of a peripheral nerve showing the protective connective tissue coverings.</p>
<ul>
<li>autonomic nerves (sympathetic and parasympathetic) involved in cardiac and smooth muscle contraction and glandular secretion, all involuntary functions.</li>
</ul>
<p>There may be one or two nerves involved in motor nerve pathways in the PNS (see Fig. 7.8). Somatic motor nerve pathways, which supply skeletal (voluntary) muscle, have only one neurone, which leaves the spinal cord and travels directly to the skeletal muscle. This nerve is called the lower motor neurone (p. 174); its synapse with the muscle is specifically named the neuromuscular junction (p. 456) and the neurotransmitter is always acetylcholine. Autonomic nerve pathways (p. 186) involve two nerves, the preganglionic neurone that leaves the spinal cord and synapses with a second nerve, the postganglionic neurone, which in turn synapses with the effector tissue, e.g. cardiac muscle, smooth muscle or glands. The main neurotransmitters in these pathways are noradrenaline (norepinephrine) and acetylcholine.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mixed-nerves">Mixed nerves<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mixed-nerves" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In the spinal cord, sensory and motor nerves are arranged in separate groups, or tracts. Outside the spinal cord, when sensory and motor nerves are enclosed within the same sheath of connective tissue, they are called mixed nerves.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-247f84ca.jpeg" alt="img-224.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-e799dc1c.jpeg" alt="img-225.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 7.11 Star-shaped astrocytes in the cerebral cortex.
(Standring S, 2004 Gray's anatomy: the anatomical basis of clinical practice, 39th edn. Edinburgh: Churchill Livingstone. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<p>Figure 7.10 Neurones and glial cells. Stained light micrograph of neurones (gold) and nuclei of the more numerous glial cells (blue). (Young B, Lowe JS, Stevens A et al. 2006 Wheater's functional histology: a text and colour atlas. Edinburgh: Churchill Livingstone. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="neuroglia">Neuroglia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#neuroglia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The neurones of the CNS are supported by non-excitable glial cells (Fig. 7.10). Unlike nerve cells, which cannot divide, glial cells continue to replicate throughout life. There are four types: astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, ependymal cells and microglia.</p>
<p>Astrocytes
These cells are the most abundant neuroglia (Fig. 7.11). They are star-shaped with fine branching processes and they lie in a mucopolysaccharide ground substance. At the free ends of some of the processes there are small swellings called foot processes. Astrocytes are found in large numbers adjacent to blood vessels, with their foot processes forming a sleeve round them. This means that the blood is separated from the neurones by the capillary wall and a layer of astrocyte foot processes, which together constitute the blood-brain barrier (Fig. 7.12).</p>
<p>The blood-brain barrier is a selective barrier that protects the brain from potentially toxic substances and chemical variations in the blood, e.g. after a meal. Oxygen, carbon dioxide, glucose and other lipid-soluble substances, such as alcohol, quickly cross the barrier into the brain. Some large molecules, many drugs, inorganic ions and amino acids pass more slowly, or do not pass at all, from the blood to the brain.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-8e16e9a9.jpeg" alt="img-226.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 7.12 Blood-brain barrier. (A) Longitudinal section. (B) Transverse section.</p>
<p>Oligodendrocytes
These cells are smaller than astrocytes. They are found in clusters round nerve cell bodies in grey matter and are located adjacent to, and along the length of, myelinated nerve fibres. Like Schwann cells in the PNS, oligodendrocytes form and maintain myelin in the CNS.</p>
<p>These cells form the epithelial lining of the ventricles of the brain and the central canal of the spinal cord. Those cells that form the choroid plexuses of the ventricles secrete cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Some also have cilia that assist the flow of CSF.</p>
<p>Microglia
The smallest and least numerous glial cells, these cells are
Ependymal cells
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-6eb6478c.jpeg" alt="img-227.jpeg">
thought to be derived from monocytes that migrate from the blood into the nervous system before birth. They are dispersed throughout the brain. They migrate and</p>
<p>become phagocytic, removing microbes and damaged tissue, in areas of inflammation and cell destruction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="response-of-nervous-tissue-to-injury">Response of nervous tissue to injury<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#response-of-nervous-tissue-to-injury" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A Cut ends in apposition
Unlike neuroglia, which have the capacity to reproduce, neurones reach maturity a few weeks after birth and cannot divide.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-f63ab03d.jpeg" alt="img-228.jpeg"></p>
<p>Damage to neurones can lead either to rapid necrosis with sudden acute functional failure, or to slow atrophy with gradually increasing dysfunction. These changes may result from:</p>
<ul>
<li>hypoxia and anoxia</li>
<li>nutritional deficiencies</li>
<li>poisons, e.g. organic lead</li>
<li>trauma</li>
<li>infections</li>
<li>ageing</li>
<li>hypoglycaemia.</li>
</ul>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="central-nervous-system">Central nervous system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#central-nervous-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The CNS consists of the brain and the spinal cord (see Fig. 7.1). These essential structures are both well protected from damage and injury: the brain is enclosed within the skull and the spinal cord by the vertebrae that form the spinal column. Membranous coverings called the meninges provide further protection. The structure and functions of the meninges, brain and spinal cord are explored in this section.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="meninges-and-cerebrospinal-fluid">Meninges and cerebrospinal fluid<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#meninges-and-cerebrospinal-fluid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the structure of the meninges</li>
<li>describe the flow of cerebrospinal fluid in the brain</li>
<li>list the functions of cerebrospinal fluid.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="meninges">Meninges<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#meninges" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The brain and spinal cord are completely surrounded by three layers of tissue, the meninges (Fig. 7.14), lying between the skull and the brain, and between the vertebral foramina and the spinal cord. Named from outside inwards, they are the:</p>
<ul>
<li>dura mater</li>
<li>arachnoid mater</li>
<li>pia mater.</li>
</ul>
<p>In the brain, two spaces are associated with the meninges:</p>
<ul>
<li>the subdural space - this is a potential space that lies between the dural and arachnoid maters, and contains a very small amount of serous fluid</li>
<li>the subarachnoid space - this separates the arachnoid and pia maters, and contains cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).</li>
</ul>
<p>These continue into the spinal canal, which contains an additional space: the epidural space (see Fig. 7.26).</p>
<p>Dura mater
The cerebral dura mater consists of two layers of dense fibrous tissue. The outer layer takes the place of the</p>
<p>periosteum on the inner surface of the skull bones and the inner layer provides a protective covering for the brain. There is only a potential space between the two layers, except where the inner layer sweeps inwards, forming membranous extensions that partially divide the cranial cavity:</p>
<ul>
<li>the falx cerebri, which separates the two cerebral hemispheres (see Fig. 7.14).</li>
<li>the falx cerebelli, which separates the two cerebellar hemispheres</li>
<li>the tentorium (meaning Tent-like') cerebelli, which separates the cerebrum and the cerebellum (see Fig. 7.14).</li>
</ul>
<p>Venous blood from the brain drains into venous sinuses between the two layers of dura mater. The superior sagittal sinus is formed by the falx cerebri, and the tentorium cerebelli forms the straight and transverse sinuses (see Fig. 5.33).</p>
<p>Spinal dura mater forms a loose sheath round the spinal cord, extending from the foramen magnum to the 2nd sacral vertebra. Thereafter it encloses the filum terminale and fuses with the periosteum of the coccyx. It is an extension of the inner layer of cerebral dura mater and is separated from the periosteum of the vertebrae and ligaments within the neural canal by the epidural space (see Fig. 7.26), containing blood vessels and areolar connective tissue. It is attached to the foramen magnum and by strands of fibrous tissue to the posterior longitudinal ligament at intervals along its length. Nerves entering and leaving the spinal cord pass through the epidural space. These attachments stabilise the spinal cord in the neural canal. Dyes, used for diagnostic purposes, and local anaesthetics or analgesics to relieve pain may be injected into the epidural space.</p>
<p>Arachnoid mater
This is a layer of fibrous tissue that lies between the dura and pia maters. It is separated from the dura mater by the subdural space, which contains a small amount of serous fluid, and from the pia mater by the subarachnoid space, which contains CSF. The arachnoid mater passes over the convolutions of the brain and accompanies the inner layer of dura mater in the formation of the falx cerebri, tentorium cerebelli and falx cerebelli. It continues downwards to envelop the spinal cord (see Fig. 7.25) and ends by merging with the dura mater at the level of the 2nd sacral vertebra.</p>
<p>Pia mater
This is a delicate layer of connective tissue containing many minute blood vessels. It adheres to the brain, completely covering the convolutions and dipping into each fissure. It continues downwards, surrounding the spinal cord (see Fig. 7.25). Beyond the end of the cord it continues as the filum terminale, pierces the arachnoid tube and goes on, with the dura mater, to fuse with the periosteum of the coccyx (see Fig. 7.26).</p>
<p>Superior sagittal venous sinus
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-9dbf1b2f.jpeg" alt="img-229.jpeg"></p>
