<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ventricles-of-the-brain-and-the-cerebrospinal-fluid-pi-7-5">Ventricles of the brain and the cerebrospinal fluid PI 7.5<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ventricles-of-the-brain-and-the-cerebrospinal-fluid-pi-7-5" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The brain contains four irregular-shaped cavities, or ventricles, containing CSF (Fig. 7.15). They are the:</p>
<ul>
<li>right and left lateral ventricles</li>
<li>third ventricle</li>
<li>fourth ventricle.</li>
</ul>
<p>Lateral ventricles
These cavities lie within the cerebral hemispheres, one on each side of the median plane just below the corpus callosum. They are separated from each other by a thin membrane, the septum lucidum, and are lined with ciliated epithelium. They communicate with the third ventricle by interventricular foramina.</p>
<p>The third ventricle is a cavity situated below the lateral ventricles between the two parts of the thalamus. It
communicates with the fourth ventricle by a canal, the cerebral aqueduct.
Fourth ventricle
The fourth ventricle is a diamond-shaped cavity situated below and behind the third ventricle, between the cerebellum and pons. It is continuous below with the central canal of the spinal cord and communicates with the subarachnoid space by foramina in its roof. CSF enters the subarachnoid space through these openings.</p>
<p>Cerebrospinal fluid
CSF circulates constantly from the ventricles through the subarachnoid space around the brain and spinal cord.</p>
<p>CSF is a clear, slightly alkaline fluid with a specific gravity of 1.005 , consisting of:</p>
<ul>
<li>water</li>
<li>mineral salts</li>
<li>glucose</li>
<li>plasma proteins: small amounts of albumin and globulin
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-a52498c3.jpeg" alt="img-230.jpeg"></li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 7.15 The ventricles of the brain. (A) Viewed from the left side. (B) Anterior view.</p>
<ul>
<li>a few leukocytes</li>
<li>small amounts of creatinine</li>
<li>small amounts of urea.</li>
</ul>
<p>CSF is secreted into each ventricle of the brain by choroid plexuses. These are vascular areas that are rich in blood vessels and surrounded by ependymal cells in the lining of ventricle walls. CSF passes back into the blood through tiny fingerlike projections of arachnoid mater, called arachnoid villi (arachnoid granulations, see Fig. 7.14B), which project into the venous sinuses. The movement of CSF from the subarachnoid space to venous sinuses depends on the difference in pressure on each side of the walls of the arachnoid villi, which act as one-way valves. When CSF pressure is higher than venous pressure, CSF is pushed into the blood, and when the venous pressure is higher, the arachnoid villi collapse, preventing the passage of blood constituents into the CSF. There may also be some reabsorption of CSF by cells in the walls of the ventricles.</p>
<p>From the roof of the fourth ventricle, CSF flows through foramina into the subarachnoid space and completely</p>
<p>Superior sagittal sinus Arachnoid villus
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-4aa571e0.jpeg" alt="img-231.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 7.16 Frontal section of the skull. Black arrows, Flow of cerebrospinal fluid.
surrounds the brain and spinal cord (Fig. 7.16). There is no discrete CSF pump, but its movement is aided by pulsating blood vessels, respiration and changes of posture.</p>
<p>CSF is secreted continuously at a rate of about 0.5 mL per minute, i.e. 720 mL per day. The volume remains fairly constant at about 150 mL , as absorption keeps pace with secretion. CSF may be sampled by inserting a needle into the subarachnoid space above or below the 4th lumbar vertebra, which is about 2 cm below the end of the spinal cord. This procedure is known as a lumbar puncture; CSF pressure can be measured by attaching a vertical tube to the needle.</p>
<p>The pressure remains fairly constant at about 10 cm H 2 O when lying on one side and about 30 cm H 2 O when sitting up. If the brain is enlarged by, for example, haemorrhage or tumour, some compensation is made by a reduction in the amount of CSF. When the volume of brain tissue is reduced, such as in degeneration or atrophy, the volume of CSF is increased.</p>
<p>Functions of cerebrospinal fiuid
CSF supports and protects the brain and spinal cord by maintaining a uniform pressure around these vital structures and by acting as a cushion or shock absorber between the brain and the skull.</p>
<p>CSF keeps the brain and spinal cord moist and there may be exchange of nutrients and waste products between CSF and the interstitial fluid of the brain. CSF is involved in regulation of breathing, as it bathes the surface of the medulla where the central respiratory chemoreceptors are located (Ch. 10).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="brain">Brain<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#brain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the blood supply to the brain</li>
<li>name the lobes and principal sulci of the brain</li>
<li>outline the functions of the cerebrum</li>
<li>identify the main sensory and motor areas of the cerebrum</li>
<li>outline the position and functions of the thalamus and hypothalamus</li>
<li>describe the position and functions of the midbrain, pons, medulla oblongata and reticular activating system</li>
<li>describe the structure and functions of the cerebellum.</li>
</ul>
<p>The brain is a large organ weighing around 1.4 kg , which lies within the cranial cavity. Its parts are (Fig. 7.17) the:</p>
<p>cerebrum thalamus hypothalamus midbrain pons
medulla oblongata cerebellum 137.6 .
the diencephalon
the brain stun</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="blood-supply-and-venous-drainage">Blood supply and venous drainage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-supply-and-venous-drainage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The circulus arteriosus and its contributing arteries (see Fig. 5.31) play a vital role in maintaining a constant supply of oxygen and glucose to the brain when the head is moved and also when a contributing artery is narrowed. The brain receives about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>15</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">15 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">15%</span></span></span></span></span> of the cardiac output, approximately 750 mL of blood per minute. Autoregulation of cerebral arteriolar diameter maintains a constant blood flow to the brain, compensating for fluctuations in systemic blood pressure. This mechanism protects the brain, provided that systemic blood pressure remains within the <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>65</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>140</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">65-140 \mathrm{mmHg}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">65</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">140</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mmHg</span></span></span></span></span></span> range.</p>
<p>Venous blood from the brain drains into the dural venous sinuses and then downwards into the internal jugular veins (see Fig. 5.33).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cerebrum">Cerebrum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cerebrum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the largest part of the brain and it occupies the anterior and middle cranial fossae (see Fig. 16.12). It is divided by a deep cleft, the longitudinal cerebral fissure, into right and left cerebral hemispheres, each containing one of the lateral ventricles. Deep within the brain, the hemispheres are connected by a mass of white matter (nerve fibres) called the corpus callosum. The falx cerebri is formed by the dura mater (see Fig. 7.14). It separates the two cerebral hemispheres and penetrates to the depth of the corpus callosum. The superficial part of the cerebrum is composed of nerve cell bodies (grey matter), forming the cerebral cortex, and the deeper layers consist of nerve fibres (axons, white matter).</p>
<p>The surface of the cerebral cortex shows many infoldings or furrows of varying depth. The exposed areas of the folds are the gyri (convolutions) and these are separated by sulci (fissures). These convolutions greatly increase the surface area of the cerebrum.</p>
<p>For descriptive purposes, each hemisphere of the cerebrum is divided into lobes, which take the names of the bones of the cranium above them:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>frontal</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>parietal</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>temporal</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>occipital.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>The boundaries of the lobes are marked by deep sulci. These are the central, lateral and parieto-occipital sulci (Fig. 7.18).</p>
<p>Cerebral tracts and basal ganglia
The surface of the cerebral cortex is composed of grey matter (nerve cell bodies). Within the cerebrum the lobes are connected by masses of nerve fibres, or tracts, which make up the white matter of the brain (Fig. 7.19). The afferent and efferent fibres linking the different parts of the brain and spinal cord are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Association (arcuate) tracts, which are most numerous and connect different parts of a cerebral hemisphere by extending from one gyrus to another, some of which are adjacent and some distant.</li>
<li>Commissural tracts, which connect corresponding areas of the two cerebral hemispheres; the largest and most important commissure is the corpus callosum.</li>
<li>Projection tracts, which connect the cerebral cortex with grey matter of lower parts of the brain and with the spinal cord, e.g. the internal capsule.</li>
</ul>
<p>The internal capsule (Fig. 7.19) is an important projection tract that lies deep within the brain between the basal ganglia and the thalamus. Many nerve impulses passing to and from the cerebral cortex are carried by fibres that form the internal capsule. Motor fibres within the internal capsule form the pyramidal tracts (corticospinal tracts) that cross</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

over (decussate) at the medulla oblongata and are the main pathway to skeletal muscles. Those motor fibres that do not pass through the internal capsule form the extrapyramidal tracts and have connections with many parts of the brain, including the basal ganglia, thalamus and cerebellum.</p>
<p>Basal ganglia
The basal ganglia are groups of cell bodies that lie deep within the brain and form part of the extrapyramidal tracts. They act as relay stations with connections to many parts of the brain, including motor areas of the cerebral cortex and thalamus. Their functions include initiation and fine control of complex movement and learned coordinated activities, such as posture and walking. If control is inadequate or absent, movements are jerky, clumsy and uncoordinated.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-the-cerebral-cortex">Functions of the cerebral cortex<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-the-cerebral-cortex" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There are three main types of activity associated with the cerebral cortex:</p>
<ul>
<li>higher-order functions, e.g. language, memory, sense of responsibility, thinking, reasoning, moral decision making and learning</li>
<li>sensory perception, including the perception of pain, temperature, touch, sight, hearing, taste and smell</li>
<li>initiation and control of skeletal muscle contraction and therefore voluntary movement.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functional-areas-of-the-cerebral-cortex-07-7">Functional areas of the cerebral cortex 07.7<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functional-areas-of-the-cerebral-cortex-07-7" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The main functional areas of the cerebral cortex (Fig. 7.20) have been identified but it is unlikely that any area is associated exclusively with one function. Except where</p>
<p>Primary motor area Central sulcus
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-8045150b.jpeg" alt="img-235.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 7.20 The cerebrum showing the main functional areas.
Viewed from the left side.
specially mentioned, the different areas are active in both hemispheres; however, there is some variation between individuals. There are different types of functional area:</p>
<ul>
<li>motor, which direct skeletal (voluntary) muscle movements</li>
<li>sensory, which receive and decode sensory impulses, enabling sensory perception</li>
<li>association, which are concerned with integration and processing of complex mental functions such as intelligence, memory, reasoning, judgement and emotions.</li>
</ul>
<p>In general, areas of the cortex lying anterior to the central sulcus are associated with motor functions, and those lying posterior to it are associated with sensory functions.</p>
<p>Motor areas of the cerebral cortex Primary motor area
This lies in the frontal lobe, immediately anterior to the central sulcus. The cell bodies are pyramid-shaped and they control skeletal muscle activity. Two neurones are involved in the pathway to skeletal muscle. The first, the upper motor neurone, descends from the motor cortex through the internal capsule to the medulla oblongata. Here it crosses to the opposite side and descends in the spinal cord. At the appropriate level in the spinal cord it synapses with a second neurone (the lower motor neurone), which leaves the spinal cord and travels to the target muscle. It terminates at the motor end-plate of a muscle fibre (Fig. 7.21). This means that the motor area of the right hemisphere of the cerebrum controls voluntary muscle movement on the left side of the body and vice versa. Damage to either of these neurones may result in paralysis.</p>
<p>In the motor area of the cerebrum the body is represented upside down, i.e. the uppermost cells control the feet and those in the lowest part control the head, neck, face and fingers (Fig. 7.22A). The sizes of the areas of the cerebral cortex representing different parts of the body are proportional to the complexity of movement of the body part, not to its size. Fig. 7.22A shows that - in comparison with the trunk - the hand, foot, tongue and lips are represented by large cortical areas, reflecting the greater degree of motor control associated with these areas.</p>
<p>Motor speech (Broca's) area
This is situated in the frontal lobe just above the lateral sulcus and controls the muscle movements needed for speech. It is dominant in the left hemisphere in right-handed people and</p>
<p>Sensory areas of the cerebral cortex Somatosensory area
This is the area immediately behind the central sulcus, where sensations of pain, temperature, pressure and touch, awareness of muscular movement and the position of
vice versa.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-66dbb920.jpeg" alt="img-236.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 7.21 The motor nerve pathways. Upper and lower motor neurones.
joints (proprioception) are perceived. The somatosensory area of the right hemisphere receives impulses from the left side of the body and vice versa. The size of the cortical areas representing different parts of the body (Fig. 7.22B) is proportional to the extent of sensory innervation; for example, the large area for the face is consistent with the extensive sensory nerve supply by the three branches of the trigeminal nerves (5th cranial nerves).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="auditory-hearing-area">Auditory (hearing) area<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#auditory-hearing-area" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This lies immediately below the lateral sulcus within the temporal lobe. The nerve cells receive and interpret impulses transmitted from the inner ear by the cochlear (auditory) part of the vestibulocochlear nerves (8th cranial nerves).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="olfactory-smell-area">Olfactory (smell) area<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#olfactory-smell-area" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This lies deep within the temporal lobe, where impulses from the olfactory epithelium of the nose, transmitted via the olfactory nerves (1st cranial nerves), are received and interpreted.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="taste-area">Taste area<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#taste-area" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This lies just above the lateral sulcus in the deep layers of the somatosensory area. Here, impulses from sensory receptors in taste buds are received and perceived as taste.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="visual-area">Visual area<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#visual-area" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This lies behind the parieto-occipital sulcus and includes the greater part of the occipital lobe. The optic nerves (2nd cranial nerves) pass from the eye to this area, which receives and interprets the impulses as visual impressions.</p>
<p>Association areas</p>
<p>These are connected to each other and other areas of the cerebral cortex by association tracts and some are outlined here. They receive, coordinate and interpret impulses from the sensory and motor cortices, permitting higher cognitive abilities. Although Fig. 7.23 depicts some of the areas involved, their functions are much more complex.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="premotor-area">Premotor area<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#premotor-area" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This lies in the frontal lobe, immediately anterior to the motor area. The neurones here coordinate movement initiated by the primary motor cortex, ensuring that learned patterns of movement can be repeated. For example, in tying a shoelace or writing, many muscles contract but the movements must be coordinated and carried out in a particular sequence. Such a pattern of movement, when established, is described as manual dexterity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="prefrontal-area">Prefrontal area<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#prefrontal-area" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This extends anteriorly from the premotor area to include the remainder of the frontal lobe. It is a large area and is more highly developed in humans than in other animals. Intellectual functions controlled here include perception and comprehension of the passage of time, the ability to anticipate consequences of events and the normal management of emotions.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="sensory-speech-wernicke-s-area">Sensory speech (Wernicke's) area<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sensory-speech-wernicke-s-area" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This is situated in the temporal lobe, adjacent to the parieto-occipital area. It is here that language, both written and spoken, is perceived, and comprehension and intelligence are based. Understanding language is central to higher mental functions, as they are language-based. This area is dominant in the left hemisphere in right-handed people and vice versa.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="parieto-occipital-area">Parieto-occipital area<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#parieto-occipital-area" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This lies behind the somatosensory area and includes most of the parietal lobe (including Wernicke's area). Its functions are thought to include spatial awareness, interpretation of language and the ability to name objects (Fig. 7.23). It has been suggested that objects can be recognised by touch alone because of the knowledge from past experience (memory) retained in this area.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="diencephalon">Diencephalon<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diencephalon" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The diencephalon (see Fig. 7.17) connects the cerebrum and the midbrain. It consists of several structures situated around the third ventricle, the main ones being the thalamus.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-1c351e75.jpeg" alt="img-237.jpeg"></p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="motor">Motor<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#motor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Planning complex movements and Speech
thinking production</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a">A<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Behaviour,
. emotions, motivation</p>
<p>Somato- Spatial awareness sensory of body and
surroundings</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="language">Language<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#language" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="understanding">Understanding<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#understanding" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Auditory intelligence processing
-B of words
Naming of
objects Vision
Figure 7.23 Areas of the cerebral cortex involved in higher mental functions. (A) Motor speech (Broca's) area. (B) Sensory speech (Wernicke's) area. (C) Parietooccipital area.
and hypothalamus, which are considered here. The pineal gland (p. 247) and the optic chiasma (see Fig. 7.40) are also situated there.</p>
<p>Thalamus
This consists of two masses of grey and white matter situated within the cerebral hemispheres just below the corpus callosum, one on each side of the third ventricle (see Fig. 7.19). Sensory receptors in the skin and viscera send information about touch, pain and temperature, and
input from the special sense organs travels to the thalamus, where there is recognition, although only in a basic form, as refined perception also involves other parts of the brain. The thalamus is thought to be involved in arousal, and the processing of some emotions and complex reflexes. It relays and redistributes impulses from most parts of the brain to the cerebral cortex.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hypothalamus">Hypothalamus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypothalamus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The hypothalamus (see Fig. 7.17) is a small but important structure, which weighs around 7 g and consists of a number of nuclei. It is situated below and in front of the thalamus, immediately above the pituitary gland. The hypothalamus is linked to the posterior lobe of the pituitary gland by nerve fibres and to the anterior lobe by a complex system of blood vessels (see Figs 9.2 and 9.3). Through these connections the hypothalamus controls the output of hormones from both anterior and posterior lobes of the pituitary gland (p. 235). Other functions of the hypothalamus include control of:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>effectors of the autonomic nervous system (p. 186)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>appetite and satiety</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>thirst and water balance</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>body temperature (p.397)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>emotional reactions, e.g. pleasure, fear, rage, sexual arousal</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>circadian rhythms, including sleeping and waking cycles.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="brain-stem">Brain stem<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#brain-stem" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is shown in Fig. 7.17.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="midbrain">Midbrain<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#midbrain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The midbrain is the area of the brain situated around the cerebral aqueduct (see Fig. 7.15) between the cerebrum above and the pons below. It consists of nuclei and nerve fibres (tracts), which connect the cerebrum with lower parts of the brain and with the spinal cord. The nuclei act as relay stations for the ascending and descending nerve fibres and have important roles in auditory and visual reflexes.</p>
<p>Pons
The pons is situated in front of the cerebellum, below the midbrain and above the medulla oblongata. It consists mainly of nerve fibres (white matter) that form a bridge between the two hemispheres of the cerebellum, and of fibres passing between the higher levels of the brain and the spinal cord. The pons also processes information from several of the cranial nerves, including the 5th cranial nerve (sensory information from the face, scalp, mouth and nose, and motor control of chewing) and 8th cranial nerve (hearing and balance). In addition, the pons contains the pneumotaxic area that operates in conjunction with the respiratory centre in the medulla oblongata to control respiration (Ch. 10).</p>
<p>The anatomical structure of the pons is opposite to that of the cerebrum, in that the cell bodies (grey matter) lie deeply and the nerve fibres are on the surface.</p>
<p>Medulla oblongata
The medulla oblongata, or simply the medulla, is the most inferior region of the brain stem (Fig. 7.24; see also Fig. 7.17). Extending from the pons above, it is continuous with the spinal cord below. It is about 2.5 cm long and lies just within the cranium, above the foramen magnum. Its anterior and posterior surfaces are marked by central fissures. The outer aspect is composed of white matter, which passes between the brain and the spinal cord, and grey matter, which lies centrally. Some medullary nerves relay information from the special senses of hearing and balance to higher centres in the brain.</p>
<p>The vital centres, consisting of groups of cell bodies (nuclei) associated with autonomic reflex activity, lie in its deeper structure. These are the:</p>
<ul>
<li>cardiovascular centre</li>
<li>respiratory centre</li>
<li>reflex centres of vomiting, coughing, sneezing and swallowing.</li>
</ul>
<p>The medulla oblongata has several special features.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-6898ae05.jpeg" alt="img-238.jpeg"></p>
<p>B Left hemisphere Right hemisphere
Figure 7.24 The cerebellum. (A) Showing associated structures. (B) Posterior view.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="decussation-crossing-of-the-pyramids">Decussation (crossing) of the pyramids<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#decussation-crossing-of-the-pyramids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In the medulla, motor nerves descending from the motor area in the cerebrum to the spinal cord in the pyramidal (corticospinal) tracts cross from one side to the other. This means that the left hemisphere of the cerebrum controls the right half of the body and vice versa. These tracts are the main pathways to skeletal (voluntary) muscles.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sensory-decussation">Sensory decussation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sensory-decussation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Some of the sensory nerves ascending to the cerebrum from the spinal cord cross from one side to the other in the medulla. Others decussate lower down in the spinal cord.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cardiovascuiar-centre">Cardiovascuiar centre<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cardiovascuiar-centre" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The cardiovascular centre (CVC) controls blood pressure, and the rate and force of cardiac contraction (p. 98). Within the CVC, other groups of nerve cells forming the vasomotor centre control the diameter of the blood vessels, especially the small arteries and arterioles. The vasomotor centre is stimulated by the arterial baroreceptors, body temperature and emotions such as sexual arousal and anger. Pain usually causes vasoconstriction, although severe pain may cause vasodilation, a fall in blood pressure and fainting.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="respiratory-centre">Respiratory centre<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#respiratory-centre" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This area controls the rate and depth of respiration. From here, nerve impulses pass to the phrenic and intercostal nerves, which stimulate contraction of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles, thus initiating inspiration. It functions in close association with the pneumotaxic area in the pons
(p. 281).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reflex-centres">Reflex centres<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reflex-centres" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Irritants in the stomach or respiratory tract stimulate the medulla oblongata, activating the reflex centres. Vomiting, coughing and sneezing are protective reflexes that attempt to expel irritants.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reticular-formation">Reticular formation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reticular-formation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The reticular formation is a collection of neurones in the core of the brain stem, surrounded by numerous and diffuse neural pathways that conduct ascending and descending nerve impulses between the brain and the spinal cord. It has a vast number of synaptic links with other parts of the brain and is therefore constantly receiving 'information' being transmitted in ascending and descending tracts.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reticular-activating-system">Reticular activating system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reticular-activating-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The reticular activating system (RAS) consists of areas within the reticular formation that, when activated, bring about increased stimulation of the cerebral cortex, accompanied by arousal and increased alertness, although the mechanisms involved are poorly understood. The RAS also mediates selective awareness, meaning that it selectively blocks or permits transmission of sensory information to the cerebral cortex; for example, the slightest noise made by a sick child moving in bed may arouse a sleeping mother but the noise of regularly passing trains does not disturb her.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cerebellum">Cerebellum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cerebellum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The cerebellum (Fig. 7.24) is situated behind the pons and immediately below the posterior portion of the cerebrum occupying the posterior cranial fossa. It is ovoid in shape and has two hemispheres, separated by a narrow median strip called the</p>
<p>vermis. Grey matter forms the surface of the cerebellum, and the white matter lies deeply.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The cerebellum controls and coordinates the movements of various groups of skeletal muscles, ensuring smooth, even and precise actions. Cerebellar activity is not under voluntary control. It coordinates activities associated with the maintenance of posture, balance and equilibrium. The sensory input for these functions is derived from the muscles, joints, eyes and ears. Proprioceptor impulses from the stretch receptors in the muscles and joints indicate their position in relation to the body as a whole; the eyes and the semicircular canals in the ears provide information about
the position of the head in space. The cerebellum integrates this information and regulates skeletal muscle activity so that balance and posture are maintained.</p>
<p>The cerebellum may also have a role in learning and language processing.
Damage to the cerebellum results in clumsy, uncoordinated muscular movement, staggering gait and inability to carry out smooth, steady and precise movements.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spinal-cord">Spinal cord<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spinal-cord" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the gross structure of the spinal cord</li>
<li>state the functions of the sensory (afferent) and motor (efferent) nerve tracts in the spinal cord</li>
<li>explain the events of a simple reflex arc.</li>
</ul>
<p>The spinal cord is an elongated, almost cylindrical part of the CNS, which is suspended in the vertebral canal surrounded by the meninges and CSF (Fig. 7.25). The meninges are described on page 162. The spinal cord is continuous above with the medulla oblongata and extends from the upper border of the atlas (first cervical vertebra) to the lower border of the 1st lumbar vertebra (Fig. 7.26). It is approximately 45 cm long in adult males and is about the thickness of the little finger.</p>
<p>Except for the cranial nerves, the spinal cord is the nervous tissue link between the brain and the rest of the body (Fig. 7.27). Nerves conveying impulses from the brain to the various organs and tissues descend through the spinal cord. At the appropriate level they leave the cord between</p>

<p>Figure 7.28 A transverse section of the spinal cord showing nerve roots.
adjacent vertebrae and pass to the structure they supply. Similarly, sensory nerves from organs and tissues enter and pass upwards in the spinal cord to the brain.</p>
<p>Some activities of the spinal cord are independent of the brain and are controlled at the level of the spinal cord by spinal reflexes. To facilitate these, there are extensive neurone connections between sensory and motor neurones at the same or different levels in the cord.</p>
<p>A cross-section of the spinal cord shows that it is almost completely divided into two equal parts: anteriorly by a short, shallow median fissure and posteriorly by a deep narrow septum, the posterior median septum. It is composed of grey matter in the centre surrounded by white matter supported by neuroglia. Two bundles of nerve fibres merge into each side of the spinal cord. Known as nerve roots, those of the dorsal (or posterior) nerve roots carry sensory nerve impulses into the spinal cord while the fibres of the ventral (or anterior) nerve root carry motor impulses away from the spinal cord. Fig. 7.28 shows the parts of the spinal cord and the nerve roots. 7.8</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="grey-matter">Grey matter<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#grey-matter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The arrangement of grey matter in the spinal cord resembles the shape of the letter H , having two posterior, two anterior and two lateral columns. The grey columns extend the length of the spinal cord, containing the cell bodies of the neurones that run up and down the cord. The area of grey matter lying transversely is the</p>
<p>transverse commissure and it is pierced by the central canal, an extension from the fourth ventricle containing CSF. The nerve cell bodies may belong to:</p>
<ul>
<li>sensory neurones, which receive impulses from the periphery of the body</li>
<li>lower motor neurones, which transmit impulses to the skeletal muscles</li>
<li>interneurones, which directly link a sensory and a motor neurone to form a reflex arc.</li>
</ul>
<p>The sensory and motor nerves may enter and leave the spinal cord at the same or at different levels.</p>
<p>Posterior columns of grey matter
These are composed of the cell bodies of sensory nerves, which carry information from the body up to the brain. The nerve fibres of these cells contribute to the white matter of the cord and transmit the sensory impulses upwards to the brain. The posterior (dorsal) root ganglia are formed by the cell bodies of the sensory nerves.</p>
<p>Anterior columns of grey matter
These are composed of the cell bodies of the lower motor neurones that are stimulated by the upper motor neurones or the interneurones linking the anterior and posterior columns to form reflex arcs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="white-matter">White matter<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#white-matter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The white matter of the spinal cord is arranged in three columns or tracts: anterior, posterior and lateral. These tracts are formed by sensory nerve fibres ascending to the brain, motor nerve fibres descending from the brain and fibres of interneurones.</p>
<p>Tracts are often named according to their points of origin and destination, e.g. spinothalamic, corticospinal.</p>
<p>Sensory nerve tracts in the spinal cord
Neurones that transmit impulses towards the brain are called sensory (afferent, ascending). There are two main sources of sensation transmitted to the brain via the spinal cord.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-skin">The skin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-skin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Sensory receptors (nerve endings) in the skin are stimulated by pain, heat, cold and touch, including pressure (Ch. 14). The nerve impulses generated are conducted by three neurones to the sensory area in the opposite hemisphere of the cerebrum where the sensation and its location are perceived (Fig. 7.29). Crossing to the other</p>
<p>side, or decussation, occurs either at the level of entry into the cord or in the medulla.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-tendons-muscles-and-joints">The tendons, muscles and joints<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-tendons-muscles-and-joints" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Sensory receptors are specialised nerve endings in these structures, called proprioceptors, and they are stimulated by stretch. Together with impulses from the eyes and the ears, they are associated with the maintenance of balance and posture, and with perception of the position of the body in space. These nerve impulses have two destinations:</p>
<ul>
<li>By a three-neurone system, the impulses reach the sensory area of the opposite hemisphere of the cerebrum.</li>
<li>By a two-neurone system, the nerve impulses reach the cerebellar hemisphere on the same side.</li>
</ul>
<p>Table 7.1 summarises the main sensory pathways.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="motor-nerve-tracts-in-the-spinal-cord">Motor nerve tracts in the spinal cord<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#motor-nerve-tracts-in-the-spinal-cord" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Neurones that transmit nerve impulses away from the brain are motor (efferent or descending) neurones. Stimulation of motor neurones results in:</p>
<ul>
<li>contraction of muscle (skeletal, smooth or cardiac)</li>
<li>glandular secretion.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-ffc48ae3.jpeg" alt="img-243.jpeg"></li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 7.29 A sensory nerve pathway fronn the skin to the cerebrum.</p>
<p>Voluntary muscle movement</p>
<p>Muscle contraction that moves the joints is, in the main, under conscious (voluntary) control, which means that the stimulus to contract originates at the level of consciousness in the cerebrum. However, skeletal muscle activity is regulated by output from the midbrain, brain stem and cerebellum. This involuntary activity is associated with coordination of muscle activity, e.g. in very fine movement and in the maintenance of posture and balance.</p>
<p>Efferent nerve impulses are transmitted from the brain to other parts of the body via bundles of nerve fibres (tracts) in the spinal cord. The motor pathways from the brain to the muscles are made up of two neurones (see Fig. 7.21). These pathways, or tracts, are either pyramidal (corticospinal) or extrapyramidal (p. 165).</p>
<p>Upp6r motor neuronos. These have their cell bodies in the primary motor area of the cerebrum. The axons pass through the internal capsule, pons and medulla. In the spinal cord they form the lateral corticospinal tracts of white matter, and the fibres synapse with the cell bodies of the lower motor neurones in the anterior columns of grey matter. The axons of the upper motor neurones make up the pyramidal tracts and decussate in the medulla oblongata, forming the pyramids. Lower motor neurones. These have their cell bodies in the anterior horn of grey matter in the spinal cord. The axons emerge from the spinal cord by the anterior root, join with the incoming sensory fibres and form the mixed spinal nerve that passes through the intervertebral foramen.</p>
<p>The lower motor neurone is the final common pathway for the transmission of nerve impulses to skeletal muscles. The cell body of this neurone is influenced by a number of upper motor neurones originating from various sites in the brain and by some neurones that begin and end in the spinal cord. Some of these neurones stimulate the lower motor neurone while others inhibit it. The outcome of these influences is smooth, coordinated muscle movement, some of which is voluntary and some involuntary.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="involuntary-muscle-movement">Involuntary muscle movement<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#involuntary-muscle-movement" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Upper motor neurones. These have their cell bodies in the brain at a level below the cerebrum, i.e. in the midbrain, brain stem, cerebellum or spinal cord. They influence muscle activity that maintains posture and balance, coordinates skeletal muscle movement and controls muscle tone.</p>
<p>Table 7.1 Sensory nerve impulses: origins, routes, destinations</p>

<p>Table 7.2 provides details of the area of origin of these neurones and the tracts that their axons form before reaching the cell body of the lower motor neurone in the spinal cord. Spinal reflexes. These consist of three elements:</p>
<ul>
<li>sensory neurones</li>
<li>interneurones in the spinal cord</li>
<li>lower motor neurones. 07.9</li>
</ul>
<p>In the simplest reflex arc there is only one of each of these neurones (Fig. 7.30). A reflex action is an involuntary and immediate motor response to a sensory stimulus that is invariably protective. For example, the pain impulses initiated by touching a very hot surface with the finger are transmitted to the spinal cord by sensory fibres in mixed nerves. These stimulate many interneurones and lower motor neurones in the spinal cord, which results in the contraction of many skeletal muscles of the hand, arm and shoulder, and the removal of the finger. Reflex action happens very quickly; in fact, the motor response may occur simultaneously with the perception of the pain in the cerebrum. Protective reflexes can occasionally be inhibited. For example, if a precious plate is very hot when lifted, every effort will be made to overcome the pain to prevent dropping it!</p>
<p>Stretch reflexes. Only two neurones are involved. The cell body of the lower motor neurone is stimulated directly by the sensory neurone, with no interneurone in between (Fig.</p>

7.30). The knee jerk is one example but this type of reflex can be demonstrated at any point where a stretched tendon crosses a joint. If the tendon is tapped just below the knee when it is bent, the sensory nerve endings in the tendon and in the thigh muscles are stretched. This initiates a nerve impulse that passes into the spinal cord to the cell body of the lower motor neurone in the anterior column of grey matter on the same side. As a result the thigh muscles suddenly contract and the foot kicks forwards. This is used as a test of the integrity of the reflex arc. This type of reflex also has a protective function: it prevents excessive joint movement that may damage tendons, ligaments and muscles.</p>
<p>Autonomic reflexes. These include the pupillary light reflex, when the pupil immediately constricts in response to bright light, preventing retinal damage.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>Describe the secretion and reabsorption of cerebrospinal fluid.</li>

</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="peripheral-nervous-system">Peripheral nervous system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#peripheral-nervous-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-5b7a9c08.jpeg" alt="img-245.jpeg"></p>
<p>The PNS is made up of all nerves, belonging to both the somatic and the autonomic nervous systems, entering and leaving the CNS. These are grouped as:</p>
<ul>
<li>spinal nerves, which leave the spinal cord through spaces called intervertebral foramina between the vertebrae</li>
<li>cranial nerves, which originate in the base of the brain and flow out through foramina (tiny holes) in the base of the skull.</li>
</ul>
<p>Peripheral nerves can be sensory (carrying input from the body to the brain), motor (carrying impulses from the brain to skeletal, smooth or cardiac muscle and glands) or mixed (containing both sensory and motor fibres).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="spinal-nerves">Spinal nerves<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spinal-nerves" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Thirty-one pairs of spinal nerves leave the vertebral canal by passing through the intervertebral foramina, formed by adjacent vertebrae. They are named and grouped according to the vertebrae with which they are associated (see Fig. 7,27):</p>
<ul>
<li>8 cervical</li>
<li>12 thoracic</li>
<li>5 lumbar</li>
<li>5 sacral</li>
<li>1 coccygeal.</li>
</ul>
<p>Although there are only seven cervical vertebrae, there are eight nerves because the first pair leaves the vertebral canal between the occipital bone and the atlas (first cervical vertebra), and the eighth pair leaves below the last cervical vertebra. Thereafter, the nerves are given the name and number of the vertebra immediately above.</p>
<p>The lumbar, sacral and coccygeal nerves leave the spinal cord near its termination, at the level of the 1st lumbar vertebra, and extend downwards inside the vertebral canal in the subarachnoid space, forming a sheaf of nerves that resembles a horse's</p>
<p>tail, the cauda equina (see Fig. 7.27). These nerves leave the vertebral canal at the appropriate lumbar, sacral or coccygeal level, depending on their destination.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="nerve-roots">Nerve roots<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nerve-roots" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The Spinal nerves arise from both sides of the spinal cord and emerge through the intervertebral foramina (see Fig. 16.27). Each nerve is formed by the union of a motor (anterior) and a sensory (posterior) nerve root and is, therefore, a mixed nerve (Fig. 7.31). Thoracic and upper lumbar (LI and L2) spinal nerves have a contribution from the sympathetic part of the autonomic nervous system in the form of a preganglionic fibre (neurone).</p>
<p>Chapter 16 describes the bones and muscles mentioned in the following sections. Bones and joints are supplied by adjacent nerves.</p>
<p>The anterior nerve root consists of motor nerve fibres, which are the axons of the lower motor neurones from the anterior column of grey matter in the spinal cord and, in the thoracic and lumbar regions, sympathetic nerve fibres, which are the axons of cells in the lateral columns of grey matter.</p>
<p>The posterior nerve root consists of sensory nerve fibres. Just outside the spinal cord there is a spinal ganglion (posterior, or dorsal, root ganglion), consisting of a little cluster of cell bodies. Sensory nerve fibres pass through
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-a7dbfca6.jpeg" alt="img-246.jpeg"></p>

<p>For a very short distance after leaving the spinal cord the nerve roots have a covering of dura and arachnoid maters. These terminate before the two roots join to form the mixed spinal nerve. The nerve roots have no covering of pia mater.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="branches">Branches<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#branches" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Immediately after emerging from the intervertebral foramen, spinal nerves divide into branches, or rami: a ramus communicans, a posterior ramus and an anterior ramus.</p>
<p>The rami communicantes are part of preganglionic sympathetic neurones of the autonomic nervous system (Fig. 7,31).</p>
<p>The posterior rami pass backwards and divide into smaller medial and lateral branches to supply skin and muscles of relatively small areas of the posterior aspect of the head, neck and trunk.</p>
<p>The anterior rami supply the anterior and lateral aspects of the neck, trunk and the upper and lower limbs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="plexuses">Plexuses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plexuses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In the cervical, lumbar and sacral regions the anterior rami unite near their origins to form large masses of nerves, or plexuses, where nerve fibres are regrouped and rearranged before proceeding to supply skin, bones, muscles and joints of a particular area (Fig. 7.32). This means that these structures have a nerve supply from more than one spinal nerve and therefore damage to one spinal nerve does not cause loss of function of a region. Moreover, they lie deep within the body, often under large muscles, and are therefore well protected from injury.</p>
<p>In the thoracic region the anterior rami do not form plexuses.
There are five large plexuses of mixed nerves formed on each side of the vertebral column. They are the:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>cervical plexuses</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>brachial plexuses</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>lumbar plexuses</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>sacral plexuses</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>coccygeal plexuses.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Cervical plexus
The cervical plexus (Fig. 7.33) is formed by the anterior rami of the first four cervical nerves. It lies deep within the neck opposite the 1st, 2nd, 3rd and 4th cervical vertebrae under the protection of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.</p>
<p>The superficial branches supply the structures at the back and side of the head, and the skin of the front of the neck to the level of the sternum.</p>
<p>The deep branches supply muscles of the neck, e.g. the sternocleidomastoid and the trapezius.</p>
<p>The phrenic nerve originates from cervical nerve roots 3,4 and 5 and passes downwards through the thoracic cavity in front of the root of the lung to supply the diaphragm, initiating inspiration. Disease or spinal cord injury at this level will result in death, as spontaneous respiration is not possible.</p>
<p>Brachial plexus
The anterior rami of the lower four cervical nerves and a large part of the 1st thoracic nerve form the brachial plexus. Fig. 7.34 shows its formation and the nerves that emerge from it. The plexus is situated deeply within the neck and shoulder above and behind the subclavian vessels and in the axilla.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-31a562e2.jpeg" alt="img-248.jpeg"></p>

<p>Ulnar nerve
Figure 7.34 The brachial plexus.
The branches of the brachial plexus supply the skin and muscles of the upper limbs and some of the chest muscles. Five large nerves and a number of smaller ones emerge from this plexus, each with a contribution from more than one nerve root, containing sensory, motor and autonomic fibres:</p>
<ul>
<li>axillary (circumflex) nerve: C5, 6</li>
<li>radial nerve: C5, 6, 7, 8, T1</li>
<li>musculocutaneous nerve: C5, 6, 7</li>
<li>median nerve: C5, 6, 7, 8, T1</li>
<li>ulnar nerve: C7, 8, T1</li>
<li>medial cutaneous nerve: C8, T1.</li>
</ul>
<p>The axillary (circumflex) nerve winds round the humerus at the level of the surgical neck. It then divides into minute branches to supply the deltoid muscle, shoulder joint and overlying skin.</p>
<p>The radial nerve is the largest branch of the brachial plexus. It supplies the triceps muscle behind the humerus, crosses in front of the elbow joint and then winds round to the back of the forearm to supply extensor muscles of the wrist and finger joints. The superficial branch continues into the back of the hand to supply the skin of the posterior aspect of the thumb, first two fingers and the lateral half of the third finger.</p>
<p>The musculocutaneous nerve passes downwards to the lateral aspect of the forearm. Its branches supply the muscles of the upper arm and, as cutaneous nerves, the skin of the forearm.</p>
<p>The median nerve passes down the midline of the arm in close association with the brachial artery. It passes in front of the elbow joint and then down to supply the muscles of the front of the forearm. It continues into the hand, where it supplies small muscles and the skin of the front (palmar aspect) of the thumb, first two fingers and the lateral half of the third finger. It gives off no branches above the elbow.</p>
<p>The ulnar nerve descends through the upper arm, lying medial to the brachial artery. It passes behind the medial epicondyle of the humerus to supply the muscles on the ulnar aspect of the forearm. It continues downwards to supply the muscles in</p>
<p>the palm of the hand and the skin of the whole of the little finger and the medial half of the third finger. It gives off no branches above the elbow.</p>
<p>The main nerves of the arm are shown in Fig. 7.35. The distribution and origins of the cutaneous sensory nerves of the arm, i.e. the dermatomes, are shown in Fig. 7.36 .</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lumbar-plexus-d-7-10">Lumbar plexus D 7.10<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lumbar-plexus-d-7-10" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The lumbar plexus (Figs 7.37-7.39) is formed by the anterior rami of the first three and part of the 4th lumbar nerves. The plexus is situated in front of the transverse processes of the lumbar vertebrae and behind the psoas muscle. The main branches and their nerve roots are the:</p>
<ul>
<li>iliohypogastric nerve: LI</li>
<li>ilioinguinal nerve: LI

</ul>

<li>lumbosacral trunk: L4, 5.</li>
</ul>
<p>The iliohypogastric, ilioinguinal and genitofemoral nerves supply muscles and the skin in the area of the lower abdomen, upper and medial aspects of the thigh and the inguinal region.</p>
<p>The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of the thigh supplies the skin of the lateral aspect of the thigh, including part of the anterior and posterior surfaces.</p>

<p>The femoral nerve is one of the larger branches. It passes behind the inguinal ligament to enter the thigh in close association with the femoral artery. It divides into cutaneous and muscular branches to supply the skin and the muscles of the front of the thigh. One branch, the saphenous nerve, supplies the medial aspect of the leg, ankle and foot.</p>
<p>The obturator nerve supplies the adductor muscles of the thigh and skin of the medial aspect of the thigh. It ends just above the level of the knee joint.</p>
<p>The lumbosacral trunk descends into the pelvis and makes a contribution to the sacral plexus.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sacral-plexus">Sacral plexus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sacral-plexus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The sacral plexus (Figs 7.37-7.39) is formed by the anterior rami of the lumbosacral trunk and the 1st, 2nd and 3rd sacral nerves. The lumbosacral trunk is formed by the 5th and part</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-21608efd.jpeg" alt="img-254.jpeg">
of the 4th lumbar nerves. It lies in the posterior wall of the pelvic cavity.
The sacral plexus divides into a number of branches, supplying the muscles and skin of the pelvic floor, muscles around the hip joint and the pelvic organs. In addition to these it provides the sciatic nerve, which contains fibres from L4 and 5 and SI-3.</p>
<p>The sciatic nerve is the largest nerve in the body. It is about 2 cm wide at its origin. It passes through the greater sciatic foramen into the buttock and then descends through the posterior aspect of the thigh, supplying the hamstring muscles. At the level of the middle of the femur it divides to form the tibial and the common fibular (peroneal) nerves. IJ7.11</p>
<p>The tibial nerve descends through the popliteal fossa to the posterior aspect of the leg, where it supplies muscles and skin. It passes under the medial malleolus to supply muscles and skin of the sole of the foot and toes. One of the main</p>
