branches is the sural nerve, which supplies the tissues in the area of the heel, the lateral aspect of the ankle and a part of the dorsum of the foot.</p>
<p>The common fibular (peroneal) nerve descends obliquely along the lateral aspect of the popliteal fossa and winds round the neck of the fibula into the front of the leg, where it divides into the deep fibular (anterior tibial) and the superficial fibular (musculocutaneous) nerves. These nerves supply the skin and muscles of the anterior aspect of the leg and the dorsum of the foot and toes.</p>
<p>The perineal branch of the pudendal nerve (S2, 3, 4) supplies the external anal sphincter, the external urethral sphincter and adjacent skin.</p>
<p>Figs 7.38 and 7.39 show the main nerves of the leg, the dermatomes and the origins of the main nerves.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="coccygeal-plexus">Coccygeal plexus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#coccygeal-plexus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The coccygeal plexus (see Fig. 7.37) is a very small plexus formed by part of the 4th and 5th sacral and the coccygeal nerves. The nerves from this plexus supply the skin around the coccyx and anal area.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="thoracic-nerves">Thoracic nerves<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thoracic-nerves" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There are 12 pairs of thoracic nerves; unlike the cervical, lumbar and sacral nerves, they do not intermingle to form plexuses. The first 11 are the intercostal nerves, which pass between the ribs, supplying them, the intercostal muscles and overlying skin. The 12th pair comprises the subcostal nerves. The 7th-12th thoracic nerves also supply the muscles and the skin of the posterior and anterior abdominal walls.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cranial-nerves-o-7-12">Cranial nerves O 7.12<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cranial-nerves-o-7-12" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There are 12 pairs of cranial nerves (Figs 7.40 and 7.41 ) originating from nuclei in the inferior surface of the brain, mainly from the brain stem. Some are sensory, some motor and some mixed. Their names suggest their distribution or function, which, in the main, is generally related to the head and neck. They are numbered using Roman numerals, according to the order in which they connect to the brain, starting anteriorly. They are:
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-71484feb.jpeg" alt="img-258.jpeg"></p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i-olfactory-nerves-sensory">I. Olfactory nerves (sensory)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-olfactory-nerves-sensory" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are the nerves of the sense of smell. Their sensory receptors and nerve fibres originate in the olfactory epithelium of the nasal cavity, pass upwards through the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone and then pass to the olfactory bulb (see Fig. 8.24). The nerves then proceed backwards as the olfactory tract, to the temporal lobe of the cerebrum, where smell is perceived (Ch. 8).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-optic-nerves-sensory">II. Optic nerves (sensory)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-optic-nerves-sensory" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are the nerves of sight. Their fibres originate in the retinae of the eyes and they combine to form the optic nerves</p>
<p>(see Fig. 8.13). They run backwards and medially through the posterior part of the orbital cavity and then pass through the optic foramina of the sphenoid bone into the cranial cavity, where they join at the optic chiasma. The nerves proceed backwards as the optic tracts to the lateral geniculate bodies of the thalamus. Impulses pass from there to the visual areas in the occipital lobes of the cerebrum and to the cerebellum.</p>
<p>Sight is perceived in the visual cortex, which lies in the occipital lobe of the cerebral cortex, and in the cerebellum the impulses from the eyes contribute to the maintenance of balance, posture and orientation of the head in space.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-oculomotor-nerves-motor">III. Oculomotor nerves (motor)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-oculomotor-nerves-motor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These nerves arise from nuclei near the cerebral aqueduct.
They supply:</p>
<ul>
<li>four of the six extrinsic muscles that move the eyeball, i.e. the superior, medial and inferior recti and the inferior oblique muscle (see Table 8.1)</li>
<li>the intrinsic (intraocular) muscles:</li>
<li>ciliary muscles, which alter the shape of the lens, changing its refractive power to focus images on the retina</li>
<li>circular muscles of the iris, which constrict the pupil</li>
<li>the levator palpebrae muscles, which raise the upper eyelids.
^ 183</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-f162e5b8.jpeg" alt="img-259.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="oculomotor-nerve-iii">Oculomotor nerve [III]<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#oculomotor-nerve-iii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<p>Motor: superior, medial and inferior recti muscles and inferior oblique muscle of eye, ciliary muscles, muscles of the iris, levator palpebrae muscles</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="trochlear-nerve-iv">Trochlear nerve (IV)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#trochlear-nerve-iv" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Sensory: smell
Motor: superior oblique muscle of eye
Sensory: vision</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="abducent-nerve-vi">Abducent nerve (VI)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#abducent-nerve-vi" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="facial-nerve-vii">Facial nerve (VII)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#facial-nerve-vii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Motor: lateral rectus muscle of eye</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="trigeminal-nerve-v">Trigeminal nerve (V)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#trigeminal-nerve-v" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Motor: muscles of facial expression
Sensory: face

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="auditory-nerve-viii">Auditory nerve (VIII)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#auditory-nerve-viii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="motor-root">Motor root<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#motor-root" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

Vestibular nerve, sensory:
posture, balance</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hypoglossal-nerve-xii">Hypoglossal nerve (XII)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypoglossal-nerve-xii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cochlear nerve, sensory:
hearing

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="glossopharyngeal-nerve-ix">Glossopharyngeal nerve (IX)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#glossopharyngeal-nerve-ix" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Accessory nerve (XI)
Motor: pharynx, larynx, trachea, bronchi, heart, gastrointestinal tract, spleen, kidneys, ureters, blood vessels of thoracic and abdominal cavities</p>
<p>Motor: tongue, pharynx (swallowing), salivary glands
Sensory: pharynx, larynx, trachea, bronchi, heart, gastrointestinal tract, spleen, kidneys, ureters, blood vessels of thoracic and abdominal cavities</p>
<p>Sensory: posterior part of tongue, tonsil, pharynx

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-trochlear-nerves-motor">IV. Trochlear nerves (motor)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-trochlear-nerves-motor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These nerves arise from nuclei near the cerebral aqueduct. They supply the superior oblique muscles, extrinsic muscles of the eyes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-trigeminal-nerves-mixed">V. Trigeminal nerves (mixed)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-trigeminal-nerves-mixed" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These nerves are among the largest of the cranial nerves. They are the chief sensory nerves for the face and head (including the oral and nasal cavities and teeth), transmitting sensory impulses, e.g. for pain, temperature and touch. The motor fibres stimulate the muscles for chewing (mastication).</p>
<p>As the name suggests, there are three main branches of the trigeminal nerves. The dermatomes innervated by the sensory fibres on the right side are shown in Fig. 7.42 .</p>
<p>The ophthalmic nerves are sensory only and supply the lacrimal glands, conjunctiva of the eyes, forehead, eyelids, anterior aspect of the scalp and mucous membrane of the nose.</p>
<p>The maxillary nerves are sensory only and supply the cheeks, upper gums, upper teeth and lower eyelids.</p>
<p>The mandibular nerves contain both sensory and motor fibres. These are the largest of the three divisions and they supply the teeth and gums of the lower jaw, pinnae of the ears, lower lip and tongue. The motor fibres supply the muscles for chewing.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vi-abducent-nerves-motor">VI. Abducent nerves (motor)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-abducent-nerves-motor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These nerves arise from nuclei lying under the floor of the fourth ventricle. They supply the lateral rectus muscles, extrinsic muscles of the eyeballs that cause abduction, as the name suggests.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vii-facial-nerves-mixed">VII. Facial nerves (mixed)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-facial-nerves-mixed" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These nerves arise from nuclei in the lower part of the pons. The motor fibres supply the muscles of facial expression. The sensory fibres convey impulses from the taste buds in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue to the taste perception area in the cerebral cortex (see Fig. 7.20).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="viii-vestibulocochlear-auditory-nerves-sensory">VIII. Vestibulocochlear (auditory) nerves (sensory)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viii-vestibulocochlear-auditory-nerves-sensory" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These nerves are composed of two divisions: the vestibular nerves and cochlear nerves.</p>
<p>The vestibular nerves arise from the semicircular canals of the inner ear and convey impulses to the cerebellum. They are associated with the maintenance of posture and balance.</p>
<p>The cochlear nerves originate in the spiral organ (of Corti) in the inner ear and convey impulses to the auditory cortex in the temporal lobe of the cerebral cortex, where sound is perceived.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ix-glossopharyngeal-nerves-mixed">IX. Glossopharyngeal nerves (mixed)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ix-glossopharyngeal-nerves-mixed" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The motor fibres arise from nuclei in the medulla oblongata and stimulate the muscles of the tongue and pharynx and the secretory cells of the parotid (salivary) glands.</p>
<p>The sensory fibres convey impulses to the cerebral cortex from the posterior third of the tongue, the tonsils and pharynx, and taste buds in the tongue and pharynx. These nerves are essential for the swallowing and gag reflexes. Some fibres conduct impulses from the carotid sinus, which plays an important role in the control of blood pressure (p.98).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="x-vagus-nerves-mixed">X. Vagus nerves (mixed)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#x-vagus-nerves-mixed" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These nerves have the most extensive distribution of the cranial nerves (Fig. 7.43); their name aptly means 'wanderer'. They pass downwards through the neck into the thorax and the abdomen. These nerves form an important part of the parasympathetic nervous system (see Fig. 7.45).</p>
<p>The motor fibres arise from nuclei in the medulla and supply the smooth muscle and secretory glands of the pharynx, larynx, trachea, bronchi, heart, carotid body, oesophagus, stomach, intestines, exocrine pancreas, gall bladder, bile ducts, spleen, kidneys, ureter and blood vessels in the thoracic and abdominal cavities.</p>
<p>The sensory fibres convey impulses from the membranes lining the same structures to the brain.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="xi-accessory-nerves-motor">XI. Accessory nerves (motor)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#xi-accessory-nerves-motor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These nerves arise from nuclei in the medulla oblongata and in the spinal cord. The fibres supply the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles. Branches join the vagus nerves and supply the pharyngeal and laryngeal muscles in the neck.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-7fa1993e.jpeg" alt="img-261.jpeg"></p>
<p>Medulla

Figure 7.43 Structures supplied by the right vagus nerve.</p>
<ul>
<li>sympathetic (thoracolumbar outflow)</li>
<li>parasympathetic (craniosacral outflow).</li>
</ul>
<p>The two divisions work in an integrated and complementary manner to maintain involuntary functions and homeostasis. Most body organs have both sympathetic and parasympathetic supply, and their effects usually oppose one another. Such activities include coordination and control of breathing, blood pressure, water balance, digestion and metabolic rate. Sympathetic activity predominates in stressful situations, as it equips the body to respond when exertion and exercise are required. Parasympathetic activity is increased (and sympathetic activity is normally lessened) in calm and non-stressful situations. There are similarities and differences between the two divisions. Some similarities are outlined in this section before the descriptions of the two divisions that follow.</p>
<p>As with other parts of the nervous system, the effects of autonomic activity are rapid. The effector organs are:</p>
<ul>
<li>smooth muscle, which controls the diameter of smaller airways and blood vessels</li>
<li>cardiac muscle, which controls the rate and force of cardiac contraction</li>
<li>glands, which control the volumes of gastrointestinal secretions.</li>
</ul>
<p>The efferent (motor) nerves of the autonomic nervous system arise from the brain and emerge at various levels between the midbrain and the sacral region of the spinal cord. Many of them travel within the same nerve sheath as peripheral nerves to reach the organs they innervate.</p>
<p>Each division has two efferent neurones between the CNS and effector organs. These are:</p>
<ul>
<li>the preganglionic neurone</li>
<li>the postganglionic neurone.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="xii-hypoglossal-nerves-motor">XII. Hypoglossal nerves (motor)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#xii-hypoglossal-nerves-motor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These nerves arise from nuclei in the medulla oblongata. They supply the muscles of the tongue and muscles surrounding the hyoid bone, and contribute to swallowing and speech.</p>
<p>Functions of the cranial nerves
The functions of the cranial nerves are summarised in Fig. 7.41.
Autonomic nervous system <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>117.13</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>7.14</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>7.15</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">117.13,7.14,7.15</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">117.13</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">7.14</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">7.15</span></span></span></span></span>
The autonomic or involuntary nervous system (see Fig. 7.1) controls involuntary body functions. Although control is not voluntary, the individual can sometimes be conscious of its effects, e.g. an increase in heart rate.</p>
<p>The autonomic nervous system is separated into two divisions:
The cell body of the preganglionic neurone is located in the brain or spinal cord. Its axon terminals synapse with the cell body of the postganglionic neurone in an autonomic ganglion outside the CNS. The postganglionic neurone conducts impulses to the effector organ.</p>
<p>Sympathetic nervous system
This is summarised in Fig. 7.44, along with the main structures supplied and the effects of stimulation. Since the preganglionic neurones originate in the spinal cord at the thoracic and lumbar levels, the alternative name of Thoracolumbar outflow' is apt.</p>
<p>The preganglionic neurone
This has its cell body in the lateral column of grey matter in the spinal cord between the levels of the 1st thoracic and 2 nd or 3 rd lumbar vertebrae. The nerve fibre of this cell leaves the cord by the anterior root and terminates at a synapse in</p>
<p>one of the ganglia in the lateral chain of sympathetic ganglia, or passes through it to one of the prevertebral ganglia (see</p>

There are right and left lateral chains of ganglia. later). Acetylcholine is the neurotransmitter at sympathetic ganglia.</p>
<p>The postganglionic neurone
This has its cell body in a sympathetic ganglion and terminates in the organ or tissue supplied. Noradrenaline (norepinephrine) is usually the neurotransmitter at sympathetic effector organs. The major exception is the lack of parasympathetic supply to the sweat glands, the skin and blood vessels of skeletal muscles. These structures are supplied only by sympathetic postganglionic neurones, which are known as sympathetic cholinergic nerves, and usually have acetylcholine as their neurotransmitter (see Fig. 7.8).</p>
<p>Sympathetic ganglia
The lateral chains of sympathetic ganglia
These chains extend from the upper cervical level to the sacrum, one chain lying on each side of the vertebral bodies.</p>
<p>The ganglia are attached to each other by nerve fibres. Preganglionic neurones that emerge from the cord may synapse with the cell body of the postganglionic neurone at the same level or they may pass up or down the chain through one or more ganglia before synapsing. For example, the nerve that dilates the pupil of the eye leaves the cord at the level of the 1st thoracic vertebra and passes up the chain to the superior cervical ganglion before it synapses with the cell body of the postsynaptic neurone. The postganglionic neurones then pass to the eyes.</p>
<p>The arrangement of the ganglia allows excitation of nerves at multiple levels very quickly, providing a rapid and widespread sympathetic response and enabling the body to respond effectively when Tight or flight <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>1</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is required.</p>
<p>Prevertebral ganglia
There are three prevertebral ganglia situated in the abdominal cavity close to the origins of arteries of the same names:</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-05393a06.jpeg" alt="img-263.jpeg"></p>
<p>Structures
Iris muscle
Lacrimal gland
Salivary glands: submandibular sublingual parotid gland
Effects of stimulation
Pupil constricted: radial muscle contracted Accommodation for close vision Tear secretion increased</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="stomach">Stomach<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stomach" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bladder">Bladder<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bladder" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
