Figure 7.45 The parasynnpathetic outflow, the main structures supplied and the effects of stimulation. Solid blue lines, preganglionic fibres; broken blue lines, postganglionic fibres. Where there are no broken lines, the postganglionic neurone is in the wall of the structure.</p>
<ul>
<li>coeliac ganglion</li>
<li>superior mesenteric ganglion</li>
<li>inferior mesenteric ganglion.</li>
</ul>
<p>The ganglia consist of nerve cell bodies rather diffusely distributed among a network of nerve fibres that form plexuses. Preganglionic sympathetic fibres pass through the lateral chain to reach these ganglia.</p>
<p>Parasympathetic nervous system
This is summarised in Fig. 7.45, which shows the main structures supplied and the effects of stimulation. Like the sympathetic nervous system, two neurones</p>
<p>(preganglionic and postganglionic) are involved in the transmission of impulses to the effector organs. The neurotransmitter at both synapses is acetylcholine.</p>
<p>The preganglionic neurone
This is usually long in comparison to its counterpart in the sympathetic nervous system, and has its cell body either in the brain or in the spinal cord. The cell bodies originating in the brain form the cranial outflow and are cranial nerves III, VII, IX and X, arising from nuclei in the midbrain and brain stem. The cell bodies of the sacral outflow are located in the lateral columns of grey matter at the distal end of the spinal cord. Their fibres leave the cord in sacral segments 2,3 and 4. The nerve fibres of parasympathetic preganglionic neurones usually synapse with their postganglionic counterparts at or near the effector organs.</p>
<p>The postganglionic neurone
This is usually very short and has its cell body either in a ganglion or, more often, in the wall of the organ supplied.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="e69c229b"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0-1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">0</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e69c229b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Functions of the autonomic nervous system <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">□</mi><mn>7.16</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>7.17</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square 7.16,7.17</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8694em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">□</span><span class="mord">7.16</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">7.17</span></span></span></span></span>
The autonomic nervous system is involved in many complex involuntary reflex activities (Figs 7.44 and 7.45), which, like the reflexes described in earlier sections, depend not only on sensory input to the brain or spinal cord but also on motor output. In this case the reflex action is rapid contraction, or inhibition of contraction, of involuntary (smooth and cardiac) muscle or glandular secretion. These activities are coordinated subconsciously. Sometimes sensory input does reach consciousness and may result in temporary inhibition of the reflex action, e.g. reflex micturition can be inhibited temporarily.</p>
<p>The majority of the body organs are supplied by both sympathetic and parasympathetic nerves, which have complementary, and usually opposite, effects that are finely balanced to ensure that optimum functioning meets body needs at any moment.</p>
<p>Sympathetic nervous system
Sympathetic stimulation prepares the body to deal with exciting and stressful situations, e.g. strengthening its defences in times of danger and in extremes of environmental temperature. A range of emotional states, e.g. fear, embarrassment and anger, also cause sympathetic stimulation.</p>
<p>The adrenal glands secrete noradrenaline (norepinephrine) and some adrenaline (epinephrine) into the bloodstream in response to sympathetic stimulation. These hormones act as neurotransmitters when they reach target organs of the sympathetic</p>
<p>nervous system. Through this effect, they potentiate and sustain the effects of sympathetic stimulation.</p>
<p>Sympathetic stimulation mobilises the body for 'Tight or flight'. The effects of stimulation on the heart, blood vessels and lungs (see later) enable the body to respond by preparing itself for exercise. Additional effects are an increase in the metabolic rate and increased conversion of glycogen to glucose. During exercise, e.g. fighting or running away, when oxygen and energy requirements of skeletal muscles are greatly increased, these changes enable the body to respond quickly to meet the increased energy demand.</p>
<p>Parasympathetic nervous system
Parasympathetic stimulation has a tendency to slow down cardiac and respiratory activity but it stimulates digestion and absorption of food and the functions of the genitourinary systems. Its general effect is that of 'rest and digest', allowing digestion and restorative processes to occur quietly when required.</p>
<p>Effects of autonomic stimulation
Normally the two systems function together, maintaining a regular heartbeat, normal temperature and an internal
environment compatible with both physiological needs and the immediate external surroundings.</p>
<p>Cardiovascular system Sympathetic stimulation</p>
<ul>
<li>Accelerates firing of the sinoatrial node in the heart, increasing the rate and force of the heartbeat.</li>
<li>Dilates the coronary arteries, increasing the blood supply to cardiac muscle increasing the supply of oxygen and nutritional materials and the removal of metabolic waste products, thus increasing the capacity of the muscle to work.</li>
<li>Dilates the blood vessels supplying skeletal muscle, with the same effects as those on cardiac muscle, above.</li>
<li>Raises peripheral resistance and blood pressure by constricting the small arteries and arterioles in the skin.</li>
</ul>
<p>In this way an increased blood supply is available for highly active tissue, such as skeletal muscle, heart and brain.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Constricts the blood vessels in the secretory glands of the digestive system. This raises the volume of blood available for circulation in dilated blood vessels, e.g. cardiac muscle, skeletal muscles.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Accelerates blood coagulation because of vasoconstriction.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Parasympathetic stimulation</p>
<ul>
<li>Decreases the rate and force of the heartbeat.</li>
<li>Constricts the coronary arteries, reducing the blood supply to cardiac muscle.</li>
</ul>
<p>The parasympathetic nervous system exerts little or no effect on blood vessels except the coronary arteries.</p>
<p>Respiratory system Sympathetic stimulation
This causes smooth muscle relaxation and therefore dilation of the airways (bronchodilation), especially the bronchioles, allowing more air to enter the lungs at each inspiration, and increases the respiratory rate. In conjunction with the increased heart rate, the oxygen intake and carbon dioxide output of the body are increased to deal with 'fight or flight' situations.</p>
<p>Parasympathetic stimulation
This causes contraction of the smooth muscle in the airway walls, leading to bronchoconstriction.</p>
<p>Digestive and urinary systems Sympathetic stimulation</p>
<ul>
<li>Increases conversion of glycogen to glucose by the liver, making more fuel immediately available to provide energy.</li>
<li>Inhibits smooth muscle contraction and secretion of
digestive juices in the stomach and small intestine, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>∧</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\wedge</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5556em;"></span><span class="mord">∧</span></span></span></span></span>
delaying digestion, onward movement and absorption of food; increases the tone of sphincter muscles.</li>
<li>Increases secretion of adrenaline (epinephrine) and noradrenaline (norepinephrine) from the adrenal glands; this potentiates and sustains the effects of sympathetic stimulation throughout the body.</li>
<li>Increases the tone of the urethral and anal sphincters, and relaxes the bladder wall, inhibiting micturition and defaecation.</li>
<li>Significantly increases metabolic rate.</li>
</ul>
<p>Parasympathetic stimulation</p>
<ul>
<li>Increases secretion of bile by the liver.</li>
<li>Increases motility and secretion of the stomach and small intestine, together with the rate of digestion and absorption.</li>
<li>Increases the secretion of pancreatic juice.</li>
<li>Relaxation of the internal urethral sphincter is accompanied by contraction of the muscle of the bladder wall, and micturition occurs. Similar relaxation of the internal anal sphincter is accompanied by contraction
of the muscle of the rectum, and defaecation occurs. In both cases, there is voluntary relaxation of the external sphincters.</li>
</ul>
<p>In contrast to sympathetic stimulation, parasympathetic stimulation has no effect on either the adrenal glands or metabolic rate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="eye">Eye<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#eye" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sympathetic-stimulation">Sympathetic stimulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sympathetic-stimulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This causes contraction of the radiating muscle fibres of the iris, dilating the pupil. Retraction of the levator palpebrae muscles occurs, opening the eyes wide and giving the appearance of alertness and excitement. The ciliary muscle that adjusts the thickness of the lens is slightly relaxed, facilitating distant vision.</p>
<p>Parasympathetic stimulation
This contracts the circular muscle fibres of the iris, constricting the pupil. The eyelids tend to close, giving the appearance of sleepiness. The ciliary muscle contracts, facilitating near vision.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="skin">Skin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#skin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Sympathetic stimulation</p>
<ul>
<li>Increases sweat secretion, leading to more loss of heat generated by increased skeletal muscle activity.</li>
<li>Contracts the arrector pili (the muscles in the hair follicles of the skin), giving the appearance of 'goose flesh'.</li>
<li>Constricts the peripheral blood vessels, increasing blood supply available to active organs, e.g. the heart and skeletal muscle.</li>
</ul>
<p>There is no parasympathetic nerve supply to the skin. Some sympathetic fibres are adrenergic, causing vasoconstriction, and some are cholinergic, causing vasodilation (see Fig. 7.8).</p>
<p>Afferent impulses from viscera
Sensory fibres from the viscera travel with autonomic fibres and are sometimes called autonomic afferents. The impulses they transmit are associated with:</p>
<ul>
<li>visceral reflexes, usually at an unconscious level, e.g. cough, blood pressure (baroreceptors)</li>
<li>sensation, for example, of hunger, thirst, nausea, sexual sensation, rectal and bladder distension</li>
<li>visceral pain.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="visceral-pain">Visceral pain<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#visceral-pain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Normally the viscera (internal organs) are insensitive to cutting, burning and crushing. However, a sensation of dull, poorly located pain is experienced when:</p>
<ul>
<li>visceral nerves are stretched</li>
<li>a large number of fibres are stimulated</li>
<li>there is ischaemia and local accumulation of metabolites</li>
<li>the sensitivity of nerve endings to painful stimuli is increased, e.g. during inflammation.</li>
</ul>
<p>If the cause of the pain, e.g. inflammation, affects the parietal layer of a serous membrane (pleura, peritoneum, p. 314), the pain is acute and easily located over the site of inflammation. This is because the peripheral spinal nerves that innervate the superficial tissues also innervate the parietal layer of serous membranes. They transmit the impulses to the cerebral cortex, where somatic pain is perceived and accurately located. Appendicitis is an example of this type of pain. Initially, it is dull and vaguely located around the midline of the abdomen. As the condition progresses the parietal peritoneum becomes involved and acute pain becomes clearly located in the right iliac fossa, i.e. over the appendix.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="referred-pain">Referred pain<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#referred-pain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In some cases of visceral disease, pain may be felt in superficial tissues remote from its site of origin, i.e. referred pain (Fig. 7.46). This occurs when sensory fibres from the affected organ enter the same segment of the spinal cord as somatic nerves, i.e. those from the superficial tissues. It is believed that the sensory nerve</p>
<p>from the damaged organ stimulates the closely associated nerve in the spinal cord and it transmits the impulses to the sensory area in the cerebral cortex, where the pain is perceived as originating in the area supplied by the somatic nerve. Examples of referred pain are given in Table 7.3.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-f3b9cc48.jpeg" alt="img-264.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 7.46 Referred pain. Ischaemic heart tissue generates impulses in nerve Y, which then stimulate nerve X , and pain is perceived in the shoulder.</p>
<p>Table 7.3 Referred pain</p>
<p>Tissue of origin of pain
Site of referred pain</p>
<p>Heart
Left shoulder</p>
<p>Liver 1
Right shoulder</p>
<p>Biliary tract J</p>
<p>Kidney 1
Loin and groin</p>
<p>Ureter J</p>
<p>Uterus
Low back</p>
<p>Male genitalia
Low abdomen</p>
<p>Prolapsed intervertebral discLeg</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effects-of-ageing-on-the-nervous-system">Effects of ageing on the nervous system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effects-of-ageing-on-the-nervous-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the effects of ageing on the nervous system.</li>
</ul>
<p>As neurones are not replaced after birth, a natural decrease in numbers occurs with ageing; however, a considerable reserve means that cognitive function is not necessarily impaired. The brain of older adults is generally reduced in size and weighs less; the gyri become narrower and sulci wider. In older adults, plaques, accumulations of protein material, are often found around CNS neurones and neurofibrillary tangles may develop inside them, although their significance is unknown.</p>
<p>Decreased blood flow may develop in the arteries that supply the brain over a long period (atheroma and arteriosclerosis, Ch. 4), making their walls more prone to rupture. Should this occur, bleeding into the surrounding brain tissue causes the signs and symptoms of a stroke (p. 194).</p>
<p>Motor control of precise movement diminishes, meaning that older adults take longer to carry out motor actions than younger adults and they also become more prone to falls. The conduction rate of nerve impulses becomes slower, and this may contribute to less effective control of, for example, vasodilation, vasoconstriction and the baroreceptor reflex (Ch. 5).</p>
<p>Memory of the recent past typically becomes more difficult to access, although long-term memories, including problem-solving skills, remain intact and are generally still retrievable. For unknown reasons, some older adults are much more incapacitated by progressive CNS changes than others, e.g. dementia (p. 156).</p>
<p>Effects of ageing on the special senses are almost universal and are considered in Chapter 8. Thermoregulation is discussed in Chapter 14.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c33b1df7">I <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>⋅</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\cdot</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">⋅</span></span></span></span></span> SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c33b1df7" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I 5. Outline the impact of ageing on memory.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcome">Learning outcome<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Disorders of the brain</p>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>list three causes of raised intracranial pressure</li>
<li>relate the effects of raised intracranial pressure to the functions of the brain and changes in vital signs</li>
<li>outline how the brain is damaged during different types of head injury</li>
<li>describe four complications of head injury</li>
<li>explain the effects of cerebral hypoxia and stroke</li>
<li>outline the causes and effects of dementia</li>
<li>relate the pathology of Parkinson's disease to its effects on body function.</li>
</ul>
<p>Increased intracranial pressure
This is a serious complication of many conditions that affect the brain. The cranium forms a rigid cavity enclosing the brain, the cerebral blood vessels and CSF. An increase in volume of any one of these will lead to raised intracranial pressure (ICP).</p>
<p>Sometimes the effects of ICP are more serious than the condition causing it, e.g. disruption of the blood supply or distortion of the shape of the brain, especially if the ICP rises rapidly. A slow rise in ICP allows time for compensatory adjustment to be made, i.e. a slight reduction in the volume of circulating blood and of CSF. The slower the rise in ICP, the more effective is the compensation.</p>
<p>Rising ICP is accompanied by bradycardia and hypertension. As it reaches its limit, a further small increase in pressure is followed by a sudden and usually serious reduction in the cerebral blood flow as autoregulation fails. The result is hypoxia and a rise in carbon dioxide levels, causing arteriolar dilation, which further increases ICP. This leads to rapid and progressive loss of functioning neurones, which exacerbates bradycardia and hypertension. Without physiological compensation or medical intervention, rising ICP is usually fatal.</p>
<p>The causes of increased ICP include:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>cerebral oedema</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>hydrocephalus, the accumulation of excess CSF</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>expanding lesions inside the skull, also known as space-occupying lesions, such as:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>haemorrhage or haematoma (traumatic or spontaneous)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>tumours (primary or secondary).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Expanding lesions may occur in the brain or in the meninges, and they can damage the brain in various ways (Fig. 7.47).</p>
<p>Effects of increased intracranial pressure</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="displacement-of-the-brain">Displacement of the brain<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#displacement-of-the-brain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Lesions causing displacement are usually one-sided but may affect both sides. Such lesions may cause:</p>
<ul>
<li>herniation (displacement of part of the brain from its usual compartment) of the cerebral hemisphere between the corpus callosum and the free border of the falx cerebri on the same side</li>
<li>herniation of the midbrain between the pons and the free border of the tentorium cerebelli on the same side
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-fa8c6cc2.jpeg" alt="img-265.jpeg"></li>
</ul>
<p>A Subdural haematoma
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-529aa3b4.jpeg" alt="img-266.jpeg"></p>
<p>B Subarachnoid haemorrhage
C Tumour or intracerebral haemorrhage
Figure 7.47 Effects of different types of expanding lesions inside the skull. (A) Subdural haematonna. (B) Subarachnoid haemorrhage. (C) Tumour or intracerebral haemorrhage.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>compression of the subarachnoid space and flattening of the cerebral convolutions</li>
<li>distortion of the shape of the ventricles and their ducts</li>
<li>herniation of the cerebellum through the foramen magnum</li>
<li>protrusion of the medulla oblongata through the foramen magnum ('coning').</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="obstruction-of-the-flow-of-cerebrospinal-fluid">Obstruction of the flow of cerebrospinal fluid<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#obstruction-of-the-flow-of-cerebrospinal-fluid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The ventricles or their ducts may be displaced or a duct obstructed. The effects depend on the position of the lesion; for example, compression of the cerebral aqueduct causes dilation of the lateral ventricles and the third ventricle, further increasing the ICP.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vascular-damage">Vascular damage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vascular-damage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Blood vessels may be stretched or compressed, causing:</p>
<ul>
<li>haemorrhage when stretched blood vessels rupture</li>
<li>intracranial ischaemia and infarction due to compression of blood vessels</li>
<li>papilloedema (oedema round the optic disc) due to compression of the retinal vein in the optic nerve sheath, where it crosses the subarachnoid space.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="neural-damage">Neural damage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#neural-damage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The vital centres in the medulla oblongata may be damaged when the increased ICP causes 'coning'. Stretching of the brain stem may damage cranial nerves, especially the oculomotor (III) and the abducent (VI), causing disturbances of eye movement and accommodation. Dilation of a pupil and loss of the light reflex (failure of the pupil to constrict in response to bright light) are caused by compression of the oculomotor nerve.</p>
<p>Cerebral oedema</p>
<p>Oedema (p. 129) occurs when there is excess fluid in tissue cells and/or interstitial spaces. In the brain, this is known as cerebral oedema and it increases ICP. It is associated with:</p>
<ul>
<li>traumatic head injury</li>
<li>haemorrhage</li>
<li>infections and abscesses</li>
<li>hypoxia, local ischaemia or infarcts</li>
<li>tumours</li>
<li>inflammation of the brain or meninges</li>
<li>hypoglycaemia (p. 257).</li>
</ul>
<p>Hydrocephalus
In this condition the volume of CSF is abnormally high and this is usually accompanied by increased ICP. An obstruction to CSF flow is the most common cause. It is described as communicating when there is free flow of CSF
from the ventricular system to the subarachnoid space and non-communicating when there is not, i.e. there is obstruction in the system of ventricles, foramina or ducts (see Fig. 7.15).</p>
<p>Enlargement of the head occurs in children when ossification of the cranial bones is incomplete but, in spite of this, the ventricles dilate and cause stretching and thinning of the brain. After ossification is complete, hydrocephalus leads to a marked increase in ICP and destruction of nervous tissue.</p>
<p>Head injuries
Damage to the brain may be serious, even when there is no outward sign of injury. At the site of injury there may be:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>a scalp wound, with haemorrhage between scalp and skull bones</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>damage to the underlying meninges and/or brain with local haemorrhage inside the skull</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>a depressed skull fracture, causing local damage to the underlying meninges and brain tissue</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>a temporal bone fracture, creating an opening between the middle ear and the meninges</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>a fracture involving the air sinuses of the sphenoid, ethmoid or frontal bones, making an opening between the nose and the meninges.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Acceleration-deceleration injuries
Because the brain floats relatively freely in a 'cushion' of CSF, sudden acceleration or deceleration has an inertia effect. For example, when a vehicle stops suddenly, passengers are thrown forwards: the head then moves forwards or backwards relative to the rest of the body, causing injury to the brain at the site of impact if it moves within the skull. In 'contre-coup' injuries, brain damage is more severe on the side opposite to the site of impact. Other injuries include:</p>
<ul>
<li>nerve cell damage, usually to the frontal and parietal lobes, due to movement of the brain over the rough surface of bones of the base of the skull</li>
<li>nerve fibre damage due to stretching, especially following rotational movement</li>
<li>haemorrhage (see the next section).</li>
</ul>
<p>Complications of head injury
If the individual survives the immediate effects, complications may develop hours or days later. Sometimes they are the first indication of serious damage caused by a seemingly trivial injury. Their effects may increase ICP, damage brain tissue or provide a route of entry for infection.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="traumatic-intracranial-haemorrhage">Traumatic intracranial haemorrhage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#traumatic-intracranial-haemorrhage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Haemorrhage may occur, causing secondary brain damage at the site of injury, on the opposite side of the brain or
diffusely throughout the brain. If bleeding continues, the expanding haematoma increases the ICP, compressing the brain.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="extradural-haemorrhage">Extradural haemorrhage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#extradural-haemorrhage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This may follow a direct blow that may or may not cause a fracture. The individual may recover quickly and signs of increased ICP typically appear only several hours later as the haematoma grows and the outer layer of dura mater (periosteum) is stripped off the bone. The haematoma grows rapidly when arterial blood vessels are damaged. In children, fractures are rare because the skull bones are still soft and the joints (sutures) have not fused. The haematoma usually remains localised.</p>
<p>Acute subdural haemorrhage</p>
<p>This is due to haemorrhage from either small veins in the dura mater or larger veins between the layers of dura mater before they enter the venous sinuses. The blood may spread in the subdural space over one or both cerebral hemispheres (Fig. 7.47A). There may be concurrent subarachnoid haemorrhage (Fig. 7.47B), especially when there are extensive brain contusions and lacerations.</p>
<p>Chronic subdural haemorrhage
This may occur weeks or months after minor injuries and sometimes there is no history of injury. It occurs most commonly when there is some cerebral atrophy, e.g. in older adults and in alcohol misuse. Evidence of increased ICP may be delayed when brain volume is reduced. The haematoma gradually increases in size owing to repeated small haemorrhages and causes mild chronic inflammation and accumulation of inflammatory exudate. In time, it is isolated by a wall of fibrous tissue.</p>
<p>Intracerebral haemorrhage and cerebral oedema
These occur following contusions, lacerations and shearing injuries associated with acceleration and deceleration, especially rotational movements.</p>
<p>Cerebral oedema (p. 193) is a common complication of contusions of the brain, leading to increased ICP, hypoxia and further brain damage.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="meningitis">Meningitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#meningitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>See page 197 .</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="post-traumatic-epilepsy">Post-traumatic epilepsy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#post-traumatic-epilepsy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is characterised by seizures (fits) and may develop in the first week or several months after injury. Early development is most common after severe injuries, although in children the injury itself may have appeared trivial. After depressed fractures or large haematomas, epilepsy tends to develop later.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vegetative-states">Vegetative states<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vegetative-states" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This condition is a consequence of severe cortical brain damage. The individual appears awake and is observed to undergo sleep-wake cycles; however, there are no signs of awareness or responses to the external environment. As the brain stem remains intact, the vital centres continue to function: i.e. breathing and blood pressure are maintained. It is considered permanent if there is no recovery 12 months after trauma or longer than 6 months after any other cause.</p>
<p>Cerebral hypoxia</p>
<p>Hypoxia may be due to disturbances in the autoregulation of blood supply to the brain or conditions affecting cerebral blood vessels.</p>
<p>When the mean blood pressure falls below about 60 mmHg , the autoregulating mechanisms that control the blood flow to the brain by adjusting the diameter of the arterioles fail. The consequent rapid decrease in the cerebral blood supply leads to hypoxia and lack of glucose. If severe hypoxia is sustained for more than a few minutes, there is irreversible brain damage. Neurones are affected first, then the neuroglial cells and later the meninges and blood vessels. Conditions in which autoregulation breaks down include:</p>
<ul>
<li>cardiorespiratory arrest</li>
<li>sudden severe hypotension</li>
<li>carbon monoxide poisoning</li>
<li>hypercapnia (excess blood carbon dioxide)</li>
<li>drug overdosage with, for example, opioid analgesics or hypnotics.</li>
</ul>
<p>Conditions affecting cerebral blood vessels that may lead to cerebral hypoxia include:</p>
<ul>
<li>occlusion of a cerebral artery by, for example, a rapidly expanding intracranial lesion, atheroma, thrombosis or embolism (Ch. 5)</li>
<li>arterial stenosis that occurs in arteritis, e.g. polyarteritis nodosa, syphilis, diabetes mellitus, or degenerative changes in older adults.</li>
</ul>
<p>If the individual survives the initial episode of ischaemia, then infarction, necrosis and loss of function of the affected area of brain may occur.</p>
<p>Stroke
Cerebrovascular disease is the underlying cause of most strokes and transient ischaemic attacks. Predisposing factors include:</p>
<ul>
<li>hypertension</li>
<li>atheroma</li>
<li>diabetes mellitus</li>
<li>cigarette smoking.</li>
</ul>
<p>Stroke is a very common cause of death and disability in older adults. The incidence is greater in Asian and black African populations, and increases steeply</p>
<p>with age. Effects appear in a few minutes and usually include paralysis of a limb or one side of the body (hemiparesis), often accompanied by disturbances of speech and vision. The nature and extent of damage depend on the location of the affected blood vessels. The vast majority are caused by cerebral infarction (about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>85</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">85 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">85%</span></span></span></span></span> ), with spontaneous intracranial haemorrhage accounting for most of the remainder.</p>
<p>Around <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>80</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">80 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">80%</span></span></span></span></span> of patients survive for at least a month following an acute stroke; gradual improvement of limb movement follows in about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">50%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases, which is sometimes accompanied by improved speech. Recurrence is common.</p>
<p>Transient ischaemic attack
In contrast to a stroke, a transient ischaemic attack (TIA) is a brief period of reversible cerebral deficit. Typically, there is a short period (minutes or hours) where there is weakness of a limb and/or loss of speech and/or vision, followed by complete recovery. A TIA may precede a stroke (about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>30</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">30 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">30%</span></span></span></span></span> in 5 years) or, less commonly, myocardial infarction (Ch. 5). The arbitrary definition of a TIA lasting for less than 24 hours is no longer used.</p>
<p>Cerebral infarction
This occurs when blood flow to the brain is suddenly interrupted, resulting in cerebral hypoxia. The main cause is atheroma affecting the carotid artery or aortic arch, which is complicated by thrombosis (p. 124), although a blocked artery supplying the brain can also arise from an embolus originating in the heart, e.g. infective endocarditis (p. 133).</p>
<p>Spontaneous intracranial haemorrhage
The haemorrhage may be into the subarachnoid space or may be intracerebral (Fig. 7.48). It is commonly associated with an aneurysm or hypertension. In each case the escaped blood may cause arterial spasm, leading to ischaemia, infarction, fibrosis (gliosis) and hypoxic brain damage. A severe haemorrhage may be instantly fatal, while repeated small haemorrhages have a cumulative effect in extending brain damage (multi-infarct dementia).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="intracerebral-haemorrhage">Intracerebral haemorrhage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intracerebral-haemorrhage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Prolonged hypertension leads to the formation of multiple microaneurysms in the walls of very small arteries in the brain. Rupture of one or more of these, due to a continuing rise in blood pressure, is usually the cause of intracerebral haemorrhage. The most common sites are branches of the middle cerebral artery in the region of the internal capsule and the basal ganglia (see Fig. 7.19).</p>
<p>Microaneurysm</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-a0f155cc.jpeg" alt="img-267.jpeg"></p>
<p>Middle cerebral artery
Severe haemorrhage causes compression and destruction of tissue, a sudden increase in ICP and distortion and herniation of the brain. Death follows when the vital centres in the medulla oblongata are damaged by haemorrhage or if there is coning.</p>
<p>Less severe haemorrhage causes paralysis and loss of sensation of varying severity, affecting the side of the body opposite the haemorrhage. If the bleeding stops and does not recur, a fluid-filled cyst develops, i.e. the haematoma is walled off by gliosis, the blood clot is gradually absorbed and the cavity becomes filled with tissue exudate. When the ICP returns to normal, some function may be restored, e.g. speech and movement of limbs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="subarachnoid-haemorrhage">Subarachnoid haemorrhage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#subarachnoid-haemorrhage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This accounts for a small number of strokes and is usually due to rupture of a berry aneurysm on one of the major cerebral arteries, or less often bleeding from a congenitally malformed blood vessel (Fig. 7.48). The blood may remain localised but usually spreads in the subarachnoid space
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-a474155c.jpeg" alt="img-268.jpeg"></p>
<p>Subarachnoid space
Aneurysm
Figure 7.48 Types of haemorrhage causing stroke.
round the brain and spinal cord, causing a general increase in ICP without distortion of the brain (see Fig. 7.47B). The irritant effect of the blood may cause arterial spasm, leading to ischaemia, infarction, gliosis and the effects of localised</p>
<p>brain damage. It occurs most commonly in middle life, but occasionally in young people owing to rupture of a malformed blood vessel. This condition is often fatal or results in permanent disability.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="dementia">Dementia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dementia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There is gradual impairment of memory (especially short term), intellect and reasoning, although consciousness is not affected. Emotional lability and personality change may also occur. Dementia is caused by progressive, irreversible degeneration of the cerebral cortex and results in mental deterioration, usually over several years.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="alzheimer-s-disease">Alzheimer's disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#alzheimer-s-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This condition is the commonest form of dementia in developed countries. The aetiology is unknown, although genetic factors may be involved. Females are affected twice as often as males and it is usually found in those over 60 years, the incidence increasing with age. It commonly affects people with Down's syndrome by the age of 40 years.</p>
<p>There is progressive atrophy of the cerebral cortex, accompanied by deteriorating mental functioning. Death usually occurs between 2 and 8 years after onset.</p>
<p>Huntington's disease
This usually manifests itself between the ages of 30 and 50 years. It is inherited as an autosomal dominant disorder (p. 481) and is associated with deficient production of the neurotransmitter gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA). A child of a Huntington's parent has a <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">50%</span></span></span></span></span> chance of inheriting the gene.</p>
<p>Extrapyramidal changes cause chorea: rapid, uncoordinated jerking movements of the limbs and involuntary twitching of the facial muscles. As the disease progresses, cortical atrophy causes personality changes and dementia.</p>
<p>Secondary dementias
Dementia may occur in association with other conditions:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>vascular dementia, also known as multi-infarct dementia, which may accompany cerebrovascular disease</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>toxicity, e.g. alcohol and solvent misuse and, less often, vitamin B deficiencies</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>tumours, usually metastases but sometimes primary intracranial tumours</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>metabolic (e.g. uraemia, liver failure) and endocrine (e.g. hypothyroidism)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>infections, although these are less common, e.g. syphilis, HIV and CreutzfeldtJakob disease (CJD).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Parkinson's disease
In this condition there is gradual and progressive degeneration of dopaminereleasing neurones in the extrapyramidal system, especially at the basal ganglia. This leads to lack of control and coordination of muscle movement, resulting in:</p>
<ul>
<li>slowness of movement (bradykinesia) and difficulty initiating movements</li>
<li>fixed muscle tone, causing expressionless facial features, and rigidity of voluntary muscles, causing the slow and characteristic stiff, shuffling gait and stooping posture</li>
<li>muscle tremor of extremities that usually begins in one hand, e.g. 'pill-rolling' movement of the fingers</li>
<li>speech problems, excessive salivation and, in advanced disease, dysphagia.</li>
</ul>
<p>Onset is usually between 45 and 60 years, with more men than women affected. The cause is usually unknown but some cases are associated with repeated trauma as in, for example, 'punch-drunk' boxers; tumours causing midbrain compression; drugs such as phenothiazines; and heavy metal poisoning. There is progressive physical disability but cognitive function is not impaired (Fig. 7.49).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-55bf2220.jpeg" alt="img-269.jpeg"></p>
<p>Rigidity and trembling of head and extremities
Slow shuffling gait
Stooped posture
Lack of facial expression
Figure 7.49 Typical posture of Parkinson's disease.</p>
<p>Effects of poisons on the brain
Many chemicals, including drugs, environmental toxins, microbial products and metabolic wastes, can damage nervous tissue. This may range from short-term reversible neurological disturbance, such as depression of cognitive and
motor functions after drinking alcohol, through to long-term permanent damage, such as heavy metal poisoning (e.g. lead) or hepatic encephalopathy (p. 363).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="6">
<li>Explain why hydrocephalus in children, but not adults, may be accompanied by enlargement of the skull.</li>
<li>Relate the pathology of Parkinson's disease to its common signs and symptoms.</li>
</ol>
<p>Infections of the central nervous system
Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe common infections of the nervous system and their effects on body function.</li>
</ul>
<p>The brain and spinal cord are relatively well protected from microbial infection by the blood-brain barrier.</p>
<p>CNS infections are usually bacterial or viral but may also be protozoal or fungal. Infections may originate in the meninges (meningitis) or in the brain (encephalitis), then spread from one site to the other.</p>
<p>Bacterial infections
Entry of bacteria into the CNS may be:</p>
<ul>
<li>direct - through a compound skull fracture or through the skull bones from, for example, middle ear or paranasal sinus infections, mastoiditis</li>
<li>blood-borne - from infection elsewhere in the body, e.g. septicaemia, bacterial endocarditis (p. 133)</li>
<li>iatrogenic - introduced during an invasive procedure, e.g. lumbar puncture.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bacterial-meningitis">Bacterial meningitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bacterial-meningitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The term 'meningitis' usually refers to inflammation of the subarachnoid space. Infection is most commonly transmitted through contact with an infected</p>
<p>individual. Bacterial meningitis is usually preceded by a mild upper respiratory tract infection, during which a few bacteria enter the bloodstream and are carried to the meninges. Common microbes include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Haemophilus influenzae in children between 2 and 5 years of age</li>
<li>Neisseria meningitidis in those between 5 and 30 years (the most common type)</li>
<li>Streptococcus pneumoniae in people over 30 years.</li>
</ul>
<p>Other pathogenic bacteria can also cause meningitis, e.g. those involved in tuberculosis (p. 291) and syphilis.</p>
<p>Meningitis can also affect the dura mater, especially when spread is direct through a compound skull fracture, as leakage of CSF and blood from the site provides a route of entry for microbes. CSF and blood may escape through the:</p>
<ul>
<li>skin, in compound skull fractures</li>
<li>middle ear, in fractures of the temporal bone (CSF otorrhoea)</li>
<li>nose, in fractures of the sphenoid, ethmoid or frontal bones when air sinuses are involved (CSF rhinorrhoea).</li>
</ul>
<p>It may also arise from nearby infections, for example, of the ear. If an extradural or subdural abscess forms, the infection may spread further locally, should it rupture.</p>
<p>The onset is usually sudden with severe headache, neck stiffness, photophobia (intolerance of bright light) and fever. This is sometimes accompanied by round pinpoint spots just under the skin due to bleeding, known as a petechial rash. CSF appears cloudy owing to the presence of many bacteria and neutrophils. Mortality and morbidity rates are considerable.</p>
<p>Entry of viruses into the CNS is usually blood-borne from viral infection elsewhere in the body; less commonly, it is transmitted through the nervous system. In the latter situation, neurotropic viruses, i.e. those with an affinity for nervous tissue, travel along peripheral nerves from a site elsewhere, e.g. poliovirus. They enter the body via:</p>
<ul>
<li>the alimentary tract, e.g. poliomyelitis</li>
<li>the respiratory tract, e.g. shingles</li>
<li>skin abrasions, e.g. rabies.</li>
</ul>
<p>The effects of viral infections vary, according to the site and the amount of tissue destroyed. Viruses may damage neurones by multiplying within them or</p>
<p>stimulating an immune reaction, which may explain why signs of some infections do not appear until there is a high antibody titre, 1-2 weeks after infection.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="viral-meningitis">Viral meningitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viral-meningitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is the most common form of meningitis, which is usually relatively mild and followed by complete recovery.</p>
<p>Viral encephalitis is rare and usually associated with a recent viral infection. Most cases are mild and recovery is usually complete. More serious cases are usually associated with rabies or herpes simplex viruses. Many different sites can be</p>
<p>Viral infections
Viral encephalitis</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>affected and, as neurones cannot be replaced, loss of function reflects the extent of damage. In severe infections, neurones and neuroglia may be affected, followed by necrosis and gliosis. If the individual survives the initial acute phase, there may be residual dysfunction, e.g. cognitive impairment and epilepsy. If vital centres in the medulla are involved, the condition can be fatal.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="herpes-zoster-shingles">Herpes zoster (shingles)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#herpes-zoster-shingles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Herpes zoster viruses cause chickenpox (varicella), mainly in children, and shingles (zoster) in adults. Susceptible children may contract chickenpox from a person with shingles but the reverse is not true. Infected adults may show no immediate signs of disease. The viruses may remain dormant in posterior root ganglia of the spinal nerves and then become active years later, causing shingles. Reactivation may be either spontaneous or associated with intercurrent illness or depression of the immune system, e.g. by drugs, old age or AIDS.</p>
<p>The posterior root ganglion becomes acutely inflamed. From there the viruses travel along the sensory nerve to the surface tissues supplied, e.g. skin or cornea. The infection is usually unilateral and the most common sites are:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>nerves supplying the trunk, sometimes two or three
adjacent dermatomes</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve (see Fig.
7.42), causing trigeminal neuralgia, and, if vesicles form
on the cornea, there may be ulceration, scarring and</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>residual interference with vision.
Affected tissues become inflamed and vesicles, containing serous fluid and viruses, develop along the course of the nerve. This is accompanied by persistent pain and hypersensitivity to touch (hyperaesthesia). Recovery is usually slow and there may be some loss of sensation, depending on the severity of the disease.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="poliomyelitis">Poliomyelitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#poliomyelitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This disease is caused by polioviruses usually and by other enteroviruses occasionally. The infection is spread by food contaminated with infected faecal matter and, initially, viral multiplication occurs in the alimentary tract. The viruses are then blood-borne to the nervous system and invade anterior horn cells in the spinal cord. Usually, there is a mild febrile illness with no indication of nerve damage. In mild cases there is complete recovery but there is permanent disability in many others. Irreversible damage to lower motor neurones (p. 174) causes muscle paralysis, which, in the limbs, may lead to deformity because of the unopposed tonal contraction of antagonistic muscles. Death may be caused by respiratory paralysis (failure) if the intercostal muscles are affected. Vaccination programmes have now almost eradicated this disease in developed countries.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rabies">Rabies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rabies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>All warm-blooded animals are susceptible to the rabies virus, which is endemic in many countries but not in the UK. The main reservoirs of this virus are wild animals, some of which may be carriers. When these infect domestic pets, the latter then become the source of human infection. The viruses multiply in the salivary glands and are present in large numbers in saliva. They enter the body through skin abrasions and are believed to travel to the brain along peripheral nerves. The incubation period varies from about 2 weeks to several months, possibly reflecting the distance that viruses travel between the site of entry and the brain. There is acute encephalomyelitis with extensive damage to the basal ganglia, midbrain and medulla oblongata. Involvement of the posterior root ganglia of the peripheral nerves causes meningeal irritation, extreme hyperaesthesia, muscle spasm and convulsions. Hydrophobia (hatred of water) and overflow of saliva from the mouth are due to painful spasm of the throat muscles that inhibits swallowing. In the advanced stages, muscle spasm may alternate with flaccid paralysis, and death is usually due to respiratory muscle spasm or paralysis.</p>
<p>Not all people exposed to the virus contract rabies, but in those who do, the mortality rate is high.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="human-immunodeficiency-virus">Human immunodeficiency virus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#human-immunodeficiency-virus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The brain is often affected in individuals with AIDS (p. 418), resulting in opportunistic infection (e.g. meningitis) and dementia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="creutzfeldt-jakob-disease">Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#creutzfeldt-jakob-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This infective condition may be caused by a 'slow' virus, the nature and transmission of which are poorly understood. Transmission is thought to be via a heat-resistant transmissible particle known as a prion protein. CJD is a rapidly progressive form of dementia (p. 196), for which there is no known treatment, so the condition is always fatal.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="myalgic-encephalitis">Myalgic encephalitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#myalgic-encephalitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Myalgic encephalitis (ME) is also known as postviral syndrome or chronic fatigue syndrome. It affects mostly teenagers and young adults, and the aetiology is unknown. Sometimes the condition follows a viral illness. The effects include malaise, severe fatigue, poor concentration and myalgia. Recovery is usually spontaneous but sometimes results in chronic disability.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5205029c">■ SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5205029c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="8">
<li>Outline the relationship between chickenpox and shingles.</li>
</ol>
<p>Demyelinating diseases
Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>explain how the signs and symptoms of demyelinating disease are related to pathological changes in the nervous system.</li>
</ul>
<p>These diseases are caused either by injury to axons or by disorders of cells that secrete myelin, i.e. oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells.</p>
<p>Multiple sclerosis
In multiple sclerosis (MS), areas of demyelinated white matter, called plaques, replace myelin. They are irregularly distributed throughout the brain and spinal cord. Grey matter in the brain and spinal cord may also be affected because of the arrangement of satellite oligodendrocytes round cell bodies. In the early stages there may be little damage to axons.</p>
<p>MS usually develops between the 20 and 40 years of age and affects twice as many women as men. The actual cause(s) of MS are not known but several factors seem</p>
<p>to be involved. It appears to be an autoimmune disorder, possibly triggered by a viral infection, e.g. measles.</p>
<p>Environment before adolescence is implicated because the disease is most prevalent in people who spend their preadolescent years in temperate climates, and those who move to other climates after that age retain their susceptibility to MS. People from equatorial areas moving into a temperate climate during adolescence or later life appear not to be susceptible.</p>
<p>Genetic factors are implicated too, as there is an increased incidence of MS among siblings, especially identical twins, and parents of patients.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effects-of-multiple-sclerosis">Effects of multiple sclerosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effects-of-multiple-sclerosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Symptoms depend on the size and location of the developing plaques and include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Weakness of skeletal muscles and sometimes paralysis.</li>
<li>Loss of coordination and movement.</li>
<li>Disturbed sensation, e.g. burning or pins and needles.</li>
<li>Incontinence of urine.</li>
<li>Visual disturbances, especially blurring and double vision. The optic nerves are commonly affected early in the disease.</li>
</ul>
<p>The disease pattern is usually one of relapses and remissions of widely varying duration. Each relapse causes further loss of nervous tissue and progressive dysfunction.</p>
<p>In some cases, there may be chronic progression without remission, or acute disease rapidly leading to death.</p>
<p>Acute disseminated encephalomyeiitis
This is a rare but serious condition that may occur as a complication of a viral infection, e.g. measles or chickenpox, or may rarely follow primary immunisation against viral diseases, mainly in older children and adults.</p>
<p>The cause of the acute diffuse demyelination is not known. It has been suggested that an autoimmune effect on myelin is triggered either by viruses during a viral infection such as measles, or by an immune response to vaccines. The effects vary considerably, according to the distribution and degree of demyelination, and are similar to those of MS. The early febrile state may progress to paralysis and coma. Most patients survive the initial phase and recover completely but some have severe neurological impairment.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="9">
<li>Outline the pathological changes characteristic of multiple sclerosis.</li>
</ol>
<p>Diseases of the spinal cord</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>explain how disorders of the spinal cord cause abnormal function.</li>
</ul>
<p>Because space in the neural canal and intervertebral foramina is limited, any condition that distorts their shape or reduces the space may damage the spinal cord or peripheral nerve roots, or compress blood vessels, causing ischaemia. Such conditions include:</p>
<ul>
<li>fracture and/ or dislocation of vertebrae</li>
<li>tumours of the meninges or vertebrae</li>
<li>prolapsed intervertebral disc.</li>
</ul>
<p>The effects of disease or injury depend on the severity of the damage, and the type and position of the neurones involved.</p>
<p>Motor neurones
Table 7.4 gives a summary of the effects of damage to the motor neurones. The parts of the body affected depend on</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
