<p>Upper motor neurone Lower motor neurone</p>
<p>Muscle weakness and spastic paralysis</p>
<p>Exaggerated tendon reflexes</p>
<p>Muscle weakness and flaccid paralysis</p>
<p>Absence of tendon reflexes</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="muscle-twitching">Muscle twitching<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscle-twitching" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Muscle wasting
Contracture of muscles
Impaired circulation
which neurones have been damaged and their site in the brain, spinal cord or peripheral nerve.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="upper-motor-neurone-lesions">Upper motor neurone lesions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#upper-motor-neurone-lesions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Lesions of the upper motor neurones (UMNs) above the level of the decussation of the pyramids affect the opposite side of the body, e.g. haemorrhage or infarction in the internal capsule of one hemisphere causes paralysis of the opposite side of the body. Lesions below the decussation affect the same side of the body. The lower motor neurones are released from cortical control and muscle tone is increased (Table 7.4).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lower-motor-neurone-lesions">Lower motor neurone lesions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lower-motor-neurone-lesions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The cell bodies of lower motor neurones (LMNs) are in the spinal cord and the axons are part of peripheral nerves. Lesions of LMNs lead to weakness or paralysis and atrophy of the effector muscles they supply.</p>
<p>Motor neurone disease
This is a chronic progressive degeneration of UMNs and LMNs, occurring more commonly in men over 50 years of age. The cause is seldom known, although a few cases are inherited as an autosomal dominant disorder (p. 481). Motor neurones in the cerebral cortex, brain stem and anterior horns of the spinal cord are destroyed and replaced by gliosis. Early effects are usually weakness and twitching of the small muscles of the hand and the muscles of the arm and shoulder girdle. The legs are affected later. Death occurs within 3-5 years and is usually due to respiratory difficulties or complications of immobility.</p>
<p>Mixed motor and sensory conditions
Subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord
This condition most commonly occurs as a complication of pernicious anaemia (p. 74). Vitamin B 12 is needed for the formation and maintenance of myelin by Schwann cells and oligodendrocytes. Although degeneration of the spinal cord may be apparent before the anaemia, it is arrested by treatment with vitamin B 12 .</p>
<p>The degeneration of myelin occurs in the posterior and lateral columns of white matter in the spinal cord, especially in the upper thoracic and lower cervical</p>
<p>regions. Less frequently the changes occur in the posterior root ganglia and peripheral nerves. Demyelination of proprioceptor fibres (sensory) leads to ataxia, and involvement of upper motor neurones leads to increased muscle tone and spastic paralysis. Without treatment, death may occur within 5 years.</p>
<p>Compression of the spinal cord and nerve roots
The causes include:</p>
<ul>
<li>prolapsed intervertebral disc</li>
<li>syringomyelia</li>
<li>tumours: metastatic, meningeal or nerve sheath</li>
<li>fractures with displacement of bone fragments.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="prolapsed-intervertebral-disc">Prolapsed intervertebral disc<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#prolapsed-intervertebral-disc" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is the most common cause of compression of the spinal cord and/or nerve roots. The vertebral bodies are separated by the intervertebral discs, each consisting of an outer rim of cartilage, the annulus fibrosus, and a central core of soft gelatinous material, the nucleus pulposus.</p>
<p>Prolapse of a disc is herniation of the nucleus pulposus, causing the annulus fibrosus and the posterior longitudinal ligament to protrude into the neural canal. It is most common in the lumbar region, usually below the level of the spinal cord, i.e. below L2, and therefore affects nerve roots only (Fig. 7.50). If it occurs in the cervical region the cord may also be compressed. Herniation may occur suddenly, typically in young adults during strenuous exercise or exertion, or progressively in older people when there is bone disease
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-83d03779.jpeg" alt="img-270.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 7.50 Prolapsed intervertebral disc.</p>
<p>or degeneration of the disc, which leads to rupture during minimal exercise. The hernia may be:</p>
<ul>
<li>one-sided, causing pressure damage to a nerve root</li>
<li>midline, compressing the spinal cord, the anterior spinal artery and possibly bilateral nerve roots.</li>
</ul>
<p>The outcome depends on the size of the hernia and the length of time the pressure is applied. Small herniations cause local pain due to pressure on the nerve endings in the posterior longitudinal ligament. Large herniations may cause:</p>
<ul>
<li>unilateral or bilateral paralysis</li>
<li>acute or chronic pain perceived to originate from the area supplied by the compressed sensory nerve, e.g. in the leg or foot</li>
<li>compression of the anterior spinal artery, causing ischaemia and possibly necrosis of the spinal cord</li>
<li>local muscle spasm due to pressure on motor nerves.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="syringomyelia">Syringomyelia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#syringomyelia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This dilation (syrinx) of the central canal of the spinal cord occurs most commonly in the cervical region and is associated with congenital abnormality of the distal end of the fourth ventricle. As the central canal dilates, pressure causes progressive damage to sensory and motor neurones.</p>
<p>Early effects include dissociated anaesthesia, i.e. insensibility to heat and pain, due to compression of the sensory fibres that cross the cord immediately they enter. In the long term, there is destruction of motor and sensory tracts, leading to spastic paralysis and loss of sensation and reflexes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5205029c">■ SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5205029c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="10">
<li>Describe the changes in an intervertebral disc that has prolapsed.</li>
</ol>
<p>Diseases of peripheral nerves
Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>compare and contrast the causes and effects of polyneuropathies and mononeuropathies</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>describe the effects of Guillain-Barre syndrome and Bell's palsy.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Peripheral neuropathy
This is a group of diseases of peripheral nerves not associated with inflammation. They are classified as:</p>
<ul>
<li>polyneuropathy: several nerves are affected</li>
<li>mononeuropathy: a single nerve is usually affected.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="polyneuropathy">Polyneuropathy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#polyneuropathy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Damage to a number of nerves and their myelin sheaths occurs in association with other disorders such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>vitamin deficiencies, e.g. vitamins <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></mrow><mo separator="true">,</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi></mrow><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mn>12</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Bi}, \mathrm{Be}, \mathrm{B} 12</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Bi</span></span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Be</span></span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">B</span><span class="mord">12</span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li>metabolic disorders, e.g. diabetes mellitus, uraemia (in renal failure), hepatic failure, malignancy</li>
<li>toxic reactions to, e.g., alcohol, lead, mercury, aniline dyes and some drugs, such as phenytoin, isoniazid.</li>
</ul>
<p>Long nerves are usually affected first, e.g. those supplying the feet and legs. The outcome depends on the cause of the neuropathy and the extent of the damage.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mononeuropathy">Mononeuropathy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mononeuropathy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Usually only one nerve is damaged and the most common cause is ischaemia due to pressure. The resultant dysfunction depends on the site and extent of the injury. Examples include:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>pressure applied to cranial nerves in cranial bone foramina due to distortion of the brain by increased ICP</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>compression of a nerve in a confined space caused by surrounding inflammation and oedema, e.g. the median nerve in carpal tunnel syndrome (p. 472)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>external pressure on a nerve, e.g. in an unconscious person lying with an arm hanging over the side of a bed or trolley</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>compression of the axillary (circumflex) nerve by ill-fitting crutches</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>trapping of a nerve between the broken ends of a bone</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>ischaemia due to thrombosis of blood vessels supplying a nerve.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Guillain-Barre syndrome
Also known as acute inflammatory polyneuropathy, this is sudden, acute, progressive, bilateral ascending muscular weakness or paralysis. It begins in the lower limbs and spreads to the arms, trunk and cranial nerves. It usually occurs 1-3 weeks after an upper respiratory tract infection. There is widespread inflammation, accompanied by some demyelination of spinal, peripheral and cranial nerves and the spinal ganglia. Paralysis may affect all the limbs and the respiratory muscles. Patients who survive the acute phase usually recover completely in weeks or months.</p>
<p>Bell's palsy
Compression of a facial nerve in the temporal bone foramen causes paralysis of facial muscles with drooping and loss of facial expression on the affected side. The immediate cause is inflammation and oedema of the nerve. The underlying cause is thought to be viral. The onset may be sudden or</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>develop over several hours. Distortion of the features is due to muscle tone on the unaffected side, the affected side being expressionless. Recovery is usually complete within 3-8 weeks, although the condition is sometimes permanent.
defects may be of genetic origin or due to environmental factors, e.g. irradiation, or maternal infection (rubella) at a critical stage in development of the fetal vertebrae and spinal cord. The effects depend on the extent of the abnormality.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="11">
<li>Describe Bell's palsy and its usual consequences.</li>
</ol>
<p>Developmental abnormalities of the nervous system
Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe developmental abnormalities of the nervous system</li>
<li>relate their effects to abnormal body function.</li>
</ul>
<p>Spina bifida
This is a congenital malformation of the embryonic neural tube and spinal cord (Fig. 7.51). The vertebral (neural) arches are absent and the dura mater is abnormal,</p>
<p>most commonly in the lumbosacral region. The causes are not known, although the condition is associated with dietary deficiency of folic acid at the time of conception. These neural tube</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="occult-spina-bifida">Occult spina bifida<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#occult-spina-bifida" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In this 'hidden' condition the skin over the defect is intact and excessive growth of hair over the site may be the only sign of abnormality. This is sometimes associated with minor nerve defects that commonly affect the bladder.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="meningocele">Meningocele<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#meningocele" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The skin over the defect is very thin and may rupture after birth. There is dilation of the subarachnoid space posteriorly. The spinal cord is correctly positioned.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="meningomyelocele">Meningomyelocele<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#meningomyelocele" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The meninges and spinal cord are grossly abnormal. The skin may be absent or rupture. In either case, there is leakage of CSF and the meninges may become infected. Serious nerve defects result in paraplegia and lack of sphincter control, causing incontinence of urine and faeces. There may also be mental impairment.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="12">
<li>Identify the factors thought to predispose to spina bifida.

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Hydrocephalus
See page 193 .
Tumours of the nervous system
Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>outline the effects of tumours of the nervous system.</li>
</ul>
<p>Some <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">50%</span></span></span></span></span> of brain tumours are metastases from the other primary sites, often the bronchus, breast, stomach or prostate (see later).</p>
<p>Primary tumours of the nervous system usually arise from the neuroglia, meninges or blood vessels. Neurones are rarely involved because they do not normally multiply. Nervous tissue tumours rarely metastasise. Because of this, the rate of growth of an intracranial tumour is more important than the likelihood of spread outside the nervous system. In this context, 'benign' means slow growing and 'malignant' rapid growing. For instance, a small, benign, capsulated tumour can have massive and disproportionate consequences if it blocks CSF drainage or compresses critical centres. Early signs typically include headache, vomiting, visual disturbances and papilloedema (swelling of the optic disc seen by</p>
<p>ophthalmoscopy). Signs of raised ICP appear after the limits of compensation have been reached (p. 192).</p>
<p>Within the confined space of the skull, haemorrhage within a tumour exacerbates the increased ICP caused by the tumour.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="slow-growing-tumours">Slow-growing tumours<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#slow-growing-tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These allow time for compensation for increasing ICP, so the tumour may be quite large before its effects are evident. Compensation involves gradual reduction in the volume of CSF and circulating blood.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rapidly-growing-tumours">Rapidly growing tumours<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rapidly-growing-tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These do not allow time for adjustment to compensate for the rapidly increasing ICP, so the effects quickly become apparent (see Fig. 7.47C). Complications include:</p>
<ul>
<li>neurological impairment, depending on tumour site and size</li>
<li>effects of increased ICP (p. 192)</li>
<li>necrosis of the tumour, causing haemorrhage and oedema.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="specific-tumours">Specific tumours<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#specific-tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Brain tumours typically arise from different cells in adults and children, and may range from benign to highly malignant. The most common tumours in adults are glioblastomas and meningiomas, which are usually benign and originate from arachnoid granulations. Astrocytomas and medulloblastomas account for most brain tumours in children.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="metastases-in-the-brain">Metastases in the brain<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#metastases-in-the-brain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The prognosis of this condition is poor and the effects depend on the site(s) and rate of growth of metastases. There are two forms: discrete multiple tumours, mainly in the cerebrum, and diffuse tumours in the arachnoid mater.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="13">
<li>Explain why primary tumours of the nervous system nearly always arise from the glia, meninges or blood vessels.</li>
</ol>

<p>The special senses are hearing, sight, smell, taste and balance; all have specialised sensory receptors that collect and transmit information to specific areas of the brain. Incoming nerve impulses from the ears, eyes, nose and mouth are integrated and coordinated within the brain, allowing perception of this information. Up to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>80</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">80 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">80%</span></span></span></span></span> of what we perceive comes from external sensory stimuli. The first sections of this chapter explore the special senses, while the later ones consider the effect of ageing and problems that arise when disorders occur in the structures involved in hearing and vision.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hearing-and-the-ear">Hearing and the ear<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hearing-and-the-ear" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the structure of the outer, middle and inner parts of the ear</li>
<li>explain the physiology of hearing.</li>
</ul>
<p>CHAPTER C
The ear is the organ of hearing and is also involved in balance. It is supplied by the cochlear branch of the 8th cranial (vestibulocochlear) nerve, which responds to the vibrations generated by sound waves and transmits this information to the brain.</p>
<p>With the exception of the auricle (pinna), the structures that form the ear are encased within the petrous portion of the temporal bone.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="structure">Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The ear is divided into three distinct parts (Fig. 8.1): the outer ear, middle ear (tympanic cavity) and inner ear.</p>
<p>The outer ear collects sound waves and directs them to the middle ear, which in turn transfers them to the inner ear. The inner ear converts the sound waves into nerve impulses, which are transmitted to the auditory cortex (hearing area) of the brain.</p>
<p>Outer ear
The outer ear consists of the auricle (pinna) and the external acoustic meatus (auditory canal).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="auricle-pinna">Auricle (pinna)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#auricle-pinna" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The auricle is the visible part of the ear that projects from the side of the head. It is composed of fibroelastic cartilage and covered with skin. It is deeply grooved and ridged; the most prominent outer ridge is the helix.</p>
<p>The lobule (earlobe) is the soft pliable part at the lower extremity, composed of fibrous and adipose tissue richly supplied with blood.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="external-acoustic-meatus-auditory-canal">External acoustic meatus (auditory canal)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#external-acoustic-meatus-auditory-canal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a slightly 'S'-shaped tube about 2.5 cm long, extending from the auricle to the tympanic membrane (eardrum). The lateral third is embedded in cartilage and the remainder lies within the temporal bone. It is lined with skin continuous with that of the auricle. There are numerous ceruminous glands and hair follicles, with associated sebaceous glands, in the skin of the lateral third. Ceruminous glands are modified sweat glands that secrete cerumen (earwax), a sticky material containing protective substances including the bactericidal enzyme lysozyme and immunoglobulins. Foreign materials, e.g. dust, insects and microbes, are prevented from reaching the tympanic membrane by wax, hairs and the curvature</p>
<p>Auricle</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-49fd4fa3.jpeg" alt="img-274.jpeg"></p>

<p>The tympanic membrane (eardrum) (Fig. 8.2) completely separates the external acoustic meatus from the middle ear. It is oval shaped with the slightly broader edge upwards and is formed by three layers of tissue: an outer covering of hairless</p>
<p>skin, a middle layer of fibrous tissue and an inner lining of mucous membrane continuous with that of the middle ear.</p>
<p>Middle ear (tympanic cavity)
This is an irregular-shaped air-filled cavity within the petrous portion of the temporal bone (Fig. 8.3; see also Fig. 8.1). The cavity, its contents and the air sacs that open out of it are lined with either simple squamous or cuboidal epithelium.</p>
<p>The lateral wall of the middle ear is formed by the tympanic membrane.
The roof and floor are formed by the temporal bone.
The posterior wall is formed by the temporal bone with openings leading to the mastoid antrum, through which air passes to the air cells within the mastoid process.</p>
<p>The medial wall is a thin layer of temporal bone in which there are two openings:</p>
<ul>
<li>oval window</li>
<li>round window (see Fig. 8.6).</li>
</ul>
<p>The oval window is covered by part of a small bone called the stapes and the round window by a fine sheet of fibrous tissue.</p>
<p>Figure 8.3 The auditory ossicles.
Air reaches the cavity through the pharyngotympanic (auditory or Eustachian) tube, which links the nasopharynx and middle ear. It is about 4 cm long and lined with ciliated columnar epithelium. The presence of air at atmospheric pressure on both sides of the tympanic membrane is maintained by the pharyngotympanic tube and this enables the membrane to vibrate when sound waves strike it. The pharyngotympanic tube is normally closed but when there is unequal pressure across the tympanic membrane, e.g. at high altitude, it is opened by swallowing or yawning and the ears 'pop', equalising the pressure again.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="auditory-ossicles">Auditory ossicles<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#auditory-ossicles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are three very small bones, only a few millimetres in size, that form a chain across the middle ear from the tympanic membrane to the oval window (Fig. 8.3; see also Fig. 8.1). Between the bones there are synovial joints that allow the bones to vibrate within the air-filled tympanic cavity. The ossicles are held in place by fine ligaments and are named according to their shapes.</p>
<p>Malleus. This is the lateral hammer-shaped bone. The handle is in contact with the tympanic membrane, and the head forms a synovial joint with the incus.</p>
<p>Incus. This is the middle anvil-shaped bone. Its body articulates with the malleus, and the long process with the stapes; it is stabilised by the short process, fixed by fibrous tissue to the posterior wall of the tympanic cavity.</p>
<p>Stapes. This is the medial stirrup-shaped bone. Its head articulates with the incus and its footplate fits into the oval window.</p>
<p>Lateral membranous Anterior membranous
semicircular canal and duct semicircular canal and duct

<p>Figure 8.4 The inner ear. The membranous labyrinth within the bony labyrinth.
Inner ear
The inner ear (Fig. 8.4) or labyrinth (meaning 'maze') contains the organs of hearing and balance. It is described in two parts: the bony labyrinth and the membranous labyrinth. It is divided into three main regions:</p>
<ul>
<li>the vestibule, containing the utricle and saccule</li>
<li>three semicircular canals</li>
<li>the cochlea.</li>
</ul>
<p>The inner ear is formed from a network of channels and cavities in the temporal bone (the bony labyrinth). Within the bony labyrinth, like a tube within a tube, is the membranous labyrinth, a network of fluid-filled membranes that lines and fills the bony labyrinth (Fig. 8.4).</p>
<p>Bony labyrinth
This is lined with periosteum. Within the bony labyrinth, the membranous labyrinth is suspended in a watery fluid called perilymph.</p>
<p>Membranous labyrinth
This is filled with endolymph.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vestibule">Vestibule<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vestibule" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is the expanded part nearest the middle ear. The oval and round windows are located in its lateral wall. It contains two membranous sacs, the utricle and the saccule, which are important in balance (p. 212).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="semicircular-canals">Semicircular canals<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#semicircular-canals" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are three tubes arranged so that one is situated in each of the three planes of space. They are continuous with the vestibule and are also important in balance (p. 212).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cochlea">Cochlea<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cochlea" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This resembles a snail's shell. It has a broad base where it is continuous with the vestibule and a narrow apex, and it spirals round a central bony column.</p>
<p>A cross-section of the cochlea (Fig. 8.5) contains three compartments:</p>
<ul>
<li>the scala vestibuli</li>
<li>the scala media, or cochlear duct</li>
<li>the scala tympani.</li>
</ul>

<p>Perilymph Endolymph Perilymph</p>
<p>Fluid Fluid wave Fluid ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">\</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\backslash</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">\</span></span></span></span></span>

<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span></span></span></span></span>

<p>B
Figure 8.6 Passage of sound waves: (A) The ear with cochlea uncoiled. (B) Summary of transmission.</p>
<p>In cross-section the bony cochlea has two compartments containing perilymph: the scala vestibuli, which originates at the oval window, and the scala tympani, which ends at the round window. The two compartments are continuous with each other and Fig. 8.6 shows the relationship between these structures. The cochlear duct, which is an extension of the membranous labyrinth, lies between the scala vestibuli and the scala tympani, is triangular in cross-section and contains the organs of hearing. On the basilar membrane, or base of the triangle, there are supporting cells and specialised cochlear hair cells containing auditory receptors. These cells form the spiral organ (of Corti), the sensory organ that responds to vibration by initiating nerve impulses that are then perceived as hearing within the brain. The auditory receptors are dendrites of afferent (sensory) nerves that combine, forming the cochlear (auditory) part of the vestibulocochlear nerve (8th cranial nerve), which</p>
<p>passes through a foramen in the temporal bone to reach the hearing area in the temporal lobe of the cerebrum (see Fig. 7.20).</p>
<p>Physiology of hearing II 8.i
Sound is carried as pressure (sound) waves in the air, which travel at about 340 metres per second. The auricle, because of its shape, collects and concentrates sound waves and directs them along the auditory canal, causing the tympanic membrane to vibrate. Tympanic membrane vibrations
are transmitted and amplified through the middle ear by movement of the ossicles (Fig. 8.6). At their medial end the footplate of the stapes rocks to and fro in the oval window, setting up fluid waves in the perilymph of the scala vestibuli. Some of the force of these waves is transmitted along the length of the scala vestibuli and scala tympani, but most of the pressure is transmitted into the cochlear duct. This causes a corresponding wave motion in the endolymph, resulting in vibration of the basilar membrane and stimulation of the auditory receptors in the hair cells of the spiral organ. The nerve impulses generated pass to the brain in the cochlear (auditory) portion of the vestibulocochlear nerve. The fluid wave is finally expended into the middle ear by vibration of the membrane of the round window. The vestibulocochlear nerve transmits the impulses to the auditory nuclei in the medulla, where they synapse before they are conducted to the auditory area in the temporal lobe of the cerebrum (see Fig. 7.20). Because some fibres cross over in the medulla and others do not, the left and right auditory areas of the cerebrum receive impulses from both ears.</p>
<p>Sound waves have the properties of pitch and volume (Fig. 8.7). Pitch is determined by the frequency of the sound waves and is measured in hertz <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">z</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{Hz})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Hz</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>. Sounds of different frequencies stimulate the basilar membrane (see Fig. 8.6A) at different places along its length, allowing discrimination of pitch. The basilar membrane close to the oval window is sensitive to high-pitched sounds, whereas the region
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-0884a7f8.jpeg" alt="img-280.jpeg"></p>
<p>CD
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">□</mi><mn>0</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square 0</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">□</span><span class="mord">0</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2f499b24"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">△</mi><mi>A</mi><mi>A</mi><mi>A</mi><mi>A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">△</mi><mi>A</mi><mi>A</mi><mi>A</mi><mi>A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\triangle A A A A \triangle A A A A</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">△</span><span class="mord mathnormal">AAAA</span><span class="mord">△</span><span class="mord mathnormal">AAAA</span></span></span></span></span><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2f499b24" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

towards the tip of the cochlea is responsive to lower-pitched sounds.
The volume depends on the magnitude of the sound waves and is measured in decibels <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{dB})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">dB</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>. The greater the amplitude of the wave created in the endolymph, the greater is the stimulation of the auditory receptors in the hair cells in the spiral organ, enabling perception of sounds with different volume. Long-term exposure to excessive noise causes hearing impairment because it damages the sensitive hair cells of the spiral organ.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="spot-check">- SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<p>Balance and the ear
Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to: describe the physiology of balance.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-semicircular-canals-and-vestibule">The semicircular canals and vestibule<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-semicircular-canals-and-vestibule" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The semicircular canals (see Fig. 8.4) have no auditory function, although they are closely associated with the
cochlea. Instead, they provide information about the position of the head in space, contributing to maintenance of posture and balance.</p>
<p>There are three semicircular canals, one lying in each of the three planes of space. They are situated above, beside and behind the vestibule of the inner ear and open into it.</p>
<p>The semicircular canals, like the cochlea, are composed of an outer bony wall and inner membranous tubes or ducts. The membranous ducts contain endolymph and are separated from the bony wall by perilymph.</p>
<p>The utricle is a membranous sac that is part of the vestibule, and the three membranous ducts open into it at their dilated ends, the ampullae. The saccule is a part of the vestibule and communicates with the utricle and the cochlea.</p>
<p>In the walls of the utricle, saccule and ampullae are fine, specialised epithelial cells with minute projections, called hair cells. Among the hair cells there are receptors on sensory nerve endings, which combine, forming the vestibulocochlear nerve.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="physiology-of-balance">Physiology of balance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physiology-of-balance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The semicircular canals and the vestibule (utricle and saccule) are concerned with balance, or equilibrium. The arrangement of the three semicircular canals, one in each plane, allows perception not only of the position of the head in space but also of the direction and rate of any movement. Any change of position of the head causes movement in the endolymph bathing the hair cells, which distorts them and stimulates the sensory receptors in the utricle, saccule and ampullae. The resultant nerve impulses are transmitted by the vestibular nerve, which joins the cochlear nerve to form the vestibulocochlear nerve. The vestibular branch passes first to the vestibular nucleus, then to the cerebellum.</p>
<p>The cerebellum also receives nerve impulses from the eyes and proprioceptors (sensory receptors) in the skeletal muscles and joints. The cerebellum coordinates incoming impulses from the vestibular nerve, the eyes and proprioceptors.
Thereafter, impulses are transmitted to the cerebrum and skeletal muscles, enabling perception of body position and any adjustments needed to maintain posture and balance. This maintains upright posture and fixing of the eyes on the same point, independently of head movements.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">- SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="3">

</ol>

<p>Sight and the eye
Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the gross structure of the eye</li>
<li>describe the route taken by nerve impulses from the retina to the cerebrum</li>
<li>explain how light entering the eye is focused on the retina</li>
</ul>
<p>■ state the functions of the extraocular eye muscles
■ explain the functions of the accessory organs of the eye.
The eye is the organ of sight. It is situated in the orbital cavity, a bony socket built into the bones of the face and supplied by the optic nerve (2nd cranial nerve). It is almost spherical in
shape and about 2.5 cm in diameter. The space between the eye and the orbital cavity is occupied by adipose tissue. The bony walls of the orbit and the fat within it protect the eye from injury.</p>
<p>Structurally, the two eyes are separate but, unlike the ears, some of their activities are coordinated so that they normally function as a pair. It is possible to see with only one eye (monocular vision) but three-dimensional vision is impaired when only one eye is used, especially in relation to the judgement of speed and distance.</p>
<p>Structure
Internally, the eye is divided into two chambers, the anterior and the posterior chambers, with the lens of the eye, the ciliary body and the suspensory ligaments (Fig. 8.8) separating them. The anterior chamber is filled with a clear, watery fluid called aqueous humour, and the posterior chamber is filled with a jelly-like substance called vitreous humour (vitreous body).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-63c9ba33.jpeg" alt="img-281.jpeg"></p>
<p>Macula lutea

<p>Figure 8.8 Transverse section of the right eye.</p>
<p>Learning outcomes</p>
<p>There are three layers of tissue in the walls of the eye:</p>
<ul>
<li>the outer fibrous layer: sclera and cornea</li>
<li>the middle vascular layer or uveal tract: the choroid, ciliary body and iris</li>
<li>the inner nervous tissue layer: the retina.</li>
</ul>
<p>Sclera and cornea</p>
<p>The sclera, or white of the eye, forms the outermost layer of the posterior and lateral aspects of the eyeball and is continuous anteriorly with the cornea. It is a firm fibrous membrane that maintains the shape of the eye and gives attachment to the extrinsic muscles of the eye (see Table 8.1,
p.221).</p>
<p>Anteriorly the sclera continues as a clear transparent epithelial membrane, the cornea. Light rays pass through the cornea to reach the retina. The cornea is convex</p>
<p>anteriorly and is involved in refracting (bending) light rays to focus them on the retina.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="choroid">Choroid<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#choroid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The choroid (Fig. 8.9; see also Fig. 8.8) lines the posterior five-sixths of the inner surface of the sclera. It is very rich in blood vessels and is deep chocolate brown in colour. Light enters the eye through the pupil, stimulates the sensory receptors in the retina (see below) and is then absorbed by the choroid.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ciliary-body">Ciliary body<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ciliary-body" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The ciliary body is the anterior continuation of the choroid, consisting of ciliary muscle (circular smooth muscle fibres) and secretory epithelial cells. The lens is attached to the ciliary body by radiating suspensory ligaments, like the spokes of a wheel (see Fig. 8.10). Contraction and relaxation of the ciliary muscle fibres, which are attached to these ligaments, determine the size and thickness of the lens.</p>
<p>The epithelial cells secrete aqueous humour, which circulates through the anterior chamber to nourish its structures.</p>
<p>The ciliary body is supplied by parasympathetic branches of the oculomotor nerve (3rd cranial nerve). Stimulation causes contraction of the ciliary muscle and accommodation of the eye (p. 218).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iris">Iris<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iris" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The iris is the visible coloured ring at the front of the eye and extends anteriorly from the ciliary body, lying behind the cornea and in front of the lens. It divides the anterior chamber of the eye into anterior and posterior cavities, which contain aqueous humour secreted by the ciliary body. The iris is composed of pigment cells and two layers of smooth muscle fibres, one circular and the other radiating (see Fig. 8.9). In the centre is an aperture called the pupil.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-8229263c.jpeg" alt="img-282.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 8.9 The choroid, ciliary body and iris. Viewed from the front.
The iris is supplied by parasympathetic and sympathetic nerves. Parasympathetic stimulation constricts the pupil and sympathetic stimulation dilates it (see Figs 7.45 and 7.44 , respectively).</p>
<p>The colour of the iris is genetically determined and depends on the number of pigment cells present. Albinos have no pigment cells and people with blue eyes have fewer than those with brown eyes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lens">Lens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The lens (Fig. 8.10) is a highly elastic circular biconvex body, lying immediately behind the pupil. It consists of fibres enclosed within a capsule and is suspended from the ciliary body by the suspensory ligament. Its thickness is controlled by the ciliary muscle through the suspensory ligament. The lens bends (refracts) light rays reflected into the eye from objects in the visual field. It is the only structure in the eye that can vary its thickness, and therefore its refractory power, to focus light rays on the retina.</p>
<p>When the ciliary muscle contracts, it releases its pull on the lens, increasing its thickness. The nearer the object being viewed, the thicker the lens becomes to allow focusing (see Fig. 8.18).</p>
<p>Retina
The retina is the innermost lining of the eye (see Fig. 8.8). It is an extremely delicate structure composed of several layers of nerve cell bodies and their axons, lying on a pigmented layer of epithelial cells. The light-sensitive layer consists of</p>
<p>sensory receptor cells, rods and cones, which contain photosensitive pigments that convert light rays into nerve impulses.</p>
<p>The retina lines about three-quarters of the eyeball and is thickest at the back. It thins out anteriorly to end just behind the ciliary body. Near the centre of the posterior part is the macula lutea, or yellow spot (Figs 8.11A and 8.12). In the centre of the yellow spot is a little depression called the fovea
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-1e088e61.jpeg" alt="img-283.jpeg"></p>
<p>Ciliary body
Ciliary
muscle</p>
<p>Lens</p>
<p>Suspensory
ligaments</p>
<p>Retina</p>
<p>Choroid</p>
<p>Sclera</p>
<p>Figure 8.10 The lens and suspensory ligaments viewed from the front. The iris has been removed.
centralis, consisting only of cones. Towards the anterior part of the retina there are fewer cones than rods.</p>
<p>About 0.5 cm to the nasal side of the macula lutea all the retinal nerve fibres converge to form the optic nerve. The small area of retina where the optic nerve leaves the eye is the optic disc or blind spot. It has no light-sensitive cells.</p>
<p>Blood supply to the eye</p>
<p>Arterial supply is from the ciliary arteries and the central retinal artery. These are branches of the ophthalmic artery, a branch of the internal carotid artery.</p>
<p>Venous drainage is by a number of veins, including the central retinal vein, which eventually empty into a deep venous sinus.</p>
<p>The central retinal artery and vein are encased in the optic nerve, which enters the eye at the optic disc (see Fig. 8.8).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-f0ee2a17.jpeg" alt="img-284.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 8.12 The retina. Viewed through the pupil with an ophthalmoscope. (Paul Barker/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-1402241c.jpeg" alt="img-285.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 8.11 The retina. (A) Magnified section. (B) Light-sensitive nerve cells: rods and cones. (C) Coloured scanning electron micrograph of rods (green) and cones (blue). (C, Omikron/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="interior-of-the-eye">Interior of the eye<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#interior-of-the-eye" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The anterior chamber of the eye, i.e. the space between the cornea and the lens, is incompletely divided into anterior and posterior cavities by the iris (see Fig. 8.8). Both cavities contain a clear aqueous fluid, aqueous humour, secreted into the posterior cavity by the ciliary glands. It circulates in front of the lens, through the pupil into the anterior cavity, and returns to the venous circulation through the scleral venous sinus (canal of Schlemm) in the angle between the iris and cornea (see Fig. 8.8). The intraocular pressure remains fairly constant between 1.3 and 2.6 kPa ( 10 and 20 mmHg ), as production and drainage rates of aqueous humour are equal. An increase in this pressure causes glaucoma (p. 228). Aqueous humour supplies nutrients and removes wastes from the transparent structures in the front of the eye that have no blood supply, i.e. the cornea, lens and lens capsule.</p>
<p>Behind the lens and filling the posterior chamber of the eyeball is the vitreous body. This is a soft, colourless, transparent, jelly-like substance composed of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>99</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">99 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">99%</span></span></span></span></span> water, mineral salts and mucoprotein. It maintains sufficient intraocular pressure to support the retina against the choroid and prevent the eyeball from collapsing.</p>
<p>The eye keeps its shape because of the intraocular pressure exerted by the vitreous body and the aqueous humour.</p>
<p>Optic nerves (second cranial nerves)
The fibres of the optic nerve (Fig. 8.13) originate in the retina and converge to form the optic nerve about 0.5 cm to the nasal side of the macula lutea at the optic disc. The nerve pierces the choroid and sclera before passing backwards and medially through the orbital cavity. It then passes through the optic foramen of the sphenoid bone, backwards and medially to meet its counterpart from the other eye at the optic chiasma.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="optic-chiasma">Optic chiasma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#optic-chiasma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is situated immediately in front of and above the pituitary gland, which lies in the hypophyseal fossa of the sphenoid bone (see Fig. 9.2). In the optic chiasma the nerve fibres of the optic nerve from the nasal side of each retina cross over to the opposite side. The fibres from the temporal side do not cross but continue backwards on the same side. This crossing over provides both cerebral hemispheres with sensory input from each eye.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="optic-tracts">Optic tracts<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#optic-tracts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are the pathways of the optic nerves, posterior to the optic chiasma (see Fig. 8.13). Each tract consists of the nasal fibres from the retina of one eye and the temporal fibres from the retina of the other. The optic tracts pass backwards to synapse with nerve cells of the lateral geniculate bodies of the thalamus. From there the nerve fibres proceed backwards and medially as the optic radiations, to terminate in the visual area of the cerebral cortex in the occipital lobes</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-f5b4a5c0.jpeg" alt="img-286.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 8.13 The optic nerves and their pathways.
of the cerebrum (see Fig. 7.20). Other neurones originating in the lateral geniculate bodies transmit impulses from the eyes to the cerebellum, where, together with impulses from the semicircular canals of the inner ears and from the skeletal muscles and joints, they contribute to the maintenance of posture and balance. 13 8.2</p>
<p>Physiology of sight
Light waves travel at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>300</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>000</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>000</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">300,000,000</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">300</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">000</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">000</span></span></span></span></span> metres per second ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathrm">s</span></span></span></span></span> ), or about 186,000 miles per second. This is much greater than the speed of sound in air (about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>340</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">340 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">340</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathrm">s</span></span></span></span></span> ) and explains why we see lightning before hearing thunder.</p>
<p>Light is reflected into the eyes by objects within the field of vision. White light is a combination of all the colours of the visual spectrum (rainbow), i.e. red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo and violet. This is demonstrated by passing white light through a glass prism that refracts (bends) the rays of the different colours to a greater or lesser extent, depending on their wavelengths (Fig. 8.14). Red light has the longest wavelength and violet the shortest.</p>
<p>This range of colour is the spectrum of visible light. In a rainbow, white light from the sun is broken up by raindrops, which act as prisms and reflectors.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-864be4fd.jpeg" alt="img-287.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 8.14 Refraction. White light is broken into the colours of the visible spectrum when it passes through a glass prism.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="refraction-of-the-light-rays">Refraction of the light rays<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#refraction-of-the-light-rays" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When light rays pass from a medium of one density to a medium of a different density, they are refracted. Fig. 8.14 shows how a glass prism separates a beam of white light into its constituent colours, by refracting each wavelength to a different degree. In the eye the biconvex lens refracts and focuses light rays (Fig. 8.16). This principle is used to focus light on the retina. Before reaching the retina, light rays pass successively through the conjunctiva, cornea, aqueous fluid, lens and vitreous body. These structures are all denser than air and, with the exception of the lens, they have a constant refractory power, similar to that of water. This means that although they all refract light rays entering the eye, their ability to do this is fixed and so cannot be adjusted to assist in focusing.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-electromagnetic-spectrum">The electromagnetic spectrum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-electromagnetic-spectrum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The electromagnetic spectrum is broad but only a small part is visible to the human eye (Fig. 8.15). Beyond the long end are infrared waves (heat), microwaves and radio waves. Beyond the short end are ultraviolet (UV) rays. X-rays and gamma rays. UV light is not normally visible because it is absorbed by a yellow pigment in the lens. Following removal of the lens (cataract extraction), it is usually replaced with an artificial one to prevent long-term damage to the retina from UV light rays.</p>
<p>A specific colour is perceived when only one wavelength is reflected by the object and all the others are absorbed, e.g. an object appears red when it reflects only red light. Objects appear white when they reflect all wavelengths of light into the eye, and black when they absorb all the light hitting them and so reflect nothing.</p>
<p>In order to achieve clear vision, light reflected from objects within the visual field is focused on to the retina of each eye. The processes involved in producing a clear visual image are:</p>
<ul>
<li>refraction of light rays</li>
<li>change in the size of the pupils</li>
<li>accommodation (adjustment of the lens for near vision; see below).</li>
</ul>
<p>Each of these processes is explained individually in the next sections, but effective vision is dependent on all three operating in a coordinated manner.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-85781894.jpeg" alt="img-288.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 8.16 Refraction of light rays passing through a biconvex lens. (A) A glass lens. (B) The lens in the eye.</p>
<p>The spectrum of visible light</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="long-wavelength">LONG WAVELENGTH<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#long-wavelength" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<p>If</p>

<p>X-rays</p>
<p>SHORT WAVELENGTH Gamma rays
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">□</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">□</span></span></span></span></span></p>
