<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-bdb06d27.jpeg" alt="img-289.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 8.17 Section of the eye showing the focusing of light rays on the retina. Diagrammatic representation of light rays reaohing the retina showing inverted image.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="focusing-of-an-image-on-the-retina">Focusing of an image on the retina<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#focusing-of-an-image-on-the-retina" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Light rays reflected from an object are refracted by the lens when they enter the eye, as shown in Fig. 8.16, although the image on the retina is actually upside down (Fig. 8.17). The brain adapts to this early in life so that objects are perceived 'the right way up'.</p>
<p>Abnormal refraction within the eye is corrected using biconvex or biconcave lenses (p. 230).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lens">Lens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The lens is a biconvex elastic transparent body suspended behind the iris from the ciliary body by the suspensory ligament (see Fig. 8.10) and is the only structure in the eye able to change its refractive power. Light rays entering the eye need to be refracted to focus them on the retina. Light from distant objects needs least refraction and, as the object comes closer, the amount of refraction needed increases. To focus light rays from near objects on the retina, the refractory power of the lens must be increased - by accommodation. To do this, the ciliary muscle contracts, moving the ciliary body inwards towards the lens. This lessens the pull on the suspensory ligaments and allows the lens to bulge, increasing its convexity and focusing light rays on the retina (Fig. 8.18B).</p>
<p>To focus light rays from distant objects on the retina, the circular ciliary muscle relaxes, increasing its pull on the suspensory ligaments. This makes the lens thinner and focuses light rays from distant objects on the retina (Fig. 8.18A).</p>
<p>Size of the pupils
Pupil size contributes to clear vision by controlling the amount of light entering the eye. In bright light the pupils are constricted and in dim light they are dilated (Fig. 8.19).</p>
<p>If the pupils were dilated in bright light, too much light would enter the eye and damage the sensitive retina. In dim light, if the pupils were constricted, insufficient</p>
<p>light would enter the eye to activate the light-sensitive pigments in the rods and cones, which stimulate the nerve endings in the retina, enabling vision.</p>
<p>The iris consists of one layer of circular and one of radiating smooth muscle fibres. Contraction of the circular fibres constricts the pupil, and contraction of the radiating fibres dilates it. The size of the pupil is controlled by the autonomic nervous system; sympathetic stimulation dilates the pupils and parasympathetic stimulation constricts them.</p>
<p>Accommodation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="near-vision">Near vision<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#near-vision" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In order to focus on near objects, i.e. within about 6 metres, accommodation is required and the eye must make the following adjustments:</p>
<ul>
<li>constriction of the pupils</li>
<li>convergence</li>
<li>change in the refractory power of the lens.</li>
</ul>
<p>Constriction of the pupils
This assists accommodation by reducing the width of the beam of light entering the eye so that it passes through the central curved part of the lens (see Fig. 8.17).</p>
<p>Convergence (movement of the eyebaiis)
Light rays from nearby objects enter the two eyes at different angles and for clear vision they must stimulate corresponding areas of the two retinae. Extrinsic muscles move the eyes and to obtain a clear image they also rotate them so that they converge on the object viewed. This coordinated muscle activity is under autonomic control. When there is voluntary movement of the eyes, both eyes move and convergence is maintained. The nearer an object is to the eyes, the greater the eye rotation needed to achieve convergence; for example, focusing near the tip of one's nose gives the appearance of being 'cross-eyed'. If convergence is not complete, the eyes are focused on different objects or on different points of the same object. There are then two images sent to the brain and this can lead to double vision, or diplopia. If convergence is not possible, the brain tends to ignore the impulses received from the divergent eye (see Squint, p. 229).</p>
<p>Changing the refractory power of the lens
Changes in the thickness of the lens are made to focus light on the retina. The amount of adjustment depends on the distance of the object from the eyes, i.e. the lens is thicker for near vision and at its thinnest when focusing on objects more than 6 metres away (see Fig. 8.18). Looking at near objects 'tires' the eyes more</p>
<p>quickly, owing to the continuous use of the ciliary muscle. The lens loses its elasticity and stiffens with age, a condition known as presbyopia (p. 225).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-6f4eedae.jpeg" alt="img-290.jpeg"></p>

pigments in these cells and they generate nerve impulses, which are conducted to the occipital lobes of the cerebrum via the optic nerves (see Fig. 8.13).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cones">Cones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The cones are sensitive to light and colour; bright light is required to activate them and give sharp, clear colour vision. Cones are concentrated at the macula lutea, which is the spot on the retina where light rays fall from an object in the direct field of vision. This means that whatever is being directly observed is seen in detail, brightly coloured and in sharp focus. Cone numbers fall sharply and rod numbers rise on the retina peripheral to the macula lutea.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="distant-vision">Distant vision<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#distant-vision" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Objects more than 6 metres away from the eyes are focused on the retina without adjustment of the lens or convergence of the eyes.</p>
<p>Functions of the retina
The retina is the light-sensitive (photosensitive) part of the eye. The light-sensitive nerve cells are the rods and cones, and their distribution in the retina is shown in Fig. 8.11A. Light rays cause chemical changes in light-sensitive</p>
<p>Rods
The rods are much more light-sensitive than the cones (see Fig. 8.11), so they are used when light levels are low. Stimulation of rods leads to monochromic (black</p>
<p>and white) vision. Rods outnumber cones in the retina by about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>16</mn><mo>:</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">16: 1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">16</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">:</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span> and are much more numerous towards the periphery.</p>
<p>Rhodopsins
This is a family of light-sensitive pigments, found in both rods and cones, which are broken down (bleached) when they absorb light hitting the cell. Degradation of the
rhodopsin molecule generates an action potential. Following bleaching, the rhodopsin molecule has to be reassembled before it is functional again. There is only one type of rhodopsin in rods, absorbing at a single wavelength, which is why rods give monochromatic vision. Cones, however, have one of three different rhodopsins, absorbing at three different wavelengths and giving rise to so-called red, blue and green cones. Colour perception depends on the combination of red, blue and green cones stimulated. A good supply of vitamin A is needed for adequate rhodopsin production.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="colour-blindness">Colour blindness<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#colour-blindness" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is a common condition that affects more men than women. Although affected individuals see colours, they cannot always differentiate between them, as the lightsensitive pigments (to red, green or blue) in cones are abnormal. There are different forms but the most common is red-green colour blindness, which is transmitted a by sex-linked recessive gene (see Fig. 17.11); greens, oranges, pale reds and browns all appear to be the same colour and can be distinguished only by their intensity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dark-adaptation">Dark adaptation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dark-adaptation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When exposed to bright light, the rhodopsin within the sensitive rods is completely degraded. This does not affect vision in good light, when there is enough light to activate the cones. However, moving into a darkened area where the light intensity is insufficient to stimulate the cones causes temporary visual impairment while the rhodopsin is being regenerated within the rods: 'dark adaptation'. When regeneration of rhodopsin has occurred, normal sight returns.</p>
<p>Sudden exposure to bright light, e.g. a camera flash, causes immediate bleaching of rhodopsin in rods and cones, and temporary blindness until the rhodopsin is regenerated.</p>
<p>It is easier to see a dim star in the sky at night if the head is turned slightly away from it because light of low intensity is then focused on an area of the retina where there is a greater concentration of rods. If a dim star is looked at directly, the light intensity is not sufficient to stimulate the less sensitive cones in the area of the macula lutea. In dim evening light, colours cannot be distinguished because the light intensity is insufficient to stimulate colour-sensitive pigments in cones.</p>
<p>Binocular vision
Binocular or stereoscopic vision enables three-dimensional views, although each eye 'sees' a scene from a slightly different angle (Fig. 8.20). The visual fields overlap in the middle but the left eye sees more on the left than can be seen by the other eye and vice versa. The images from the two
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-85d081f0.jpeg" alt="img-293.jpeg"></p>
<p>Image perceived by visual centre in occipital lobe
Figure 8.20 Parts of the visual field. Monocular and binocular.
eyes are integrated in the cerebrum so that only one image is perceived.
Binocular vision provides a much more accurate assessment of one object relative to another, e.g. its distance, depth, height and width. People with monocular vision may find it difficult, for example, to judge the speed and distance of an approaching vehicle.</p>
<p>Extraocular muscles of the eye
These include the muscles of the eyelids and those that move the eyeballs. The eyeball is moved by six extrinsic muscles, attached at one end to the eyeball and at the other to the walls of the orbital cavity. There are four straight (rectus) muscles and two oblique muscles (Fig. 8.21).</p>
<p>Moving the eyes to look in a particular direction is under voluntary control but coordination of movement, needed for convergence and accommodation to near or distant vision, is under autonomic (involuntary) control. Movements of the eyes resulting from the action of these muscles are shown in Table 8.1.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-54c93d41.jpeg" alt="img-294.jpeg"></p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="eyebrows">Eyebrows<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#eyebrows" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are two arched ridges of the supraorbital margins of the frontal bone. Numerous hairs (eyebrows) project obliquely from the surface of the skin. They protect the eyeball from sweat, dust and other foreign bodies.</p>
<p>Eyelids (palpebrae)
The eyelids are two movable folds of tissue situated above and below the front of each eye. On their free edges are short, curved hairs: the eyelashes. The layers of tissue that form them are:</p>
<ul>
<li>eyebrows</li>
<li>eyelids and eyelashes</li>
<li>lacrimal apparatus.</li>
<li>a thin covering of skin</li>
<li>a thin sheet of subcutaneous connective (loose areolar) tissue</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">Table 6.1: Extrinsic muscles of the eye: their actions and cranial nerve supply</th><th style="text-align: center;"></th><th style="text-align: center;"></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Name</td><td style="text-align: center;">Action</td><td style="text-align: center;">Cranial nerve supply</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Medial rectus</td><td style="text-align: center;">Rotates eyeball inwards</td><td style="text-align: center;">Oculomotor nerve (3rd cranial nerve)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Lateral rectus</td><td style="text-align: center;">Rotates eyeball outwards</td><td style="text-align: center;">Abslucent nerve (6th cranial nerve)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Superior rectus</td><td style="text-align: center;">Rotates eyeball upwards</td><td style="text-align: center;">Oculomotor nerve (3rd cranial nerve)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Inferior rectus</td><td style="text-align: center;">Rotates eyeball downwards</td><td style="text-align: center;">Oculomotor nerve (3rd cranial nerve)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Superior oblique</td><td style="text-align: center;">Rotates eyeball downwards and outwards</td><td style="text-align: center;">Trochlear nerve (4th cranial nerve)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Inferior oblique</td><td style="text-align: center;">Rotates eyeball upwards and outwards</td><td style="text-align: center;">Oculomotor nerve (3rd cranial nerve)</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul>
<li>
<p>two muscles - the orbicularis oculi and levator palpebrae superioris</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>a thin sheet of dense connective tissue - the tarsal plate, larger in the upper than the lower eyelid, which supports the other structures</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>a membranous lining - the conjunctiva.</p>
</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="conjunctiva">Conjunctiva<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#conjunctiva" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is a fine transparent membrane that lines the eyelids and the front of the eyeball (Fig. 8.22). Where it lines the eyelids it consists of highly vascular columnar epithelium. Corneal conjunctiva consists of avascular stratified epithelium, i.e. epithelium without blood vessels. When the eyelids are closed the conjunctiva becomes a closed sac. It protects the delicate cornea and the front of the eye. When eyedrops are administered, they are placed in the lower conjunctival sac. The medial and lateral angles of the eye, where the upper and lower lids come together, are called the medial canthus and the lateral canthus, respectively.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="eyelid-margins">Eyelid margins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#eyelid-margins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Along the edges of the lids are numerous sebaceous glands, some with ducts opening into the hair follicles of the eyelashes and some on to the eyelid margins between the hairs. Tarsal glands are modified sebaceous glands embedded in the tarsal plates with ducts that open on to the inside of the free margins of the eyelids. They secrete an oily material, spread over the conjunctiva by blinking, which delays evaporation of tears.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The eyelids and eyelashes protect the eye from injury:</p>
<ul>
<li>Reflex closure of the lids occurs when the conjunctiva or eyelashes are touched, when an object comes close to the eye, if a bright light is shone into the eye (see Fig. 8.19), or if anything comes into direct contact with the cornea itself (the corneal reflex).</li>
<li>Blinking at about 3-7-second intervals spreads tears and oily secretions over the cornea, preventing drying.</li>
</ul>
<p>When the orbicularis oculi muscles contract, the eyes close. When the levator palpebrae muscles contract, the eyelids open (see Fig. 16.60).</p>
<p>Lacrimal apparatus
The lacrimal apparatus (Fig. 8.23) consists of the structures that secrete tears and drain them from the front of the eyeball:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>1 lacrimal gland and its ducts</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>2 lacrimal canaliculi</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>1 lacrimal sac</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>1 nasolacrimal duct.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Lacrimal gland
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-916ce980.jpeg" alt="img-296.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 8.23 The lacrimal apparatus. Blue arrows, Direction of the flow of tears.
The lacrimal glands are exocrine glands situated in recesses in the frontal bones on the lateral aspect of each eye, just behind the supraorbital margin. Each gland is approximately the size and shape of an almond, and is composed of secretory epithelial cells. The glands secrete tears composed of water, mineral salts, antibodies (immunoglobulins, Ch. 15) and lysozyme, a bactericidal enzyme.</p>
<p>The tears leave the lacrimal gland by several small ducts and pass over the front of the eye under the lids towards the medial canthus, where they drain into the two lacrimal canaliculi; the opening of each is called the punctum. The two canaliculi lie one above the other, separated by a small red body, the caruncle. The tears then drain into the lacrimal sac, which is the upper expanded end of the nasolacrimal duct. This is a membranous canal approximately 2 cm long, extending from the lower part of the lacrimal sac to the nasal cavity, opening at the level of the inferior concha. Normally, the rate of secretion of tears keeps pace with the rate of drainage. When a foreign body or other irritant enters the eye, the secretion of tears is greatly increased and the conjunctival blood vessels dilate. Secretion of tears is also increased in emotional states, e.g. crying, laughing.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The fluid that fills the conjunctival sac is a mixture of tears and the oily secretion of tarsal glands, which is spread over the cornea by blinking. The functions of this fluid include:</p>
<ul>
<li>provision of oxygen and nutrients to the avascular corneal conjunctiva and drainage of wastes</li>
<li>washing away of irritating materials, e.g. dust, grit</li>
<li>prevention of microbial infection by the bactericidal enzyme lysozyme</li>
<li>delay of evaporation and prevention of friction or drying of the conjunctiva due to its oiliness.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5205029c">■ SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5205029c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>Name the adjustments made by the eye to focus on nearby objects.</li>

<p>Sense of smell
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-73cc2cf5.jpeg" alt="img-297.jpeg"></p>
<p>Frontal sinus Olfactory bulb
Olfactory nerve endings and nerves
Olfactory tract
Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to: describe the physiology of smell.</p>
<p>The sense of smell, or olfaction, originates in the nasal cavity. The human sense of smell is less acute than in other animals. Many animals secrete odorous chemicals called pheromones, which play an important part in chemical communication in, for example, territorial behaviour, mating and the bonding of mothers and their newborn. The role of pheromones in humans is unknown.</p>
<p>Olfactory bulb Olfactory tract</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-1fb014a6.jpeg" alt="img-298.jpeg"></p>
<p>Olfactory nerves'
Olfactory cells Supporting cell
B</p>
<p>To olfactory area in temporal lobe of cerebrum
Ethmoid bone
In epithelium of roof of nasal cavity</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="olfactory-nerves-first-cranial-nerves">Olfactory nerves (first cranial nerves)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#olfactory-nerves-first-cranial-nerves" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are the sensory nerves of smell. They originate as chemoreceptors (specialised olfactory nerve endings) in the mucous membrane of the roof of the nasal cavity above the superior nasal conchae (Fig. 8.24). On each side of the nasal septum nerve fibres pass through the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone to the olfactory bulb, where interconnections and synapses occur. From the bulb, bundles of nerve fibres form the olfactory tract, which passes backwards to the olfactory area in the temporal lobe of the cerebral cortex in each hemisphere, where the impulses are interpreted and odour perceived.</p>
<p>Physiology of smell D 8.3
All odorous materials give off volatile molecules, which are carried into the nose with inhaled air, and even very low concentrations, when dissolved in mucus, stimulate the olfactory chemoreceptors.</p>
<p>The air entering the nose is warmed and convection currents carry eddies of inspired air to the roof of the nasal cavity. 'Sniffing' concentrates volatile molecules in the roof of the nose. This increases the number of olfactory receptors</p>
<p>Figure 8.24 The sense of smell. (A) The olfactory structures. (B) An enlarged section of the olfactory apparatus in the nose and on the inferior surface of the cerebrum.
stimulated and thus perception of the smell. The sense of smell and the sense of taste are closely related; the sense of smell may affect the appetite. If the odours are pleasant the appetite may improve and vice versa. When accompanied by the sight</p>
<p>of food, an appetising smell increases salivation and stimulates the digestive system (Ch. 12). The sense of smell may create powerful and long-lasting memories, especially for distinctive odours, e.g. hospital smells, or favourite or least-liked foods.</p>
<p>Inflammation of the nasal mucosa prevents odorous substances from reaching the olfactory area of the nose, causing loss of the sense of smell (anosmia). The usual cause is a cold.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="adaptation">Adaptation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adaptation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When an individual is continuously exposed to an odour, perception of it decreases and stops within a few minutes. This loss of perception affects only that specific odour.</p>
<p>Learning outcome</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">- SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="6">
<li>Define the term olfaction.</li>
</ol>
<p>Sense of taste</p>
<p>Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to: describe the physiology of taste.</p>
<p>The sense of taste, or gustation, is closely linked to the sense of smell and, like smell, also involves stimulation of chemoreceptors by dissolved chemicals.</p>
<p>Taste buds contain chemoreceptors (sensory receptors) that are found in the papillae of the tongue and are widely distributed in the epithelia of the tongue. There are three types of papillae (Fig. 8.25 A).</p>
<p>Vallate papillae are the largest, and are visible at the base of the tongue arranged in an inverted V shape. There are about 10 of this type.</p>
<p>Fungiform papillae are located mainly around the tip and edges of the tongue, and are more numerous than the vallate papillae.</p>
<p>Filiform papillae are the smallest and most numerous papillae. They are situated on the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. These papillae do not contain taste buds, but they
roughen the surface of the tongue and provide 'grip' as it pushes food around inside the mouth.</p>
<p>Taste buds consist of small sensory nerve endings of the glossopharyngeal, facial and vagus nerves (cranial nerves VII, IX and X). Some of the cells have hair-like cilia on their free border, projecting towards tiny pores in the epithelium (Fig. 8.25 C ). The sensory receptors are highly sensitive and stimulated by very small amounts of chemicals that enter the pores dissolved in saliva. Nerve impulses are generated and conducted along the glossopharyngeal, facial and vagus nerves before synapsing in the medulla and thalamus. Their final destination is the taste area in the parietal lobe of the cerebral cortex, where taste is perceived (see Fig. 7.20).</p>
<p>Physiology of taste
Four fundamental sensations of taste have been described: sweet, sour, bitter and salt; however, others have also been suggested, including metallic and umami (a Japanese 'savoury' taste). However, perception varies widely and many 'tastes' cannot be easily classified. It is thought that all taste buds are stimulated by all 'tastes'. Taste is impaired when the mouth is dry because substances can be 'tasted' only when in solution.</p>
<p>The sense of taste is closely linked to the sense of smell. For example, when a person has a cold, it is common for food to taste bland and unappealing. In addition, taste triggers salivation and the secretion of gastric juice (Ch. 12). The sense of taste also has a protective function, e.g. when foul-tasting food is eaten, reflex gagging or vomiting may be induced.

(D) Coloured scanning electron micrograph of a taste bud (centre) on the tongue. (D, Steve G Schmeissner/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="learning-outcome">Learning outcome<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">- SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="7">
<li>Name the four fundamental tastes.</li>
</ol>
<p>Effects of ageing on the special senses
Changes in hearing and vision that occur as part of normal ageing are almost universal and often accompanied by diminished senses of taste and smell. The number of olfactory receptors reduces around the age of 50 , diminishing the sense of taste; older adults may complain of their food being bland while children can find the same food too spicy. In a similar way, older adults may not smell (perceive) weak odours. The effect of changes associated with ageing on hearing and vision are considered here.</p>
<p>Presbycusis
This form of hearing impairment accompanies the ageing process and is therefore common in older adults. Degenerative changes in the sensory cells of the spiral organ result in sensorineural hearing loss (p. 226). Perception of high-frequency sound is impaired first and later low-frequency sound may also be affected. Difficulty in discrimination develops, e.g. following a conversation, especially in the presence of background noise.</p>
<p>Vision
Presbyopia and cataracts are common consequences of normal ageing.
Presbyopia
Age-related changes in the lens lead to loss of accommodation as the lens loses its elasticity and becomes firmer. This prevents focusing of light on the retina, giving blurred vision. Correction is achieved using glasses with convex lenses for near vision, e.g. reading (see Fig. 8.29).</p>
<p>Cataracts
Cataracts arise when there is opacity of the lens (Fig. 8.26). Weak light rays cannot easily pass through a less transparent or cloudy lens and this is the reason why many older adults use brighter light for reading and may also experience difficulty with night vision. It is most commonly age-related, occurring as a result of exposure to predisposing factors that include UV light. X-rays and cigarette smoke. There are also other important causes of cataracts (p. 229).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="8">
<li>Which age-related condition that affects the eyes leads to most people over the age of 40 requiring glasses for reading?
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-c00fd134.jpeg" alt="img-300.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Figure 8.26 Cataract. (Sue Ford/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<p>Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the impact of ageing on the special senses.</li>
</ul>
<p>Learning outcome</p>
<p>Disorders of the ear</p>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>compare and contrast the features of conductive and sensorineural hearing loss</li>
<li>describe the causes and effects of diseases of the ear.</li>
</ul>
<p>Hearing loss
Hearing impairment can be classified in two main categories: conductive and sensorineural. Hearing impairment can also be mixed when there is a combination of conductive and sensorineural hearing loss in one ear.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="conductive-hearing-impairment">Conductive hearing impairment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#conductive-hearing-impairment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This occurs when an abnormality of the outer or middle ear impairs conduction of sound waves to the oval window; common examples are listed in Box 8.1.</p>
<p>Otosclerosis
This is a common cause of progressive conductive hearing loss in young adults, which may affect one ear but is more commonly bilateral. It is usually hereditary, and more common in females than males; it often worsens during</p>
<p>Box 8.1 Common causes of hearing loss
Conductive
Acute otitis media Serous otitis media Chronic otitis media Barotrauma
Otosclerosis External otitis
Injury of the tympanic membrane
Sensorineural
Impacted earwax or foreign body Presbycusis
Long-term exposure to excessive noise
Congenital
Meniere's disease
Ototoxic drugs, e.g. aminoglycoside antibiotics, diuretics, chemotherapy
Infections, e.g. mumps, herpes zoster, meningitis, syphilis</p>
<p>pregnancy. Abnormal bone develops around the footplate of the stapes, fusing it to the oval window and reducing the ability to transmit sound waves across the tympanic cavity.</p>
<p>Serous otitis media
Also known as 'glue ear', or secretory otitis media, this is a collection of fluid (effusion) in the middle ear cavity. Causes include:</p>
<ul>
<li>obstruction of the auditory tube by, for example, pharyngeal swelling, enlarged adenoids or tumour</li>
<li>barotrauma (usually caused by descent in an aeroplane when suffering from a cold)</li>
<li>untreated acute otitis media.</li>
</ul>
<p>The air normally present in the middle ear is absorbed and negative pressure develops, causing retraction of the tympanic membrane. Thereafter, fluid is drawn into the low-pressure cavity from surrounding blood vessels, causing conductive hearing loss.</p>
<p>Adults experience hearing loss and blockage of the ear, which is usually painless. In preverbal children, however, this is a common cause of hearing impairment, which may manifest as delayed speech and/or achievement of developmental milestones. Secondary infection can complicate this condition in both adults and children.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sensorineural-hearing-impairment">Sensorineural hearing impairment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sensorineural-hearing-impairment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is the more prevalent form of hearing impairment and is the result of a disorder of the nerves of the inner ear or the central nervous system, e.g. the cochlea, cochlear branch of the vestibular nerve or the auditory area of the cerebrum. Noise-induced hearing loss is one cause of sensorineural hearing impairment, which may arise as a consequence of:</p>
<ul>
<li>employment, e.g. construction work, manufacturing or the music industry</li>
<li>social activities, e.g. listening to loud music on personal equipment or at nightclubs.</li>
</ul>
<p>Other causes are listed in Box 8.1.
Risk factors for congenital sensorineural hearing impairment include family history, exposure to intrauterine viruses, e.g. maternal rubella, and acute hypoxia at birth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="meniere-s-disease">Meniere's disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#meniere-s-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In this condition there is accumulation of endolymph, causing distension and increased pressure within the membranous labyrinth with destruction of the sensory cells in the ampulla and cochlea. It is usually unilateral at first but both ears may be affected later. The cause is not known. Meniere's disease is associated with recurrent episodes of incapacitating dizziness (vertigo), nausea and vomiting, lasting for several hours. Periods of remission vary from days to months. During and between attacks there may be continuous ringing in the affected ear (tinnitus). Loss of hearing is experienced during episodes, which may</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Learning outcomes</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Box 8.1 Common causes of hearing loss</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Conductive</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Acute otitis media</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Serous otitis media</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Chronic otitis media</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Barotrauma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Otosclerosis</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">External otitis</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Injury of the tympanic membrane</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Sensorineural</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Impacted earwax or foreign body</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Presbycusis</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Long-term exposure to excessive noise</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Congenital</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Ménière's disease</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Ototoxic drugs, e.g. aminoglycoside antibiotics,</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">diuretics, chemotherapy</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Infections, e.g. mumps, herpes zoster, meningitis,</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">syphilis</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Motion sickness
gradually become permanent over a period of years as the spiral organ is destroyed.
Presbycusis
See page 225 .
Ear infections</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="external-otitis">External otitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#external-otitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Infection by Staphylococcus aureus is the usual cause of localised inflammation (boils) in the auditory canal. More generalised inflammation may be caused by prolonged exposure to bacteria or fungi or by an allergic reaction to, for example, soaps, hair sprays or hair dyes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acute-otitis-media-q-8-4">Acute otitis media Q 8.4<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-otitis-media-q-8-4" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is inflammation of the middle ear cavity, usually caused by upward spread of microbes from an upper respiratory tract infection via the auditory tube. It is very</p>
<p>common in children and is accompanied by severe earache. Occasionally, it spreads inwards from the outer ear through a perforation in the tympanic membrane.</p>
<p>Bacterial infection leads to the accumulation of pus and the outward bulging of the tympanic membrane. Sometimes the tympanic membrane ruptures and pus discharges from the middle ear (otorrhoea). The spread of infection may cause mastoiditis and labyrinthitis (see later). As the petrous portion of the temporal bone is very thin, the infection may spread through the bone and cause meningitis (p. 197) and brain abscess.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chronic-otitis-media">Chronic otitis media<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chronic-otitis-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In this condition there is permanent perforation of the tympanic membrane following acute otitis media (especially when recurrent, persistent or untreated) and mechanical or blast injuries. As healing occurs, stratified epithelium from the outer ear sometimes grows into the middle ear, forming a cholesteatoma. This is a collection of desquamated epithelial cells and purulent material. Continued development of cholesteatoma may lead to:</p>
<ul>
<li>destruction of the ossicles and conductive hearing loss</li>
<li>erosion of the roof of the middle ear and meningitis</li>
<li>spread of infection to the inner ear, which may cause labyrinthitis.</li>
</ul>
<p>Labyrinthitis
This complication of middle ear infection may be caused by development of a fistula from a cholesteatoma (see previous section). It is accompanied by vertigo, nausea and vomiting, and nystagmus. In some cases the spiral organ is destroyed, causing sudden profound sensorineural hearing loss in the affected ear.</p>
<p>This occurs when the brain receives conflicting sensory information; the visual information received from the eye does not match the information from the semicircular canals of the inner ear about one's position in relation to the environment. It causes nausea and vomiting in some people, and is usually associated with travel, e.g. by car, boat or aeroplane.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="stye">Stye<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stye" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Also known as hordeolum, this is an acute and painful bacterial infection of sebaceous or tarsal glands of the eyelid margin. The most common cause is Staphylococcus aureus. A 'crop' of styes may occur due to localised spread to adjacent glands. Infection of tarsal glands may block their ducts, leading to cyst formation (chalazion), which may damage the cornea.</p>
<p>This is chronic inflammation of the eyelid margins, usually caused by bacterial infection or allergy, e.g. staphylococcal infection or seborrhoea (excessive</p>
<p>sebaceous gland secretion). If ulceration occurs, healing by fibrosis may distort the eyelid margins, preventing complete closure of the eye. This may lead to drying of the eye, conjunctivitis and possibly corneal ulceration.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="conjunctivitis">Conjunctivitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#conjunctivitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Inflammation of the conjunctiva may be caused by irritants, such as smoke, dust, wind, cold or dry air, microbes or antigens, and may be acute or chronic (Fig. 8.27). Corneal ulceration (see later) is a rare complication.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-1-1-spot-check"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">1%</span></span></span></span></span> SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-1-1-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="9">
<li>What is 'glue ear'?</li>

</ol>
<p>Disorders of the eye
Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the pathological changes and effects of diseases of the eye.</li>
</ul>
<p>Inflammatory conditions</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blepharitis">Blepharitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blepharitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-e19c5bfe.jpeg" alt="img-301.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 8.27 Conjunctivitis. (Dr P Marazzi/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<p>Infection
This is highly contagious and in adults is usually caused by strains of staphylococci, streptococci or Haemophilus.</p>
<p>Neonatal conjunctivitis</p>
<p>Sexually transmitted disease in the mother, including gonorrhoea, chlamydia and genital herpes, can infect the newborn infant's eyes as the baby passes through the birth canal.</p>
<p>Allergic conjunctivitis
This may be a complication of hay fever or be caused by a wide variety of airborne antigens, e.g. dust, pollen, fungus spores, animal dander, cosmetics, hair sprays or soaps. The condition sometimes becomes chronic.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="trachoma">Trachoma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#trachoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This chronic inflammatory condition is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis and is a common cause of sight loss in developing countries. Deposition of fibrous tissue in the conjunctiva and cornea leads to eyelid deformity and corneal scarring as the eyelashes rub against the surface of the eye. The microbes are spread by poor hygiene, e.g. communal use of contaminated washing water, cross-infection between mother and child, or contaminated towels and clothing.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="corneal-ulcer">Corneal ulcer<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#corneal-ulcer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is local necrosis of corneal tissue, usually associated with corneal infection (keratitis) following trauma (e.g. abrasion), or infection spread from the conjunctiva or eyelids. Causative organisms include staphylococci, streptococci and herpes viruses. Acute pain, injection (redness of the cornea), photophobia and lacrimation interfere with sight during the acute phase. In severe cases, extensive ulceration or perforation and healing by fibrosis can cause opacity of the cornea, requiring corneal transplantation.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-f8db2f9f.jpeg" alt="img-302.jpeg"></p>
<p>Aqueous fluid secreted from ciliary body
Scleral venous sinus (canal of Schlemm) Drainage angle
Iris
Flow of aqueous fluid
Normal eye</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-218f9968.jpeg" alt="img-303.jpeg"></p>
<p>Acute glaucoma
Drainage angle blocked by iris
Iris and lens touch, causing build-up of fluid
Trapped fluid in posterior chamber pushes the iris forward
Figure 8.28 Glaucoma. (A) Normal eye. (B) Acute glaucoma.
Glaucoma
This is a group of conditions in which intraocular pressure rises due to impaired drainage of aqueous fluid through the scleral venous sinus (canal of Schlemm) in the angle between the iris and cornea in the anterior chamber (Fig. 8.28).
Persistently raised intraocular pressure may damage the optic nerve by mechanical compression or by compression of its blood supply, causing ischaemia. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>∧</mo><mn>38.5</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\wedge 38.5</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">∧</span><span class="mord">38.5</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>Damage to the optic nerve impairs vision, the extent of which varies from some visual impairment to complete loss of sight.</p>
<p>In addition to the primary glaucomas described here, the condition is occasionally congenital or secondary to other causes, e.g. anterior uveitis or a tumour.</p>
<p>Primary glaucomas Primary open-angle glaucoma
In primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) there is a gradual painless rise in intraocular pressure with progressive loss of
vision. Peripheral vision is lost first but may not be noticed until only central (tunnel) vision remains. As the condition progresses, atrophy of the optic disc occurs, leading to irreversible loss of vision. It is commonly bilateral and occurs mostly in people over 40 years of age. The cause is not known but there is a familial tendency.</p>
<p>Acute closed-angle glaucoma</p>
<p>This is most common in people over 40 years of age and usually affects one eye. During life the lens gradually increases in size, pushing the iris forwards. In dim light, when the pupil dilates, the lax iris bulges still further forwards and may come into contact with the cornea, blocking the scleral venous sinus (canal of Schlemm) and suddenly raising the intraocular pressure. Sudden severe pain, photophobia, headache, nausea and blurred vision accompany an acute attack. It may resolve spontaneously if the iris responds to bright light, constricting the pupil and releasing the pressure on the scleral venous sinus. After repeated attacks, spontaneous recovery may be incomplete and vision is progressively impaired.</p>
<p>Chronic closed-angle glaucoma
The intraocular pressure rises gradually without symptoms. Later, peripheral vision deteriorates, followed by atrophy of the optic disc and loss of sight.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="strabismus-squint-cross-eye">Strabismus (squint, cross-eye)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#strabismus-squint-cross-eye" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In normal binocular vision, the eyes are aligned so that each eye sees the same image, meaning that both eyes send very similar images to the brain. In strabismus, only one eye is directed at the observed object and the other diverges (is directed elsewhere). The result is that two quite different images are sent to the brain, one from each eye. It is caused by one-sided extrinsic muscle weakness or impairment of the cranial nerve (III, IV or VI) supply to the extrinsic muscles. In most cases the image from the squinting eye is suppressed by the brain; otherwise there is double vision (diplopia).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="presbyopia">Presbyopia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#presbyopia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>See page 225 .</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cataract">Cataract<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cataract" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is opacity of the lens, which impairs vision, especially in poor light and darkness when weak light rays can no longer pass through the cloudy lens to the retina (see Fig. 8.26). Although most commonly age-related (p. 225), this condition can also be congenital or secondary to other conditions, e.g. ocular trauma, uveitis or diabetes mellitus.</p>
<p>The most common cause of visual impairment worldwide, cataracts can affect one or both eyes. The extent
of visual impairment depends on the location and extent of the opacity.
Congenital cataract may be idiopathic, or due to genetic abnormality or maternal infection in early pregnancy, e.g. rubella. Early treatment is required to prevent permanent loss of sight.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="retinopathies">Retinopathies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#retinopathies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vascular-retinopathies">Vascular retinopathies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vascular-retinopathies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Occlusion of the central retinal artery or vein causes sudden, painless unilateral loss of vision, as these vessels provide the sole arterial supply and venous drainage. Arterial occlusion is usually due to embolism from, for example, atheromatous plaques or endocarditis. Venous occlusion is usually associated with increased intraocular pressure in, for example, glaucoma, diabetes mellitus or hypertension. The retinal veins become distended and retinal haemorrhages occur.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diabetic-retinopathy">Diabetic retinopathy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diabetic-retinopathy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This occurs in type 1 and type 2 diabetes mellitus (p. 255) and is the most common cause of blindness in adults aged between 30 and 65 years in developed countries. Changes in retinal blood vessels increase with the severity and duration of hyperglycaemia. Capillary microaneurysms develop and later there may be proliferation of blood vessels. Haemorrhages, fibrosis and secondary retinal detachment may follow and, over time, there may be severe retinal degeneration and loss of vision.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="retinopathy-of-prematurity">Retinopathy of prematurity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#retinopathy-of-prematurity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) affects premature babies. Risk factors include birth before 32 weeks' gestation, birth weight of less than 1500 g , requirement for oxygen therapy and serious illness. There is abnormal development of retinal blood vessels and formation of fibrovascular tissue in the vitreous body, causing varying degrees of interference with light transmission. The prognosis depends on the severity and many cases resolve spontaneously. In severe cases there may also be haemorrhage in the vitreous body, retinal detachment and loss of vision.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="retinal-detachment">Retinal detachment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#retinal-detachment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This painless condition occurs when a tear or hole in the retina allows fluid to accumulate between the layers of retinal cells or between the retina and choroid. It is usually localised at first but as fluid collects the detachment spreads. There are visual disturbances, often spots before the eyes or flashes of light due to abnormal stimulation of sensory nerves, and progressive loss of vision, sometimes described as a 'shadow' or 'curtain'. In many cases the cause is
unknown but it may be associated with trauma to the eye or head, tumours, haemorrhage, cataract surgery when intraocular pressure is reduced, or diabetic retinopathy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="retinitis-pigmentosa">Retinitis pigmentosa<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#retinitis-pigmentosa" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is a group of hereditary diseases in which there is degeneration of the retina that mainly affects the rods. Progressive impairment of peripheral vision, especially in dim light, usually becomes apparent in early childhood. Over time this leads to tunnel vision and, eventually, loss of sight.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="tumours">Tumours<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="choroidal-malignant-melanoma">Choroidal malignant melanoma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#choroidal-malignant-melanoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the most common ocular malignancy in adults, occurring between 40 and 70 years of age. Vision is not normally affected until the tumour causes retinal detachment or secondary glaucoma, usually when well advanced. The tumour spreads locally in the choroid, and blood-borne metastases usually develop in the liver.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="retinoblastoma">Retinoblastoma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#retinoblastoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the most common malignant tumour in children. A small number of cases are familial. It is normally evident before the age of 4 years and usually affects one side. The condition presents with a squint and enlargement of the eye. As the tumour grows, visual impairment develops and the pupil looks pale. It spreads locally to the vitreous body and may grow along the optic nerve, invading the brain.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="11">

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="refractive-errors-of-the-eye">Refractive errors of the eye<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#refractive-errors-of-the-eye" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>explain how corrective lenses overcome refractive errors of the eye.</li>
</ul>
<p>In the emmetropic or normal eye, light from near and distant objects is focused on the retina (Fig. 8.29A).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="myopia">Myopia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#myopia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This abnormality is also called nearsightedness or shortsightedness. Because the eyeball is too long, distant objects are focused in front of the retina (Fig. 8.29B). Close objects are focused normally but distant vision is blurred. Correction is achieved using a biconcave lens (Fig. 8.29D).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hyperopia">Hyperopia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hyperopia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This abnormality is also called farsightedness or longsightedness. It causes a near image to be focused behind the retina because the eyeball is too short (Fig. 8.29C). Distant objects are focused normally but close vision is blurred. A convex lens corrects this (Fig. 8.29E).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="astigmatism">Astigmatism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#astigmatism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is abnormal curvature of part of the cornea or lens. It interferes with the light path though the eye and prevents focusing of light on the retina, causing blurred vision. Correction requires cylindrical lenses. It is very common and may coexist with other refractive disorders.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="13">
<li>In which refractive error is the eyeball too long?</li>
</ol>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="review-and-revise">Review and revise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#review-and-revise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<p>Indicate whether each of the following statements is true or false:

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-endocrine-system">The endocrine system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-endocrine-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
