9.1 Overview of the endocrine system 233
9.2 Steroid hormones 234
9.3 Control of thyroid secretion 241</p>
<p>The endocrine system consists of glands, which are widely separated and have no physical connections with each other (Fig. 9.1). Endocrine glands are groups of secretory cells surrounded by extensive networks of capillaries that facilitate diffusion of hormones (chemical messengers) from the secretory cells into the bloodstream. They are also referred to as ductless glands because hormones
diffuse directly into the bloodstream. Hormones are then carried in the bloodstream to target tissues and organs that may be distant, where they influence cell growth and metabolism. 9.1</p>
<p>Homeostasis of the internal environment is maintained partly by the autonomic nervous system and partly by the endocrine system. The autonomic nervous system is</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter-o">CHAPTER (O<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-o" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-b026b978.jpeg" alt="img-308.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 9.1 Positions of the endocrine glands.
concerned with rapid changes, while endocrine control is generally involved in slower and more precise adjustments.</p>
<p>The main endocrine glands are shown in Fig. 9.1, although many other organs and tissues also secrete hormones as a secondary function. For example, adipose tissue produces leptin (Table 9.4, p. 247), which is involved in the regulation of appetite, and the heart secretes atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP, Table 9.4, p. 247), which acts on the kidneys.</p>
<p>Although the hypothalamus is classified as a part of the brain rather than an endocrine gland, it controls the pituitary gland and indirectly influences many others.</p>
<p>The ovaries and the testes secrete hormones associated with the reproductive system after puberty; their functions are described in Chapter 18. The placenta, which develops to nourish the developing fetus during pregnancy, also has an endocrine function, which is outlined in Chapter 5.</p>
<p>The most important endocrine glands are explored in the early sections of this chapter. Some hormones, e.g. prostaglandins, do not travel to remote organs but act locally instead and some of these are considered briefly on page 248. Changes in endocrine functions that accompany ageing are explored. Problems that arise when abnormalities</p>
<p>occur are caused by the over- or under-activity of endocrine glands and are explained in the final sections of the chapter.</p>
<p>Overview of hormone action
When a hormone arrives at its target cell, it binds to a specific receptor, where it acts as a switch influencing chemical or metabolic reactions inside the cell. Receptors for peptide hormones are situated on the cell membrane and those for lipid-based hormones are located inside cells. Examples of peptide and lipid-based hormones are shown in Box 9.1. n9.2</p>
<p>The level of a hormone in the blood is variable and self-regulating within its normal range. A hormone is released in response to a specific stimulus and usually its action reverses or negates the stimulus through a negative feedback mechanism (p. 35). This may be controlled either indirectly through the release of hormones by the hypothalamus and the anterior pituitary gland, e.g. steroid and thyroid hormones, or directly by blood levels of the stimulus, e.g. insulin and glucagon, which are determined by plasma glucose levels.</p>
<p>Box 9.1 Examples of lipid-based and peptide hormones Lipid-based hormones
Steroids, e.g. glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids Thyroid hormones
Peptide hormones
Adrenaline (epinephrine), noradrenaline (norepinephrine)
Insulin
Glucagon
The effect of a positive feedback mechanism is amplification of the stimulus and increasing release of the hormone until a particular process is complete and the stimulus ceases, e.g. release of oxytocin during labour (p. 239).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pituitary-giand-and-hypothaiamus">Pituitary giand and hypothaiamus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pituitary-giand-and-hypothaiamus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the structure of the hypothalamus and the pituitary gland</li>
<li>explain the influence of the hypothalamus on the lobes of the pituitary gland</li>
<li>outline the actions of the hormones secreted by the anterior and posterior lobes of the pituitary gland.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-5470b731.jpeg" alt="img-309.jpeg"></p>
<p>Optic chiasma
Thalamus

Figure 9.2 The pituitary gland. Median section showing its position and associated structures.
that has already passed through a capillary bed in the hypothalamus (see later), and the posterior lobe is supplied directly.</p>
<p>The pituitary gland and the hypothalamus act as a unit, regulating the activity of most of the other endocrine glands. The pituitary gland lies in the hypophyseal fossa of the sphenoid bone below the hypothalamus, to which it is attached by a stalk (Fig. 9.2). It is the size of a pea, weighs about 500 mg and consists of two main parts that originate from different types of cell. The anterior pituitary is composed of glandular tissue secreting hormones because it is an upgrowth of glandular tissue from the pharynx, and the posterior pituitary is composed of nervous tissue because it is a downgrowth of nervous tissue from the brain. There is a network of nerve fibres between the hypothalamus and the posterior pituitary (Fig. 9.3).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="venous-drainage">Venous drainage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#venous-drainage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Venous blood, containing hormones from both lobes, leaves the gland in short veins that enter the venous sinuses between the layers of dura mater.</p>
<p>The influence of the hypothalamus on the pituitary gland
The hypothalamus controls release of hormones from both the anterior and posterior pituitary but in different ways that are explained in the next sections.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="anterior-pituitary">Anterior pituitary<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anterior-pituitary" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Blood supply</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="arterial-blood">Arterial blood<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#arterial-blood" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Arterial supply is from branches of the internal carotid artery. The anterior lobe is supplied indirectly by blood</p>
<p>The anterior pituitary is supplied with arterial blood that has already passed through a capillary bed in the hypothalamus (Fig. 9.3A). The hypothalamus and anterior pituitary are linked by a network of capillaries called the pituitary portal system.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-55cc5339.jpeg" alt="img-310.jpeg"></p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pituitary-portal-system">Pituitary portal system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pituitary-portal-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This network of vessels transports blood from the hypothalamus to the anterior pituitary, where it enters a network of tiny sinusoids (p. 83) that are in close contact with the secretory cells, permitting easy passage of hormones into the bloodstream. As well as providing oxygen and nutrients, this blood transports releasing and inhibiting hormones secreted by the hypothalamus. These hormones specifically influence secretion and release of other hormones formed in the anterior pituitary (Table 9.1).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="stimulation-and-inhibition-of-the-anterior-pituitary">Stimulation and inhibition of the anterior pituitary<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stimulation-and-inhibition-of-the-anterior-pituitary" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Some of the hormones secreted by the anterior lobe stimulate or inhibit secretion by other endocrine glands (target glands) while others have a direct effect on target tissues. Table 9.1 summarises the main relationships between the hormones of the hypothalamus, the anterior pituitary and target glands or tissues.</p>
<p>Secretion of an anterior pituitary hormone follows stimulation of the gland by a specific releasing hormone produced by the hypothalamus and carried to the gland through the pituitary portal system already described. The whole system is controlled by a negative feedback mechanism (Ch. 2): that is, when the level of a hormone in the blood supplying the hypothalamus is low it produces the appropriate releasing hormone, which stimulates release of a trophic hormone by the anterior pituitary. This in turn stimulates the target gland to produce and release its hormone. As a result, the blood level of that hormone rises and inhibits secretion of its releasing factor by the hypothalamus (Fig. 9.4).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="growth-hormone">Growth hormone<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#growth-hormone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Growth hormone <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{GH})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">GH</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> is the most abundant hormone synthesised by the anterior pituitary. It stimulates growth and division of most body cells, i.e. has anabolic effects, especially on those in the bones and skeletal muscles.</p>
<p>Table 9.1 Hormones of the hypothalamus, anterior pituitary and their target tissues</p>

(LH)</p>
<p>Its secretion is highest in childhood and adolescence, accelerating cell division, increasing tissue mass and driving the rapid body growth taking place at this time. In adult life, GH controls growth and regeneration of nearly all body tissues, especially skeletal muscle and bone. It also regulates aspects of metabolism in many organs, e.g. liver, intestines and pancreas. It stimulates protein synthesis, especially for tissue growth and repair, promotes breakdown of fats and increases blood glucose levels (Ch. 12).</p>
<p>Its release is stimulated by growth hormone releasing hormone (GHRH) and suppressed by growth hormone release inhibiting hormone (GHRIH), also known as somatostatin, both of which are secreted by the hypothalamus.</p>
<p>GH secretion is controlled by a negative feedback system; it is inhibited when the blood level rises and also when GHRIH is released by the hypothalamus. GHRIH also suppresses secretion of thyroid stimulating hormone and gastrointestinal secretions, e.g. gastric juice, gastrin and cholecystokinin (Ch. 12).</p>
<p>Secretion of GH is greater at night during deep sleep and is also stimulated by hypoglycaemia (low blood glucose), exercise and anxiety. Ongoing sleep disturbances in children, e.g. in childhood asthma, can lead to restriction of normal growth.</p>
<p>GH is a stress hormone and, as such, is released during situations such as starvation and trauma.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-90881163.jpeg" alt="img-312.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 9.4 Negative feedback regulation of secretion of hornnones by the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="prolactin">Prolactin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#prolactin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This hormone, also known as lactogenic hormone, is secreted during pregnancy to prepare the breasts for lactation (milk production) after childbirth. The blood level of prolactin is stimulated by prolactin releasing hormone (PRH) released from the hypothalamus and it is lowered by prolactin inhibiting hormone (PIH, dopamine) and by an increased blood level of prolactin. Immediately after birth, suckling stimulates prolactin secretion and lactation. The resultant high blood level is a factor in reducing the incidence of conception during lactation.</p>
<p>Prolactin, together with oestrogens, corticosteroids, insulin and thyroxine, is involved in initiating and maintaining lactation. Prolactin secretion is related to sleep, rising during any period of sleep, night or day.</p>
<p>Thyroid stimulating hormone
Release of thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) is stimulated by thyrotrophin releasing hormone (TRH) from the hypothalamus. It stimulates growth and activity of the
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-7d0271f6.jpeg" alt="img-313.jpeg">
thyroid gland, which secretes the hormones thyroxine (T4) and tri-iodothyronine (T3). Secretion is regulated by a negative feedback mechanism: i.e. when the blood</p>
<p>level of thyroid hormones is high, secretion of TSH is reduced, and vice versa (Fig. 9.4). Exposure to cold is a powerful stimulant of TSH secretion, leading to increased thyroid hormone release and an increase in metabolic rate.</p>
<p>Adrenocorticotrophic hormone (corticotrophin)
Corticotrophin releasing hormone (CRH) from the hypothalamus promotes synthesis and release of adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH) by the anterior pituitary. This stimulates growth and activity of the adrenal cortex, increasing the output of adrenocortical steroid hormones, especially cortisol.</p>
<p>ACTH levels are highest at about 8 a.m. and fall to their lowest about midnight, although high levels sometimes occur at midday and 6 p.m. This circadian rhythm is maintained throughout life. It is associated with sleep patterns and adjustment to changes takes several days, e.g. following changing work shifts or travelling to a different time zone (jet lag).</p>
<p>Secretion is also regulated by a negative feedback mechanism, being suppressed when the blood level of ACTH rises (Fig. 9.4). Other factors that stimulate secretion include hypoglycaemia, exercise and other stressors, e.g. emotional states and fever.</p>
<p>Gonadotrophins
Just before puberty, two gonadotrophins (sex hormones) are secreted in gradually increasing amounts by the anterior pituitary in response to hypothalamic release of luteinising hormone releasing hormone (LHRH), also known as gonadotrophin releasing hormone <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{GnRH})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">GnRH</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>. Rising levels of these hormones at puberty promotes maturation of the reproductive organs. In both males and females the hormones responsible are:</p>
<ul>
<li>follicle stimulating hormone (FSH)</li>
<li>luteinising hormone <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{LH})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">LH</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="in-both-sexes">In both sexes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#in-both-sexes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>FSH stimulates production of gametes (ova or spermatozoa) by the gonads (the ovary in the female and the testis in the male).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="in-females">In females<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#in-females" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>LH and FSH control the secretion of the hormones oestrogen and progesterone during the menstrual cycle (see Figs 18.9 and 18.10). As the levels of oestrogen and progesterone rise, secretion of LH and FSH is suppressed.</p>
<p>Table 9.2 Summary of the hormones secreted by the anterior pituitary gland and their functions</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="in-males">In males<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#in-males" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>LH, also called interstitial cell stimulating hormone (ICSH), stimulates the interstitial cells of the testes to secrete the hormone testosterone (Ch. 18).</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="posterior-pituitary">Posterior pituitary<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#posterior-pituitary" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The posterior pituitary is formed from nervous tissue and consists of nerve cells surrounded by supporting glial cells called pituicytes. These neurones have their cell bodies in the supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus and their axons form a bundle known as the hypothalamohypophyseal tract (see Fig.</p>
<p>9.3A). Posterior pituitary hormones are synthesised in the nerve cell bodies, transported along the axons and stored in vesicles within the axon terminals in the posterior pituitary (see Fig. 9.3B).</p>
<p>Unlike in the anterior pituitary, where secretion is stimulated by hormones, nerve impulses from the hypothalamus trigger exocytosis of the vesicles, releasing posterior pituitary hormones into the bloodstream.</p>
<p>The structure of the posterior pituitary gland and its relationship with the hypothalamus is explained on page 235. Oxytocin and antidiuretic hormone (ADH, vasopressin) are the hormones released from axon terminals within the posterior pituitary (see Fig. 9.3B). These hormones act directly on non-endocrine tissue.</p>
<p>Oxytocin
Oxytocin stimulates two target tissues during and after childbirth (parturition): uterine smooth muscle and the muscle cells of the lactating breast.</p>
<p>In labour, uterine contractions force the baby's head into the cervix

<p>Oxytocin levels rise during sexual arousal in both males and females. This increases smooth muscle contraction, which is associated with glandular secretion and ejaculation in males. In females, contraction of smooth muscle in the vagina and uterus promotes movement of sperm towards the uterine tubes. It is believed that the smell of oxytocin may be involved in social recognition and bonding between mother and newborn baby.</p>
<p>Antidiuretic hormone (vasopressin)
The main effect of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) is to reduce urine output (diuresis is the production of large volumes of urine). ADH acts on the distal convoluted tubules and collecting ducts of the kidneys, increasing their permeability to water (Ch. 13). This results in increased reabsorption of water from the glomerular filtrate and a corresponding reduction in the volume of urine produced. ADH secretion is determined by the osmotic pressure of the blood circulating to the osmoreceptors, which lie in the hypothalamus close to the supraoptic nucleus (see Fig. 9.3A).</p>
<p>As osmotic pressure rises, e.g. as a result of dehydration, secretion of ADH increases. More water is therefore reabsorbed by the kidneys and the urine output is reduced. This means that the body retains more water and the rise in osmotic pressure is reversed. Conversely, when the osmotic pressure of the blood is low, e.g. after a large fluid intake, secretion of ADH is reduced, less water is reabsorbed and more urine is produced (Fig. 9.6).</p>
<p>Blood osmotic pressure raised</p>
<p>During childbirth the posterior pituitary releases increasing amounts of oxytocin into the bloodstream in response to increasing stimulation of sensory stretch receptors in the uterine cervix as the baby's head progressively dilates it. Sensory impulses are generated and transmitted to the hypothalamus, stimulating the posterior pituitary to release more oxytocin. In turn, this stimulates more forceful uterine contractions and greater stretching of the uterine cervix as the baby's head is forced further downwards. This is an example of a positive feedback mechanism, which stops soon after the baby is delivered when distension of the uterine cervix is greatly reduced (Fig. 9.5).</p>
<p>The process of milk ejection also involves a positive feedback mechanism. Suckling generates sensory impulses that are transmitted from the breast to the hypothalamus, triggering release of oxytocin from the posterior pituitary. On reaching the lactating breast, oxytocin stimulates contraction of the milk ducts and myoepithelial cells around the glandular cells, ejecting milk. Suckling also inhibits the

<p>At high concentrations, e.g. after severe blood loss, ADH causes smooth muscle contraction, especially vasoconstriction in small muscular arteries (arterioles). This has a pressor effect, raising systemic blood pressure; the alternative name of this hormone, vasopressin, reflects this effect.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="thyroid-gland">Thyroid gland<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thyroid-gland" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the position of the thyroid gland and its related structures</li>
<li>describe the microscopic structure of the thyroid gland</li>
<li>outline the actions of the thyroid hormones</li>
<li>explain how blood levels of the thyroid hormones T 3 and T 4 are regulated.</li>
</ul>
<p>The thyroid gland (Fig. 9.7) is situated in the neck in front of the larynx and trachea at the level of the 5th, 6 th and 7th cervical and 1st thoracic vertebrae. It is a highly vascular gland that weighs about 25 g and is surrounded by a fibrous capsule. It resembles a butterfly in shape, consisting of two lobes, one on either side of the thyroid cartilage and upper cartilaginous rings of the trachea. The lobes are joined by a narrow isthmus, lying in front of the trachea. The lobes are roughly cone shaped and are about 5 cm long and 3 cm wide.</p>
<p>The gland is composed of largely spherical follicles formed from cuboidal epithelium (Fig. 9.8). These secrete and store colloid, a thick, sticky protein material. Between the follicles are parafollicular cells (sometimes called C-cells), found singly or in groups. They secrete the hormone calcitonin.</p>
<p>Blood and nerve supply. The arterial blood supply to the gland is through the superior and inferior thyroid arteries. The superior thyroid artery is a branch of the external carotid artery and the inferior thyroid artery is a branch of the subclavian artery.</p>
<p>The venous return is by the thyroid veins, which drain into the internal jugular veins.</p>
<p>The recurrent laryngeal nerves pass upwards, close to the lobes of the gland, and lie near the inferior thyroid artery, especially on the right side (see Fig. 9.7).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-6953c39d.jpeg" alt="img-316.jpeg"></p>

Thyroxine and tri-iodothyronine
Iodine is essential for the formation of the thyroid hormones, thyroxine (T4) and tri-iodothyronine (T3), so numbered as these molecules contain four and three atoms of iodine, respectively. The main dietary sources of iodine are seafood, vegetables grown in iodine-rich soil and iodinated table salt. The thyroid gland selectively takes up iodine from the blood, a process called iodine trapping.</p>
<p>Thyroid hormones are synthesised as large precursor molecules called thyroglobulin, the major constituent of colloid. The release of T 3 and T 4 into the blood is stimulated</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<p>Figure 9.9 Negative feedback regulation of secretion of thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3).
by thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) from the anterior pituitary.
Secretion of TSH is stimulated by thyrotrophin releasing hormone (TRH) from the hypothalamus and secretion of TRH is stimulated by exposure to cold, exercise, stress, malnutrition, low plasma glucose levels and sleep. TSH secretion depends on the plasma levels of T 3 and T 4 because it is these hormones that control the sensitivity of the anterior pituitary to TRH. Through the negative feedback mechanism, increased levels of T 3 and T 4 decrease TSH secretion and vice versa (Fig. 9.9). Dietary iodine deficiency greatly increases TSH secretion causing proliferation of thyroid gland cells and enlargement of the gland (goitre, see Fig. 9.17).</p>
<p>Secretion of T 3 and T 4 begins in about the 3rd month of fetal life and increases at puberty and in women during the</p>

reproductive years, especially during pregnancy. Otherwise, it remains fairly constant throughout life. Of the two thyroid hormones, T 4 is much more abundant. However, it is less potent than T3, which is more physiologically important. Most T 4 is converted into T 3 inside target cells. 9.3</p>
<p>Thyroid hormones enter the cell nucleus and regulate gene expression, i.e. they increase or decrease protein synthesis (Ch. 17). They enhance the effects of other hormones, e.g. adrenaline (epinephrine) and noradrenaline (norepinephrine). T 3 and T 4 affect most cells of the body by:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>increasing the metabolic rate and heat production</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>regulating metabolism of carbohydrates, proteins and fats.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>T 3 and T 4 are essential for normal growth and development, especially of the skeleton and nervous system. Most other organs and systems are also influenced by thyroid hormones. Physiological effects of T 3 and T 4 on the heart, skeletal muscles, skin and digestive and reproductive systems are more evident when there is under-activity or over-activity of the thyroid gland and can be profound in childhood (Table 9.3).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="calcitonin">Calcitonin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calcitonin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This hormone is secreted by the parafollicular or C-cells in the thyroid gland (see Fig. 9.8). Calcitonin lowers blood calcium <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\left(\mathrm{Ca}^{2+}\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.2373em; vertical-align: -0.35em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">(</span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Ca</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8873em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">)</span></span></span></span></span></span></span> levels. It does this by acting on:</p>
<ul>
<li>bone cells, promoting their storage of calcium (Ch. 16)</li>
<li>kidney tubules, inhibiting the reabsorption of calcium.</li>
</ul>
<p>Its action opposes that of parathyroid hormone, secreted by the parathyroid glands. Release of calcitonin is stimulated by increased blood calcium levels.</p>
<p>This hormone is important during childhood, when developing bones undergo considerable changes in size and shape.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="2">
<li>Which hormone involved in regulation of blood calcium levels is secreted by the thyroid gland?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="parathyroid-glands">Parathyroid glands<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#parathyroid-glands" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the position and gross structure of the parathyroid glands</li>
<li>outline the functions of parathyroid hormone and calcitonin</li>
<li>explain how blood levels of parathyroid hormone and calcitonin are regulated.</li>
</ul>
<p>There are four parathyroid glands, each weighing around 50 g ; two are embedded in the posterior surface of each lobe of the thyroid gland (Fig. 9.10). They are surrounded by fine connective tissue capsules that contain spherical cells arranged in columns, with sinusoids containing blood in between them.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-70e92289.jpeg" alt="img-319.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 9.10 The parathyroid glands. Posterior view showing their position and associated structures.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="function">Function<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#function" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These glands secrete parathyroid hormone (PTH, also known as parathormone), which regulates blood calcium levels. When these fall, secretion of PTH is increased and vice versa.</p>
<p>PTH secretion increases blood calcium levels by releasing calcium stored in bone via a dual action: it stimulates osteoclasts (bone-destroying cells) and increases calcium reabsorption from the renal tubules.</p>
<p>PTH and calcitonin from the thyroid gland act in a complementary manner to maintain blood calcium levels within the normal range. Calcium is essential for:</p>
<ul>
<li>muscle contraction</li>
<li>transmission of nerve impulses</li>
<li>blood clotting</li>
<li>normal action of many enzymes.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="3">
<li>Describe the function of parathyroid hormone.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="adrenal-glands">Adrenal glands<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adrenal-glands" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes</p>
<p>The two adrenal (suprarenal) glands are situated on the upper pole of each kidney, enclosed within the renal fascia. They are about 4 cm long and 3 cm thick.</p>
<p>The glands are composed of two parts (Fig. 9.11), which have different structures and functions. The outer layer is the cortex and the inner core the medulla. The adrenal cortex is essential to life but the medulla is not.</p>
<p>Blood supply
The arterial blood supply is by branches from the abdominal aorta and renal arteries.</p>
<p>The venous return is by suprarenal veins. The right gland drains into the inferior vena cava and the left into the left renal vein.</p>
<p>After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the structure of the adrenal glands</li>
<li>describe the actions of each of the three groups of adrenocorticoid hormones</li>
<li>explain how blood levels of glucocorticoids are regulated</li>
<li>describe the actions of adrenaline (epinephrine) and noradrenaline (norepinephrine)</li>
<li>outline how the adrenal glands respond to stress.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-062cf548.jpeg" alt="img-320.jpeg"></li>
</ul>
<p>Right adrenal gland
Inferior vena cava</p>
<p>Medulla
Cortex
Cross-section
Inferior
Left adrenal gland
Figure 9.11 The adrenal glands.
The adrenal glands and the stress response
A stressor is any effect on the body, either internal or external, that disturbs homeostasis. Stressors can be major or minor, and physical or psychological. They include infection, exercise, trauma, surgery, disease, emotional states, fasting, extremes of temperature and sleep deprivation.</p>
<p>Immediate responses to short-term stress include activation of the 'flight or fight' response (p. 189). This is mediated by the sympathetic nervous system and the principal effects are shown in Fig. 9.12.</p>
<p>Longer-term stress leads to release of ACTH from the anterior pituitary, which stimulates the release of glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids from the adrenal cortex, providing a more prolonged response to stress (Fig. 9.12).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="adrenal-medulla">Adrenal medulla<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adrenal-medulla" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The medulla is completely surrounded by the adrenal cortex. It develops from nervous tissue in the embryo and is part of the sympathetic nervous system (Ch. 7). When stimulated by its extensive sympathetic nerve supply, the glands release the hormones adrenaline (epinephrine, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>80</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">80 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">80%</span></span></span></span></span> ) and noradrenaline (norepinephrine, 20%).</p>
<p>Adrenaline (epinephrine) and noradrenaline (norepinephrine)
Noradrenaline is the postganglionic neurotransmitter of the sympathetic division of the autonomic nervous system (see Fig. 7.44). Adrenaline and some noradrenaline are released into the blood from the adrenal medulla during stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system. These hormones prolong and augment stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system. Structurally, they are very similar, which explains their similar effects. Together they potentiate the fight or flight response by:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>increasing heart rate</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>increasing blood pressure</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>diverting blood to essential organs, including the heart, brain and skeletal muscles, by dilating their blood vessels and constricting those of less essential organs, such as the skin</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>increasing metabolic rate</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>dilating the pupils.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Adrenaline has a greater effect on the heart and metabolic processes, whereas noradrenaline has more influence on blood vessel diameter.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="adrenal-cortex">Adrenal cortex<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adrenal-cortex" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The adrenal cortex produces three groups of steroid hormones from cholesterol, collectively called adrenocorticoids (corticosteroids). The groups are:</p>
<ul>
<li>glucocorticoids</li>
<li>mineralocorticoids</li>
<li>sex hormones (gonadocorticoids).</li>
</ul>
<p>The hormones in each group have different actions, but as they are structurally similar, their actions may overlap.</p>
<p>Glucocorticoids
Cortisol (hydrocortisone) is the main glucocorticoid but small amounts of corticosterone and cortisone are also produced. Glucocorticoids are essential for life, regulating metabolism, the inflammatory and immune responses, and responses to stress (see Fig. 9.12). Secretion is controlled through a negative feedback system involving the hypothalamus and anterior pituitary. It is stimulated by ACTH from the anterior pituitary and by stress (Fig. 9.13). Cortisol secretion shows marked circadian variation, peaking between 4 a.m. and 8 a.m. and being lowest between midnight and 3 a.m. When the sleep/wake pattern is changed, e.g. in night shift working, it takes several days for ACTH/cortisol secretion to readjust (p. 238). Glucocorticoid secretion increases in response to stress (Figs 9.12 and 9.13), including infection and surgery.</p>
<p>Glucocorticoids have widespread metabolic effects, generally concerned with catabolism (breakdown) of protein</p>

and fat that makes glucose and other substances available for use to help the body combat stress. These include:</p>
<ul>
<li>hyperglycaemia (raised blood glucose levels) caused by breakdown of glycogen and gluconeogenesis (formation of new sugar from, for example, protein)</li>
<li>lipolysis (breakdown of triglycerides into fatty acids and glycerol for energy production), raising circulating levels of free fatty acids</li>
<li>stimulation of breakdown of protein, releasing amino acids and increasing blood levels; amino acids are then used for synthesis of other proteins, e.g. enzymes, or for energy production (Ch. 12)</li>
<li>promotion of absorption of sodium and water from renal tubules (a weak mineralocorticoid effect).</li>
</ul>
<p>In pathological and pharmacological quantities, glucocorticoids also have other effects, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>anti-inflammatory actions</li>
<li>suppression of immune responses</li>
<li>delayed wound healing.</li>
</ul>
<p>When corticosteroids are administered in the treatment of common disorders, e.g. asthma, the high circulating levels exert a negative feedback effect on the</p>
<p>hypothalamus and pituitary that can completely suppress natural secretion of CRH and ACTH , respectively.</p>
<p>Mineralocorticoids (aldosterone)
Aldosterone is the main mineralocorticoid. It is involved in maintaining water and electrolyte balance. <div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i">I<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-mathbf-c-c"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="bold">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6861em;"></span><span class="mord mathbf">C</span></span></span></span></span><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-mathbf-c-c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Raised blood glucocorticoid levels</p>

<p>Blood potassium levels regulate aldosterone secretion by the adrenal cortex. When blood potassium levels rise, more aldosterone is secreted (Fig. 9.14). Low blood potassium has the opposite effect. Angiotensin (see next section) also stimulates the release of aldosterone.</p>
<p>Renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system
0

<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span></span></span></span></span>

t blood pressure
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{ACE}=</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">ACE</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span></span></span></span></span> Angiotensin converting enzyme
When renal blood flow is reduced or blood sodium levels fall, the enzyme renin is secreted by kidney cells. Renin converts the plasma protein angiotensinogen, produced by the liver, to angiotensin 1. Angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE), formed in small quantities mainly in the lungs, converts angiotensin 1 to angiotensin 2, which stimulates secretion of aldosterone. Angiotensin 2 causes vasoconstriction and increases blood pressure, closing the negative feedback loop (Fig. 9.14).</p>

<p>S ex hormones (gonadocorticoids)
Sex hormones secreted by the adrenal cortex are mainly androgens (male sex hormones), although the amounts produced are insignificant compared with those secreted by the testes and ovaries in late puberty and adulthood (Ch. 18).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5205029c">■ SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5205029c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pancreatic-islets">Pancreatic islets<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pancreatic-islets" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>list the hormones secreted by the endocrine pancreas</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>describe the actions of insulin and glucagon</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>explain how blood glucose levels are regulated.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>The gross structure of the pancreas is described in Chapter 12. Only 2% of pancreatic tissue has an endocrine function and this consists of clusters of cells, known as the pancreatic islets (islets of Langerhans), scattered throughout the gland. Pancreatic hormones are secreted directly into the bloodstream and circulate throughout the body. This is in contrast to the exocrine pancreas and its associated ducts (p.336).</p>
<p>There are 1-2 million pancreatic islets, which contain three main types of hormonesecreting cell:</p>
<ul>
<li>a (alpha) cells, which secrete glucagon</li>
<li>P (beta) cells, the most numerous, which secrete insulin</li>
<li>5 (delta) cells, which secrete somatostatin (GHRIH, p.237).</li>
</ul>
<p>The normal blood glucose level is between 3.5 and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>8</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>63</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>144</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>100</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">8 \mathrm{mmol} / \mathrm{L}(63-144 \mathrm{mg} / 100 \mathrm{~mL})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">8</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mmol</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">63</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">144</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mg</span></span><span class="mord">/100</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mL</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>. Blood glucose levels are controlled mainly by the opposing actions of insulin and glucagon:</p>
<ul>
<li>Glucagon increases blood glucose levels.</li>
<li>Insulin reduces blood glucose levels.</li>
</ul>
<p>Insulin
Insulin is a polypeptide hormone consisting of about 50 amino acids. Body cells require glucose to fuel their metabolic activities but glucose does not freely cross the cell membrane. All body cells have insulin receptors on their plasma membranes, and in the presence of insulin
can actively import glucose. Insulin also has an essential function in lowering raised blood nutrient levels, not only glucose but also amino acids and fatty acids. These are anabolic effects, i.e. they promote storage of nutrients. When nutrients, especially glucose, are in excess of immediate needs, insulin promotes their storage by:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>activating glucose transporters in cell membranes and stimulating uptake and use of glucose by muscle and connective tissue cells</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>increasing conversion of glucose to glycogen (glycogenesis), especially in the liver and skeletal muscles</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>accelerating uptake of amino acids by cells, and the synthesis of protein</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>promoting synthesis of fatty acids and storage of fat in adipose tissue (lipogenesis)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>decreasing glycogenolysis (breakdown of glycogen into glucose)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>preventing the breakdown of protein and fat, and gluconeogenesis (formation of new sugar from, for example, protein).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Secretion of insulin is stimulated by increased blood glucose levels, e.g. after eating a meal, and to a lesser extent by parasympathetic stimulation, raised blood amino acid and fatty acid levels, and gastrointestinal hormones, e.g. gastrin, secretin and cholecystokinin. Secretion is decreased by sympathetic stimulation, glucagon, adrenaline (epinephrine), cortisol and somatostatin (GHRIH), which is secreted by the hypothalamus and pancreatic islets.</p>
<p>Glucagon
Glucagon increases blood glucose levels by stimulating:</p>
<ul>
<li>conversion of glycogen to glucose in the liver and skeletal muscles (glycogenolysis)</li>
<li>gluconeogenesis.</li>
</ul>
<p>Secretion of glucagon is stimulated by low blood glucose levels and exercise, and decreased by somatostatin and insulin.</p>
<p>Somatostatin
Somatostatin (GHRIH), also produced by the hypothalamus, inhibits secretion of both insulin and glucagon in addition to inhibiting the secretion of GH from the anterior pituitary (p.237).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<li>The secretion of which hormone is stimulated by low blood sugar levels?</li>
</ol>
<p>Learning outcomes</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pineal-gland">Pineal gland<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pineal-gland" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>state the position of the pineal gland</li>
</ul>
<p>■ outline the actions of melatonin.
The pineal gland is a small body attached to the roof of the third ventricle and is connected to it by a short stalk containing nerves, many of which terminate in the hypothalamus. The pineal gland is about 10 mm long, reddish brown in colour and surrounded by a capsule. The gland tends to atrophy after puberty and may become calcified in later life.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="melatonin">Melatonin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#melatonin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is the main hormone secreted by the pineal gland. It is structurally similar to serotonin (see below). Secretion is suppressed by daylight and increased during darkness; levels fluctuate during each 24 -hour period, being highest at night and the lowest around midday. Secretion is also influenced by the number of daylight hours, i.e. there may be seasonal variations. Although its functions are not fully understood, melatonin is believed to be associated with:</p>
<ul>
<li>coordination of the circadian and diurnal rhythms of many tissues, possibly by influencing the hypothalamus</li>
<li>mood, as melatonin has been implicated in seasonal affective disorder, also known as 'winter depression', a condition associated with low mood during winter when there are few hours of daylight</li>
<li>inhibition of growth and development of the sex organs before puberty, possibly by preventing synthesis or release of gonadotrophins.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>6 . At what time of day are melatonin levels highest?</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="organs-with-secondary-endocrine-functions">Organs with secondary endocrine functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#organs-with-secondary-endocrine-functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i-spot-check">I# SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
