<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="local-hormones">Local hormones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#local-hormones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to: outline the actions of local hormones.</p>
<p>A number of body tissues not normally described as endocrine glands secrete substances that act on local tissues. Some of these are described here.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="histamine">Histamine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#histamine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is synthesised and stored by mast cells in the tissues and basophils in blood. It is released as part of inflammatory responses, especially when these are caused by allergy (p. 417), increasing capillary permeability and causing vasodilation. It also acts as a neurotransmitter, causes contraction of smooth muscle of the bronchi and alimentary tract, and stimulates the secretion of gastric juice.</p>
<p>Serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine)
Serotonin (5-HT) is present in platelets, in the brain and in the intestinal wall. It stimulates intestinal secretion and contraction of smooth muscle, and its role in haemostasis (blood clotting) is outlined in Chapter 4. It is a neurotransmitter in the central nervous system and is known to influence mood.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="prostaglandins">Prostaglandins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#prostaglandins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Prostaglandins (PCs) are lipid substances found in most tissues. They act on neighbouring cells but their actions are short-lived as they are quickly metabolised</p>
<p>and their blood levels are negligible. Prostaglandins have potent and wide-ranging physiological effects in:</p>
<ul>
<li>inflammatory responses</li>
<li>potentiation of pain</li>
<li>stimulation of gastric mucus production</li>
<li>fever</li>
<li>regulation of blood pressure</li>
<li>blood clotting</li>
<li>uterine contractions during labour.</li>
</ul>
<p>Other chemically similar compounds include leukotrienes, which are involved in inflammatory and immune responses, and thromboxanes, e.g. thromboxane A 2 , which is a potent aggregator of platelets. All of these active substances are found in only small amounts, as they are rapidly degraded.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="spot-check">- SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>8 . Name two functions of serotonin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="effects-of-ageing-on-the-endocrine-system">Effects of ageing on the endocrine system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effects-of-ageing-on-the-endocrine-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the effects of ageing on the endocrine system.</li>
</ul>
<p>Endocrine function often declines with age, although levels of some important hormones can remain unchanged well into old age. Reduced levels of aldosterone and renin may contribute to age-related postural hypotension, and increase sodium and water loss.</p>
<p>In the pancreatic islets, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>∣</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mid 3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mrel">∣</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span></span></span></span></span>-cell function declines with age. Especially when this is associated with weight gain in middle life and older age, it predisposes to type 2 diabetes mellitus (p. 256).</p>
<p>Ovarian secretion of female sex hormones declines after the menopause (Ch. 18), although secretion of the male sex hormone testosterone often remains high well into old age. Some hormones may actually rise with age, including PTH, which may contribute to osteoporosis.</p>
<p>The risk of most endocrine cancers rises with age.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="9">
<li>What condition is associated with declining pancreatic function in older life?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcome">Learning outcome<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcome">Learning outcome<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Endocrine disorders are commonly caused by tumours or autoimmune diseases, and their effects are usually the result of:</p>
<ul>
<li>hypersecretion (over-production) of hormones, or</li>
<li>hyposecretion (under-production) of hormones.</li>
</ul>
<p>The effects of many conditions explained in this section can therefore be readily linked to the underlying abnormality.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disorders-of-the-pituitary-gland">Disorders of the pituitary gland<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-pituitary-gland" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">□</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">□</span></span></span></span></span> list the causes of diseases in this section
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-6b8a257a.jpeg" alt="img-323.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>relate the features of conditions affecting the anterior pituitary to the actions of the hormones involved</li>
<li>relate the features of diabetes insipidus to abnormal secretion of antidiuretic hormone.</li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 9.15 Historical drawing showing the effects of normal and abnormal growth hormone secretion. From left to right: normal stature, gigantism ( 2.3 m tall) and restrioted growth (dwarfism;
0.9 m tall). (George Bernard/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hypersecretion-of-anterior-pituitary-hormones">Hypersecretion of anterior pituitary hormones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypersecretion-of-anterior-pituitary-hormones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Gigantism and acromegaly
The most common cause is prolonged hypersecretion of growth hormone (GH), usually by a hormone-secreting pituitary tumour. The conditions are occasionally due to excess growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH) secreted by the hypothalamus. As the tumour increases in size, compression of nearby structures may lead to hyposecretion of other pituitary hormones (from both lobes) and damage to the nearby optic nerves (see Fig. 9.2), causing visual disturbances. The effects of excess GH include:</p>
<ul>
<li>excessive growth of bones</li>
<li>enlargement of internal organs</li>
<li>formation of excess connective tissue</li>
<li>enlargement of the heart and raised blood pressure</li>
<li>reduced glucose tolerance and a predisposition to diabetes mellitus.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-fab1c929.jpeg" alt="img-324.jpeg"></li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 9.16 Facial features and large hands in acromegaly. (John Radcliffe Hospital/Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gigantism">Gigantism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gigantism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This occurs in children when there is excess GH while epiphyseal cartilages of long bones are still growing, i.e. before ossification of bones is complete. It is evident mainly in the bones of the limbs, and affected individuals may grow to heights of 2.1 to 2.4 m , although body proportions remain normal (Fig. 9.15).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acromegaly">Acromegaly<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acromegaly" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This means Targe extremities' and occurs in adults when there is excessive GH secretion after ossification is</p>
<p>complete. The bones become abnormally thick and there is also thickening of the soft tissues. These changes are most noticeable as coarse facial features (especially excessive growth of the lower jaw), an enlarged tongue and excessively large hands and feet (Fig. 9.16).</p>
<p>Hyperprolactinaemia
This is caused by a tumour that secretes large amounts of prolactin. It leads to galactorrhoea (inappropriate milk secretion), amenorrhoea (cessation of menstruation) and sterility in women and impotence in men.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hyposecretion-of-anterior-pituitary-hormones">Hyposecretion of anterior pituitary hormones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hyposecretion-of-anterior-pituitary-hormones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The number of hormones involved and the extent of hyposecretion vary. Panhypopituitarism is the absence of all anterior pituitary hormones. Causes of hyposecretion include:</p>
<ul>
<li>tumours of the hypothalamus or pituitary</li>
<li>trauma, usually caused by fractured base of skull, or surgery</li>
<li>pressure caused by a tumour adjacent to the pituitary gland, e.g. glioma, meningioma</li>
<li>infection, e.g. meningitis, encephalitis, syphilis</li>
<li>ischaemic necrosis</li>
<li>ionising radiation or cytotoxic drugs.</li>
</ul>
<p>Pituitary necrosis
Also known as postpartum necrosis or Sheehan's syndrome, this occurs following hypotensive shock associated with severe haemorrhage during or after childbirth. The arrangement of its blood supply makes the anterior pituitary unusually susceptible to a fall in systemic blood pressure. Failure of lactation precedes the other effects, which include deficient stimulation of target glands and consequent hypofunction of all or some of the thyroid, adrenal cortex and gonads. The outcome depends on the extent of pituitary necrosis and hormone deficiency. In severe cases, glucocorticoid deficiency may be life-threatening or fatal.</p>
<p>Pituitary dwarfism (Lorain-Levi syndrome)
This is caused by severe deficiency of GH, and possibly of other hormones, in childhood. The individual is of small stature but is normally proportioned and cognitive development is not affected. Puberty is delayed and there may be</p>
<p>episodes of hypoglycaemia. The condition may be due to genetic abnormality or a tumour.</p>
<p>Frohlich's syndrome
In this condition there is panhypopituitarism but the main effects are associated with deficiency of GH, FSH and LH. In children the effects are diminished growth, lack of sexual development, obesity with female distribution of fat and learning disabilities. Obesity and sterility are the main features in a similar condition in adults. It may arise from a tumour of the anterior pituitary and/or the hypothalamus but in most cases the cause is unknown.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="disorders-of-the-posterior-pituitary-diabetes-insipidus">Disorders of the posterior pituitary Diabetes insipidus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-posterior-pituitary-diabetes-insipidus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In this relatively rare condition there is hyposecretion of ADH from the posterior pituitary. It is usually secondary
to damage to the hypothalamus by, for example, trauma, tumour or encephalitis. Occasionally, it occurs when the renal tubules fail to respond to ADH. Water reabsorption by the renal tubules is impaired, leading to excretion of excessive amounts of dilute urine, often more than 10 litres daily, causing dehydration and extreme thirst (polydipsia). Water balance is disturbed unless fluid intake is greatly increased to compensate for excess losses.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-check">- SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="10">
<li>Excessive urine excretion is associated with which posterior pituitary condition?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disorders-of-the-thyroid-giand">Disorders of the thyroid giand<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-thyroid-giand" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>compare and contrast the effects of hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism, relating them to the actions of Tg and T 4 .</li>
</ul>
<p>Disorders of the thyroid gland fall into three main categories:</p>
<ul>
<li>abnormal secretion of thyroid hormones (T3 and T4), causing hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism</li>
<li>goitre - enlargement of the thyroid gland</li>
<li>tumours.</li>
</ul>
<p>Abnormal thyroid function may arise not only from thyroid disease but also from disorders of the pituitary or hypothalamus; in addition, insufficient dietary iodine</p>
<p>impairs synthesis of thyroid hormones. The main effects are caused by an abnormally high or low basal metabolic rate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hyperthyroidism">Hyperthyroidism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hyperthyroidism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This syndrome, also known as thyrotoxicosis, arises as the body tissues are exposed to excessive levels of T3 and T4. The main effects are due to increased basal metabolic rate (see Table 9.3).</p>
<p>In older adults, cardiac failure is another common consequence, as the ageing heart must work harder to deliver more blood and nutrients to the hyperactive body cells. The main causes of hyperthyroidism are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Graves' disease</li>
<li>toxic nodular goitre</li>
<li>adenoma (a benign tumour, p. 252).</li>
</ul>
<p>Graves' disease
Sometimes called Graves' thyroiditis, this condition accounts for <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>75</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">75 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">75%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases of hyperthyroidism. It affects more women than men and may occur at any age, being most common
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-5545417d.jpeg" alt="img-325.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 9.17 Enlarged thyroid gland in goitre. (Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-e5a46729.jpeg" alt="img-326.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 9.18 Abnormally bulging eyes in exophthalmos. (Science Photo Library. Reproduced with permission.)
between the ages of 30 and 50 years. It is an autoimmune disorder in which an antibody that mimics the effects of TSH is produced, causing:</p>
<ul>
<li>increased release of T 3 and T 4 and signs of hyperthyroidism (see Table 9.3)</li>
<li>goitre (visible enlargement of the gland. Fig. 9.17) as the antibody stimulates thyroid growth</li>
<li>exophthalmos in many cases.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="exophthalmos">Exophthalmos<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#exophthalmos" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is protrusion of the eyeballs that gives the appearance of staring; it is due to the deposition of excess fat and fibrous tissue behind the eyes (Fig. 9.18), and is often present in Graves' disease. Effective treatment of hyperthyroidism does not completely reverse exophthalmos, although it may lessen after 2-3 years. In severe cases the eyelids become retracted and may not completely cover the eyes during blinking and sleep, leading to drying of the conjunctiva and predisposing to infection. It does not occur in other forms of hyperthyroidism.</p>
<p>Toxic nodular goitre
In this condition, one or two nodules of a gland that is already affected by goitre (see Fig. 9.17) become active and secrete excess T3 and T4, causing the effects of hyperthyroidism (see Table 9.3). It is more common in women than men and after
middle age. As this condition affects an older age group than Graves' disease, arrhythmias and cardiac failure are more common. Exophthalmos does not occur in this condition.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hypothyroidism">Hypothyroidism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypothyroidism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Prevalent in older adults, this condition is five times more common in females than males. Deficiency of T 3 and T 4 in adults results in an abnormally low metabolic rate and other effects shown in Table 9.3. There may be accumulation of mucopolysaccharides in the subcutaneous tissues, causing swelling (non-pitting oedema), especially of the face, hands, feet and eyelids (myxoedema). The most common causes are autoimmune thyroiditis, severe iodine deficiency (see Goitre) and healthcare interventions, e.g. antithyroid drugs, surgical removal of thyroid tissue or ionising radiation.</p>
<p>Autoimmune thyroiditis
The most common cause of acquired hypothyroidism is Hashimoto's disease. It is more common in women than men and, like Graves' disease, is an organ-specific autoimmune condition. Autoantibodies that react with thyroglobulin and thyroid gland cells develop and prevent synthesis and release of thyroid hormones, causing hypothyroidism. Goitre is sometimes present.</p>
<p>Congenital hypothyroidism</p>
<p>This is a profound deficiency or absence of thyroid hormones that becomes evident a few weeks or months after birth. Hypothyroidism is endemic in parts of the world where the diet is severely deficient in iodine and contains insufficient for synthesis of T3 and T4. Absence of thyroid hormones results in profound impairment of growth and cognitive development. Unless treatment begins early in life, cognitive impairment is permanent and the individual typically has disproportionately short limbs, a large, protruding tongue, coarse, dry skin, poor abdominal muscle tone and, often, an umbilical hernia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="simple-goitre">Simple goitre<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#simple-goitre" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is enlargement of the thyroid gland without signs of hyperthyroidism. It is caused by a relative lack of T 3 and T 4 and the low levels stimulate secretion of TSH, resulting in hyperplasia of the thyroid gland (see Fig. 9.17). Sometimes the extra thyroid tissue is able to maintain normal hormone levels, but if not, hypothyroidism develops. Causes are:</p>
<ul>
<li>persistent iodine deficiency - in parts of the world where there is dietary iodine deficiency, this is a common condition known as endemic goitre</li>
<li>genetic abnormality affecting synthesis of T 3 and T 4</li>
<li>iatrogenic factors, e.g. antithyroid drugs, surgical removal of excess thyroid tissue.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-038cb560.jpeg" alt="img-327.jpeg"></li>
</ul>
<p>The enlarged gland may cause pressure damage to adjacent tissues, especially if it lies in an abnormally low position, i.e. behind the sternum. The structures most commonly affected are the oesophagus, causing dysphagia; the trachea, causing dyspnoea; and the recurrent laryngeal nerve, causing hoarseness.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tumours-of-the-thyroid-gland">Tumours of the thyroid gland<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tumours-of-the-thyroid-gland" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Malignant tumours are rare.
Benign tumours</p>
<p>Single adenomas are fairly common and may become cystic. Sometimes the adenoma secretes hormones and hyperthyroidism may develop. The tumours may become malignant, especially in older adults.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i-spot-check">I # SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="11">
<li>The symptoms of thyrotoxicosis are due to excessive blood levels of T 3 and T 4 . List six of them.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disorders-of-the-parathyroid-glands">Disorders of the parathyroid glands<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-parathyroid-glands" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>explain how the diseases described here are related to abnormal secretion of parathyroid hormone.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hyperparathyroidism">Hyperparathyroidism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hyperparathyroidism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This condition is characterised by high blood calcium levels (hypercalcaemia) and is usually caused by a benign parathyroid tumour, which secretes high levels of parathormone (PTH). This results in release of calcium from bones, raising blood calcium levels. The effects may include:</p>
<ul>
<li>polyuria and polydipsia</li>
<li>formation of renal calculi</li>
<li>anorexia and constipation</li>
<li>muscle weakness</li>
<li>general fatigue.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hypoparathyroidism">Hypoparathyroidism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypoparathyroidism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>PTH deficiency causes hypocalcaemia, i.e. abnormally low blood calcium levels, and is much rarer than hyperparathyroidism. There is less reabsorption of calcium from bone and glomerular filtrate. Low blood calcium causes:</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-993bdae4.jpeg" alt="img-328.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 9.19 Characteristic positions adopted during tetanic spasms.</p>
<ul>
<li>tetany (Fig. 9.19)</li>
<li>anxiety</li>
<li>paraesthesia</li>
<li>grand mal seizures</li>
<li>in some cases, cataracts (opacity of the lens, see Fig. 8.26) and brittle nails.</li>
</ul>
<p>Causes of hypoparathyroidism include damage to or removal of the glands during thyroidectomy, ionising radiation, development of autoantibodies to PTH and parathyroid cells, and congenital abnormalities.</p>
<p>Tetany
This is caused by hypocalcaemia because low blood calcium levels increase excitability of peripheral nerves. There are very strong painful spasms of skeletal muscles, causing characteristic inward bending of the hands, forearms and feet (see Fig. 9.19). In children there may also be laryngeal spasm and seizures.</p>
<p>Hypocalcaemia
In addition to hyperthyroidism, this may be due to:</p>
<ul>
<li>chronic kidney disease, as the failing kidney is unable to retain calcium and excretes large quantities in the urine; this is the commonest cause of hypocalcaemia</li>
<li>deficiency of vitamin D or dietary deficiency of calcium</li>
<li>alkalosis - metabolic or respiratory</li>
<li>acute pancreatitis.</li>
<li>SPOT CHECK</li>
</ul>
<ol start="12">
<li>What is the most common cause of hyperparathyroidism?</li>
</ol>
<p>Learning outcome</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="disorders-of-the-adrenal-cortex">Disorders of the adrenal cortex<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-adrenal-cortex" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>relate the features of Cushing's syndrome to the physiological actions of adrenocorticoids</li>
<li>relate the features of Addison's disease to the physiological actions of adrenocorticoids.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hypersecretion-of-glucocorticoids-cushing-s-syndrome">Hypersecretion of glucocorticoids (Cushing's syndrome)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypersecretion-of-glucocorticoids-cushing-s-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cortisol is the main glucocorticoid hormone secreted by the adrenal cortex. Causes of hypersecretion include:</p>
<ul>
<li>most commonly, hypersecretion of adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH) by the anterior pituitary</li>
<li>prolonged systemic treatment with ACTH or glucocorticoids</li>
<li>abnormal secretion of ACTH by a non-pituitary tumour, e.g. bronchial or pancreatic tumour</li>
<li>hormone-secreting adrenal tumours.</li>
</ul>
<p>Hypersecretion of cortisol exaggerates its physiological
effects (Fig. 9.20). These include:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>adiposity of the face ('moon face'), neck and abdomen</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>excessive tissue protein breakdown, causing thinning of subcutaneous tissue and muscle wasting, especially of the limbs</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>diminished protein synthesis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>suppression of GH secretion, preventing normal growth in children</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>osteoporosis (p. 468), and kyphosis if vertebral bodies are involved</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>pathological fractures caused by calcium loss from bones</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>excessive gluconeogenesis, resulting in hyperglycaemia and glycosuria, which can precipitate diabetes mellitus (p.255)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-99a30908.jpeg" alt="img-329.jpeg"></p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Hypertension
Vertebral collapse Central obesity
Striae (stretch marks)
Muscle weakness and wasting
Figure 9.20 The systemic features of Cushing's syndrome.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>atrophy of lymphoid tissue and depression of immune responses</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>susceptibility to infection due to reduced febrile response and depressed immune and inflammatory responses</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>impaired collagen production, leading to capillary fragility, cataract and striae (stretch marks)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>insomnia, excitability, euphoria, depression or psychosis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>hypertension due to salt and water retention</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>menstrual disturbances</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>formation of renal calculi</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>peptic ulceration.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hyposecretion-of-glucocorticoids">Hyposecretion of glucocorticoids<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hyposecretion-of-glucocorticoids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Inadequate cortisol secretion causes diminished gluconeogenesis, low blood glucose levels, muscle weakness and pallor. This may be primary, i.e. due to disease of the adrenal cortex, or secondary, due to deficiency of ACTH from the anterior pituitary. In primary deficiency there is also hyposecretion of aldosterone (see later), but in secondary deficiency aldosterone secretion is not usually affected because aldosterone release is controlled by the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (p. 245).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hypersecretion-of-mineralocorticoids">Hypersecretion of mineralocorticoids<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypersecretion-of-mineralocorticoids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Excess aldosterone affects kidney function, with consequences elsewhere:</p>
<ul>
<li>excessive reabsorption of sodium chloride and water, causing increased blood volume and hypertension</li>
<li>excessive excretion of potassium, causing hypokalaemia, which leads to cardiac arrhythmias, alkalosis, syncope and muscle weakness.</li>
</ul>
<p>Primary hyperaldosteronism
This is due to excessive secretion of mineralocorticoids, independent of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. It is usually caused by a tumour affecting only one adrenal gland.</p>
<p>Secondary hyperaldosteronism
This is caused by over-stimulation of normal glands by the excessively high blood levels of renin and angiotensin that result from low renal perfusion or low blood sodium.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hyposecretion-of-mineralocorticoids">Hyposecretion of mineralocorticoids<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hyposecretion-of-mineralocorticoids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Hypoaldosteronism results in failure of the kidneys to regulate sodium, potassium and water excretion, leading to:</p>
<ul>
<li>blood sodium deficiency (hyponatraemia) and potassium excess (hyperkalaemia)</li>
<li>dehydration, low blood volume and low blood pressure.</li>
</ul>
<p>There is usually hyposecretion of other adrenal cortical hormones, as in Addison's disease.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chronic-adrenocortical-insufficiency-addison-s-disease">Chronic adrenocortical insufficiency (Addison's disease)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chronic-adrenocortical-insufficiency-addison-s-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is due to destruction of the adrenal cortex, which results in hyposecretion of glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid hormones. The most common causes are development of autoantibodies to cortical cells, metastases (secondary tumours) and infections. Autoimmune disease of other glands can be associated with Addison's disease, e.g. diabetes mellitus, thyrotoxicosis and hypoparathyroidism. The most important effects are:</p>
<ul>
<li>muscle weakness and wasting</li>
<li>gastrointestinal disturbances, e.g. vomiting, diarrhoea, anorexia</li>
<li>increased skin pigmentation, especially of exposed areas</li>
<li>listlessness and tiredness</li>
<li>hypoglycaemia</li>
<li>confusion</li>
<li>menstrual disturbances and loss of body hair in women</li>
<li>electrolyte imbalance, including hyponatraemia, low blood chloride levels and hyperkalaemia</li>
<li>chronic dehydration, low blood volume and hypotension.</li>
</ul>
<p>The adrenal glands have a considerable tissue reserve and Addison's disease is not usually severely debilitating unless more than <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">90%</span></span></span></span></span> of cortical tissue is destroyed, but this condition is fatal without treatment.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="acute-adrenocortical-insufficiency-addisonian-crisis">Acute adrenocortical insufficiency (Addisonian crisis)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-adrenocortical-insufficiency-addisonian-crisis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is characterised by sudden severe nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, hypotension, electrolyte imbalance (hyponatraemia and hyperkalaemia) and, in severe cases, circulatory collapse. It is precipitated when an individual with chronic adrenocortical insufficiency is subjected to stress, e.g. an acute infection.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="8fd23025">■・SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8fd23025" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="13">
<li>List the main features of Cushing's syndrome.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="disorders-of-the-adrenal-medulla">Disorders of the adrenal medulla<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-adrenal-medulla" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcome
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>explain how the features of the diseases described here are related to excessive secretion of adrenaline (epinephrine) and noradrenaline (norepinephrine).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tumours">Tumours<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diabetes-mellitus">Diabetes mellitus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diabetes-mellitus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Most tumours of the adrenal medulla secrete increased quantities of hormones, and so the predominant symptoms are consequences of hypersecretion of adrenaline (epinephrine) and noradrenaline (norepinephrine). These include:</p>
<ul>
<li>hypertension</li>
<li>weight loss</li>
<li>nervousness and anxiety</li>
<li>headache</li>
<li>excessive sweating and alternate flushing and blanching of the skin</li>
<li>hyperglycaemia and glycosuria</li>
<li>constipation.</li>
</ul>
<p>Phaeochromocytoma
This is usually a benign tumour, occurring in one or both glands. Hormone secretion may be constantly elevated or occur in intermittent bursts, often precipitated by raised intra-abdominal pressure, e.g. coughing or defaecation.</p>
<p>Neuroblastoma
This is a rare and malignant tumour, occurring in infants and children. Tumours that develop early tend to be highly malignant but there may be spontaneous regression.</p>
<ul>
<li>SPOT CHECK</li>
</ul>
<ol start="14">
<li>Explain why tumours of the adrenal medulla cause symptoms including hypertension, weight loss, anxiety, nervousness and excessive sweating.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="disorders-of-the-pancreatic-islets">Disorders of the pancreatic islets<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-pancreatic-islets" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>compare and contrast the onset and features of types 1 and 2 diabetes mellitus</li>
<li>relate the signs and symptoms of diabetes mellitus to deficiency of insulin</li>
<li>explain how the causes and effects of the following conditions occur: diabetic ketoacidosis and hypoglycaemic coma</li>
<li>describe the long-term complications of diabetes mellitus.</li>
</ul>
<p>Diabetes mellitus (DM) is the most common endocrine disorder. The primary sign is hyperglycaemia, which is accompanied by varying degrees of disruption of carbohydrate and fat metabolism. DM is caused by complete absence of, relative deficiency of or resistance to the hormone insulin. Box 9.2 shows the classification of diabetes. Primary DM is categorised as type 1 or type 2. In secondary DM, the disorder arises as a result of other conditions, and gestational diabetes develops in pregnancy. The worldwide increase in DM over the past few decades has been described as an epidemic. The global prevalence in adults over 18 years has risen from <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>4.7</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">4.7 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">4.7%</span></span></span></span></span> in 1980 to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>8.5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">8.5 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">8.5%</span></span></span></span></span> in 2014 , representing an increase in those affected from 108 million to 422 million over the same period (WHO, 2016). Genetic predisposition and environmental factors, including viral infections, are implicated in both types. Table 9.5 shows some distinguishing features of types 1 and 2 DM.</p>
<p>Box 9.2 Classification of diabetes mellitus
Primary
Type 1 diabetes mellitus Type 2 diabetes mellitus
Secondary
Due to other situations, e.g.:
Acute or chronic pancreatitis (p. 361)
Drug therapy, e.g. corticosteroids
Other endocrine disorders involving hormones that increase plasma glucose levels, e.g. growth hormone, thyroid hormones, cortisol (Cushing's syndrome, p. 253)</p>
<p>Gestational diabetes</p>
<p>Develops during pregnancy and may disappear after delivery, but often recurs in later life</p>
<p>Associated with birth of heavier than normal and stillborn babies, and deaths shortly after birth</p>

<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-52d2d91a.jpeg" alt="img-330.jpeg"></p>
<p>Type 1 diabetes mellitus
Previously known as insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (IDDM), this occurs mainly in children and young adults; the onset is usually sudden and can be lifethreatening. There is severe deficiency or absence of insulin secretion due to destruction of P -islet cells of the pancreas by autoantibodies. Treatment with insulin is required.</p>
<p>Type 2 diabetes mellitus
Previously known as non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM), this is the most common form of diabetes, accounting for about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">90%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases. The causes are multifactorial and predisposing factors include:</p>
<ul>
<li>obesity</li>
<li>sedentary lifestyle</li>
<li>increasing age, predominantly affecting middle-aged and older adults</li>
<li>genetic factors.</li>
</ul>
<p>Its onset is gradual, often over many years, and it frequently goes undetected until signs are found on routine investigation or a complication occurs. Insulin secretion may be below or above normal. Body cells are unable to extract glucose from the extracellular fluid, and there are two main reasons for this. First, inadequate insulin levels means that activation of the insulin-mediated glucose transport mechanisms in the plasma membrane is deficient. Secondly, insulin receptors on the cell surface may become dysfunctional (insulin resistance), so even in the presence of normal or elevated blood glucose and insulin levels, the cells cannot extract the insulin they require. Treatment involves diet and/or drugs, although sometimes insulin injections are required.</p>
<p>Pathophysiology of diabetes mellitus
Raised plasma glucose level (hyperglycaemia)
After a carbohydrate-rich meal is eaten, the plasma glucose level remains high because:</p>
<ul>
<li>cells are unable to take up and use glucose from the bloodstream, despite high plasma glucose levels</li>
<li>conversion of glucose to glycogen in the liver and muscles is diminished</li>
<li>there is gluconeogenesis from protein, in response to deficiency of intracellular glucose.</li>
</ul>
<p>Hyperglycaemia causes long-term damage to blood vessels and nerves (see later).
Glycosuria and polyuria
The concentration of glucose in the glomerular filtrate is the same as in the blood and, although DM raises the renal
threshold for glucose, it is not all reabsorbed by the tubules. The glucose remaining in the filtrate raises its osmotic pressure, water reabsorption is reduced and the volume of urine is increased (polyuria). This results in electrolyte imbalance and excretion of urine of high specific gravity. Polyuria leads to dehydration, extreme thirst (polydipsia) and increased fluid intake.</p>
<p>Weight loss
The cells are essentially starved of glucose because, in the absence of insulin, they are unable to extract it from the bloodstream, leading to derangement of energy metabolism as cells must use alternative pathways to produce the energy they need. This results in weight loss, especially in type 1 DM , due to:</p>
<ul>
<li>gluconeogenesis from amino acids and body protein, causing muscle wasting, tissue breakdown and further increases in blood glucose</li>
<li>catabolism of body fat, releasing some of its energy and excess production of ketone bodies.</li>
</ul>
<p>This is not uncommon in type 1 DM but is rare in type 2 DM.
Ketosis and ketoacidosis
This nearly always affects people with type 1 DM.</p>
<p>In the absence of insulin to promote normal intracellular glucose metabolism, alternative energy sources must be used instead and increased breakdown of fat occurs (see Fig. 12.43). Ketones, including acetone and butyrate, are released as by-products. The liver has a limited capacity to metabolise these ketones, and normal buffering systems maintain pH balance so long as the levels of ketone bodies are not excessive. Ketosis (p. 346) develops as ketone bodies accumulate. Excretion of ketones is via the urine (ketonuria) and/ or the lungs, giving the breath a characteristic smell of acetone or 'pear drops'.</p>
<p>Ketoacidosis is a medical emergency, indicating severely deranged cell metabolism secondary to insulin deficiency. It may be due to stressors such as pregnancy, infection or acute illness, or missed or inadequate doses of insulin, especially when requirements are increased. Severe and dangerous ketoacidosis may occur without loss of consciousness. When worsening ketosis swamps the compensatory buffer systems, control of acid-base balance is lost; the blood pH falls and ketoacidosis occurs. If this is untreated, the consequences are:</p>
<ul>
<li>increasing acidosis (abnormally low blood pH ) due to accumulation of keto acids</li>
<li>increasing hyperglycaemia</li>
<li>hyperventilation as the lungs excrete excess hydrogen ions as CO 2 in an attempt to correct the acidosis</li>
<li>acidification of urine - the result of kidney buffering</li>
<li>polyuria as the renal threshold for glucose is exceeded</li>
<li>dehydration and hypovolaemia (characterised by hypotension and tachycardia) caused by polyuria</li>
<li>disturbances of electrolyte balance accompanying fluid loss - hyponatraemia (decreased plasma sodium) and hypokalaemia (decreased plasma potassium)</li>
<li>confusion and coma</li>
<li>death.</li>
</ul>
<p>Acute complications of diabetes mellitus</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diabetic-ketoacidosis">Diabetic ketoacidosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diabetic-ketoacidosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The effects and consequences of diabetic ketoacidosis were outlined in the previous section.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hypoglycaemic-coma">Hypoglycaemic coma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypoglycaemic-coma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This occurs when insulin administered is in excess of that needed to balance the food intake and expenditure of energy. Hypoglycaemia is of sudden onset and may be the result of:</p>
<ul>
<li>accidental overdose of insulin</li>
<li>delay in eating after insulin administration</li>
<li>drinking alcohol on an empty stomach</li>
<li>strenuous exercise.</li>
</ul>
<p>It may also arise from an insulin-secreting tumour, especially if it produces irregular bursts of secretion. Because neurones are more dependent on glucose for their energy needs than are other cells, glucose deprivation causes disturbed neurological function, leading to coma and, if prolonged, irreversible damage.</p>
<p>Common signs and symptoms of hypoglycaemia include drowsiness, confusion, speech difficulty, sweating, trembling, anxiety and a rapid pulse. This can progress rapidly to coma without treatment, which usually enables rapid recovery. Most people can readily recognise the symptoms of hypoglycaemia and are able to take appropriate action.</p>
<p>Long-term complications of diabetes mellitus
These increase with the severity and duration of hyperglycaemia and represent significant causes of morbidity (poor health) and mortality (death) in people with both type 1 and type 2 DM.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cardiovascular-disturbances">Cardiovascular disturbances<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cardiovascular-disturbances" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>DM is a significant risk factor for cardiovascular disorders. Blood vessel abnormalities (angiopathies) may still occur even when the disease is well controlled.</p>
<p>Diabetic macroangiopathy
The most common lesions are atheroma and calcification of the tunica media of the large arteries. In type 1 DM these changes may occur at a relatively early age. The most common consequences are serious and often fatal:</p>
<ul>
<li>ischaemic heart disease, i.e. angina and myocardial infarction (p. 125)</li>
<li>stroke (p. 194)</li>
<li>peripheral vascular disease.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diabetic-microangiopathy">Diabetic microangiopathy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diabetic-microangiopathy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This affects small blood vessels and there is thickening of the epithelial basement membrane of arterioles, capillaries and, sometimes, venules. These changes may lead to:</p>
<ul>
<li>peripheral vascular disease, progressing to gangrene and 'diabetic foot' (see later)</li>
<li>diabetic retinopathy and visual impairment (p. 229)</li>
<li>diabetic nephropathy and chronic kidney disease
(p.384)</li>
<li>peripheral neuropathy, causing sensory deficits and motor weakness (p. 201), especially when myelination is affected.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="infection">Infection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#infection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>DM predisposes to infection, especially by bacteria and fungi, possibly because phagocyte activity is depressed by insufficient intracellular glucose. Infection may cause:</p>
<ul>
<li>boils and carbuncles</li>
<li>vaginal candidiasis (thrush, p. 506)</li>
<li>pyelonephritis (p.385)</li>
<li>diabetic foot.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="renal-failure">Renal failure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#renal-failure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Chronic kidney disease is due to diabetic nephropathy (p.386) and is a common cause of death.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="visual-impairment-and-blindness">Visual impairment and blindness<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#visual-impairment-and-blindness" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Diabetic retinopathy (p. 229) is the most common cause of blindness in adults between 30 and 65 years in developed countries. DM also increases the risk of early development of cataracts (p. 229) and other visual disorders.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diabetic-foot">Diabetic foot<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diabetic-foot" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Many factors commonly present in DM contribute to the development of this serious situation. Disease of large and small blood vessels impairs blood supply to</p>
<p>and around the extremities. If peripheral neuropathy is present, sensation is reduced and a small injury to the foot may go unnoticed, especially when there is visual impairment. In DM, healing is slower and injuries easily worsen if aggravated, e.g. by</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter">CHAPTER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The first part of this chapter describes the structure and functions of the respiratory system. Later sections consider the effects of ageing on respiratory function and discuss some important respiratory disorders.</p>
<p>The cells of the body need energy for all their metabolic activities. Most of this energy is derived from chemical reactions, which can take place only in the presence of oxygen (O 2 ). The main waste product of these reactions is carbon dioxide ( CO 2 ). The respiratory system provides the route by which atmospheric oxygen enters the body, and the route for carbon dioxide excretion.</p>
<p>The condition of the atmospheric air entering the body varies considerably according to the external environment, e.g. it may be dry or moist, warm or cold, and carry varying quantities of pollutants, dust or dirt. As inhaled air moves through the air passages to reach the lungs, it is warmed or cooled to body temperature, saturated with water vapour and 'cleaned' as particles of dust stick to the mucus that coats the lining membrane. Blood provides the transport system for O 2 and CO 2 between the lungs and the cells of the body. Exchange of gases between the blood and the lungs is called external respiration and that between the blood and the cells internal respiration.</p>
<p>Fig. 10.1 shows the organs of the respiratory system and associated structures. Q <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10.1</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>10.2</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10.1,10.2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">10.1</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">10.2</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>Nose and nasal cavity</p>
<p>Learning outcomes</p>
<p>After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the location of the nasal cavities</li>
<li>relate the structure of the nasal cavities to their function in respiration</li>
<li>outline the physiology of smell.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="position-and-structure">Position and structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#position-and-structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The nostrils (nares) are the openings into the nose and are the main route of air entry into the respiratory system. Behind each nostril lies a large cavity, the walls of which are formed by several bones of the face. The right and left nasal cavities are separated by the nasal septum (Fig. 10.2), a perpendicular sheet of bone and cartilage, formed from the vomer and ethmoid bones and also the cartilage forming the anterior part of the nose.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-51d1f971.jpeg" alt="img-333.jpeg"></p>
