<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bones-forming-the-nasal-cavity">Bones forming the nasal cavity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bones-forming-the-nasal-cavity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The roof is formed by the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone and the sphenoid bone, frontal bone and nasal bones.</p>
<p>The floor is formed by the roof of the mouth and consists of the hard palate in front and the soft palate behind. The hard palate is composed of the maxilla and palatine bones, and the soft palate consists of involuntary muscle.</p>
<p>The medial wall is formed by the septum.
The lateral walls are formed by the maxilla, the ethmoid bone and the inferior conchae (Fig. 10.3).</p>
<p>The posterior wall is formed by the posterior wall of the pharynx.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="9ddbeefa">Lining of the nasal cavity <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">□</mi><mn>10.3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square 10.3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">□</span><span class="mord">10.3</span></span></span></span></span><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#9ddbeefa" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The nasal cavity is lined with very vascular ciliated columnar epithelium (ciliated mucous membrane, see Fig. 10.12; respiratory mucosa), which contains mucussecreting goblet cells. At the anterior nares this blends with the skin and posteriorly it extends into the nasal part of the pharynx (the nasopharynx). Anteriorly, the</p>
<p>epithelium has coarse hairs, covered in sticky mucus, that filter air passing towards the back of the nose.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="openings-into-the-nasal-cavity">Openings into the nasal cavity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#openings-into-the-nasal-cavity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The anterior nares, or nostrils, are the openings from the exterior into the nasal cavity. The posterior nares are the openings from the nasal cavity into the pharynx.</p>
<p>The paranasal sinuses are four groups of tiny cavities in the bones of the face and the cranium, containing air. They open into the nasal cavity and are lined with mucous membrane, continuous with that of the nasal cavity. The main sinuses are:</p>
<ul>
<li>maxillary sinuses in the lateral walls</li>
<li>frontal and sphenoidal sinuses in the roof (Fig. 10.3)</li>
<li>ethmoidal sinuses in the upper part of the lateral walls.</li>
</ul>
<p>The sinuses are involved in speech (p. 267) and also lighten the skull. The nasolacrimal ducts extend from the lateral walls of the nose to the conjunctival sacs of the eye (p. 222). They drain tears from the eyes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Respiratory function of the nose
The nose is the first of the respiratory passages through which the inspired air passes. In the nasal cavity, air is warmed, moistened and filtered. The three projecting conchae (Figs 10.3 and 10.4) increase the surface area and cause turbulence, spreading inspired air over the whole nasal surface. The large surface area maximises warming, humidification and filtering.</p>
<p>Warming
The immense vascularity of the mucosa permits rapid warming as the air flows past. This also explains the large blood loss when a nosebleed (epistaxis) occurs.</p>
<p>Filtering and cieaning
Hairs at the anterior nares trap larger particles. Smaller particles such as dust and bacteria settle and adhere to the mucus. Mucus protects the underlying epithelium from irritation and prevents drying. Synchronous beating of</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-3aac5bac.jpeg" alt="img-336.jpeg"></p>

the cilia wafts the mucus towards the throat, where it is swallowed or coughed up.
Humidification
As air travels over the moist mucosa, it becomes saturated with water vapour. Irritation of the nasal mucosa results in sneezing, a reflex action that forcibly expels an irritant.</p>
<p>The sense of smell
The nose is the organ of the sense of smell (olfaction). Specialised receptors that detect smell, the olfactory epithelium, are located in the roof of the nose in the area of the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bones and the superior conchae (see Figs 10.4 and 8.24 A ). These receptors are stimulated by airborne odours. The resultant nerve signals are carried by the olfactory nerves to the brain, where the sensation of smell is perceived (p. 223).</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pharynx">Pharynx<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pharynx" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the location of the pharynx</li>
<li>relate the structure of the pharynx to its function.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="position">Position<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#position" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The pharynx (throat) is a passageway about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>12</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>14</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">12-14 \mathrm{~cm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">12</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">14</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">cm</span></span></span></span></span></span> long. It extends from the posterior nares and runs behind the mouth and the larynx to the level of the 6th cervical vertebra, where it becomes the oesophagus.</p>
<p>Structures associated with the pharynx
Superiorly - the inferior surface of the base of the skull. Inferiorly - it is continuous with the oesophagus.</p>
<p>Anteriorly - the wall is incomplete because of the openings into the nose, mouth and larynx.</p>
<p>Posteriorly - areolar tissue, involuntary muscle and the bodies of the first six cervical vertebrae.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>For descriptive purposes the pharynx is divided into three parts: nasopharynx, oropharynx and laryngopharynx.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nasopharynx">Nasopharynx<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nasopharynx" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The nasal part of the pharynx lies behind the nose above the level of the soft palate. On its lateral walls are the two openings of the auditory tubes (see Fig. 8.1), one leading to each middle ear. On the posterior wall are the pharyngeal tonsils (adenoids; see Fig. 6.7). They are most prominent in children up to approximately 7 years of age. Thereafter they gradually atrophy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="oropharynx">Oropharynx<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#oropharynx" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The oral part of the pharynx lies behind the mouth, extending from below the level of the soft palate to the level of the upper part of the body of the 3rd cervical vertebra. The lateral walls of the pharynx blend with the soft palate to form two folds on each side. Between each pair of folds is a collection of lymphoid tissue called the palatine tonsil (see Fig. 6.7).</p>
<p>During swallowing, the soft palate and uvula are pushed upwards, sealing off the nasal cavity and preventing the entry of food and fluids.</p>
<p>The laryngeal part of the pharynx extends from the oropharynx above and continues as the oesophagus below, with the larynx lying anteriorly.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="structure">Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The walls of the pharynx contain several types of tissue.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mucous-membrane-lining">Mucous membrane lining<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mucous-membrane-lining" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The mucosa varies slightly in the different regions. In the nasopharynx it is continuous with the lining of the nose and consists of ciliated columnar epithelium; in the oropharynx and laryngopharynx it is formed by tougher stratified squamous epithelium, which is continuous with the lining of the mouth and oesophagus. This lining protects underlying tissues from the abrasive action of foodstuffs passing through during swallowing. This is important because of the dual function of the pharynx as a passageway in both the respiratory and the digestive tracts.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="submucosa">Submucosa<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#submucosa" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The layer of tissue below the epithelium (the submucosa) is rich in mucosaassociated lymphoid tissue (MALT, p. 147), involved in protection against infection. Tonsils are masses of MALT that bulge through the epithelium. Some glandular tissue is also found here.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="smooth-muscle">Smooth muscle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#smooth-muscle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The pharyngeal muscles help to keep the pharynx permanently open so that breathing is not obstructed. Sometimes in sleep, and particularly if sedative drugs or alcohol have been taken, the tone of these muscles is reduced and the opening through the pharynx can become partially or totally blocked. This contributes to snoring and periodic wakenings, which disturb sleep.</p>
<p>Constrictor muscles close the pharynx during swallowing, pushing food and fluid into the oesophagus.</p>
<p>Blood and nerve supply
Blood is supplied to the pharynx by several branches of the facial artery. The venous return is into the facial and internal jugular veins.</p>
<p>The nerve supply is from the pharyngeal plexus, and includes both parasympathetic and sympathetic nerves. Parasympathetic supply is by the vagus and glossopharyngeal nerves. Sympathetic supply is by nerves from the superior cervical ganglia (see Fig. 7.44).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Passageway for air and food
The pharynx is involved in both the respiratory and the digestive systems: air passes through the nasal and oral sections, and food through the oral and laryngeal sections.</p>
<p>Warming and humidifying
By the same methods as in the nose, the air is further warmed and moistened as it passes towards the lungs.</p>
<p>Hearing
The auditory tube, extending from the nasopharynx to each middle ear, allows air to enter the middle ear. This leads to air in the middle ear being at the same pressure as the outer ear, protecting the tympanic membrane (eardrum, see Fig. 8.1) from any changes in atmospheric pressure.</p>
<p>Protection
The lymphatic tissue of the pharyngeal and laryngeal tonsils produces antibodies in response to swallowed or inhaled antigens (Ch. 15). The tonsils are larger in children and tend to atrophy in adults.</p>
<p>Speech
The pharynx functions in speech; by acting as a resonating chamber for sound ascending from the larynx, it helps (together with the sinuses) to give the voice its individual characteristics.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="10-spot-check">10 SPOT CHECK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#10-spot-check" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="3">
<li>Identify the locations of the main tonsils.</li>
<li>Which cavities are linked by the auditory tube?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="larynx">Larynx<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#larynx" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the structure and function of the larynx</li>
<li>outline the physiology of speech generation.</li>
</ul>
<p>The larynx, or Voice box', links the laryngopharynx and the trachea (see Figs 10.1 and 10.4). It lies in front of the laryngopharynx and the 3rd, 4th, 5th and 6th cervical vertebrae. Until puberty there is little difference in the size of the larynx between the sexes. Thereafter, it grows larger in the male, which explains the prominence of the 'Adam's apple' and the generally deeper voice.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-c63f0f73.jpeg" alt="img-337.jpeg"></p>
<p>Structures associated with the larynx
Superiorly - the hyoid bone and the root of the tongue. Inferiorly - it is continuous with the trachea.</p>
<p>Anteriorly - the muscles attached to the hyoid bone and the muscles of the neck.
Posteriorly - the laryngopharynx and 3rd-6th cervical vertebrae.
Laterally - the lobes of the thyroid gland.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="structure">Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cartilages">Cartilages<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cartilages" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The larynx is composed of nine irregularly shaped cartilages attached to each other by ligaments and membranes. The main cartilages are:</p>
<ul>
<li>1 thyroid cartilage</li>
<li>1 cricoid cartilage</li>
<li>2 arytenoid cartilages</li>
<li>1 epiglottis
hyaline cartilage elastic fibrocartilage</li>
</ul>
<p>Several ligaments attach the cartilages to each other and to the hyoid bone (Figs 10.5 and 10.6; see also Fig. 10.8).</p>
<p>Thyroid cartilage
The thyroid cartilage (Figs 10.5 and 10.6) is the most prominent of the laryngeal cartilages. Made of hyaline cartilage, it lies to the front of the neck. Its anterior wall projects into the soft tissues of the front of the throat, forming the laryngeal prominence or Adam's apple, which is easily felt and often visible in adult males. The anterior wall is partially divided by the thyroid notch. The cartilage is incomplete posteriorly, and is bound with ligaments to the hyoid bone above and the cricoid cartilage below.</p>
<p>Figure 10.5 Larynx. View from the side.
The upper part of the thyroid cartilage is lined with stratified squamous epithelium like the larynx, and the lower part with ciliated columnar epithelium like the trachea. There are many muscles attached to its outer surface.</p>
<p>The thyroid cartilage forms most of the anterior and lateral walls of the larynx.
Cricoid cartiiage
The cricoid cartilage (Fig. 10.7) lies below the thyroid cartilage and is also composed of hyaline cartilage. It is shaped like a signet ring, completely encircling the larynx with the narrow part anteriorly and the broad part posteriorly. The broad posterior part articulates with the arytenoid cartilages and with the thyroid cartilage. It is lined with ciliated columnar epithelium and there are muscles and ligaments attached to its outer surface (Fig. 10.7). The lower border of the cricoid cartilage marks the end of the upper respiratory tract.</p>
<p>Arytenoid cartilages
These are two roughly pyramid-shaped hyaline cartilages situated on top of the broad part of the cricoid cartilage, forming part of the posterior wall of the larynx (see Fig. 10.6B). They give attachment to the vocal cords and to muscles, and are lined with ciliated columnar epithelium.</p>
<p>Epiglottis
The epiglottis (Fig. 10.8; see also Figs 10.4 and 10.6) is a leaf-shaped fibroelastic cartilage attached by a flexible stalk of cartilage to the inner surface of the anterior wall of the thyroid cartilage, immediately below the thyroid notch. It rises obliquely upwards behind the tongue and the body of the hyoid bone. It is covered with stratified squamous epithelium. If the larynx is likened to a box, then the epiglottis acts as the lid; it closes off the larynx during</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-8e3e32c2.jpeg" alt="img-338.jpeg"></p>

Blood and nerve supply
Blood is supplied to the larynx by the superior and inferior laryngeal arteries and drained by the thyroid veins, which join the internal jugular vein.</p>
<p>The parasympathetic nerve supply is from the superior laryngeal and recurrent laryngeal nerves, which are branches of the vagus nerves. The sympathetic nerves are from the superior cervical ganglia, one on each side. These provide the motor nerve supply to the muscles of the larynx and sensory fibres to the lining membrane.</p>
<p>Interior of the larynx
The vocal cords (Fig. 10.8) are two pale folds of mucous membrane with cord-like free edges, stretched across the laryngeal opening. They extend from the inner wall of the
thyroid prominence anteriorly to the arytenoid cartilages posteriorly.
When the muscles controlling the vocal cords are relaxed, the vocal cords open and the passageway for air coming up through the larynx is clear; the vocal cords are said to be abducted (open. Fig. 10.9 A). Vibrating the vocal cords in this position produces low-pitched sounds. When the muscles controlling the vocal cords contract, the vocal cords are stretched out tightly across the larynx (Fig. 10.9B) and are said to be adducted (closed). When the vocal cords are stretched to this extent</p>
<p>and are vibrated by air passing through from the lungs, the sound produced is highpitched. The pitch of the voice is therefore determined by the tension applied to the vocal cords by the appropriate sets of muscles. When not in use, the vocal cords are adducted. The space between the vocal cords is called the glottis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Production of sound
Sound has the properties of pitch, volume and resonance.</p>
<ul>
<li>Pitch of the voice depends on the length and tightness of the cords. The tightness of the cords is controlled by the muscles to which they attach. Shorter cords produce higher-pitched sounds. At puberty the male vocal cords begin to grow longer; hence the lower pitch of the adult male voice.</li>
<li>Volume of the voice depends on the force with which the cords vibrate. The greater the force of expired air, the more strongly the cords vibrate and the louder the sound emitted.</li>
<li>Resonance, or tone, is dependent on the shape of the mouth, the position of the tongue and the lips, the facial muscles and the air in the paranasal sinuses.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-39040ae1.jpeg" alt="img-340.jpeg"></li>
</ul>
<p>Vestibular

<ol start="5">
<li>Name the main cartilages of the larynx and state which ones are paired.</li>
<li>How are the pitch and volume of speech controlled?</li>

<p>Speech
This is produced when the sounds produced by the vocal cords are amplified and manipulated by the tongue, cheeks and lips.</p>
<p>Protection of the lower respiratory tract
During swallowing (p. 323) the larynx moves upwards, blocking the opening into it from the pharynx. In addition, the hinged epiglottis closes over the larynx. This ensures that food passes into the oesophagus and not into the trachea.</p>
<p>Passageway for air
The larynx links the pharynx above with the trachea below.
Humidifying, filtering and warming
These processes continue as inspired air travels through the larynx.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="trachea">Trachea<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#trachea" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>describe the location of the trachea</li>
<li>outline the structure of the trachea</li>
<li>explain the functions of the trachea in respiration.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="position">Position<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#position" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The trachea, or windpipe, is a continuation of the larynx and extends downwards to about the level of the 5th thoracic vertebra, where it divides at the carina into the right and left primary bronchi. The carina is rich in sensory nerve</p>

The trachea is approximately <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>11</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10-11 \mathrm{~cm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">11</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">cm</span></span></span></span></span></span> long and lies mainly in the median plane in front of the oesophagus (Fig. 10.10).</p>

of hyaline cartilage lying one above the other. The rings are incomplete posteriorly, where the trachea lies against the oesophagus (Fig. 10.11). The cartilages are embedded in a sleeve of smooth muscle and connective tissue, which also forms the posterior wall, where the rings are incomplete. Three layers of tissue 'clothe' the cartilages of the trachea.</p>
<ul>
<li>The outer layer contains fibrous and elastic tissue and encloses the cartilages.</li>
<li>The middle layer consists of cartilages and bands of smooth muscle that wind round the trachea in a helical arrangement. There is some areolar tissue, containing blood and lymph vessels and autonomic nerves. The free ends of the incomplete cartilages are connected by the trachealis muscle, which allows for limited adjustment of tracheal diameter.</li>
<li>The lining is ciliated columnar epithelium, containing mucus-secreting goblet cells (Fig. 10.12A).</li>
</ul>
<p>Blood and nerve supply, lymph drainage
Arterial blood supply is mainly by the inferior thyroid and bronchial arteries, and venous return is by the inferior thyroid veins into the brachiocephalic veins.</p>
<p>Parasympathetic nerve supply is by the recurrent laryngeal nerves and other branches of the vagus nerves. Sympathetic supply is by nerves from the sympathetic ganglia. Parasympathetic stimulation constricts the trachea, and sympathetic stimulation dilates it.</p>
<p>Lymph from the respiratory passages drains through lymph nodes situated round the trachea and in the carina, the area where it divides into two bronchi.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="structure">Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The tracheal wall is composed of three layers of tissue, and is held open by between 16 and 20 incomplete (C-shaped) rings</p>
<p>Support and patency</p>
<p>Tracheal cartilages hold the trachea permanently open (patent), but the soft tissue bands in between the cartilages allow flexibility so that the head and neck can move freely</p>
<p>Layer of mucus with trapped particles Cilia

<p>Warming, humidifying and filtering
These continue as in the nose, although air is normally saturated and at body temperature when it reaches the trachea.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lungs">Lungs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lungs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Learning outcomes
After studying this section, you should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>name the air passages of the bronchial tree in descending order of size</li>
<li>describe the structure and changing functions of the different levels of airway</li>
<li>describe the location and gross anatomy of the lungs</li>
<li>identify the functions of the pleura</li>
<li>describe the pulmonary blood supply.
without obstructing or kinking the trachea. The absence of cartilage posteriorly permits the oesophagus to expand comfortably during swallowing. Contraction or relaxation of the trachealis muscle, which links the free ends of the C -shaped cartilages, helps to regulate the diameter of the trachea.</li>
</ul>
<p>Mucociliary escalator
This is the synchronous and regular beating of the cilia of the mucous membrane lining that wafts mucus with adherent particles upwards towards the larynx, where it is either swallowed or coughed up (Fig. 10.12B).</p>
<p>Cough reflex
Nerve endings in the larynx, trachea and bronchi are sensitive to irritation, which generates nerve impulses conducted by the vagus nerves to the respiratory centre in the brain stem (p. 171). The reflex motor response is deep inspiration followed by closure of the glottis, i.e. closure of the vocal cords. The abdominal and respiratory muscles then</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="position-and-gross-structure">Position and gross structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#position-and-gross-structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There are two cone-shaped lungs, one lying on each side of the midline in the thoracic cavity (Figs 10.13 and 10.14). Each has an apex, a base, a costal surface and a medial surface.</p>
<p>Apex
This is rounded and rises into the root of the neck, about 25 mm above the level of the middle third of the clavicle. It lies close to the first rib and the blood vessels and nerves in the root of the neck (see Fig. 10.13 A).</p>
<p>Base
This is concave and semilunar in shape, and lies on the upper (thoracic) surface of the diaphragm.</p>
<p>Costal surface
This is the broad outer surface of the lung that lies directly against the costal cartilages, the ribs and the intercostal muscles.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<p>Medial surface
The medial surface of each lung faces the other directly across the space between the lungs, the mediastinum. Each is concave and has a roughly triangular-shaped area, called the hilum, at the level of the 5th, 6th and 7th thoracic vertebrae. The primary bronchus, the pulmonary artery supplying the lung and the two pulmonary veins draining it, the bronchial
artery and veins, and the lymphatic and nerve supply enter and leave the lung at the hilum (Fig. 10.14).</p>
<p>The mediastinum contains the heart, great vessels, trachea, right and left bronchi, oesophagus, lymph nodes, lymph vessels and nerves (see Fig. 10.13C).</p>
<p>The right lung is divided into three distinct lobes: superior, middle and inferior (see Fig. 10.13B). The left
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">□</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">□</span></span></span></span></span>
lung is smaller because the heart occupies space left of the midline. It is divided into only two lobes: superior and inferior. The divisions between the lobes are called fissures.</p>
<p>Pleura and pleural cavity</p>
<p>Visceral pleura</p>
<p>This adheres to the lung, covering each lobe and passing into the fissures that separate them. It folds back on itself in the region of the hilum to form the parietal pleura.</p>
<p>The pleura consists of a closed sac of serous membrane (one for each lung), which contains a small amount of serous fluid, called pleural fluid. Fig. 10.15 illustrates the arrangement, using a balloon partly filled with water to represent the pleural sac and a fist to represent the lung. The membrane of the balloon is a single membrane, but when the fist is pushed into the balloon, it is effectively coated in two membranes, with water in between. The fist can be slid around within the pouch it has formed for itself but it does not get wet and the sac remains enclosed. In this way the lung can expand and recoil within the pleural sac, lubricated by the pleural fluid. Although the pleural membrane is described as two sheets, the visceral and the pleural membranes, the description refers to whether the layer is the outer or inner one: it is still all one membrane. A similar arrangement around the heart (see Fig. 5.10) allows it to beat without friction in the chest.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-d0d6ab47.jpeg" alt="img-351.jpeg"></p>
<p>Parietal pleura

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="heart">Heart<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#heart" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="parietal-pleura">Parietal pleura<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#parietal-pleura" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This adheres to the inside of the chest wall and the upper surface of the diaphragm. It is not attached to other structures in the mediastinum and simply folds back on itself in the region of the hilum to form the visceral pleura.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pleural-cavity">Pleural cavity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pleural-cavity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is only a potential space and contains no air, so the pressure within is negative relative to atmospheric pressure. In health, the space between the pleural layers, the pleural space, contains on average between 7 and 10 mL of pleural fluid, which lubricates lung movement during breathing.</p>
<p>The two layers of pleura, with pleural fluid between them, behave in the same way as two pieces of glass separated by a thin film of water. They glide over each other easily but can be pulled apart only with difficulty, because of the surface tension between the membranes and the fluid. This is essential for keeping the lung inflated against the inside of the chest wall. The airways and the alveoli of the lungs are embedded in elastic tissue, which constantly pulls the lung tissues towards the hilum, but because pleural fluid holds the two pleura together the lung remains expanded. If either layer of pleura is punctured, air is sucked into the pleural space and part or all of the entire underlying lung collapses.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="interior-of-the-lungs">Interior of the lungs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#interior-of-the-lungs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The lungs are composed of the bronchi and smaller air passages, alveoli, connective tissue, blood vessels, lymph vessels and nerves, all embedded in an elastic connective tissue matrix. Each lobe is made up of a large number of lobules.</p>
<p>Pulmonary blood supply
The pulmonary trunk divides into the right and left pulmonary arteries, carrying deoxygenated blood to each lung (Fig. 10.16). Within the lungs each pulmonary artery divides into many branches, which eventually end in a dense capillary network around the alveoli (see Fig. 10.18 A). The walls of the alveoli and the capillaries each consist of only one layer of flattened epithelial cells on a thin basement membrane. The exchange of gases between air in the alveoli and blood in the capillaries takes place across these two very fine membranes (together called the respiratory membrane). The pulmonary capillaries merge into a network of</p>
<p>Figure 10.15 The relationship of the pleura to the lungs.</p>

trunk</p>

<p>The blood supply to the respiratory passages, lymphatic drainage and nerve supply is described later (p. 274).

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bronchi-and-bronchioles">Bronchi and bronchioles<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bronchi-and-bronchioles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The two primary bronchi are formed when the trachea divides, at about the level of the 5th thoracic vertebra (Fig. 10.17).</p>
<p>Right bronchus
This is wider, shorter and more vertical than the left bronchus and is therefore more likely to become obstructed by an inhaled foreign body. It is approximately 2.5 cm long. After entering the right lung at the hilum it divides into three branches, one to each lobe. Each branch then subdivides into numerous smaller branches.</p>
<p>Left bronchus
This is about 5 cm long and is narrower than the right. After entering the lung at the hilum it divides into two branches, one to each lobe. Each branch then subdivides into progressively smaller airways within the lung substance.
structure Di0.4
The bronchial walls contain the same three layers of tissue as the trachea, and are lined with ciliated columnar epithelium. The bronchi progressively subdivide into</p>
<p>bronchioles (Eig. 10.17), terminal bronchioles, respiratory bronchioles, alveolar ducts and, finally, alveoli. The wider passages are
called conducting airways because their function is to bring air into the lungs, and their walls are too thick to permit gas exchange.
structural changes in the bronchial passages
As the bronchi divide and become progressively smaller, their structure changes to match their function.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cartilage">Cartilage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cartilage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Since rigid cartilage would interfere with expansion of lung tissue and the exchange of gases, it is present for support in the larger airways only. The bronchi contain cartilage rings like the trachea, but as the airways divide, these rings become much smaller plates, and at the bronchiolar level there is no cartilage present in the airway walls at all.</p>
<p>Smooth muscle
As the cartilage disappears from airway walls, it is replaced by smooth muscle. This allows the diameter of the airways to be increased or decreased through the influence of the autonomic nervous system, regulating airflow within each lung.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="epithelial-lining">Epithelial lining<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#epithelial-lining" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The ciliated epithelium is gradually replaced with non-ciliated epithelium, and goblet cells disappear.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-and-nerve-supply-lymph-drainage">Blood and nerve supply, lymph drainage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-and-nerve-supply-lymph-drainage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The arterial supply to the walls of the bronchi and smaller air passages is through branches of the right and left bronchial arteries, and the venous return is mainly through the bronchial veins. On the right side they empty into the azygos vein, and on the left into the superior intercostal vein (see Fig. 5.28).</p>
<p>The vagus nerves (parasympathetic) stimulate contraction of smooth muscle in the bronchial tree, causing bronchoconstriction, and sympathetic stimulation causes bronchodilation (see later).</p>
<p>Lymph is drained from the walls of the air passages in a network of lymph vessels. It passes through lymph nodes situated around the trachea and bronchial tree, then into the thoracic duct on the left side and right lymphatic duct on the other.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Control of air entry</p>
<p>The diameter of the respiratory passages is altered by contraction or relaxation of the smooth muscle in their walls, regulating the speed and volume of airflow into and within the lungs. These changes are controlled by the autonomic nerve supply: parasympathetic stimulation causes constriction and sympathetic stimulation causes dilation (see Figs 7.44 and 7.45 ).</p>
<p>Respiratory bronchioles and alveoli <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">□</mi><mn>10.5</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square 10.5</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">□</span><span class="mord">10.5</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="structure">Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Within each lobe the lung tissue is further divided by fine sheets of connective tissue into lobules. Each lobule is supplied with air by a terminal bronchiole, which further subdivides into respiratory bronchioles, alveolar ducts and large numbers of alveoli (air sacs). There are about 150 million alveoli in the adult lung. It is in these structures that the process of gas exchange occurs. As airways progressively divide and become smaller and smaller, their walls gradually become thinner until muscle and connective tissue disappear, leaving a single layer of simple squamous epithelial cells in the alveolar ducts and alveoli. These distal respiratory passages are supported by a loose network of elastic connective tissue in which macrophages, fibroblasts, nerves, and blood and lymph vessels are embedded. The alveoli are surrounded by a dense network of capillaries (Fig. 10.18). Exchange of gases in the lung (external respiration) takes place across a membrane made up of the alveolar wall and the capillary wall fused firmly together. This is called the respiratory membrane.</p>
<p>On microscopic examination, the extensive air spaces are clearly seen and healthy lung tissue has a honeycomb appearance (Fig. 10.19).</p>
<p>Respiratory bronchiole
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-21efef47.jpeg" alt="img-354.jpeg"></p>
<p>Connective tissue Alveolar
Septal cell with elastic fibres macrophage</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-ee46d3b0.jpeg" alt="img-355.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 10.18 The alveoli and their capillary network. (A) A group of intact alveoli. (B) Section through an alveolus.</p>
<p>Lying in the alveolar wall between the squamous cells are septal cells that secrete surfactant, a phospholipid fluid that stops the alveoli drying out and reduces surface tension, preventing alveolar collapse during expiration. Secretion of surfactant into the distal air passages and alveoli begins in about the 35th week of fetal life. Its presence in newborn babies permits expansion of the lungs and the establishment of respiration immediately after birth. It may not be present in sufficient amounts in the immature lungs of premature babies, causing serious breathing problems.</p>
<p>Nerve supply to bronchioles
Parasympathetic stimulation, from the vagus nerve, causes bronchoconstriction. The absence of supporting cartilage means that small airways may be completely closed off by
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-ad757cd0.jpeg" alt="img-356.jpeg"></p>

(alveoli)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="respiration">Respiration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#respiration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>External respiration
See page 280 .
Defence against infection
At this level, ciliated epithelium, goblet cells and mucus are no longer present because their presence would impede gas exchange and encourage infection. By the time inspired air reaches the alveoli, it is usually clean. Defence relies on protective cells present within the lung tissue. These include lymphocytes and plasma cells, which produce antibodies, and phagocytes, including alveolar macrophages. These cells are most active in the distal air passages, where ciliated epithelium has been replaced by flattened squamous cells.</p>
<p>SPOT CHECK
9. Describe the four main surfaces of the lungs. :</p>
<ol start="10">
<li>What is the function of the elastic tissue of the lungs?</li>
<li>What is the function of smooth muscle in bronchioles?</li>
<li>Describe the structure of the alveolar wall. :</li>
</ol>
<p>The term 'respiration' means the exchange of gases between body cells and the environment. This involves two main processes.</p>
<p>Breathing (pulmonary ventilation)
This is movement of air into and out of the lungs.
Exchange of gases
This takes place:</p>
<ul>
<li>in the lungs: external respiration</li>
<li>in the tissues: internal respiration.</li>
</ul>
<p>Each of these will be considered in this section.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="breathing">Breathing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#breathing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Breathing supplies oxygen to the alveoli and eliminates carbon dioxide.
Muscles of breathing
Expansion of the chest during inspiration occurs as a result of muscular activity, partly voluntary and partly involuntary. The main muscles used in normal quiet breathing are the external intercostal muscles and the diaphragm.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="intercostal-muscles">Intercostal muscles<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intercostal-muscles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are 11 pairs of intercostal muscles occupying the spaces between the 12 pairs of ribs. They are arranged in two layers, the external and internal intercostal muscles (Fig. 10.20).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251210-87768ade.jpeg" alt="img-357.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="external">External<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#external" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>intercostal
muscles

<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-40832bb0.jpeg" alt="img-358.jpeg"></p>
<p>Crura

Figure 10.20 The intercostal muscles and the bones of the thorax.
Figure 10.21 The diaphragm.
External intercostal muscles</p>
<p>These extend downwards and forwards from the lower border of the rib above to the upper border of the rib below. They are involved in inspiration.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="internal-intercostal-muscles">Internal intercostal muscles<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#internal-intercostal-muscles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These extend downwards and backwards from the lower border of the rib above to the upper border of the rib below, crossing the external intercostal muscle fibres at right angles. The internal intercostals are used when expiration becomes active, as in exercise.</p>
<p>The first rib is fixed. Therefore, when the external intercostal muscles contract, they pull all the other ribs towards the first rib. The ribcage moves as a unit, upwards and outwards, enlarging the thoracic cavity. The intercostal muscles are stimulated to contract by the intercostal nerves.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diaphragm-0-10-6">Diaphragm [0 10.6<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diaphragm-0-10-6" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The diaphragm is a dome-shaped muscular structure separating the thoracic and abdominal cavities. It forms the floor of the thoracic cavity and the roof of the abdominal cavity, and consists of a central tendon from which muscle fibres radiate to be attached to the lower ribs and sternum and to the vertebral column by two crura. When the diaphragm is relaxed, the central tendon is at the level of the 8th thoracic vertebra (Fig. 10.21). When it contracts, its muscle fibres shorten and the central tendon is pulled downwards to the level of the 9th thoracic vertebra, lengthening the thoracic cavity. This decreases pressure in the thoracic cavity and
increases it in the abdominal and pelvic cavities. The diaphragm is supplied by the phrenic nerves.</p>
<p>Quiet, restful breathing is sometimes called diaphragmatic breathing because <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>75</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">75 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">75%</span></span></span></span></span> of the work is done by the diaphragm.</p>
<p>During inspiration, the external intercostal muscles and the diaphragm contract simultaneously, enlarging the thoracic cavity in all directions: that is, from back to front, side to side and top to bottom (Fig. 10.22).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="accessory-muscles-of-respiration">Accessory muscles of respiration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#accessory-muscles-of-respiration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When extra respiratory effort is required, additional muscles are used (Fig. 10.22A). Forced inspiration is assisted by the sternocleidomastoid muscles (see Fig. 16.60) and the scalene muscles, which link the cervical vertebrae to the first two ribs and increase ribcage expansion. Forced expiration is helped by the activity of the internal intercostal muscles and sometimes the abdominal muscles, which increase the pressure in the thorax by squeezing the abdominal contents.</p>
<p>The respiratory muscles can expand the ribcage because of its cartilage content. If the ribcage were built entirely of bone, with no costal cartilages, changing the lung volume would depend entirely on the diaphragm below rising and falling. This would allow the lungs to lengthen and shorten only. As cartilage is strong and inelastic but still slightly flexible, the costal cartilages (see Fig. 10.21) permit enough movement between the sternum and ribs to allow lateral and anterior expansion too through the action of other muscles, including
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-2433b355.jpeg" alt="img-359.jpeg"></p>
<p>Sternocleidomastoid muscles
Scalene muscles</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="inspiration">INSPIRATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inspiration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Diaphragm
Internal intercostal muscles</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="expiration">EXPIRATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#expiration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
