Figure 10.22 Changes in chest size during inspiration. (A) Muscles involved in respiration (accessory muscles labelled in bold). (B and C) Changes in chest volume.
the intercostals. In addition, this arrangement gives the ribcage a 'sprung' structure, with the ribs under gentle outwards tension, meaning that the ribcage is constantly being pushed outwards, pulling gently on the lungs and helping to keep them expanded.</p>
<p>Cycle of breathing <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">□</mi><mn>10.7</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\square 10.7</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.675em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">□</span><span class="mord">10.7</span></span></span></span></span>
The average respiratory rate is 12-15 breaths per minute. Each breath consists of three phases: inspiration, expiration and pause.</p>
<p>The visceral pleura adheres to the lungs, and the parietal pleura to the inner wall of the thorax and to the diaphragm. Between them is a thin film of pleural fluid (p. 272).</p>
<p>Breathing depends on changes in pressure and volume in the thoracic cavity. It follows the underlying physical principle that increasing the volume of a container decreases
the pressure inside it, and that decreasing the volume of a container increases the pressure inside it. Since air flows from an area of high pressure to an area of low pressure, changing the pressure inside the lungs determines the direction of airflow.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="inspiration">Inspiration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inspiration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Simultaneous contraction of the external intercostal muscles and the diaphragm expands the thorax. As the parietal pleura sticks to the diaphragm and the inside of the ribcage, it is pulled outwards along with them. This pulls the visceral pleura outwards too, since the two pleura are held together by the thin film of pleural fluid. Because the visceral pleura is firmly adherent to the lung, the lung tissue is therefore also pulled up and out with the ribs, and downwards with the diaphragm. This expands the lungs, and the pressure
within the alveoli and in the air passages falls, drawing air into the lungs in an attempt to equalise atmospheric and alveolar air pressures.</p>
<p>The process of inspiration is active, as it needs energy for muscle contraction. The negative pressure created in the thoracic cavity aids venous return to the heart and is known as the respiratory pump.</p>
<p>At rest, inspiration lasts about 2 seconds.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="expiration">Expiration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#expiration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Relaxation of the external intercostal muscles and the diaphragm results in downward and inward movement of the ribcage (Fig. 10.22) and elastic recoil of the lungs. As this occurs, pressure inside the lungs rises and expels air from the respiratory tract. At the end of expiration, the lungs still contain some air, and are prevented from complete collapse by the intact pleura. This process is passive, as it does not require the expenditure of energy.</p>
<p>At rest, expiration lasts about 3 seconds, and after expiration there is a pause before the next cycle begins.</p>
<p>Physiological variables affecting breathing</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="elasticity">Elasticity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#elasticity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Elasticity is the ability of the lung to return to its normal shape after each breath. Loss of elasticity of the connective tissue in the lungs, e.g. in emphysema (p. 286), necessitates forced expiration and increased effort on inspiration.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="compliance">Compliance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#compliance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is the stretchability of the lungs, i.e. the effort required to inflate the alveoli. The healthy lung is very compliant and inflates with very little effort. When compliance is low the effort needed to inflate the lungs is greater than normal, e.g. when insufficient surfactant is present. Note that compliance and elasticity are opposing forces.</p>
<p>Airway resistance
When this is increased, e.g. in bronchoconstriction, more respiratory effort is required to inflate the lungs.</p>
<p>Lung volumes and capacities
These are shown in Fig. 10.23.
In normal quiet breathing there are about 15 complete respiratory cycles per minute. The lungs and the air passages are never empty and, as the exchange of gases takes place only across the walls of the alveolar ducts and alveoli, the remaining capacity of the respiratory passages is called the anatomical dead space (about 150 mL ).</p>
<p>Tidal volume
Tidal volume (TV) is the amount of air passing into and out of the lungs during each cycle of breathing (about 500 mL at rest).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251210-aad30d10.jpeg" alt="img-362.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 10.23 Lung volumes and capacities. ERV, expiratory reserve volume: FRC, functional residual capacity; 1C, inspiratory capacity:</p>
<p>IRV, inspiratory reserve volume; RV, residual volume; TLC, total lung capacity; VC, vital capacity.</p>
<p>Inspiratory reserve voiume
Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV) is the extra volume of air that can be inhaled into the lungs during maximal inspiration, i.e. over and above normal TV.</p>
<p>Inspiratory capacity
Inspiratory capacity (IC) is the amount of air that can be inspired with maximum effort. It consists of the tidal volume ( 500 mL ) plus the inspiratory reserve volume.</p>
<p>Functional residual capacity
Functional residual capacity (FRC) is the amount of air remaining in the air passages and alveoli at the end of quiet expiration. Tidal air mixes with this air, causing relatively small changes in the composition of alveolar air. As blood flows continuously through the pulmonary capillaries, this means that exchange of gases is not interrupted between breaths, preventing moment-to-moment changes in the concentration of blood gases. The functional residual volume also prevents collapse of the alveoli on expiration.</p>
<p>Expiratory reserve volume
Expiratory reserve volume (ERV) is the largest volume of air that can be expelled from the lungs during maximal expiration.</p>
<p>Residual volume
Residual volume (RV) cannot be directly measured but is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after forced expiration.</p>
<p>Vital capacity
Vital capacity (VC) is the maximum volume of air that can be moved into and out of the lungs:
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{VC}=</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">VC</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span></span></span></span></span> Tidal volume <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">+\mathrm{IRV}+\mathrm{ERV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">+</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">IRV</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">ERV</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="total-lung-capacity">Total lung capacity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#total-lung-capacity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Total lung capacity (TLC) is the maximum amount of air the lungs can hold. In an adult of average build, it is normally around 6 litres. Total lung capacity represents the sum of the VC and the RV. It cannot be directly measured in clinical tests because, even after forced expiration, the RV of air still remains in the lungs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="alveolar-ventilation">Alveolar ventilation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#alveolar-ventilation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the volume of air that moves into and out of the alveoli per minute. It is equal to the tidal volume minus the anatomical dead space, multiplied by the respiratory rate:</p>
<p>Alveolar ventilation <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=\mathrm{TV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">TV</span></span></span></span></span></span> - anatomical dead space X respiratory rate <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>500</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>150</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=(500-150)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">500</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">150</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>
mL X15 per minute <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>5.25</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=5.25</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">5.25</span></span></span></span></span> litres per minute</p>
<p>Lung function tests are carried out to determine respiratory function and are based on the parameters outlined above. Results of these tests can help in the diagnosis and monitoring of respiratory disorders.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="exchange-of-gases">Exchange of gases<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#exchange-of-gases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Although breathing involves the alternating processes of inspiration and expiration, gas exchange at the respiratory membrane and in the tissues is a continuous and ongoing process. Diffusion of oxygen and carbon dioxide depends on pressure differences, e.g. between atmospheric air and the blood, or blood and the tissues.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="composition-of-air">Composition of air<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#composition-of-air" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Atmospheric pressure at sea level is 101.3 kilopascals ( kPa ) or 760 mmHg . With increasing height above sea level, atmospheric pressure is progressively reduced and at 5500 m , about two-thirds the height of Mount Everest ( 8850 m ), it is about half that at sea level. Under water, pressure increases by approximately 1 atmosphere per 10 m below sea level.</p>
<p>Air is a mixture of gases: nitrogen, oxygen, carbon dioxide, water vapour and small quantities of inert gases.</p>
<p>The percentage of each in inspired and expired air is listed in Table 10.1. Each gas in the mixture exerts a part of the total pressure proportional to its concentration, i.e. the partial pressure (Table 10.2). This is denoted as, for example, PO 2 , PCO 2</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="alveolar-air">Alveolar air<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#alveolar-air" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The composition of alveolar air remains fairly constant and is different from atmospheric air. It is saturated with water vapour, and contains more carbon dioxide and less oxygen. Saturation with water vapour provides 6.3 kPa ( 47 mmHg ), thus reducing the partial pressure of all the other gases present. Gas exchange between the alveoli and the bloodstream (external respiration) is a continuous process, as the alveoli are never empty, so it is independent of the respiratory cycle. During each inspiration only some of the alveolar gases are exchanged.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diffusion-of-gases">Diffusion of gases<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diffusion-of-gases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Exchange of gases occurs when a difference in partial pressure exists across a semipermeable membrane. Gases diffuse from the higher concentration to the lower until equilibrium is established (p.36). Atmospheric nitrogen is not used by the body so its partial pressure remains unchanged and is the same in inspired and expired air, alveolar air and the blood.</p>
<p>These principles govern the diffusion of gases in and out of the alveoli across the respiratory membrane (external respiration) and across capillary membranes in the tissues (internal respiration).</p>
<p>Table 10.1 The composition of inspired and expired air</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="external-respiration-3-10-8">External respiration [3 10.8<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#external-respiration-3-10-8" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>External respiration (Fig. 10.24A) is exchange of gases by diffusion between the alveoli and the blood in the alveolar capillaries, across the respiratory membrane. Each alveolar wall is one cell thick and is surrounded by a network of tiny capillaries (the walls of which are also only one cell thick). The total area of respiratory membrane for gas exchange in the lungs is about equivalent to the area of a tennis court. Venous blood arriving at the lungs in the pulmonary artery has travelled from all the tissues of the body, and contains high levels of CO 2 and low levels of O 2 . Carbon dioxide diffuses from venous blood down its concentration gradient into the alveoli until equilibrium with alveolar air is reached. By the same process, oxygen diffuses from the alveoli into the blood. The relatively slow flow of blood through the capillaries increases the time available for gas exchange to occur. When blood leaves the alveolar capillaries, the oxygen and carbon dioxide concentrations are in equilibrium with those of alveolar air (Fig. 10.24A).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="internal-respiration-q-io-g">Internal respiration Q io.g<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#internal-respiration-q-io-g" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Internal respiration (Fig. 10.24B) is exchange of gases by diffusion between blood in the capillaries and the body cells. Gas exchange does not occur across the walls of the arteries carrying blood from the heart to the tissues because their walls are too thick. PO 2 of blood arriving at the capillary bed is therefore the same as blood leaving the lungs. Blood arriving at the tissues has been cleansed of its excess CO 2 and saturated with O 2 during its passage through the lungs, and therefore has a higher PO 2 and a lower PCO 2 than the tissues. This creates concentration gradients between capillary blood and the tissues, and gas exchange therefore occurs (Fig. 10.24B). O 2 diffuses from the bloodstream through the capillary wall into the tissues. CO 2 diffuses from the cells into the extracellular fluid, then into the bloodstream towards the venous end of the capillary.</p>
<p>Fig. 10.25 summarises the processes of internal and external respiration. Q 10.10</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="transport-of-gases-in-the-bloodstream">Transport of gases in the bloodstream<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transport-of-gases-in-the-bloodstream" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Oxygen and carbon dioxide are carried in the blood in different ways.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="oxygen">Oxygen<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#oxygen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Oxygen is carried in the blood in:</p>
<ul>
<li>chemical combination with haemoglobin (see Fig. 4.6) as oxyhaemoglobin <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>98.5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(98.5 \%)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">98.5%</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li>solution in plasma water <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>1.5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(1.5 \%)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">1.5%</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
</ul>
<p>Oxy haemoglobin is unstable and under certain conditions readily dissociates, releasing oxygen. Factors that increase dissociation include low O 2 levels, low pH and raised temperature (Ch. 4). In active tissues there is increased production of carbon dioxide and heat, which leads to increased release of oxygen. In this way, oxygen is available to tissues in greatest need. Oxyhaemoglobin is bright red, whereas deoxygenated blood is bluish-purple in colour.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="carbon-dioxide">Carbon dioxide<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carbon-dioxide" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Carbon dioxide is one of the waste products of metabolism. It is excreted by the lungs and is transported by three mechanisms:</p>
<ul>
<li>as bicarbonate ions (HCOs") in the plasma ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>70</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">70 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">70%</span></span></span></span></span> )</li>
<li>combined with haemoglobin in erythrocytes as carbaminohaemoglobin (23%)</li>
<li>dissolved in the plasma <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>7</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(7 \%)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">7%</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
</ul>
<p>Carbon dioxide levels must be finely managed, as either an excess or a deficiency leads to significant disruption of acid-base balance. Sufficient CO 2 is essential for the bicarbonate buffering system that protects against a fall in body pH . Excess CO 2 , on the other hand, reduces blood pH because it dissolves in body water to form carbonic acid.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="regulation-of-airflow-and-blood-flow-in-the-lung">Regulation of airflow and blood flow in the lung<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#regulation-of-airflow-and-blood-flow-in-the-lung" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>During quiet breathing, only a small portion of the lung's total capacity is ventilated with each breath. This means that only a fraction of the total alveolar numbers is being ventilated, usually in the upper lobes, and much of the remaining lung is temporarily collapsed. Airways supplying alveoli that are not being used are constricted, directing airflow into functioning alveoli. In addition, the pulmonary arterioles bringing blood into the ventilated alveoli are dilated, to maximise gas exchange, and blood flow (perfusion) past the non-functioning alveoli is reduced.</p>
<p>When respiratory requirements are increased, e.g. in exercise, the increased tidal volume expands additional alveoli, and the blood flow is redistributed to perfuse these too. In this way, airflow (ventilation) and blood flow (perfusion) are matched to maximise the opportunity for gas exchange.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="control-of-respiration">Control of respiration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-respiration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Effective control of respiration enables the body to regulate blood gas levels over a wide range of physiological.
environmental and pathological conditions, and is normally involuntary. Voluntary control is exerted during activities such as speaking and singing but is overridden if blood CO 2 rises (hypercapnia).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-respiratory-centre">The respiratory centre<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-respiratory-centre" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is formed by groups of nerves in the medulla, the respiratory rhythmicity centre, which control the respiratory pattern, i.e. the rate and depth of breathing (Eig. 10.26). There are three important groups of neurones here that regulate breathing: an inspiratory group, an expiratory group, and neurones in the pneumotaxic area. Regular automatic firing of the inspiratory neurones sets the basic rhythm of breathing. Expiratory neurones control expiration, and neurones in the pneumotaxic area help to regulate the rate and depth of breathing.</p>
<p>Motor impulses leaving the respiratory centre pass in the phrenic and intercostal nerves to the diaphragm and intercostal muscles, respectively, to stimulate respiration.</p>
<p>Although the respiratory centre controls the pattern and rate of breathing, it is also influenced by information coming in from the periphery: most importantly, chemoreceptor input related to the CO 2 content and pH of body fluids.</p>
<p>These are receptors that respond to changes in the partial pressures of oxygen and carbon dioxide in the blood and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). They are located centrally and peripherally.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="central-chemoreceptors">Central chemoreceptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#central-chemoreceptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are located on the surface of the medulla oblongata and are bathed in CSF. When arterial PCO 2 rises (hypercapnia), even slightly, this in turn increases PCO 2 in the CSF. The central chemoreceptors respond by stimulating the respiratory centre, increasing ventilation of the lungs and reducing arterial PCO 2 . The sensitivity of the central chemoreceptors to raised arterial PCO 2 is the most important factor in controlling normal blood gas levels. A small reduction in PO 2 (hypoxaemia) has the same effect, though less pronounced, but a substantial reduction depresses breathing.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="peripheral-chemoreceptors">Peripheral chemoreceptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#peripheral-chemoreceptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are situated in the arch of the aorta and in the carotid bodies (Fig. 10.26). They respond to changes in blood CO 2 and O 2 levels, but are much more sensitive to carbon dioxide than oxygen. Even a slight rise in CO 2 levels activates</p>
<p>these receptors, triggering nerve impulses to the respiratory centre via the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves. This stimulates an immediate rise in the rate and depth of respiration. An increase in blood acidity (decreased pH or raised [ff]) also stimulates the peripheral chemoreceptors, resulting in increased ventilation, increased CO 2 excretion and increased blood pH . These chemoreceptors also help to regulate blood pressure (p. 275).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chemoreceptors">Chemoreceptors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chemoreceptors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
